HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RIKERS ISLAND;
Trying to Keep Jobs Cooking in the Bronx

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
A contract that could create hundreds of jobs to supply inmates at all city jails with prepared meals should go to a company inside the five boroughs, not to Rockland County, city officials say.
Complying with a court order to improve the food at the jail complex, the Dinkins administration had decided in November to contract the job out to the State Department of Mental Health, which had planned to spend $4.5 million to expand its high-tech kitchen in Orangeburg to supply food through the cook-chill method. 
 But two weeks ago, the Legislature voted against allowing the department to spend the money. Bronx legislators and community leaders had fought the original plans, saying they were worried about hundreds of jobs being created upstate instead of within the city. The Bronx, they argued, with its proximity to Rikers Island, has many potential sites, among them the Hunts Point Produce Market, at 331 Tiffany Street.
Officials with the city's Department of Corrections will go to court tomorrow to ask a judge to allow the department to look for a contractor inside the city. Because of the Legislature's move, the judge is expected to agree.
The city is under a 1979 Federal Consent Order to change the way it prepares the meals as a result of a lawsuit filed by the Legal Aid Society for inmates in the 1970's, after a series of riots. The suit complained about a variety of conditions, including the food, cleanliness and visiting hours. The order set a deadline of September 1995.
Last week, Bert Schoenbach, executive director of the West Bronx Development Corporation, drew up a list of five potential sites that he will submit to the city.
Juan Castro, a spokesman for State Senator Efrain Gonzalez, a Bronx Democrat, said, "The Legislature was sympathetic to the concerns of the New York members who thought it was important to keep as many jobs and economic opportunities in the city as possible,"
Mr. Gonzalez is a ranking member for the Senate Committee on Commerce, Economic Development and Small business.
"We were able to convince our colleagues to keep the center in the city and not export the jobs," Mr. Castro said.
Mr. Shoenbach said: "My community is an impoverished area in desperate need of jobs. The city always wants to put the sludge plants and the medical waste incinerators here, but not the jobs. I'm glad to see that we at least have a shot at bringing some jobs in here." LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

HEADLINE: The Bottom Line on Banks

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
APRIL Tyler opened an interest-bearing checking account at Chemical Bank eight years ago, and now has thousands of dollars in an individual retirement account there, too. But the relationship took a nose dive last month when Chemical announced that it was closing 50 branches, doubling the minimum balance required for "free checking" and sharply increasing fees for checking accounts that fail to make the cutoff.
For Ms. Tyler, the changes mean a choice of tying up $7,500 between her two accounts or paying at least $9.50 a month in extra charges. 
 "Now either my money's held hostage at the bank, or I'm going to lose all the money I might make someplace else on fees," she said. While "no one would call me poor," adds Ms. Tyler, who works for a community development group in Harlem, she would be greatly inconvenienced by the new requirements. She is determined to move her money elsewhere.
While the new charges, which take effect May 2, make Chemical among the most expensive of New York banks, and while it remains unclear if other banks will follow suit, Ms. Tyler and others who bank there are far from the only unhappy customers around town these days. Caught between the changing economics of banking and the technological possibilities of the computer age, a lot of people all over the city, and across America, are being forced to pay more, with considerably less in the way of service, to maintain basic savings and checking accounts. (And New Yorkers pay especially dearly, according to a 1993 study by the United States Public Interest Research Group. The survey of 22 states found New York the third most expensive for a selection of consumer charges.)
At the same time, banks have closed branches in many neighborhoods, and especially in the inner city, driving many poorer New Yorkers to credit unions and expensive check-cashing outlets.
To people in the banking industry -- suffering from low interest rates and business left shaky by bad real-estate loans and the loss of their best corporate customers to investment banks -- the new consumer-banking policies are the only way the banks can afford a portion of their business that is especially labor intensive and not especially lucrative. Their eager hope for the future: a day when most retail banking -- from writing checks to buying money-market funds or insurance policies -- will be done over the far-more-cost-efficient telephone or by personal computer.
To many consumers and their advocates, though, these new policies amount to a snub, a declaration that the banks just don't care that much about the man or woman who needs a simple checking account. As for new technology, at least for now, an A.T.M. card represents about all that many people care to know.
"It's a very difficult market for small consumers right now," says Edmund Mierzwinski, consumer program director for the Public Interest Research Group in Washington. "They are bearing the brunt of bank fee-gouging, and they're not earning any interest as the banks lower their rates."
Still, for every April Tyler, with her vows to switch banks, there is at least one New Yorker who complains about his or her bank but is too uninformed, confused or inertial to do anything about it.
"I'm not surprised by the increases in general," said William Wolfe, a computer consultant and Chemical customer, adding that he periodically vows to comparison shop but never has. "It's sort of like a New Year's resolution. I want to get control over my banking, but I'm not there yet."
So in these in-between times, where are the best deals for consumers? What follows is a look at the various issues that are important when seeking out a bank and starting what people in the industry like to call "a relationship."
 
CHECKING: A PRIMER
 Retail banking, and especially the checking account, has long been unprofitable, sort of a loss leader, because of the labor and other costs involved in processing all that paper. Some experts estimate that the big banks lose money on as many as 80 percent of their checking accounts.
The banks do make money on customers with large deposits. And they have created all manner of special services to woo them, from free checking to a quasi-private teller windows to personal bankers.
For the rest of us, though, it's those trips to tellers that end up making retail banking so costly, explains Brian C. Hartzer of First Manhattan Consulting, which advises financial-services companies.
To offset that, he says, "banks can reduce their own costs by cutting back branches, or they say, 'Either we get these people to get their balances up to the point where we can justify serving them, or we have to raise their fees.' "
There are fees to maintain a checking account, fees if the account falls below a minimum balance, fees for bounced and returned checks, fees to write checks and fees for using A.T.M's. Even accounts with no activity are subject to monthly maintenance fees, which means money can evaporate even though the owner isn't writing checks.
These fees tend to be regressive, coming down hardest on the people who can least afford them. In fact, many of the larger commercial banks substantially shrink their fees for larger accounts.
"It's certainly become harder for people at the lower end of the income scale to get banking services," says Richard Marsico, a professor at New York Law School who advises community groups on banking concerns.
In general, the larger commercial banks charge higher fees and set higher minimum balances for free checking than savings banks. For example, the minimum balance for a no-fee, interest-bearing account at East River Savings Bank is $1,000 -- among the city's lowest. If you don't care about interest, Astoria Federal Savings charges no fees and has no minimum balance requirement.
At Citibank, though, the minimum is $5,000 for an interest-bearing checking account, or $10,000 in combined accounts. Without interest, you need $2,000 in checking or $6,000 in combined accounts.
Other fees are comparable, however. A bounced check costs you $15 just about anywhere.
Even "free" checking, promoted by some banks, is rarely that. Sometimes it means only that there is no maintenance fee -- a monthly charge just for having an account, which is now $9.50 at Chemical, for instance, if you keep less than the $6,000 minimum for non-interest-bearing checking there. There is still often a charge for each transaction (a check written, a rendezvous with an A.T.M.).
At Chemical, the managing director for New York branches, Jack Stack, said the bank had not received "that much bad feedback" about the increases, or the decision to close 50 branches, most of which duplicated branches acquired in the merger with Manufacturers Hanover.
"We're working very hard to explain to our customers that we do have a complete package that the competition can't duplicate, and we are trying to help them link accounts together so that many of them can make the minimums," he said. "In our deeds, we demonstrate that we're very much interested in the small consumer. We have 61 branches in low- to moderate-income neighborhoods in the city. We're providing products and services that we think are very attractive to the little guy."
When it comes to figuring out the best deals, it helps to compare checking charges with the cost of parking several thousand dollars in an account that pays no more than 2 percent interest, experts say.
And it helps to pin down the specifics. Some banks require a minimum balance, which means that if your balance dips below that level even for a minute, you will be charged a month's worth of fees. Others, like Chase, compute the minimum balance as a monthly average.
Another strategy for saving money: order checks from a generic printer, rather than from the bank. At East River Savings Bank, ordering 200 checks costs about $16, said Marjan Moini, a representative there. But a call to Current Inc. in Denver can get you the same number of checks for $6.95. The telephone number is (800) 426-0822.
And people who write only a few checks each month should ask their banks about a program called lifeline banking. Seldom advertised but required under a state law that goes into effect in July, it charges a fee, usually $4 or so, and sets a maximum number of transactions, usually eight. The problem is that once somebody goes over the limit, the fees increase, sometimes drastically.
 
WHERE BANKS AREN'T
 Joseph E. Vincent is the director of financial-service development for the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation. Before that, he spent 30 years as a branch manager for Chase Manhattan.
There is an entire Bronx community district, District 3, encompassing Morrisania, that has 58,000 people and no banks, Mr. Vincent says. The impact is deep and devastating.
"It's not just a question of credit," he said. "If you don't have a place to save, that doesn't encourage basic thrift. And then you lose the basis for economic empowerment. If you don't have a place to save, it's very hard to start out on that road."
April Tyler's disenchantment with Chemical peaked with the recent increases in fees and minimum balances. But it had started as she watched the bank close two of its three branches in the part of west Harlem where she works with the Ecumenical Community Development Organization. Along Broadway, she says, there is no A.T.M. between 113th and 168th Streets.
"A lot of people who could afford a bank before no longer can because of the fees," she said. "And those who still can have to travel far or bank near their work. It's demeaning."
In the South Bronx, Mr. Vincent says, there are 25 bank branches, down from about 50 in the mid-1970's. In the northern part of the Bronx, there are 78 branches. With 40 percent of the borough's population, he adds, the South Bronx has just 25 percent of its banks.
The issue is a thorny one for the banks. While not necessarily abandoning people by design, many experts say, the banks' focus on their profit margins makes operating branches in poor neighborhoods unattractive. Such branches often have many small depositers, which means less for the banks, except for fees.
"I'm not suggesting the banks are viciously plotting to do this," Mr. Vincent said. "It's a logical byproduct of the banks needing to be more profitable."
Under the 1977 Community Reinvestment Act, which gives watchdog groups and others power to question the lending practices and service records of commercial banks in poor neighborhoods, accessibility is not emphasized the same way credit availability is. Many consumer advocates would prefer to see banks evaluated more for availability.
The State Banking Department has oversight in such matters, but it does not have a lot of influence.
"While I understand that a physical bank branch can be an important economic-development vehicle," said Denise Pease, a deputy superintendent, "at this point in time, while we may encourage banks to look at underserved areas, we do not mandate them to do so."
 
CREDIT UNIONS
 Where banks have decamped, and often where they haven't, credit unions take over their functions.
New York City now has 200 credit unions, with about $3 billion in assets and about 633,000 members. Some are organized within corporations or unions, others have sprung up through churches, and some have emerged in communities where there simply are no banks anymore.
In general, credit unions charge lower fees and have considerably lower minimum balances than banks. according to the National Federation of Community Development Credit Unions. Minimums, if required, are more like $50. Fees are based on cost, rather than cost plus a profit margin. Many credit unions charge between $2.50 and $10 for a bounced check, less than most banks, and currently interest rates range from 1.75 percent to 3.5 percent, higher than at most banks, according to the federation.
One that just completed its first year is the Central Brooklyn Federal Credit Union. Begun to provide an outlet for people in the largely working-class, and sometimes bank-scarce, neighborhoods of central Brooklyn, including Flatbush, Fort Greene and Crown Heights, it has branches in churches and housing projects and recently completed a deal to take over a closed Chemical branch in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
"I used to be an advocate and I would get angry about this kind of thing," says the credit union's treasurer, Errol T. Louis. "But now I look at it as the way things are. We're trying to turn it into an opportunity."
It's not the world's most convenient system. The credit union is open two days a week, from 1 P.M. to 6 P.M. on Thursdays and from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. on Saturdays. There's no A.T.M. yet, although there probably will be, Mr. Louis said. But where big banks saw no hopes for profit, the credit union believes it will flourish, largely because it dispenses with many of a bank's operating costs, from pay for directors ( the board is made up of volunteers) to the cost of returning checks to members each month.
 
INTO THE FUTURE

Retail bankers have seen the future, and it has the bland glass face of a computer screen, the voice of Touchtone, the dimensions of a plastic wallet card. Pretty soon, bankers hope, people will do most of their banking by telephone, computer or with a debit card. It will mean goodbye to checkbooks and the paper they generate and the recovery of much of the energy lost discussing simple matters at a teller window, not to mention waiting to get there.
"The U.S. is still far behind the rest of the world, even though it's got a lot of A.T.M.'s," says Tony Saunders, a professor of finance at New York University's Stern School of Business.
Still, different banks, to different degrees, are part of the way there. While all banks with teller machines offer such basic services as deposits and withdrawals and transferring money between accounts, probably the most advanced is Citibank, where customers can set up a program, using their A.T.M. cards, that, among other things, automatically pays bills, like mortgage payments, credit card payments and utility bills, for $3.50 a month.
Reflecting the city's ethnic diversity, some teller machines are multilingual. Citibank machines are also programmed with instructions for blind or disabled people; the programs respond to taps on the screen.
Banking by telephone and by computer is an outgrowth of the advancement in A.T.M. capabilities. At Chemical, customers can track checks written, find out balances and move money between accounts by telephone, Mr. Stack said. The service is available 24 hours a day, and there is no separate charge. Chase and Citibank have similar phone lines.
A personal computer linkup available through Citibank is known as Direct Access, and while it does not permit deposits and withdrawals, it permits people to perform other banking functions from home. Citibank will give you the software, but charge you $9.95 a month to use it.
In some ways, the emphasis on electronics can be better for the consumer. The Federal regulations covering electronic banking offer tighter protections against fraud and theft, in many ways, than do regulations that cover human bank operations. Customers are liable for only the first $50 of such losses, as long as they file a report within two days.
For the banks, it's definitely cheaper. Mr. Gregor, the consultant, says a teller-assisted transaction costs about $1.07, an A.T.M. transaction closer to 25 cents. Yet many banks charge for use of teller machines, setting fees similar to those for checks.
"The A.T.M. market is maturing and two things are happening," observed the Public Interest Research Group's Mr. Mierzwinski. "One is that the costs to the bank are declining because the machines are cheaper, and now that the machines are in place, the cost of using them declines."
Which leads to one big question: As more and more people rely on technology for their banking business, will fees shrink or disappear? Don't count on it, say the consumer groups. The banks say they don't know.
"Given the history, I think it will mean increased margins for the banks and higher prices for consumers," said Travis Plunkett, a banking specialist with the New York Public Interest Research Group.
And will the advanced technology be embraced by, well, everybody.
"I really have some doubts as to whether the great American public that watches 'Beavis and Butthead' is going to be doing this," says Roy C. Smith, a former partner at Goldman Sachs who is now a professor of finance at New York University's Stern School of Business. "We'll see."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
After 27 Years, Housing Fight Is Intensifying

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
On the Lower East Side, where housing is one of the most pressing needs, a prime site cleared for development 27 years ago has stood vacant ever since, serving instead as a battleground for community groups fighting over what to build there.
That dispute is heating up anew, pitting a prominent local Orthodox Jewish group favoring commercial development against advocates of affordable housing who say more apartments are desperately needed for doubled-up and homeless families. 
 Rudolph W. Giuliani is the fifth Mayor to wrestle over what to do with the city-owned land. Valerie Jo Bradley, a spokeswoman for the City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said his administration would review the issue soon.
Another key figure is Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, who represents the area. Critics say he has failed to exert leadership to resolve the dispute and has used his clout to rebuff housing plans, in sympathy with the Orthodox voting bloc and maybe to preserve his district's demographics. He says he wants "a buildable consensus plan," but the community so far has been too split.
The area in contention, part of the Seward Park urban-renewal project, is four parcels between Essex and Attorney Streets and Delancey and Grand Streets. Community Board 3 -- itself sharply divided -- recently voted to make low- and moderate-income housing there the community's top-priority request for the city's capital budget.
"After festering for 27 years, it's long overdue," said Roberto Caballero, a Puerto Rican political leader and executive director of Pueblo Nuevo, a housing organization. But he said Mr. Silver was a stumbling block.
Proposals for more housing are opposed by the United Jewish Council, an influential voice for Orthodox residents, many of whom live in four large private complexes nearby known as the Grand Street co-ops.
"Why target the Lower East Side for more low-income units?" said Harold Jacobs, executive director of the council and manager of the co-ops. "We have enough of that type of housing already, 15,000 units in this district." He said he favored commercial development: "What we really need is more jobs for the people who live here now."
Such opposition stems from racial fear, said Frances Goldin, a leader in the Lower East Side Joint Planning Council, a coalition for housing. "They would rather have the vacant lots and rats than have minority people there," she said.
Seward Park's tortuous history started with a slum-clearance program in 1967, when 14 blocks of tenements were demolished. City officials "temporarily" relocated 1,840 poor families, promising them the right to occupy the planned new apartments. But construction was delayed into the next two decades, and the first units were diverted to outsiders. Few of the original people ever returned.
Eventually 360 apartments were built by the city, 600 by St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, 156 by the Chinatown Planning Council and 124 by the United Jewish Council. The last two were reserved for the elderly.
But prime sites remained undeveloped. The latest plan, offered last year by Kraus Enterprises, calls for 600 apartments, a park, retail center and multiplex movie theater. The project would pay for itself without public funds, the developer said. It still requires city approval. BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
A Real Taste of Home at La Marqueta

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
As a girl growing up in San Sebastian, Puerto Rico, Elba Gaffney turned up her nose at pasteles, the meat-filled pies that are a highlight of the island's holiday meals. "I was a very particular eater," she said. "Everybody looked at me like I was crazy."
 These days, however, Mrs. Gaffney rarely goes home at night without the sweet, oilysmell of banana dough used for the pies still strong on her clothes. In the last five years, through her East Harlem business, her name has become almost synonymous with the pies that offer a taste of home for the neighborhood's large Puerto Rican community. 
 In September, Mrs.Gaffney, 58, became one of the first new merchants to set up shop in La Marqueta since its decline in the 1980's. She operates a small stall where she sells coffee, cookies, rice, beans and frozen pasteles with spicy pork filling, which she prepares daily by the score in the kitchen of her nearby El Vita wholesale operation.
 The only woman to own her own business in the marketplace, Mrs. Gaffney and about a dozen other new merchants made the move after the city renovated one of the four metal buildings of the original Marqueta.
 "All I really wanted to do was sell my pasteles," she said. "But everyone convinced me to add this and add that and now I have almost a restaurant here."
 Mrs. Gaffney hopes to persuade supermarkets around the city to carry her pasteles. "You say Mexico and you think tacos," she said. "So why shouldn't we be able to say Puerto Rico and think Pasteles?" R.K.

HEADLINE: How Do You Turn On the Twentysomething Market?

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
WHEN Charlie von Simson sees the latest commercial for Budweiser pop up on his television screen, the one that features people his age joking about characters in "Gilligan's Island" and other sitcoms of the 1960's, the one that marketing experts spent months researching and developing just for people like him, he grabs the remote control.
"That Bud ad is so lame, I wince every time I see it," said Mr. von Simson, 29, who studies law in Brooklyn. "By the time we were watching those shows, they were reruns, which makes it painfully clear that these ads were made by people 10 years older than me." 
 Marketers have sat through endless hours of focus groups. They have read the research reports, the magazine articles and the op-ed pieces about the 42 million people in their 20's now known as Generation X, twentysomethings, twentynothings, post-boomers, the lost generation and boomerangers.
And now, they are trying to find a way to sell to the group, which for all the talk about its alienation and diminished expectations in the harsh 90's still manages to spend around $125 billion a year on consumer products, according to a survey by the Roper Organization. The trouble is, the group is proving it can be a hard sell.
No one can pinpoint just when marketers became interested in the group, but over the last year or so beer companies, car manufacturers and a host of others have created special campaigns to tap into the Zeitgeist of those in their 20's. The most widely used approach: appeal to the group through what marketers, many in their 40's, believe to be their sociological and cultural touchstones. By using references to old TV shows and featuring young white actors in disheveled clothing speaking the language of alienation, advertisers hoped to show an understanding of the group's visions, goals and needs.
But people in their 20's, who were raised on television, are highly skeptical of advertising that sells an image because they have been deconstructing ads all of their lives, separating the hype from the reality. They see perfectly well what marketers are up to with them, and they are responding resentfully to some of the campaigns, calling them patronizing and off the mark.
What does work, say researchers, advertising executives and members of Generation X, are campaigns that depict the life styles of a group that has come of age in the wake of the better-off baby-boom generation. Named after the title of a novel by Douglas Coupland about the often overeducated and underemployed people who were born roughly between 1965 and 1974, members of Generation X are also called baby busters, as in "from boom to bust." Many of them, as well, were reared in single-parent homes or in homes in which both parents were working. They had to help out with the shopping, or do it themselves, and so they learned about coupon clipping, comparison shopping and bargain hunting.
All of which means that as a group, they are obsessively worried about their place in the economy, frequently convinced that they are being ripped off or duped and determined to get their money's worth. And that means, according to some marketing experts, that if advertisers want to reach them, they had better get things right, especially when it comes to cultural icons. And they should also keep the smoke and mirrors to a minimum, concentrating instead on showing how their products work easily and affordably.
"Marketers who have gotten it right have realized that this generation wants items that function well with no hype, things that are useful," said Marian Salzman, president of BKG America, a market research firm in New York that recently conducted a survey of people in their 20's.
"Until now there were not a lot of people asking for research on Generation X," said Rex Briggs, a researcher at Yankelovich Partners, a market research and consulting firm in Westport, Conn., and, at 22, a member of the group. "They look at them and say that it is a fragmented group that they can't get a handle on. But they are wrong, because there are some common themes."
IT is difficult to quantify the effect ads aimed at people in their 20's or any age group have on the bottom line because sales figures by age are hard to compile. And, of course, while an audience might find an ad engaging or even hilarious, that is no guarantee that it will buy the promoted product or even remember its name. Still, some Generation X ads seem to have their work cut out for them more than others.
Consider the Budweiser commercial, part of a campaign that features Generation X at rest. Here they are shooting pool in a bar and discussing what are ostensibly icons from their youth.
"O.K., Ginger or Mary Ann?" one young man asks another, referring to "Gilligan's Island" characters. "Ginger was a bimbo," chimes in a female friend. "Mary Ann," intones the man. "Mary Ann or Jeannie?" the first man asks, in a reference to another series, "I Dream of Jeannie."
"They haven't found my icon," Mr. von Simson said about the ad. " 'Welcome Back, Kotter' would work for me. Or if they had an ad with the Fonz selling beer, I would laugh my head off. A well-done Fonz might influence my habits." The Fonz was a character in "Happy Days." Both that series and "Welcome Back, Kotter" aired in the mid-70's.
Despite such criticism, the marketers at Budweiser think the spot is terrific. "Our research shows that this generation holds Bud in the same league as their trusty blue jeans, classic rock and classic TV," said Bob Lachky, the 39-year-old director of Budweiser marketing for Anheuser-Busch in St. Louis, who sees this as a campaign for the entire age group, cutting across geographical lines and educational differences.
But whether or not Budweiser has focused on the right icons, many in Generation X have a different beef: they are tired of being linked so closely to television and resent the presentation of rerun watching, an activity favored by those who are "between jobs," as so many in this group happen to be, as a life style choice.
"The Bud ad misses the mark because it portrays us as an idle generation, and we certainly do not perceive ourselves that way," Mr. Briggs said. "Those of us who are struggling to make it are really struggling and working hard."
By contrast, a campaign for Bud Light, targeted at a general audience, has gotten a better reception because of its humor. In the campaign, a young man sneaks his way into a limousine by pretending to be someone important, and then enjoys a Bud Light as he is driven around.
And a print campaign for Dewar's Scotch has been drawing raves by relying on images of what life in the 20's is all about while avoiding corny sitcom lines. The ads, designed by Leo Burnett U.S.A., depict young men and women in their new, slightly funky apartments, getting ready to go to work at their entry-level jobs. "You finally have a real job, a real place and a real boyfriend. How about a real drink?" reads the copy of one ad.
The technique of identifying visually with a target market is timeless, marketing experts say. "The Dewar's ads are brilliant," Ms. Salzman of BKG America said. "What they do is take a slice of life and then lay the product over those lives."
VALUE, too, will trump hipness any time with this group, experts say. "This group is much more pragmatic than their parents were," said Dr. Audrey Guskey-Federouch, a professor of marketing at Duquesne University in Pittsburgh. "In a bad economy, everyone becomes more value-oriented, but economic downturns usually don't affect the spending habits of people in their 20's because they are still concerned with trying to impress peers. But not this group. They watched the group ahead of them spend, and they are rebelling."
How the value question was treated apparently made the difference between an unsuccessful campaign for Subaru and a winning one for the Chrysler Corporation's new Neon.
Subaru tried to stress the coolness of its Impreza model last year by featuring a sloppily dressed young actor who testified that the car was "like punk rock," while other brands were "boring and corporate."
Perhaps this was designed to show how alienated young shoppers feel in the modern car culture. But Wieden & Kennedy of Portland, Ore., the agency involved, was unable to bolster sales. The ad became a running joke among some members of the target audience and eventually Subaru switched agencies.
The results of the campaign for the Neon, a cute, gas-efficient little car, are not yet in, but anecdotally, it is getting a good response. What the Southfield, Mich., office of BBDO North America managed to do with Neon is demonstrate its compatibility with young people who want something fun looking and low cost. And it pulled that off without resorting to musical metaphors and contrived vernacular to explain why the product is a generational must-have.
"We are buying the Neon just because we saw the ads during the Olympics," said Siobhan Kelly, 27, who lives with her husband and 6-year-old son in Oswego, N.Y. "We saw how cool it was, and how affordable it was. The advertisers made it seem very 1994."
BABY boomers were flattered when product hawkers made them look rich and credit card commercials told them membership has its privileges. They still respond positively to ads for hot-looking cars and other products that they perceive will enhance their image.
But people in their 20's have an image problem with that kind of approach.
An ad for Sprite is very popular among those in their 20's, Mr. Briggs said, in part because its characters are a departure from the typical cast of white kids in bad hats but also because it so completely deflates the image issue.
In the commercial, by Lowe & Partners/ SMS in New York, a young black man remarks that he has seen a lot of soft drink advertising and that he doesn't want to be sold things by celebrities, that he just wants something that tastes good. "It speaks directly to this generation's need to be spoken to directly, and not as part of a mass market," Mr. Briggs said.
Likewise, while advertisers are able to appeal to a boomer's sense of entitlement, they must be equally in tune with a buster's feelings of disenfranchisement. Those in this market need to feel that they are getting a good deal and that their purchases reflect their ability to find one, which is part of the strategy of Neon's campaign.
Marketers should also pay careful attention not to offend the political sensibilities of the group. "You have to be very sensitive with male-female issues," said Dr. Guskey-Federouch. "With this generation they feel at this point that a lot of the women's issues are supposed to be settled."
She said that ads for household products would fare better, for instance, if women are presented in neutral clothing, like exercise gear, so it is unclear whether they work in or out of the home.
Dr. Renee Frengut, a consumer psychologist and president of Direct Talk, a generational marketing firm in New York, recalls an ad she saw for Dawn dishwashing liquid by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles of New York that featured a young woman who said she had tried a cheaper brand but found she had to use more to get the job done.
"This line has been around for years, but what has changed is the emotional import," Dr. Frengut said. "The emphasis is on the fact that she isn't stupid, that she knows value, rather than on her worries about whether her dishes are clean enough. It's the same story, but they have changed the presumed consumer benefit."
So there it is, marketers. All you have to do is find a straightforward, no-frills, unself-conscious way to tell consumers in their 20's about your super-functional, totally practical yet mildly indulgent and greatly affordable product in a way that acknowledges their savvy understanding of advertising. Oh, and also make sure the message is not offensive.
"The people who will win in all of this are the marketers who realize that the so-called Generation X has had a different sociological process," Mr. Briggs explained. "If they can speak to their frustrations and emphasize their ability to have small indulgences that are pleasurable options to the cold world outside, they can do well.
"I don't envy advertisers' jobs right now because these are difficult times," he added. "But it can be done."
Mondo cool opportunity, no?

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
At Home in the City, Baseball's Newest Parks Succeed

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER, Special to The New York Times; Paul Goldberger is chief cultural correspondent of The Times.

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 14

 BODY:
The most rabid football fan thinks little about what surrounds the gridiron; the ardent basketball fan dreams of 3-point goals, not of arenas. But baseball is connected intimately to the place in which it is played and derives much of its aura from that place. It is no accident that people do not merely like ball parks, they love them, and they remember them with passion.
Could any other sport yield a Wrigley Field or a Fenway Park? Only baseball, which is played over time, not against it, and whose field dimensions are never quite fixed. Every outfield is different, or at least it used to be until the concrete flying-saucer stadiums of the last generation replaced glorious eccentricity with banal, bureaucratic sameness. The Astrodome may be great for rodeos, but it is not what baseball is about. 
 Count the Astrodome Generation dead. The first blow was struck two years ago at Camden Yards, the magnificent Baltimore Orioles park that opened in 1992 and whose stunning success made it difficult, if not impossible, for anyone to seriously propose putting baseball into one of those concrete bunkers again. Now comes Camden Yards' progeny, two brand-new fields that make it clear that the Baltimore ball park was not some sort of romantic aberration, but the harbinger of a whole new way of building for baseball.
 
Family of Parks
 One of the new parks is in the midst of a city, the other seems to be waiting to have a city grow up around it, but both are the clear offspring of Camden Yards. And like many children, they owe plenty to their parent, even as they struggle to do things their elder never dreamed of.
The Ballpark in Arlington, as the Texas Rangers park that opened last Monday is called, and Jacobs Field, which the Indians inaugurated in downtown Cleveland the week before, could not be more different from each other. Yet these parks, each in its own way, continue the work begun at Camden Yards, the mission of recapturing the baseball field from the architects and owners and public sports authorities who 30 years ago pulled baseball out of ball parks and started putting it into huge, vapid concrete stadiums more suited to football and stock car races.
These two parks are for baseball, and for baseball only. The grass is real, the field is open to the sky and the connection to the surroundings is intense, particularly in Cleveland, where the city's skyline looms over center field and the park is an easy walk from downtown. But even in Arlington, where the urban context is really suburban sprawl, there is a sense of urbanity. Its brick walls and towers line the street, and they seem to cry out for a real city to surround them. (Maybe some day there will be one: the architect of the park, David M. Schwarz of Washington, has also been commissioned to do a master plan for the area around the park.)
 
Too Much of a Good Thing?
 The success of Arlington is startling, in part because the project seems, from drawings and photographs, to be just too good to be true -- too pretty, too romantic, too derivative of old-style ball parks to be convincingly a product of the 1990's. With its roof trusses recalling the original Yankee Stadium, its "home run porch" alluding to Tiger Stadium, and its right-field shape loosely calling to Fenway, the whole thing looks as if it's going to be less a ball park than a ball-theme park.
And then you go, and you discover how little you can trust drawings. It is as pleasing to watch a ball game here as at Camden Yards, maybe more so. Every detail of this park -- of which plenty are sleek and modern and look not at all to the past -- comes together to create a coherent work of architecture, a work that functions well and even has some unexpected moments of monumental grandeur.
The experience of being at Arlington begins outside the park, where the facade looms up over a messy landscape of parking lots, amusement parks, hotels and a convention center. The mix of red brick and stone, with four pyramid-topped corner towers and a rhythm of repeating arches, makes it look like a kind of simplified palazzo. The outer walls are decorated with sculpted Texas longhorns and lone stars and a frieze of Texas history in bas relief, not to mention rooftop lamps in the form of huge baseballs.
The magic moment, though, is when you step through the stone arches and catch a glimpse of the field within: It is a powerful instant when you feel the order of the city and the order of baseball coming together. You sense that in what is itself a great space, inside the concourse between the outside walls and the seating bowl, where green-painted steel trusses line the ceiling and green-steel ramps and stairs move up and down and across to give the room high drama.
 
Homer in First At-Bat
 And from there it is into the park itself, where the seating is arranged in three main tiers. It is asymmetrical, both to emphasize the tie to older ball parks and to give the field a degree of idiosyncrasy.
Schwarz had never designed a stadium before. Far from finding this a liability, it seems to have made him all the more attractive to the Rangers. "I wanted an architect who would look upon this as a once-in-a-lifetime chance, because that's what it was going to be for me," said Tom Schieffer, the president of the team.
The real achievement in this $189 million project is in the layout of the 49,292 seats to maximize a sense of intimacy with the field. The angle of the upper deck is less steep than in many recent parks, and many of the seats are angled slightly toward home plate. The columns supporting the roof of the home-run porch in right field make for a few obstructed-view seats, but the columns also frame and intensify the view of the field for those sitting far behind them, and the porch itself is a spectacular architectural element.
The layout also includes 120 private luxury suites slipped deftly into intermediate levels, avoiding the sense that this park is dominated by special seating for the rich. This is no small problem these days in arena and stadium design, where class distinctions, once altogether absent from sports architecture, seem now larger and larger. There is at least the illusion of democracy in the Arlington layout, if not the reality of it.
There is no such illusion in Cleveland, alas, and that is that park's biggest problem. The $170 million Jacobs Field, named for the Indians' owner, Richard Jacobs, also contains 120 luxury suites, but instead of being slipped unobtrusively between main seating levels, these glass-enclosed boxes dominate one whole portion of the park. Three levels of glass facing the field sends a disquieting message that is very much at odds with the larger goal of this park, which is to tie itself into the larger life of the city.
 
Cleveland, No Doubt
 Luxury skyboxes symbolize isolation, in the same way that suburban stadiums sitting in seas of parked cars symbolize isolation; they are an unavoidable part of sports economics today, but this hardly means that they have to be so conspicuous an architectural presence. It's too bad, since otherwise the Cleveland park makes every effort to integrate itself into the larger city. The views of the skyline are spectacular, and there is no mistaking from any one of its 42,000 seats that you are in Cleveland. Indeed, the open corners, which maximize the views, are one improvement over Arlington, where the frequency of high winds mandated a park closed on all sides.
Jacobs Field, which was built as a part of the city's Gateway renewal project, was designed by Joseph Spear of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, a firm that has made a specialty out of stadium architecture for years, and whose credits range all the way from the acclaimed Camden Yards to the 1992 Comiskey Park, the most disappointing of the current generation of ball parks.
While Schwarz carried the old-fashioned air of Camden Yards even further, Spear went in the other direction, trying to prove that it is possible to build a ball park that is traditional in its respect for baseball while being modern in its architectural details. This is a lighter, more hard-edged building than either Camden or Arlington, less instantly lovable, but with a kind of strength that feels right for a Northern industrial city.
The park is well laid out, with field dimensions that, like Arlington's, are slightly eccentric and a seating bowl that is asymmetrical. Unfortunately the upper deck is steeper than Arlington's, and some of its seats are far away from home plate, which came in part as a result of trying to satisfy the worthwhile goal of letting the right-field side of the building run straight along a neighboring street rather than curve inward. Given that most older ball parks responded to the pattern of the streets around them, this gesture is every bit as much a look backward as anything done at Arlington.
 
Park With a View
 To be fair, the views from the bulk of the seats at Jacobs Field, many of which are angled toward home plate, are excellent. And there is a splendid bleacher area under the huge, lively scoreboard. If you look toward the field with the skyline as a backdrop and keep your back toward the skyboxes, you'll be perfectly happy.
The exterior is handsome, with a base consisting of bands of green granite, tan kasota stone and limestone, with brick above, and lots of white-painted tubular steel, a big change from the old-style green that is in fashion elsewhere. The field lights are set not in large horizontal blocks but on narrow vertical poles, like smokestacks; along with the gently vaulted roof and the vault-topped elevator towers, these give the stadium a distinct profile.
Each of these new parks is a kind of monument, a place in which baseball and the idea of civic architecture come together. The great ball parks have always been places of rus in urbe, of the country in the city, and it is in the meeting of these two things, the soft perfection of the field with the hard lines of the city, that the special quality of ball parks lies. The infield, finite and measured and in a sense urban itself, giving onto the outfield, vast and stretching and of no particular dimension -- from the juxtaposition of these two things, the meeting of urban containment and rural expanse, comes the truth of the ball park, now rediscovered in our time.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 24, 1994, Sunday

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
'Gigantic Ears' With Room for Old, New, Even Jazz

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI; Anthony Tommasini writes about music and theater for The Boston Globe.

 BODY:
THE PIANIST Ursula Oppens whose tenacious devotion to contemporary music has been hailed by composers and critics for more than 25 years, performs new music not out of obligation or even just out of curiosity.
 "There are many, many, many, many reasons I have been involved in new music," Ms. Oppens said recently, with her trademark fourfold pattern of emphasis. "But one of them is that the only people who could tell off piano teachers, the only people who could outrank them, were composers." 
Growing up in New York, Ms. Oppens had some imposing piano teachers. One was her mother, Edith Oppens, who was an institution for years at the Mannes College of Music. Another was Leonard Shure, once a teaching assistant of Artur Schnabel's in Germany, a brilliant pianist, a probing musician and an overbearing pedagogue. Just being asked about him made Ms. Oppens nervous. "Phew," she said, wiping her brow with mock relief when the subject was dropped.
 Since those student days Ms. Oppens has won the loyalty of countless composers, including John Harbison, whose Piano Sonata No. 1 she will present on Wednesday evening in her long-awaited Carnegie Hall recital debut. The sonata also appears in her recording "American Piano Music of Our Time," Volume 2, which was nominated for a Grammy Award in 1991 and contains works by Conlon Nancarrow, Frederic Rzewski, Charles Wuorinen, Tobias Picker and Anthony Davis, all written for her.
 Some might suggest that Ms. Oppens, now 50, would have found her way to a Carnegie recital much sooner had she not been so involved in contemporary music. In 1971, with a master's degree from Juilliard and a first prize from the Busoni Competition in Bolzano, Italy, in hand, Ms. Oppens teamed up with the cellist Fred Sherry to found the enterprising contemporary-music ensemble Speculum Musicae. Five years later she was awarded the prestigious Avery Fisher Prize and an evening at Avery Fisher Hall with the New York Philharmonic. For her first Philharmonic subscription concerts, in 1978, she chose Elliott Carter's Piano Concerto, which she has championed and recorded.
 "My concerto is a very difficult work," Mr. Carter said recently, "and not the kind of thing that would be considered as enhancing to a career, not the kind of thing that New York Philharmonic people would rise up and cheer about. The devotion Ursula has had to contemporary music is extraordinary for a performer of her caliber."
 But Ms. Oppens has always played standard repertory as well, and played it impressively. "She is today's leading new-music pianist," Richard Dyer wrote in The Boston Globe, "because she is one of today's best pianists, period." Her Carnegie program typically juxtaposes the Harbison with works by Beethoven and Ravel.
 Ms. Oppens believes that the false separation of old music from new is a fundamental reason classical music is having difficulty today. "If you go to a concert only to hear music you've heard before," she said, "then it's a pretty narrow step to go to a concert to repeat an experience you've had before, which is not such an interesting thing as having a new experience."
 What this means, she explained, is that if you don't feel excited by a performance of Beethoven's "Eroica" Symphony being sold to you as the best, if you don't experience the same thrill you did the last time you heard it, then you blame yourself. "Whereas if you knew that there was a mix -- some things completely untried -- you would feel a greater freedom to trust your own reactions."
 Ms. Oppens's work shows a healthy reciprocity between the old and the new. She plays new music with a vivid sense of the tradition behind it. She plays old music with an ear for what is compositionally daring in it. Her bracing recording of Beethoven's "Hammerklavier" Sonata on Music and Arts, for example, reminds a listener that this piece was pathbreakingly modern in its time and should still sound that way.
 Reverence for composers was something Ms. Oppens grew up with. Her mother, born in Transylvania, studied music with Anton Webern in Vienna. Her father, Kurt Oppens, born in Germany, was a crusading music journalist. Being Jewish, they fled Europe for the United States in 1938. Ms. Oppens, an only child, was raised in a home where Webern, Schoenberg and Bartok were "taken for granted, part of the same canon as Beethoven," she said.
 But many struggling musicians passed through the household, complaining about their hard lives and unsettling Ms. Oppens's plans for a career in music. "My parents were very, very, very, very good about saying I should consider other things," she said. She went to Radcliffe, studied economics, majored in English, but found her way back to the piano.
 When she started working with composers, she realized that making music did not have to be reverential drudgery. "The chance to work with a composer, to learn something accurately, to be a part of history -- that's kind of thrilling," she said. "It's like taking advantage of what's in your own back yard."
 Over the years her curiosity has led Ms. Oppens to back yards far from the musical neighborhood of her youth. In 1983 she was part of a touring program sponsored by the New York State Council on the Arts. It presented Ms. Oppens playing Mr. Carter's "Night Fantasies," the jazz composer Muhal Richard Abrams and his ensemble, and the World Saxophone Quartet. She developed a musical and personal relationship with the jazz composer Julius Hemphill, a founding member of the quartet, which still continues.
 "I've always thought that in a blind listening test, anyone who knows me well could guess that I would have fallen in love with Julius's music," Ms. Oppens said. Mr. Hemp hill's music, drawing from free jazz, rhythm and blues, funk and be-bop, deftly balances elements of spontaneity and structure. A similar balance in Mr. Hemphill's personality also attracted Ms. Oppens.
 "Julius is less neurotic than I," she said. "He's centered, has more confidence. He's helped me have more confidence."
 Mr. Hemphill said, "I guess we're as different as people could be." He is 54 and black, was born in Fort Worth and played in bands with Ike Turner. "When we met," he added, "I was kind of teasing her, asking her out to dinner, basically being a wise guy. From that we started seeing each other. We've been making the most of it ever since.
 "I think she is a musical genius. She has these gigantic ears. Her faith in music is what probably attracted me to her. I'm not especially interested in classical music. When I was coming up, classical music was a whole other realm, aside from being basically segregated. I applaud Ursula's open-mindedness, a quality she has in abundance. That's probably why we get along."
 Ms. Oppens has put her gigantic ears and open mind at the service of several other composers who have worked in jazz, including Anthony Braxton, Carla Bley and Anthony Davis. She has had the courage, rare among classical pianists, to perform works that call for improvisation. "What I particularly like about improvisation is that there are no mistakes," she said. "Whatever you play, by doing the next thing, you can make the previous thing seem right."
 Ms. Oppens regrets that performers are discouraged from trying to improvise and compose -- requisite skills until early in this century. "Today you're made to feel you shouldn't do something you're not very good at," she said. "We're so caught up with the pursuit of the best. A Carnegie Hall recital is supposed to represent the best. And I'll try to live up to it. But there should be much more risk, more willingness to allow for things that may not be the best in order to get to another level entirely."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

INDUSTRY: SIC7922 THEATRICAL PRODUCERS (EXCEPT MOTION PICTURE) & MISCELLANEOUS THEATRICAL SERVICES (90%);

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Is Disney the Newest Broadway Baby?

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL 

 BODY:
ATTENTION, PLEASE.
This season, the role of the Beast, usually played on Broadway by the Shubert Organization with its 16 theaters, will be played instead by the Walt Disney Company, which is almost single-handedly rejuvenating 42d Street by renovating the New Amsterdam Theater. It is also producing the most expensive Broadway musical in theater history, opening tomorrow night at the Palace Theater. 
 What's that? Booing? Applause?
Both.
It is the oldest tradition in the theater to giveth with one hand and clubbeth with the other, and this year is no different. Broadway is finding that it loves to love Disney. But it still can't help hating itself in the morning.
"This is a world that needs targets," says Michael David of Dodger Productions, the general manager of "Beauty and the Beast." "It just comes with the territory. I told the Disneys they'd better enjoy the process of getting the show up 'cause afterward everyone will be shooting bullets."
The rivalry is intensified because this time, real estate is involved, not to mention government subsidy in the form of a $21 million low-interest loan to help Disney renovate the 91-year-old New Amsterdam, a perk that other Broadway theater owners have historically been denied. One of them calls the Disney situation similar to Wal-Mart opening in a small town, sending the local merchants into an escalating panic.
The quality of merchandise that Disney brings is top-drawer. "Beauty and the Beast" arrives on Broadway at an official cost of nearly $12 million with a cast of 38, headed by Terrence Mann as the Beast, Susan Egan as the Beauty and Tom Bosley as her father, plus the arsenal of Disney special effects transferred to the stage. The movie version won two Academy Awards for best score and best song ("Beauty and the Beast") by Alan Menken and the late Howard Ashman, and since its release in 1991 has earned about $350 million worldwide. It doesn't take a genius to see that this property has legs and, as far as Disney is concerned, the more pairs the better. If "Cats" can flourish on the road for 14 years, why not "Beauty and the Beast"?
Mr. Menken and the lyricist Tim Rice have written seven new songs to augment the fairy tale about a prince freed of an evil spell by the power of true love, which should continue to please Disney's family audience in yet another medium. Whether it pleases the people who work in that medium is another issue.
Money, of course, is a key reason for industry sniping about this show. As is power. And control. And expertise.
Disney maintains that "Beauty and the Beast" cost $11.9 million to produce, which surpasses "Miss Saigon," the last most expensive Broadway musical at $10.9 million. But some "Beast" employees have put costs between $16 and $19 million. No one will ever know the truth, they say, because, as a large corporation, Disney can itemize expenses for the show in a variety of different accounts.
"That's ridiculous," says Michael Eisner, chief executive officer and chairman of the Walt Disney Company. "The show costs less than $12 million. Every expense is charged to the show's budget only, otherwise we couldn't accurately report to our participants. Anyway, we never talk about budgets in our businesses because then the budget gets reviewed, not the product."
Even if the cost is $11.9 million, that's still a lot of money by Broadway standards, if not Disney's. Can jealous fellow producers at least hope it will take years to recoup the investment, especially given the Palace's hard-to-sell second balcony?
Bob McTyre, a Disney executive in charge of theme parks who is the designate producer of "Beauty and the Beast," estimates recoupment at one year, which for a show this size is remarkably fast. He says that after opening, the musical will settle down to costing about $380,000 per week, a figure some Broadway skeptics call low. But the skeptics may be wrong. One reason is that instead of hiring high-priced veteran Broadway talent, Disney has elected to use many of its own salaried staff, keeping expenses down, and in the bargain, exercising tight control over all artistic decisions.
And Disney being Disney, the ways those costs will be recouped won't be traditional, either. As the merchandising wizard of the Western world, Disney sold almost $10,000 worth of "Beauty and the Beast" memorabilia at the first New York preview alone. A "Beauty and the Beast" boutique opened at Bloomingdale's on April 4. And, an employee says, there are plans to step up sales of "Beauty and the Beast" videocassettes.
Mr. Eisner does not dispute this. "We have a hockey team in California called the Mighty Ducks that has some fabulous merchandising," he says. "Does it help the economics of the Mighty Ducks to see the logo, the sweatshirts, the hats around the world? Absolutely. Are we counting on the same for 'Beauty and the Beast'? No, it's not in our business plan. But we hope it will help."
And, he adds: "As far as a year being a short time to recoup an investment, all I can say is, as a businessman, a year is a ridiculously long time not to recoup an investment. The way it will work, frankly, is the road, the companies of the show in Tokyo and Toronto. And high school and college productions that will be forever."
THAT MONEY COMES LATER. Right now, the Broadway advance sale of $6 million (with a top ticket price of $65), is surprisingly low. "The Goodbye Girl," for example, a flop musical from last season, opened with a $10 million advance. Conversely, "The Phantom of the Opera" opened in 1988 with an $18 million advance and a lower ($50) top ticket price. For "Beauty and the Beast" at the Palace, where the potential weekly gross is $686,425, this advance sale adds up to just nine weeks of capacity business.
Mr. David, of Dodger, says only 15 weeks of the show are on sale, in order to sell every seat. "The advance is actually bigger than I thought," he says. "This show and 'Phantom' have nothing in common. 'Phantom' ran as a hit musical in London for over a year. 'Beauty and the Beast' hasn't proven anything past being a wonderful animated feature."
Mr. Eisner says: "The advance is irrelevant to me. What interests me is how well the show is done, and is it financially feasible and profitable enough to encourage us in this field. If we do it in a quality way, the financial rewards will be there. If somebody else is more clever about selling seats in August then so be it. I'm working on making the show the best it can be on April 18."
Mr. David emphasizes that Disney's low-key strategy in New York is similar to the way it approached the show's monthlong tryout in Houston, where it sold out. "The plan is to let the show make itself an event," Mr. David says.
But Houston is not New York. "There isn't a review that can be written to make up for a low advance," says James Freydberg, a veteran Broadway producer. "There's no question that this show is a big event to be shouted about, but they haven't done that. And events take place before reviews."
A recurring industry gripe about "Beauty and the Beast" is that despite Disney's financial resources, it has not employed the best, most experienced directors and designers the theater has to offer.
"Our team is not just Disney people," Mr. McTyre, the producer, protests. He ticks off the names of Mr. David of Dodger, Ann Hould-Ward and Natasha Katz, the costume and lighting designers, respectively.
Yes, but the word from the Palace, says one employee, speaking on condition of anonymity, is that no one could change a single moment of the show without the express permission of Jeffrey Katzenberg, chairman of Walt Disney Studios. The overwhelming feeling is that the experts who are there were not allowed to do their jobs.
"I'm sure somebody might perceive it that way," Mr. McTyre allows. "The Walt Disney Company does have its own way of operating, and the theatrical experience from our point of view is a collaborative one, not a strictly hierarchical one. Though certain decisions Jeffrey or Michael make. They talk and give ideas, and if someone doesn't agree, they say so. They are pretty darn smart guys, and it just so happens a lot of their suggestions are good ones."
Mr. Eisner also defends the approach: "We're in the movie business and we deal with both major star directors and unknown U.S.C. film school graduates, and some of each group has fabulous results and some are horrible. When I was at Paramount and we produced 'My One and Only' on Broadway with Tommy Tune and Mike Nichols, that was exhilarating and horrible. We chose our own people because of morale. In our parks we put on live entertainment and spend more on it than all of Broadway put together. And these are theater people, from Juilliard or Cal Arts. They come to Walt Disney World because there's work. I couldn't imagine doing 'Beauty and the Beast' and saying to them, 'We're going to eliminate you.' "
Mr. McTyre reiterates, "If I had it to do over, I'd use the same people." Even though the word on the street most consistently used to describe the show's creators is "amateur"?
"I think it will be right for our audience this way," he says. "We wanted the production to be a Disney production, not just funded by Disney. And to do that we felt we needed people with a Disney sensibility. In everything we do we are dedicated to having characters be the same as they are on film or television. Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck, Snow White. We try to bring those characters to life the way people would remember them. We had some creative angst about what the designs should look like, how far we could go. And in Houston we ended up burying the actors in costumes and makeup."
The other angst, a Disney insider says, came from typical tryout jitters: "None of them had any idea what Broadway entails. And after all the bad publicity with Euro Disney, they felt vulnerable to failure."
A Disney success posed another potential problem. A ticket to the touring ice show version of "Beauty and the Beast" costs only $25. That's some difference. And it raises the question of how hungry people really are for this story in all its myriad forms.
Mr. McTyre says the ice show is scheduled for New York next winter. But even when traveling elsewhere, doesn't it deplete the tourist market, which has to be considered a significant segment of this audience?
"It's certainly possible," he says. "We call that cannibalization. The only way to really know is to do it. Usually in the Broadway theaters children under 5 are not allowed. But we don't follow that policy. We know it is not inexpensive to go to the theater. We have $20 seats in the balcony."
David Geffen, the entertainment mogul who has co-produced "Cats," among other Broadway musicals, says: "All you have to do to be a successful producer is believe enough to do it, have the money to afford it and be lucky enough to have a hit. They have the things they believe in and, God knows, they have money. They're very smart and very rich, so there's no reason not to be successful."
As they surely will be on 42d Street with the New Amsterdam, a 1,700-seat former Ziegfeld palace between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. In addition to the loan for the renovation, Disney is putting up $8 million of its own, and Mr. Eisner says chances are good that a Disney store will open there by 1996, when the project is to be completed. The company has stated its intention to produce musicals at the New Amsterdam, and word is their next will be "Mary Poppins." (Mr. Eisner confirms that the project has been discussed, though he says nothing has been decided.)
When the New Amsterdam plans were first announced, the three Broadway theater owners, Shubert, Nederlander and Jujamcyn, were enraged at Disney's privileged position. They called on the theatrical unions to boycott the company's presence, but the unions didn't bite.
Ron Silver, president of Actors' Equity says: "I'm thrilled Michael Eisner is coming in. We have very few opportunities to increase employment for our membership."
SO THE THEATER OWNERS found they ultimately had no choice but to retreat from the Disney protest. They have joined a fact-finding committee of unions to formulate their own proposal for a low-interest fund for repair and upkeep of all 35 Broadway theaters. Still, the fact remains that Disney got cash up front, while the old guard has only promises. And lingering resentment.
But the theater owners aside, there are high hopes among the rest of the business that this new Beast in their midst will be transformed quickly by true love -- of Broadway -- and thrive, expanding its ranks and providing jobs for decades to come.
"First-time producers pay a high tuition on Broadway," Mr. David says. "They learn the first time, but they don't have the stomach to stick around for the next. Experience, wisdom and continuity are what make a good producer. Anyone who says they're going to stay and fight it out is good for all of us. These guys are going to hang in and presumably what they learn will apply again. We'll see how it goes."
 
 
Deep in the Magic Kingdom of Special Effects
 Yes, "Beauty and the Beast" will be Broadway's most expensive musical when it opens tomorrow night at the Palace Theater. And yes, it will have more special effects, pyrotechnics, magical illusions, evolving costumes and computer-driven set changes than any show in Broadway history. But surprisingly, Robert Jess Roth, the show's 31-year-old director, has spent much of his time scaling back. "We never wanted effects for the sake of having effects," he says. "The technology is useful only if it helps us tell the story." Based on interviews with a dozen members of the production team, here is a brief behind-the scenes look at the show. GLEN COLLINS
 Slow-Mo -- The show's designers did not want to trot out actors in foam-rubber representations of animated characters. Instead, it was decided to change the mythology of the film, where the enchanted objects in the castle are humans already transformed into objects by the spell of the Enchantress. In the musical, the spell takes effect gradually, in measured amounts, and the audience is the witness. Mrs. Potts (Played by Beth Fowler, left), the busy English housekeeper, comes onstage in a hoop skirt that has the silhouette of a teapot; soon, the skirt evolves into a hard-bodied teapot with steam coming out of its spout.
 Press-a-Button World -- About $5 million worth of computer equipment governs the sorcery of "Beauty and the Beast." Computers mind everything, says Jeremiah J. Harris, the production supervisor, from the 34 candles that pop up sequentially during one number of the show's 1,000 pieces of scenery and the two elevators that deliver cast, sets and props to the stage. There, scenery rides silently on runners beneath the floor; these are activated by electric winches that pull the sets through slits in the stage. Computers control the stationary lights and the 60 moving Vari-Lites, powered beams that are individually focused and programmed. Computers also balance the sound from the 38 miked actors and 26 musicians.
 Wood-Chopping Widget -- It wheezes, it whizzes, it hiccups and it backfires: it's the incredible contraption dreamed up by Belle's father, Maurice (Tom Bosley, at left, with Susan Egan as Belle), the Gyro Gearloose of the village in the show. The one-of-a-kind electric-powered machine manages to accomplish a single task with remarkable inefficiency: wood-chopping. Remote-controlled pyrotechnic devices aboard create its shooting sparks. These are activated by infrared remote control. So is the automatic log-chopping mechanism, which can cut two logs in half without any intervention by Beauty or Beast.
 Transformations -- The term makeup is hardly large enough to describe visual alterations that include a beast who turns into a handsome prince and a Gallic waiter whose head evolves into a wax-dripping candle. In Fact, the production designers use another term for the show's elaborate shape-changing devices: "prosthetic add-ons." They were created for the characters by one of the designers, John Dods. For example, six separate pieces of foam latex give the actor Terrence Mann the facial asymmetry of the Beast. In full costume, Mr. Mann wears a chest piece, thigh padding, a rear-end enchancer and a haunch extender. It takes the actor an hour and a half to don his makeup and costume before every show, and the process is extravagant: the latex pieces are not reusable.
 Aaaoooooo! -- When they aren't working diligently to bring about the demise of the Beast, they're attacking unwary travelers in the primordial Disney forest: They are the wild wolves of the Palace Theater, with their feral yellow eyes and menacing teeth. Essential to this menace is the blackness of the stage forest, the thick layer of ground fog, the profusion of stage smoke and a strobelight effect that blinds the audience at crucial moments during wolf attacks. Why? Because the actors who manipulate the animal puppets won't be visible then. The sickly yellow eyes? Battery powered. You were expecting sorcery?
 Fire Drill -- There are 32 pyrotechnic occurrences in the musical, including the steam that emerges from Mrs. Potts's tea spout. The most spectacular occurs during "Be Our Guest," a lavish production number in which champagne bottles blow their corks and fiery wine bubbles create a fizz of light. The pyrotechnics are usually fired with electronic triggers, using remote-controlled transmitters that are digitally encoded so that passing CB radios cannot accidentally set them off. The fireball the Enchantress throws, transforming the surly Prince into the Beast, took more than a year to develop and is patented, says Tyler Wymer, the pyrotechnics designer for Walt Disney Productions.
 Hocus-Pocus -- There are half a dozen magic illusions in the show, most of which the designers are reluctant to discuss. One, operated by remote control, is crucial to the plot: petals keep falling from a red rose under a glass dome, a reminder that the deadline for breaking the spell of the Enchantress is fast approaching. Unless released by love, the Beast and all of the enchanted objects will never regain human form. The most baffling illusions are the scenes in which Chip, the teacup with the head of a little boy, is seen to talk and move realistically, even though he has no means of visible support: the legs of a tea cart are where his body should be. The illusions, some of the oldest in magic, employ an angled miror to permit the actor, Brian Press, to fit his body in the cart.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 15; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 901 words

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Lisbon Marches to Its Own Drummer

BYLINE: By Ana Westley 

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
INVESTORS in Lisbon's small but booming stock market were barely ruffled when rising American interest rates sent most European markets into a turmoil last month. Never mind the bears on Wall Street, forget the wild swings in neighboring Madrid. Portugal is on its own cycle.
Foreign investment and falling local interest rates have been fueling a strong rally that began more than a year ago and is likely to continue, albeit at a slower pace. Lisbon's widely followed BVL index had already soared 53 percent in 1993, reaching a high of 848.54 on the last day of the year. Defying all predictions, the index continued to climb at an even dizzier pace throughout the first two months of this year, zooming up to 999.46 on Feb. 18, just short of the psychologically important 1,000 mark, which was last surpassed in October 1989. 
 While other European markets confronted post-Easter plunges, Lisbon has remained an island of relative calm. The BVL index slid slowly down in April to the 970's, which experts consider a long overdue technical correction. It may now ease upward again. On Friday, the index closed at 973.77.
"The Lisbon bourse is less influenced by outside events and will probably continue to have a sustained increase, though not as strong as last year's surge," said Jose Cardoso de Matos, marketing director of the Lisbon exchange.
Though the Lisbon exchange, which some international funds classify as "emerging," is small and narrow by European standards, money has been pouring in. Over the last year, the volume of local currency trading has shot up 186.4 percent, to 56.05 trillion escudos ($320.6 million) last month.
"The amount of money coming in is really tremendous," said Francisco D'Orey, a trader at Mello Valores, a Lisbon brokerage firm. In three years, he said, the daily trading volume has jumped tenfold, to more than 3 billion escudos. In dollar terms, daily trading has jumped to $15 million to $20 million, from $5 million to $10 million in the first half of last year.
Most analysts agree that reforms in late 1991 gave Portugal's market international credibility. Insider trading was outlawed and automation increased liquidity. The market, now 90 percent computerized with continuous trading, has become more inviting to outsiders. By late 1992, foreign fund managers began to take notice.
"They all tell me that Lisbon is still cheap compared with overvalued European stocks," Mr. Cardoso de Matos said.
Brokers agree that the first six months of 1993 were driven by frenzied foreign investment, especially American investment. But as interest rates began to crash, falling from 14 percent last year to just under 9 percent in March, local institutional investors jumped in to join the rally.
"With risk-free high returns on T-bonds, mutual funds had no time for equity portfolios," said Eduardo Stock da Cunha of Banco Santander de Negocios, a Spanish merchant bank in Lisbon. Now, he said, "funds managed by our asset management company went up by 200 percent in 1993 and we set up two stock market funds in six months."
Prime Minister Anibal Carvaci Silva forecast in March that rates could be shaved another 2 points by year's end. Inflation, currently 6.1 percent, is expected to slide to between 4.5 and 5.5 percent by the end of 1994.
Portugal's Finance Ministry is determined to continue to push its privatization program. Four companies -- two cement makers, Secil and Cimpor, and two paper pulp companies, Portucel and Celbi -- will be on the market by summer. Electricidade de Portugal (E.D.P.), Portugal Telecom and Petrogal are scheduled for 1995. The Finance Ministry predicts that these three giants alone will increase market capitalization by 5 percent.
Limits on foreign investment are to be waived and some companies may be floated on international exchanges. "This Government is more favorable to capital markets," said Jose Freyre, a market analyst at Banco Espirito Santo.
While practically any stock did well last year, experts are now urging more caution and selectivity. Blue chip banks such as Banco Comercial Portugues, Banco Espirito Santo, Banco Totta e Acores and Banco Portugues do Atlantico are still favored by traders. Shrinking profit margins caused by falling interest rates are being offset by service commissions that banks have started charging.
Despite spectacular gains in 1993, traders continue to recommend the star performers in the retail and distribution sector, which is widely viewed as underdeveloped. Sonae's Modelo/Continente, whose share price rose 320 percent last year, is considered a good buy, along with Jeronimo Martins, which has expanded with an acquisitions policy.
"There are smallish companies that gained over 50 percent last year and still stand to gain more," said Pedro Assuncao, an analyst at Central de Investimentos, a brokerage company. He likes Sumolis, a soft drink company. Traders also recommend the beer brewers Unicer and Centralcer.
Graca Carvalho, of Totta Dealer, a brokerage firm, warns that many companies are already overvalued and attention must be paid to results. She recommends Corticeira Amorim, the largest cork company in the world, which just posted a profit increase of 38 percent.
Mr. D'Orey of Mello Valores went further, recommending "anything in cork, as people around the world will unpop more corked bottles as the economy picks up."
