HEADLINE: Hoax Unravels: 'Missing' Baby Is Found Dead

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
A Canadian couple's stunning but suspicious tale of a baby's disappearance in Central Park was exposed as a hoax yesterday as the parents gave the police a dramatic new account, saying they found the child dead in her crib 10 days ago and abandoned the body in a Quebec woods.
Confronted by evidence that they had only an older child with them when they crossed the American border and when they checked into a New York City hotel, the parents said they had concocted the story because they had been accused of abusing a foster child at home in St. Romain, Quebec, last year and feared serious new charges. 
 And they said they had decided to drive 400 miles and tell the bizarre tale in New York, where they thought it might be lost in the crowd of daily deaths, disappearances and other urban woes.
As an overnight park search by helicopters, scuba divers and 100 officers was called off, the parents, Joseph Bales, 33, and Helene Lemay, 31, drew a crude map that led the Canadian police to a woods near Eastman, Quebec. There the body of 10-week-old Muguet Bales was found wrapped in plastic and tucked in a knapsack under a tree.
The cause of her death was not immediately apparent, and Canadian officials said an autopsy would be performed today. Pending the outcome, the parents were being held in New York on a misdemeanor charge of making a false report, but could face more serious charges in Canada.
"These aren't hardened criminals," Assistant Chief John J. Hill, the chief of detectives in Manhattan, said at an afternoon news conference at the 20th Precinct station on West 82d Street. "If they were hardened criminals, they wouldn't have made such stupid blunders."
While the strange case unfolded in New York, residents of St. Romain, a village of fewer than 1,000 people 35 miles north of the Maine-New Hampshire border, portrayed the couple as unusual neighbors: Seventh-day Adventists in a Roman Catholic community, strict vegetarians who worked odd jobs, avoided visitors, did not allow toys and planned to educate their children at home.
A medical examination of the couple's 4-year-old daughter, Priscille, found no signs of abuse, and after more than a day at the station house -- gobbling ice cream, grinning for photographers and dozing on a squad-room cot -- she is to be placed today with Canadian child-welfare authorities while investigators tried to sort out the twists and turns of a case riddled with deception and mystery.
What began Saturday afternoon as a French-speaking couple's account of a baby's apparent kidnapping from a carrier while her father slept on a park bench near West 67th Street unraveled in less than 12 hours as detectives -- suspicious at first because the parents could not explain why they had waited 18 hours to report the case -- turned up one contradiction after another.
 
$120 and No Jobs
 While the couple said they came to New York with their two children Friday as tourists and first went to the luxurious Pierre Hotel on Fifth Avenue, they acknowledged that both were unemployed, had rented a car with a credit card and had only $120 in their possession.
Moreover, customs agents at Massena, N.Y., where they crossed into the United States, had noted only one child in their car, and a clerk at the Roger Williams Hotel, at 28 East 31st Street, where they finally checked in at 10:53 P.M. Friday, also remembered only one child.
Priscille, who was not told of her sister's death, was apparently under the impression that the baby was along on the trip, sleeping a lot, but the police said she had been fooled by a doll her parents had brought along to simulate the missing infant.
Although the couple met with reporters and television camera crews at the station house Saturday night and made a tearful public appeal for the return of their baby, detectives said the parents were unable to satisfactorily explain why -- after supposedly losing the baby about 7 P.M. -- they had checked into a hotel four hours later and failed to go to the police until midafternoon Saturday.
While scuba divers, helicopters and ground teams searched the park for Muguet, the parents kept vigil at the station house and were questioned by detectives. They insisted the family spoke no English, and their comments were interpreted by a French-speaking officer, Sgt. Sean O'Neill. But when a detective asked if anyone wanted ice cream, Priscille piped up.
"Yes," she said, "I want ice cream."
 
Recent Fraud Arrest
 Besides the gaps and contradictions in the parents' accounts, the police learned late Saturday night from Canadian authorities that Mr. Bales had recently been arrested on a fraud charge -- the case has not yet gone to court -- and that the couple had been accused of child abuse last year, Chief Hill said.
He said a foster son about 4 years old, whom the couple had taken into their home over a year ago, had been found alone in their car at a Quebec mall last September. The boy, described by neighbors in St. Romain as severely retarded, unable to speak or walk, was undernourished and dehydrated and showed signs of prior injuries, including fractures. He was quickly taken from their custody.
Confronted with the evidence of their background and misrepresentations, the couple admitted that they had made up the story of the baby's disappearance to conceal what they called the infant's unexplained crib death at their home in St. Romain on April 8 and their decision to abandon the body that day, Chief Hill said.
"They had a history of child abuse," he said. "They were concerned that they were in trouble."
The mother broke down first, then the father, the police said. In statements that essentially matched each other in detail, Chief Hill said, the couple told of wrapping the body in three plastic bags, putting it in a knapsack and then into the trunk of their car. They put a doll on the front seat, he said, so Priscille would think the baby was asleep beside them.
They told the police they drove 75 miles southwest to Eastman, a village 20 miles north of the Vermont line, and parked in a wooded area. While his wife stayed with Priscille, Mr. Bales climbed a fence, walked 100 yards into the woods and left the knapsack between two trees, according to the account they gave the police.
 
Couple Moved Abruptly
 The next day, neighbors in St. Romain saw a moving van outside their home and the couple -- after three years in the community -- abruptly moved 200 miles away to Cornwall, Ontario, on the St. Lawrence River 75 miles west of Montreal.
In the ensuing week, the police said, the couple decided to concoct the story of a baby's disappearance and tell it in New York City. The police said it unfolded like this:
After arriving in New York late Friday and discovering that the Pierre Hotel was too expensive, they checked in at the Roger Williams. They examined various spots in Central Park the next day to familiarize themselves with details, and in the afternoon walked up to a guard at the Museum of Natural History and asked how to report a missing baby. They were directed to the 20th Precinct nearby, and soon after they told the tale the search got under way.
Tom McConnell, a spokesman for the provincial police, said the baby was found with the aid of a map drawn by the parents and faxed to Canadian authorities. The body was taken to Montreal, where an autopsy is to be performed today.
The police in New York said the couple had signed a waiver of extradition and were prepared to return to Quebec to face whatever charges might arise out of the case.
 
An Unusual Family
 Neighbors in St. Romain yesterday recalled an unusual family that had lived quietly on the outskirts of the village in a modest split-level home. Mr. Bales was said to be a handyman who occasionally did odd jobs and last worked in a furniture factory six months ago.
Ms. Lemay was described by a neighbor, Marie-Michelle St. Jean, as a highly intelligent woman who had earned several university degrees in psychology, who had a computer and photocopier at home and earned a living teaching correspondence courses on dieting and other subjects.
Ms. St. Jean said she baby-sat for Priscille when Muguet, whose name means lily of the valley, was born about 10 weeks ago. She described Priscille as a "radiant, extraordinarily happy" child who was strangely adult for her age.
It was unclear if the couple was married, but neighbors said they apparently intended to have many children and had divided their small home into many bedroom cubicles.
Ms. St. Jean said that after Ms. Lemay had a miscarriage 18 months ago, the couple decided to adopt a foster child in the belief that she could not have more children.

HEADLINE: Detroit's Booming Auto Sales Mean Waiting Lists for Some

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 17

 BODY:
What had seemed a stately recovery in the auto market turned into a boom this year, and some dealers' lots are emptying even as auto makers are piling on the overtime to raise production.
Particularly for buyers of four-wheel-drive wagons and other light trucks, the wait for vehicles with the options they want can stretch beyond three months. 
 "I don't know how anyone could have anticipated the strength of this market," said Ron Sobrero, general sales and service manager for the Chevrolet division of General Motors, which has long waiting lists for everything from sporty Camaro coupes and convertibles to the colossal Suburban wagons.
He added, "You'd rather have a better balance."
As dealers sense a sellers' market, the prices customers pay are rising, in some cases over the sticker price. Shortages in the auto industry, which occurred in other recoveries in the 70's and 80's, illustrate the strength of the economy, said David L. Littmann, senior economist with Comerica Bank here. "It's highly significant, because it represents perhaps most clearly the confidence of the consumer," he said.
In February, for the first time since the Government began tracking the data, the American auto industry was operating at slightly more than 100 percent of existing factory capacity for production of cars and light trucks, according to a Federal Reserve index. (Such capacity numbers are squishy; by paying more overtime and taking other steps, the auto makers say they can wring out vehicles at a rate of 120 percent of capacity.)
In November 1978, the record before January 1994, capacity utilization was more than 92 percent.
"The demand factor is monstrous," said Larry Rogers, a salesman at Elder-Mohns Ford in Jefferson, Wis. He said that for some pickups, in particular the large F-series truck with a diesel engine, the wait can be as long as four months. "Those on the waiting list may be looking at a '95 model, not a '94," he said.
Economists predict that the effect of rising prices and too few cars on overall inflation is likely to be mild. But the Government says its method of calculating inflation may not fully reflect the surging interest in pickup trucks, mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles.
After the brutal plant closings of the 80's, the auto makers are reluctant to expand, an attitude that is fine with auto industry analysts.
"In the very short term, it's a small problem, but generally speaking I think it's a good thing," said John Casesa, the auto industry analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company in New York. "The guys who run the Big Three recognize that this will not last, and they're not going to rush out and build new plants."
By restraining sales now, tight capacity will help prevent the cyclical recovery of the auto market from peaking earlier than expected, many industry analysts say, producing strong sales through 1996. Further, they do not expect the constraints to have much impact on market shares or company earnings, since the types of vehicles in shortest supply are practically sold out from one auto maker to the next.
 
Frustrating to Customers
 The rush for vehicles is not necessarily good news for dealers, since it can frustrate customers. Mr. Rogers said customers had threatened to report him to the Wisconsin Department of Motor Vehicles after he failed to find them the truck they wanted after he called other dealers. "I can't be held accountable for something that's not there," he said.
Automotive News, the weekly trade publication, is once again selling classified ads bought by dealers in search of hot-selling cars. "REWARD: $1,000 over invoice on New '94 Dodge Ram Pickups," one ad read last week.
"Most of the people calling me have something a little odd," said David Blackert, general manager of Executive Dodge in Wallingford, Conn., who placed the ad. For example, he said, he has received offers of pickups that can function like dump trucks. "I'll take them all," he said, even though he is paying a premium. "There's a market for all of them."
The domestic auto makers are caught in a classic bind. Because American and Japanese plants in the United States can make only so many cars and trucks, sales growth is likely to slow this spring. But while they are scrambling to bolster worker productivity and eliminate production bottlenecks, the companies are loath to add the factory space that is so costly to idle later.
By pricing Japanese imports well above their domestic rivals, the strong yen has helped to tighten the American market, effectively taking Japan's vast capacity out of the picture. Imported vehicles commanded only 15 percent of the American market in 1993, down from more than 26 percent in 1987, according to an analysis by Stephen J. Girsky, the auto industry analyst for Paine Webber.
 
'A Very Healthy Sign'
 Tight capacity "is a very healthy sign for the domestics, particularly," said Sonny Sonoguchi, president and chief executive of Mazda Motor of America. "The Japanese are not in the same very favorable position. Because of the yen situation and the pricing, we are still struggling to compete, to stay competitive."
Nevertheless, Mazda sales are also surging, and the assembly plant it operates as a joint venture with Ford in Flat Rock, Mich., has been at 100 percent capacity since October. The plant builds the Ford Probe, Mazda 626 sedan and Mazda MX-6 coupe.
In the first three months of the year, car sales increased 15.3 percent over last year's level, while light- truck sales jumped 22.8 percent. In March, Chrysler, Ford and G.M. each reported the highest monthly truck sales ever.
Detroit's car production rose 14.9 percent in the first quarter, and truck output rose 19.8 percent.
As the startling trend became unmistakable this spring, industry analysts scurried to their calculators to revise their sales projections upward for the year. "By the time we started getting into mid-February, I figured uh-oh," said David Bradley, the auto analyst for J. P. Morgan. Mr. Bradley raised his estimate for 1994 to almost 15.6 million car and light-truck sales, from 15.2 million; that compares with 13.9 million sales last year.
Switching over an existing plant to assemble a new vehicle -- let alone building a brand-new factory -- is a lengthy, expensive proposition. For example, to make more of its popular Explorer sport-utility vehicles, Ford plans to outfit a St. Louis assembly plant that now makes a rear-wheel-drive mini-van. To make the switch, part of the plant will shut down in August; the first Explorer is not scheduled to roll off the line until January 1995. Ford, which many analysts regard as one of the world's most efficient auto makers, says the changeover will cost $400 million.
 
 
58-Day Supply
 On average, dealers' inventories of cars and trucks are well below where they were a year ago at this time. Since sales generally pick up in the spring, dealers try to stock up in the preceding months, to have at least 70 selling days' supply on hand. But at the end of March, dealers had only 58 days' worth of domestically produced cars, compared with 69 days a year earlier and 59 days' worth of domestically produced light trucks, compared to 78 last year, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.
Luxurious sport-utility vehicles are not the only hot sellers. Dealers have only 30 days' supply of the Chevrolet Cavalier, a small car that has not been redesigned in 13 years. Sales have soared since last fall, when Chevrolet introduced a "value priced" version of the car, which has standard anti-lock brakes and other popular options; the coupe is $8,970 and the sedan is $9,120.
"We don't have anything," said Harold Schumaker, inventory control manager at Hank Graff Chevrolet in Davison, Mich. "We used to have no room in the front lot and the back lot and now we have all kinds of room."
He says that in some cases he does not worry about customers storming out, because they have nowhere to go. "If a customer gets mad because we don't have the Suburban he wants, and walks out the door," he said, "I wish him well: 'Good luck finding one, buddy, because no one has one.' "
 
 
Waiting for Chevys
 Waiting lists are common at Chevrolet dealerships, Mr. Sobrero said. Customers can drive away in unpopular models like the Lumina sedan without much problem. But if they want a Blazer sport-utility vehicle with particular options, they should be prepared for at least a five-week delay. For a Camaro, they will wait at least 10 weeks. And for the full-size Suburban, the wait will be four to six months.
When it comes to buying trucks, consumers have few alternatives to the Big Three, so production limits at Ford, Chrysler and G.M. leave them stranded. "Where are they going to go?" asked Mr. Bradley of J. P. Morgan. "They're going to bid up prices." The results will be good for the auto makers' earnings, but, he said, "there will be some inflation as a result of this tight supply."
A peculiarity in the way the Consumer Price Index is calculated may mean that rising truck prices will not push up the national rate. The formula for determining the relative impact of car and truck prices on the index was worked out between 1982 and 1984, before light trucks soared to 40 percent of vehicle sales last year.
As a result, a 10 percent jump in truck prices would raise the C.P.I. by only nine-hundredths of a percentage point, said Patrick C. Jackman, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. By contrast, a 10 percent jump in car prices would raise it by 40-hundredths of a point, he said.
Over the next three years, the auto makers, including the Big Three and foreign companies, plan to expand their capacity in the United States by at least 10 percent, from the current level of about 15 million units, according to Mr. Girsky of Paine Webber. The Big Three are using a cautious, targeted approach, adding a few workers here and there and shifting production among different factories rather than building new plants. BMW and Mercedes are building new assembly plants here, and Toyota recently doubled the production capacity of its Kentucky plant.
Some of the new production is intended for export, which may prevent the new factories from flooding the American market.
Most of the new capacity is committed to trucks. Truck capacity will grow by 15 to 20 percent in the next three years, compared with only 2 to 5 percent for cars, Mr. Girsky said. "As capacity comes on, the competition goes back to price and cost," he said.

HEADLINE: Schools Prosecute Parents for Children's Truancy

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PALATKA, Fla., April 12

 BODY:
Ellen Freeman concedes that from last September to December she was less than attentive to her 10-year-old son's school attendance. Beset by personal problems and "fighting off another nervous breakdown," she said she actually kept him home sometimes simply to provide her with a focus and anchor -- some needed ballast in her storm-tossed life.
So it was with a mixture of contrition and bitter resignation two weeks ago that Ms. Freeman, an unemployed single mother of four, pleaded guilty in a court here to charges of failing to insure her son's school attendance. She was sentenced to 50 hours of community service in the schools. 
 "I pled guilty because I was having a lot of personal problems, and I just gave up," Ms. Freeman, 41, said the other day as she stood in the cluttered yard of her faded pink-and-white trailer here complaining that her failure was matched by the school system's. "I pled guilty because I was tired of fighting the school system for some help with my son."
Ms. Freeman was the first parent in 22 years to be prosecuted in the north Florida district under the state's truancy laws. Officials of the Putnam County schools are also prosecuting three other parents of truant children in elementary and junior high school. Other districts across the state and the country are taking similar steps in an effort to get parents to take responsibility for their children's behavior.
Such legal actions against parents, while available to most school districts under state compulsory education laws, have rarely been used in the past, school officials and experts on education law say, partly because intermediate steps like counseling usually worked. But the use of such laws, which ebbs and flows as society recalibrates its views of parental responsibility, is now rising, said Ronald D. Stephens, the executive director of the National School Safety Center, a research center at Pepperdine University in California.
As school systems are required to meet more stringent performance standards, administrators are turning to attendance as one of quickest and simplest areas to address because unless the children are in school no learning occurs and standards cannot be met.
School systems have exerted pressure on students, linking school performance to obtaining a driver's license or hunting license, for example. In cities like New York, police have been sweeping truants off the streets and back into school.
But now, the schools are applying pressure to parents, giving rise to prosecutions like Ms. Freeman's and to experiments like those in six states that decrease the monthly welfare benefit paid to families with chronically truant children.
 
Opposition From Some
 "It's part of the larger move toward school accountability and that often means making students and then their parents more accountable as well," said Kathy Christie, a spokeswoman for the Education Commission of the States, an information clearing house.
Still Ms. Christie says that other methods might be more successful in meeting standards for schools. "The problem is that we have studies that suggest you have greater impact when you improve school programs and staffs generally than if you target problem children and their parents."
Punishing parents strikes some educators, like Randall Curren, an education professor at the University of Rochester, as "a dollar short and a day late." Most parents affected by such actions, these experts say, failed to supervise their children when they were young and responsive; now, it may be too late.
Still other districts besides the one here are trying to force parents to take responsibility for school attendance by their children. Every quarter since February 1993, Judge Michael S. Conese of Municipal Court in Hamilton, Ohio, has devoted a day of his court calendar to the cases of parents who repeatedly neglected their children's school attendance. In the last year Judge Conese heard some 160 cases, requiring all those parents to post $100 bonds that are returned when the attendance record improves. In 10 cases, he sentenced parents to jail.
He said that only five or six parents actually served sentences of 5 to 20 days in jail. In all cases attendance was nearly perfect after the sentences were served and, he said, average daily attendance in the city's schools has risen to 92 percent from 88 percent.
"I just don't permit parents to in effect wash their hands of their responsibility," Judge Conese said.
In Abilene, Tex., Judge Charles Griffin recently adopted a similar approach, working with a school attendance officer to fine parents and suspend those fines if the attendance records of their children improved.
Law-enforcement and school officials have also teamed up in Los Angeles where on any given day in the sprawling district 300,000 of the 1.6 million students are truant in an area where truants figure in 90 percent of the daytime burglaries. Since the beginning of the school year, the Los Angeles County District Attorney's office has summoned habitual truants at 18 elementary and junior high schools and their parents to weekday sessions emphasizing parenting skills, tutoring and counseling in an attempt to stop truancy early.
"There is something about the power and mystique of the district attorney's office that gets the attention of students and their parents," said Tom Higgins, the head of the District Attorney's juvenile division, who started the effort informally at two schools in 1991.
Of 1,819 students and their parents who have been summoned to the sessions so far this year, only 8 have been prosecuted by the district attorney for failing to improve school attendance.
"Fireman have to be ready to fight fires but a large part of their job is inspections designed to prevent fires," Mr. Higgins said. "As prosecutors we have to prosecute, but may we have to also think more in terms of preventing a kid from winding up before us in the courts."
Here in Palatka, the authorities started taking action against parents because of local concern about high rates of school suspensions, an increasing number of teen-agers hanging out in public during school hours and the growth of crimes committed by youths. The effort also got a push from the get-tough attitude among newly elected school officials like Geri Melosh, Superintendent of Putnam County schools, and a willingness of a recently elected district attorney to take truancy cases to court.
A town of 12,000, Palatka is 60 miles south of Jacksonville in a rural band of the state that is more like the South of the 1950's than the Florida of the 90's. Median household income in the county, which is 80 percent white, is 25 percent below the state average. Only 64.3 percent of area residents have at least completed high school, while the statewide average is 74.4 percent.
 
Little Respect for Schools
 For decades, the largest employer has been a paper mill, where until five years ago local people without a high school diploma could be hired. This long history may help explain what Ms. Melosh and her staff perceive as the low regard many parents here have for education.
"And there seems to be a difference between the attitudes of poor black parents and poor white parents, because black parents are easier to work with on truancy," said Nancy Burnett, the district's court liaison who noted that all four court cases involved white parents.
Since being sentenced, Ms. Freeman has not arranged with the schools for her community service and officials said that her son had missed two consecutive days of school recently. What was contrition two weeks ago has turned to anger for Ms. Freeman, who said in an interview that her son's absences could be traced not only to her personal problems, but also to his learning disabilities. She said her son, Brandon, can barely read, reverses letters, has trouble with math and cannot remember his left from his right, adding that the school has not addressed these problems.
Ms. Burnett said that Ms. Freeman's son has been a chronic truant since first grade and that over the years the schools have tried to work with the family to improve attendance. In the last year alone, she said, attendance officials visited the pink-and-white trailer a half-dozen times to talk with Ms. Freeman, sent several letters and signed two "contracts" under which she promised to improve the situation.
Robert Kuhn, the district's director of pupil services, said it was too early to tell whether prosecuting parents was improving school attendance, but he said he thought it was doing some good.
"We have some households where the children are telling the parents what they are going to do," Mr. Kuhn said. "This will help the parents to take back control and hopefully give them some leverage."

But she says the problem has been at least as much the responsibility of the schools. (Peter Willott for The New York Times)(pg. A12)

HEADLINE: Business Shuns Areas That Look Too White

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, April 15

 BODY:
The offer was sweeter than a bushel of Iowa roasting ears: $25 million in incentives to a Maryland biotechnology company if it would flee the nerve-rattling East Coast and settle here in America's heartland -- fresh air, quiet streets, smiling faces.
But after a closer look at Iowa, the company noticed that almost all of those faces, smiling or not, were white. The offer was ultimately rejected. 
 "We were really wooing them," said Michael Reagan, the president of the Greater Des Moines Chamber of Commerce. "And somebody in their group said: 'I think we may be uncomfortable here. We're used to all kinds of different people.' Their concerns were how homogenous we were."
The failed deal, which cost the state 250 new jobs and potentially millions of dollars to its economy, illustrates the powerful economic dimensions of the nation's racially diversifying work force, and the perils of homogeneity for cities and states competing to attract business.
"It seems a strange flip-flop -- places being considered too white," said David Messick, a professor of business at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill. "But if you think about it, it's logical. The country is changing. What was once seen as a great advantage, racial or cultural homogeneity is turning into a disadvantage."
 
Vision of the Nation
 Like "American Gothic," the tidy Main Streets and tall silos of Iowa once stood as a portrait of the nation's fundamental identity. But as the face of the nation changes, a place like Iowa, which remains 96.6 percent white, scarcely represents any kind of demographic Middle America today.
Recruiters say the biggest concern among companies considering a move to Iowa, or other overwhelmingly white regions in the nation's interior, once centered on fears of minus-50-degree winds in January. But as companies strive to broaden their work forces, an increasing number of corporate leaders voice concern about places that do not reflect the larger picture of America.
"It's becoming obvious that we have to be concerned about diversity, not just for social and moral reasons, but for economic reasons," Mr. Reagan said. "We have a lot going for us: a growing economy, a highly educated work force. But the image of homogeneity hurts us."
 
What Iowa Didn't Do
 Far too often in the past, Mr. Reagan said visiting business leaders had been met in Iowa by a team of white men, a mistake that he vowed would not be repeated. In efforts to promote diversity, several big companies in Iowa have formed "pluralism councils" that draw on the perspectives of minority workers, and the Des Moines Chamber of Commerce is planning a "diversity institute" that will focus on ways to hire and retain more minority workers.
In its unsuccessful bid to land the Maryland company, Mr. Reagan said Iowa officials might have erred by not emphasizing more clearly the small but successful presence of minority executives in Des Moines.
Officials of the company, American Type Culture Collection of Rockville, Md., which supplies tissue to researchers, declined to comment on the issue of racial diversity in its decision.
"This is emerging as a critical issue," said Max Phillips, an executive with U S West and co-chairman of the diversity committee for the Chamber of Commerce. "Companies today have offices all over the country, all over the world. And it's a good chance that some of their best people will be other than white. How is that company going to feel about sending somebody to work in Iowa if they're going to lose them in a year or two?
"People in Iowa are well-meaning," he continued. "They'll say, 'Gee, we're a friendly group of people here.' But if I'm African-American, and I can't find a church to go to, friendly isn't good enough. If I can't build a social life, if I can't find anybody of my background, then friendly just doesn't cut it."
Tammy Wheeler, a 30-year-old black woman who grew up in a housing project on the South Side of Chicago and took a job in that city with Amoco after college, was due for a promotion last year, which she knew would probably mean a move. "Please don't make my life miserable; please don't send me to Des Moines," she told her boss.
 
Difficult Decision
 But her fears came true. Her next move was to Des Moines. Although it would mean a better position and more money, she agonized over whether to take the job. "I cried really hard for a day," she said.
After a talk with her mother, she decided to make the move in the interest of her career. She supervises 15 workers, all of them white. She lives in a town house in West Des Moines and is the only black resident in the 88-unit complex.
"It's been a tremendous culture shock," Ms. Wheeler said. "I went to a comedy club with a white woman one night. I was the only black person in the whole place."
Her companion was a native of Iowa who did not understand why Ms. Wheeler should feel uncomfortable.
"I said, 'Picture this thing reversed: You're in a place and you're the only white person. How would you feel?' She said, 'Yeah, I guess I never thought about it that way.' "
In a year in Des Moines, Ms. Wheeler has not had a single date. She hopes to marry one day and raise a family, but she said her "pickings in Iowa are pretty slim."
Back in Chicago, she said, she loved to go to jazz clubs and "go stepping" in the dance halls.
"There's a lot of lonely nights that come my way now," said Ms. Wheeler, who said she did not plan to stay in Iowa for more than another year or two. "There's a lot of nights where I'm in my town house, dancing by myself in front of the mirror. Don't want to lose my step, you know."
 
No Good Place to Shop
 Ms. Wheeler said she had found only two hair parlors that catered to blacks. And she has been unable to find a brand of hosiery popular among young black women.
Jonathan Narcisse, an Iowa native who is the publisher of The Communicator, a black newspaper in Des Moines, said: "Living in Iowa can be challenging for an African-American, but there are opportunities. You have to be able to deal with white people. It's not like Washington, D.C., or Chicago. There is a lot of racism, like there is everywhere. But it's not Selma of the North. By and large, I think it's a fairly liberal place. For blacks, it's kind of like the frontier here. You either thrive -- and there are a lot of us who are thriving -- or you get ground down."
In the last few years, race relations in Iowa have been shaken by several incidents: crosses were burned on lawns in Dubuque; racist literature was passed out in a Des Moines suburb; a synagogue here was defaced.
In response, Lieut. Gov. Joy Corning sponsored a diversity commission intended to promote tolerance through meetings and workshops. A conference on racial tolerance will be held in Des Moines in October, with the poet Maya Angelou as the featured speaker. And the committee plans to give awards to people and communities in Iowa who have found ways to promote understanding.

Officials in Des Moines say they have had trouble attracting new companies because employers fear that their workers would be uncomfortable with Iowa's lack of diversity. Few faces at a downtown mall are not white. (Photographs by Jeffrey Davis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Despite Growing Support, New Laws On Smoking Are Unlikely This Year

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM with PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
The momentum is building, no doubt about it. But the time does not seem to be ripe this year for new Federal laws or regulations that would sharply curtail the use of tobacco.
Politicians are moving slowly for many reasons, but the main one may be that no one is exactly sure what to do to stop people from smoking. 
 Outlawing cigarettes seems to be out of the question. It raises the prospect of the corruption and gangsterism that prevailed during Prohibition.
"I think we have enough experience with alcohol," said Representative Mike Synar, the Oklahoma Democrat who is a leader in the anti-smoking drive in the House.
"Alcohol didn't work, because of the black market," Mr. Synar said. "Secondly, it's a little dishonest to say in one breath that nicotine is an addictive drug, that 50 million smokers are addicted, and then not have some sense of compassion and understanding that to ban the product would be cruel punishment."
Another possibility would be to eliminate or restrict nicotine in cigarettes, but that might also be easier to address in the abstract than in the particular.
Dr. David A. Kessler, Commissioner of Food and Drugs, told Congress last week that he was not sure what the public health consequences of such a policy would be. Reducing the amount of nicotine in cigarettes, he said, might simply push smokers to smoke more cigarettes, thus causing themselves more damage.
"How should nicotine be regulated?" he asked the lawmakers, the tone of his voice emphasizing the difficulty of the question. "What is the right way?"
While broad strokes against smoking seem unlikely this year, the political momentum is clearly running against the practice. Last month alone, the Labor Department took the first steps toward outlawing smoking in all workplaces in the country, and the Defense Department banned smoking in workplaces on military bases and ships around the world.
Meantime, Congress approved and President Clinton signed into law a measure that prohibits smoking in schools and in Head Start and community health centers, and the House approved a measure requiring that all schools that receive Federal drug-prevention money teach the dangers of tobacco.
Last week, the chief executives of the top seven American tobacco companies were called before a House subcommittee on health and grilled on live television about smoking.
An even more forceful blow came in February when Dr. Kessler announced that he was re-examining the authority of the Food and Drug Administration to regulate cigarettes. Because cigarettes are not considered a food or a drug, the agency has till now taken the position that it had no such authority.
 
Seeks Defining Legislation
 But Dr. Kessler said that if it could be shown that the companies manipulated the amount of nicotine in cigarettes to satisfy smokers' addiction, then the agency would have no choice but to regulate cigarettes as a drug.
As a legal matter, that would probably mean banning tobacco products. And since neither Dr. Kessler nor lawmakers believe that would be wise, the Commissioner asked Congress for legislation that would define how he should proceed.
Top F.D.A. officials said last week they would eventually act unilaterally if Congress did not deal decisively with smoking, but they said no such steps were contemplated this year.
Representatives Synar and Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, have introduced legislation that would explicitly give the Food and Drug Administration jurisdiction over tobacco but label it as neither a food nor a drug. The bill would prohibit the agency from banning tobacco but would permit the regulation of manufacturing, advertising, labeling, distribution and sale of tobacco products.
The bill is not likely to be become law this year, in part because the Congressional committees with jurisdiction are tied up with other matters like Mr. Clinton's proposed overhaul of the health care system. But the Synar-Durbin bill may be the direction Congress will eventually follow, legislators said.
Other, more modest measures stand a somewhat better chance of passage. A higher Federal tax on tobacco products has such broad support in Congress to raise money for more widespread health-care coverage that the only remaining question is how high the new tax will be.
Mr. Clinton proposed increasing the tax, now 24 cents on a pack of cigarettes, by 75 cents. A House subcommittee voted last month to raise it by $1.25. And some in Congress are considering a tax of $2 a pack or more. The prevailing view is that a higher tax might curtail smoking in the long run, but for the short term, it is seen mainly as a source of revenue.
Another bill under consideration would ban smoking in virtually all buildings except private homes. Its sponsor, Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, canceled subcommittee votes twice last month when he realized that the panel would not approve the measure. But his office said Mr. Waxman planned to bring it up again this week and believed that he had the votes.
The subcommittee seems to be the biggest obstacle to this bill in the House, and if Mr. Waxman can win there, he will probably succeed in winning House passage. But approval by the Senate is questionable. A staff assistant to the Democratic leadership there said bills restricting smoking were not the highest priority before committees and subcommittees and could probably be blocked this year by a few senators from tobacco states.
The lawmakers from tobacco states lack the political strength they once had. But like the opponents of gun control and advocates of agriculture subsidies, the political forces battling limits on smoking have such a direct stake in the matter that they care more and fight harder than do those on the anti-smoking side.
 
A Gathering Force
 Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat who has worked for years for tougher legislation against smoking, said: "What's happened in Congress is that it's very easy to block something and very hard to thread the needle. You have a group, obviously from tobacco states and districts, where there's an extremely passionate feeling."
But like most of his colleagues, Mr. Wyden senses that the forces opposing legislation against tobacco are on the decline and that it is only a matter of time before strong laws against smoking are enacted. "I personally think what they're faced with is a tidal wave," he said, "and when you talk to tobacco-state legislators, they know that."
An aide to one of the Senate's strongest opponents of tobacco restrictions agreed with that assessment. The aide said, "If you get even one or two members who can work to get something to a vote, generally speaking, it's a pretty easy vote for most members."

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE RUSSIANS;
Moscow Embarrassed When Serbs Make, and Break, Promise of Pullback

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 17

 BODY:
The Russians were embarrassed today when their power to put pressure on the Serbs in Bosnia proved to be as feeble as everyone else's, underlining the weakness of their claim of influence over their Slavic brothers.
Russia, which was infuriated last week when NATO bombed the Bosnian Serbs in the eastern Bosnian enclave of Gorazde without informing Moscow, stepped in on Saturday to make peace.
 
'Urgent Recommendations'
 But no sooner had Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev, returned to Moscow today bearing news of a cease-fire and a pullback agreement in Gorazde than Bosnian Serb tanks started moving into the town. 
 Upon his return from a 24-hour trip to Belgrade, Mr. Kozyrev told Russian reporters that the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, agreed with the Russians' "urgent recommendations" to halt the fighting around Gorazde, lift the blockade, pull back troops and deploy United Nations forces to enforce a cease-fire.
Progressive steps toward a general cease-fire in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Mr. Kozyrev told the Itar-Tass news agency, "would give Russia the chance to raise with more perseverance the question of the removal of sanctions" against the Serbs.
The lifting of United Nations-endorsed economic and military sanctions is a major Serbian demand, and Mr. Kozyrev had discussed the idea of gradually lifting them with Secretary of State Warren Christopher. The Americans were said to be reluctant to reward the Serbs prematurely but to understand the need for incentives.
But the Russians have a good idea of the value of the promises of the Bosnian Serbs. That understanding was confirmed on Saturday when Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb commander, told the Russian special envoy, Vitaly I. Churkin, that troops would not storm or shell Gorazde. The promise was made even as the Bosnian Serbs were preparing another assault.
Still, the Russians seem to be the only intermediaries the Serbs trust at all, especially after NATO intervened.
Despite the setbacks and embarrassments, Mr. Churkin and Mr. Kozyrev are continuing to seek a diplomatic settlement for two reasons. First, the Russians do not want to see or take part in a ground war in former Yugoslavia any more than the West Europeans or the Americans do.
 
Opposition Will Benefit
 Second, the use of NATO power against the Slavic Serbs, even under United Nations auspices, will be seized upon by the ultranationalist, and even centrist, opposition to Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin, whose political power is perceived to be weakening.
If the end of Communist totalitarianism has let loose virulent nationalisms in the former Yugoslavia, it has also created an equally virulent form of Russian nationalism here, where a growing anti-Westernism, built on disappointment with the slow transition to a market economy, feeds new assertions of Russia's singularity and its status as a great power.
So as Mr. Kozyrev tried to persuade the Serbs to come to a diplomatic settlement that would consolidate most of their gains in any case, he also criticized Bosnian Muslims for their "provocations" to the Serbs and called NATO's use of air power "excessive," risking a wider war.
Mr. Kozyrev also repeated today that he would not be going to Brussels on Thursday to sign a framework agreement for a new NATO partnership that could eventually lead to full membership. Russia wanted "a more serious and substantive agreement" with NATO, "adequate to the relations that must exist between NATO and a great country like Russia," he said. Such an agreement would "rule out unilateral actions, particularly military ones" like the NATO bombing of the Serbs, "in areas where we clearly have to cooperate."

HEADLINE: White House Goes Courting In California

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 17

 BODY:
It is well established that the White House is determined to stroke California voters as often and as vigorously as possible to win their allegiance in the 1996 Presidential election.
But in the latest effort to plant the Bill Clinton flag in the richest electoral soil of the nation, Vice President Al Gore stands out. 
 After Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, reopened the earthquake-damaged Santa Monica Freeway last week without first alerting the White House, Mr. Gore hurriedly flew here to credit President Clinton with making Federal money available to repair the vital expressway.
Returning to Washington with barely a break, Mr. Gore flew to Marrakech, Morocco, to address a committee of the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs. And where did he go then? Back to Los Angeles, to lead a rally of Democratic volunteers on Friday night and to be the featured speaker at the Democratic Party's state convention on Saturday. "If I make any more visits out here," Mr. Gore told the delegates, "I'm going to become a citizen of the state."
 
Taking the State Seriously
 In fact, many leading Democrats and White House officials seem to spend more time in California than in Washington -- starting from the top. No other Democratic President in memory has taken California as seriously as Mr. Clinton is. The state is widely viewed as the cornerstone of his re-election hopes, and the race for governor this year, which will pit Mr. Wilson against a Democrat to be chosen in June, will be considered a harbinger for 1996.
Nowhere has this unrelenting interest in California been more on display than at the state Democratic Party convention, which was stocked with more White House officials than usual.
The visitors all carried messages. Mr. Gore's was that the Administration deserved credit for helping California's economy to rebound. David C. Wilhelm, the national party chairman, had more than a message: $1 million for the state Democratic Party to help its candidates this year.
Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d of Massachusetts, speaking on behalf of the Kennedy family, recalled how his father, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, won his biggest victory here in the 1968 Presidential primary, just before he was assassinated. But Mr. Kennedy assured the audience that the state and his family were "the closest of friends."
Even James Carville, the consultant who made a name for himself as an architect of Mr. Clinton's 1992 victory, led a seminar, "Building a Political Powerhouse in California." While Mr. Carville's advice was short on specifics and long on generalities, like "knock on every door," the dozens of autograph hounds who surrounded him did not seem to mind.
But the politician who wins the prize for wooing California with the most hyperbole this weekend is Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader.
Asserting that the stakes were high in the race for governor of California this year, Mr. Gephardt told the delegates, "The election of 1994 is even more important, if you can believe it, than the election of 1992."
By the end of the convention, the California Democrats seemed ready to believe anything from the Washingtonians. One of the few delegates who was not sated by the attention was Michael Sedberry of Redlands. "They're doing a good job," he said. "But they could have sent Hillary."

HEADLINE: Report Shows Check Cashers Filling a Void

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Early every morning an armored car pulls up to a storefront in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. And for the next nine and a half hours, faces of all kinds pass in front of the four panes of bulletproof glass at Roebling Check Cashing -- black, Hispanic, Hasidic, male, but mostly female, with children placed on countertops.
"The whole neighborhood," William Siegel, the owner, said proudly. 
 With limited access to banks, neighborhoods like Williamsburg, with their populations of public assistance recipients and the working class, have made places like Mr. Siegel's storefront their financial centers. More and more banks are closing their branches in low-income neighborhoods -- 88.5 percent have shut their doors in the poorest sections of Brooklyn since 1978, and the Bronx as a whole has lost nearly 20 percent, according to a new report.
As a result, hundreds of customers stream daily through the doors of check-cashing outlets. It is in such establishments, with often limited security and a carnival of video games and vending machines, that paychecks become cash, bills can be paid, welfare benefits are collected, lottery tickets purchased, subway tokens bought.
 
Illusion of Cheaper Rates
 Many customers are attracted by the ease of conducting business and the illusion of cheaper rates for financial transactions.
"I took my money out of a bank," said Lina Gonzalez, a Williamsburg resident doing business at Roebling Check Cashing one morning earlier last week. "I had put my money in, but then they started taking it all. There were deductions and charges for everything. Here, though, there are no lines, no nothing. Check cashers are the best."
The endorsement is hardly universal, however, and many people who frequent check-cashing outlets do so because they feel that there is no choice, that they have been abandoned or excluded by banks that, because of mergers and concerns about profits, have closed branch after branch. These residents often lack the funds required to open bank accounts, with their sundry minimum balances and penalties.
The new report, released by Public Advocate Mark Green, concludes that a "two-tier financial services system" has developed in the city because of the disproportionate rate at which banks have closed in depressed neighborhoods with large minority populations.
The report says that 14.3 percent of Brooklyn's branches have closed in the last 15 years. In Bedford-Stuyvesant there are only three bank branches to service a population of 129,000, and in one 300-square-block area of East New York there is only a single bank branch.
According to the report, typical customers at check-cashing outlets, which must be licensed and are regulated by the State Banking Department, pay 4 to 10 times as much as they would at a bank over the course of a year. Customers at check cashers, after presenting identification, pay a state-regulated fee of 1.1 percent of the value of the checks they cash (limited to government and payroll checks), as well as unregulated charges for services like money orders and cash transfers.
The report, which says that inadequate security makes customers targets for crime, also asserts that banks have aggressively helped underwrite the check cashers that have replaced their branches, providing them with the $100,000 line of credit necessary to open an establishment.
 
'Economic Oxygen'
 "It's one more example of what has become a segregated economy," Mr. Green said. "Access to financial services may not rank with food and shelter as needs for people, but it's damn close. It's economic oxygen for families and neighborhoods."
As bank branches have dwindled, the number of check-cashing establishments has risen, to 510. In fact, there has been a nearly 45 percent increase in the number of check-cashing outlets in the city over the last decade, with a 19 percent increase since 1990 alone. The vast majority of these establishments are in the city's economically troubled neighborhoods. The total fees charged have also risen, from $31.8 million in 1981 to $86.6 million in 1992.
"Banks have abandoned poor neighborhoods, and found it very easy to go," said Dr. Donald J. Reeb, an economics professor at the State University of New York at Albany, who conducted a study of the check-cashing industry for the State Banking Department in 1991. "And check cashers don't replace a bank and its services very nicely. They charge."
 
Basic Accounts
 Officials with major banks in the city reject as unfair the report's conclusion that they have fled poor neighborhoods and that their branches have failed to offer services within the economic reach of its residents. For example, Anne Diedrick, a vice president with Chemical Bank, said 61 of the bank's 219 branches in the city are in low-income or moderate-income census tracts. She added that Chemical has set up a basic account that meets requirements of 1994 legislation mandating that low-cost "lifeline" accounts be offered by every bank in the state.
Representatives of the check-cashing industry also dispute the report's assertion that significant economic damage has been done to residents of poor neighborhoods who frequent their services. They note their lower rates for money orders, and the fact that public assistance funds are distributed without charge. And they say that New York's 1.1 percent check-cashing fee is the lowest of any state in the country.
"Banks aren't interested in the people we pick up because the banks have determined that poor neighborhoods don't offer them what they term 'good business,' " said Henry Shyne, executive director of the New York State Check Cashers Association. "We have become the 7-Eleven of financial services. What's wrong with that?"
The State Banking Department, for one, has no official objections.
"The people using check cashers need to be able to convert paper to greenbacks," said William Schilling, deputy superintendent of banks. "Check cashers exist, and they serve a purpose in the real world."
One of the people who finds herself in the real world of check-cashing stores is Madeline Marquez, the director of economic development for Banana Kelly, a nonprofit community development organization in the South Bronx. Seven bank branches have closed in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx since 1978.
"Yes, I go to check cashers," Ms. Marquez said. "What's the alternative?"
Rick Price, whose family runs six check-cashing stores in the metropolitan area, conceded it is unfortunate that banks have left poor neighborhoods, but he recognized that his business has flourished as a result.
"I'm in a dilemma," Mr. Price said. "But we're no different than people out there selling sneakers to kids in poor neighborhoods for outrageous prices. Except that our prices aren't outrageous. Our prices are an economic hardship only if they are compared against 'free.' "
 
'They Want Speed'
 Certainly the customers who strode one after the other into Roebling Check Cashing earlier this week were not complaining out loud. They were either resigned to their fate, unaware of extra charges or quite happy with the state of affairs and their choice of options. Indeed, there are five bank branches within walking distance of the outlet.
"They want their money one, two, three. They want speed," Mr. Siegel said, adding that he expected to process 300 to 400 welfare payments that day. "We've done away with the image of us being money launderers, and people here, with our money locked in what really is a steel cage, feel safer than in banks where someone can come in and blow people away to get at the money."
But one result of the expansion of check-cashing operations in poor neighborhoods has been crime. Banks usually have guards and video monitoring systems. But check-cashing outlets can rarely afford such security. There is cash, there are a great number of older women cashing Social Security checks, and there are dangerous streets outside. Victims are often surreptitiously marked with chalk or tape inside the outlets and held up outside.
"The majority of what we call our open-air robberies are connected to check-cashing places," said Haywood Batts, head of the anticrime task force for the Central Brooklyn Coordinating Council.
 
Lottery Sales
 Those who have studied check-cashing outlets also say they play a role in discouraging saving by the poor. "Selling lottery tickets at the same counter where government benefits are distributed may help the lottery, but it is dubious public policy," Mr. Green said.
Advocates for the poor and working class in New York and across the country have a range of responses to what they perceive as the problems posed by check cashers.
Among remedies under consideration are national legislation requiring banks to cash government checks for a lower fee; allowing banks to arrange for people to make bank-account deposits at check-cashing stores, and permitting community financial institutions, like neighborhood credit unions, to cash checks.
Baybank, one of the largest commercial banks in New England, decided strategically to take on inner-city check cashers in Boston in the early 1990's. Baybank offers a low-cost checking account designed for welfare recipients and has opened six branches and more than 30 automatic teller machines in poor neighborhoods in Boston.
"And we've made quite a reasonable profit," said Grady B. Hedgespeth, regional president for Baybank.
"The situation that exists with banks and check cashers is as if a utility had been allowed to turn off gas or electric service," Dr. Reeb said. "The banks, of course, say they are not a utility. And the people, of course, have a right to say, 'Yes, but banks could be if they wanted to.' "

HEADLINE: Jurors Find L.I. Murder Case Easy to Resist

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., April 17

 BODY:
Some prospective jurors said they did not want to serve on the jury in the Joel Rifkin case because they already thought he was guilty in the serial killings of several women.
Others said they could not spare the five to six weeks the murder trial was expected to take. And some said they did not want to serve because they were afraid of Mr. Rifkin. 
 More than 650 people answered jury summonses in Nassau County Court last week and found themselves face-to-face with Mr. Rifkin in court. Most said they wanted nothing to do with the case and quickly left after being excused by the judge. Their reluctance to serve pointed up the problems in selecting an impartial jury to hear one of the most publicized murder cases in Long Island history.
"Why don't they just take him out and shoot him and save the court's money?" one young man asked in a muffled voice as he walked out of the courtroom.
As expected, the task of assembling 16 Nassau County residents -- 12 jurors and 4 alternates -- willing to keep an open mind about the much-publicized case against Mr. Rifkin, a 34-year-old unemployed gardener, has been daunting. The police say Mr. Rifkin has confessed to killing 17 women, although he is being tried in Nassau in only one death, that of Tiffany Bresciani, a 22-year-old Manhattan woman. Other trials are expected in other jurisdictions.
Ms. Bresciani's body was found in Mr. Rifkin's Mazda pickup truck after he was stopped last June 28 by state troopers because he had no rear license plate. The police said Mr. Rifkin told them that he had picked her up in Manhattan and later strangled her, and had been looking for a place to dump her body when he was stopped.
Within hours of his arrest, the police said, he had confessed to killing 16 other women.
On Friday, the court ran out of jury candidates after questioning groups of 50 at a time. A new pool of 600 potential jurors is to be brought in Monday. The judge in the case, Ira H. Wexner, told those called to his courtroom that the trial could last six weeks. And while they might recall news accounts about the Rifkin case, he said, they could still serve as jurors if they kept an open mind.
"But if you have any reservations about the case and feel you could not be fair and impartial in reaching a conclusion, then feel free to leave now," Judge Wexner said.
In almost every instance, all but four or five people in each group left. Each remaining person was then questioned by Judge Wexner; the defense lawyer, John Lawrence, and the prosecutor, Frank Klein.
"What do you remember reading about the case?" Mr. Klein asked one woman, who, like the others, was given a number and not referred to by name.
"Just that he killed a lot of people," she said, shifting nervously in her seat in the jury box less than 12 feet from Mr. Rifkin, who sat slumped over the table, staring out the window.
"Did the reports shock you?" Mr. Klein asked.
"No," she said. "I just remember thinking that he had to be a very troubled man."
"By 'troubled,' do you mean that should his lawyer present an insanity defense, you could accept what he had done?" Mr. Klein asked.
"No," she said, "they would have to prove it."
Then it was Mr. Lawrence's turn to ask questions.
"Do you have any preconceived notions about Mr. Rifkin?" he asked. "Would you be willing to listening to both sides?"
"I believe I could," she said.
After the woman was led from the courtroom, both Mr. Klein and Mr. Lawrence said they would have no problem with her serving on the jury.
By the end of last week, the woman was on a list of 65 people, about 20 short of the number the lawyers need to begin final jury selection. Each side will be allowed to reject 20 finalists.
This final pool has already lost several members, mostly those who say they are afraid of Mr. Rifkin.
"I live by myself and I take the train late at night," one young woman told the judge. "I have a feeling this would have an effect on the rest of my life."

HEADLINE: A New Ford in California's Future

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 17

 BODY:
Californians beset by fires, earthquakes, recessions and riots received one glowing omen last week: Gerald J. Ford, known for his sensitivity to sweet deals and impending turnarounds, is moving to their state.
He and Ronald O. Perelman of New York won the bidding last week to buy First Nationwide Bank, the nation's fifth-largest savings and loan, from the Ford Motor Company for $1.1 billion. 
 Mr. Ford plans to move from Dallas, where he pulled off the most profitable savings and loan purchase in the whole Federal distress sale, to San Francisco, where First Nationwide is based.
Mr. Perelman and Mr. Ford formed First Gibraltar Bank from several failed Texas savings and loans they bought from regulators in 1988. With $5.1 billion in Federal aid and about $900 million in tax breaks, they at least tripled an initial investment of about $300 million.
 
Looking for Greater Rewards
 Now that the Texas economy has revived and banking here has settled down, Mr. Ford has been looking for places that offer higher rewards, even with higher risks.
"I've got to leave town for work," he said with a chuckle in a telephone interview. "We don't have any vision, intellect or genius that's proprietary. There are many people who can do as well as we do, especially when the markets are good. We tend to do better when the markets aren't so good."
That's the sort of overstated understatement that helps Mr. Ford command attention, whether at a south Texas hunting lodge or a Manhattan investment firm.
"When Gerry Ford is in the room, you tend to know it," said James T. Conroy, senior vice president of Mac-Andrews & Forbes Holdings, Mr. Perelman's investment firm.
If some analysts say that Mr. Ford could profit by breaking up First Nationwide, he will hear none of it. "I think California over the next three to five years will be a better place to be,' he said. "We plan to increase our concentration."
He is looking to build First Nationwide's deposits there by buying other savings and loans.
Mr. Ford, who is unrelated to any former Presidents or automotive families, has often gone for turnarounds instead of plodding corporate maintenance. Born in Pampa, a county seat in the Texas Panhandle, he made the National Bank of Post, Tex., pop. 3,822, his first acquisition, in 1976.
"Rather than going through a commercial banking training program, at the first bank I ever worked in I was the chairman," he said. "And it was my own money, so we loaned it out like it was my own money."
Theodore H. Strauss, who as chairman of United National Bank was one of Mr. Ford's early backers, said he soon derived as much benefit from Mr. Ford as Mr. Ford derived from the bank.
"He didn't have 10 cents, and if he did, it was borrowed," Mr. Strauss said. "But he was already helping me find prospective customers."
Mr. Strauss is now a senior managing director in the Dallas office of the Bear, Stearns investment firm, which introduced Mr. Perelman and Mr. Ford.
Adding other banks, first in small towns and then in larger Southwestern markets, Mr. Ford built his First United Bank Group, based in Albuquerque, N.M., into a company with $4 billion in assets.
 
One's Idea, the Other's Money
 The First Gibraltar purchase, the largest Government sale in Texas, involved Mr. Ford's idea and Mr. Perelman's money. Mr. Perelman, who owns or controls properties including Revlon and the Marvel comic book company, has built one of the nation's largest fortunes.
The terms of their First Gibraltar purchase -- including tax breaks, loss protection and the ability to shift bad loans back to the Government -- brought Congressional protests and another round of negotiations that somewhat reduced their profits. When regulators questioned First Gibraltar's payments for a Texas hunting lodge, a New York apartment and a corporate jet, Mr. Ford agreed to finance them separately from the savings and loan's operations.
Most Texas banks own lodges where they entertain important customers, Mr. Ford noted. "A North Carolina-based institution has one right near ours," he said, an unmistakable reference to Nationsbank, which bought the largest bank in Texas.
Mr. Ford took his profits last year, selling First United to the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis for $495 million and most of First Gibraltar to BankAmerica of San Francisco for about $110 million.
With a resulting fortune that some acquaintances estimate at $100 million, Mr. Ford by the middle of last year had become a passion in search of an object. No matter that he had suffered a mild heart attack several months earlier; he says he is now back playing tennis and working as intensely as ever. He is 49 years old, divorced and has four children 15 to 21 years old.
Industry analysts generally said that in buying First Nationwide, Mr. Perelman and Mr. Ford had found the right object at the right time and price. Ford Motor agreed to keep $1.2 billion of First Nationwide's worst loans and take back $500 million if they soured. First Nationwide has total assets of $15.5 billion, primarily real estate loans concentrated in California. Mr. Ford will own at most 20 percent of First Nationwide and Mr. Perelman the rest.
Analysts do not expect the First Nationwide deal to pay off nearly as well as First Gibraltar, however.
"Although Ford was very generous, no private corporation has exceeded the largesse of the Federal Government," said E. Gareth Plank, a savings and loan analyst at Mabon Securities.
Mr. Plank said that Mr. Ford and Mr. Perelman were still likely to reap annual returns of 15 to 20 percent, and then a big payout in several years from a sale, probably to out-of-state investors.
 
A 'Very Enviable Position'
 "They will be in a very enviable position as some look to the recovered California economy and their market position there," Mr. Plank said.
The state, aided by Federal relief and a construction boom after the Jan. 17 Los Angeles earthquake, resumed adding jobs early this year after a four-year recession. But Mr. Ford still faces several risks.
Even those savings and loans that avoided rash real estate lending face many competitors, including mortgage banks and brokerage firms. Also, California's recovery could stall, or First Nationwide's loan portfolio could turn out weaker than Mr. Ford believes.
Mr. Ford expects the Office of Thrift Supervision to approve the purchase within 120 days. He dismisses the possibility that regulators will reopen the matter of his profits from First Gibraltar.
"A nonissue,' he said. "It wasn't something we held for four years and then someone wrote us a big check. We took risks and we were rewarded."

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
Penske's Engine Has Opponents Singing Brickyard Blues

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
When Andy Granatelli whooshed into the Indianapolis Motor Speedway in 1967 with a turbine-powered car that outran the competition, the protests of other car owners could not obscure this: The car was legal, and Granatelli was the only man with the vision and resources to take advantage of a small opening in the rules.
This year, another car owner is updating that script, perhaps adding the happy ending that eluded Granatelli when a small part broke with three laps to go. Roger Penske, richly financed by Philip Morris and Mercedes-Benz, is either gambling a lot of money or using it to buy a victory in the Indianapolis 500 next month. 
 As in 1967, there are concerns among other car owners -- this time that Penske will raise speeds at Indianapolis enough to subvert new safety rules, that he will discombobulate the sport's economics by spending millions to build an engine for only one race and that Indy's competitive balance will be destroyed.
Penske and Mercedes announced on Wednesday that Penske's three Marlboro-backed cars will use a Mercedes-financed engine -- designed and built in England by Ilmor Engineering -- in the Indy 500 this year, one year earlier than expected.
But the real significance is that the engine will not be the typical overhead-cam, four-valves-per-cylinder design used in most other Indy-car engines, like the Ford and Honda. Instead, it will be a design allowed at only the Indianapolis 500: a push-rod engine with two valves per cylinder.
All else being equal, an overhead-cam engine would be more powerful because the cams open the valves directly, instead of through rocker arms and push-rods. With twice the number of valves per cylinder, the typical Indy engine has another power edge. But the Indy 500 rules allow a push-rod engine like the Mercedes to be bigger: 209 cubic inches versus 161.7 for overhead-cam engines. Indy also lets these engines use 55 inches of turbocharger boost, a big edge over the 45 inches of the Fords and Hondas.
"Most technical experts say that if you designed a push-rod engine to the current Indy 500 rules, it would have a horsepower advantage," said Dave Hederich, a spokesman for the General Motors Motorsports Technology Group.
The Mercedes engine -- designed and built in just 25 weeks last year -- is thus expected to have a large horsepower edge over, for example, the Ford, which has as much as 800 horsepower. That edge is estimated at anywhere from 10 to 15 percent more to as high as 1,100 horsepower.
"I think we shouldn't talk about horsepower so much," said Wolfgang Schattling, a Mercedes spokesman in Stuttgart, Germany. "We should try to talk about reliability."
"We hope we've got enough power that it's competitive," said Dan Luginbuhl, a Penske Racing spokesman. "But we've also got to run the distance."
 
'A Good Chance'
 Few doubt, however, that Penske -- who marshals all his organizational horsepower for Indy -- would take too much risk in that regard.
"You can bet by him announcing this," said Derrick Walker, a former Penske employee and now a competing car owner, "it has a good chance of doing well."
So far, Luginbuhl said on Friday, the engine has only 2,573 test miles on it -- with no more than 472 miles in one stretch before a breakdown.
"There's going to be a huge escalation in speed and a huge escalation in costs," Walker said. He estimated the cost of such a one-race engine project at $1 million, but others say it is at least twice that.
"We knew there was this opening in the rules, and it was just a matter of time until someone with the resources to take advantage of it came along," Walker said.
"In racing, the first thing you've got to do is read the rule book," Luginbuhl said. "There's been an awful lot of talk about building this type of engine, but nobody ever did it."
Luginbuhl added, "I've already heard from some of our competitors." But their anger, he said, is directed more toward the rule that permitted the engine rather than toward Penske. The rule has existed since 1991, but because it exists only for the Indy 500 -- and not the 15 or so other Indy-car races each year, which are run by another group -- it hasn't been economically viable for car owners to take advantage of it with a one-race engine.
 
Safety Concerns
 "I can understand why Roger would do it," Walker said, "but the safety aspect of it is just a joke. God knows what the speeds are going to be like."
A few years ago, before steps were taken to slow the cars at the speedway, cars were reaching 244 miles an hour at the track's fastest point, entering Turn 3. With an engine as strong as the new Mercedes, that figure could hit 250 m.p.h. this year.
When practice for the race opens on May 7, Penske's three drivers -- Al Unser Jr., Emerson Fittipaldi and Paul Tracy -- may not hit warp speed immediately. "If I was Roger, I'd be playing possum all month," Walker said, so there wouldn't be a risk of a rule change by the speedway before the May 29 race.
