HEADLINE: Essay;
Reds Under the Bed

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the wake of charges that a high C.I.A. official was a Russian "mole," an old question is being newly raised: how deeply did the Soviet Union penetrate the American Government?
Through two generations, that issue poisoned relations between liberals and conservatives. The liberals' villains were Joe McCarthy and Roy Cohn, and to a lesser extent, Whittaker Chambers and Richard Nixon. Among the conservatives' villains were the diplomat Alger Hiss, the nuclear scientist J. Robert Oppenheimer and the Lillian Hellmans who defended them. 
 Judging by a damning book out today by Stalin's favorite hit man, it's going to be a tough year for "anti-anti-Communists."
Pavel Sudoplatov, author with his son of "Special Tasks," is a loathsome killer. On Stalin's orders, he arranged for the assassination of Leon Trotsky; he hails Beria and derides Khrushchev. Self-serving and untrustworthy he may be, but the 87-year-old spy is, as the editors Jerrold and Leona Schecter write, "the surviving institutional memory of the Russian intelligence service's covert operations from the 1920s to 1953."
The news lede in the book, as excerpted in this week's Time magazine, is his detailed account of the way Oppenheimer, as well as Enrico Fermi and Leo Szilard, were enlisted as Soviet sources of information in the race to build the atomic bomb.
Though not Soviet contract agents, these great scientists were knowing sources for his K.G.B. operatives, reports Sudoplatov. Their motive in revealing secrets to Moscow -- beginning with Oppenheimer's leak to the Soviets of Einstein's original letter to F.D.R. -- was not to betray the U.S., but to share information with Russian scientists to defeat the Nazis.
Not all our top scientists arrogated to themselves that momentous national security decision; the K.G.B. tried and failed to attract George Kistiakowsky and Edward Teller.
Like Oppenheimer, Alger Hiss was not a paid or controlled agent, according to Sudoplatov; Hiss, K.G.B. code name "Mars," was merely "very close to our sources . . . highly sympathetic . . . a source of agent information for the Silvermaster spy cell . . . his behavior followed instructions he may have learned in the 1930s: never admit anything."
To those interested in the Ames case, the most intriguing sentences in the book attribute an allegation to an 81-year-old friend of Sudoplatov's in military intelligence, unnamed because a son serves in government. "The retired GRU officer remembers that there was a controlled agent source of information in Roosevelt's office. He was Roosevelt's assistant on intelligence affairs, and he was on bad terms with William Donovan and J. Edgar Hoover, head of the O.S.S. and the FBI, respectively."
Was there a Soviet mole in the Oval Office during World War II?
The confessed Communist courier Elizabeth Bentley identified Lauchlin Currie, an economist, and Harry Dexter White, a Treasury Assistant Secretary, as witting sources, and fingered Duncan Chaplin Lee, a law partner and later assistant to the O.S.S.'s General Donovan, as an N.K.V.D. agent. (Lee, a descendant of Robert E. Lee, denied this under oath.) But nobody has suggested a confidant of F.D.R.'s was a "controlled agent."
Assuming Sudoplatov's secondhand, unsupported recollection is true, who could that early mole be?
Two C.I.A. historians I checked say the description (F.D.R. assistant on intelligence, disliked by Donovan and Hoover) could apply to John Franklin Carter, a newspaper columnist and novelist (always a nefarious combination) who used the pen name Jay Franklin. He and a staff of six, on State Department payroll, supplied F.D.R. with reports on Nazi leaders -- and, at one time, an analysis of Soviet intelligence. He died in 1967, an ardent anti-Communist.
This fellow might have been a "controlled agent" or a patriot. As more documents and memoirs come out of the K.G.B. woodwork, we will learn more -- not just about F.D.R.'s day, but about more recent penetration agents in our intelligence agencies.
Spooks call the resultant reassessment "walking back the cat." Historians and biographers will have to reshuffle shibboleths about familiar villains and heroes. And among present and retired intelligence officers, "the Second Man" is getting worried.

HEADLINE: CUNY to Train Recruits For Police in Puerto Rico

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Tomorrow, almost 900 students will begin their first day of classes in a new City University of New York program to train police officers and confer on them an associate degree in police science.
The program is in Puerto Rico. 
 Trustees for the City University approved the proposal last month, saying the university wanted to help Puerto Rico make its police force a professional one at a time when its governor was mounting a war on crime. The students will be local recruits who will work in Puerto Rico's police force after graduating from the nine-month program.
The new program, on the campus of the Puerto Rican Police Academy, will be operated by the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, which is part of CUNY. The college will send 13 faculty members to Puerto Rico to conduct a program in police science identical to the one offered in New York, but in Spanish. John Jay will also provide staff members to help with testing, admissions and counseling of the police cadets, who are on the Puerto Rican Government's payroll as they go through the program.
Even though the program appears to have no direct benefit to students at economically pressed Cuny, the CUNY chairman, James P. Murphy, called it an "exciting project." And Herman Badillo, a CUNY trustee and member of the board's academic affairs committee, said, "It seems to me it enhances the image of John Jay." Mr. Badillo, a native of Puerto Rico, visited the campus there in February at the invitation of John Jay's president, Gerald W. Lynch.
But some faculty members and administrators said the program had come about so quietly that they had been left out of the planning.
The idea began early last year, when officials in Puerto Rico called Howard Simmons, executive director of the Commission on Higher Education of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools, to ask if he knew of a college that would help Puerto Rico set up a degree program for its police academy. Middle States is an accrediting agency that reviews college programs in five states as well as Puerto Rico.
"We get calls all the time from people asking 'Can you give us the name of a place that would be helpful to us?' so I said John Jay," Dr. Simmons said. John Jay provides academic programs for members of the Police Department and specializes in other law-enforcement programs.
Kenneth Moran, chairman of John Jay's law department, police science and criminal justice, said he was told about the idea early last year.
 
'People Were Stunned'
 "The superintendent of the Puerto Rican police came to the college a whole year earlier and asked us to give them technical help," he said. "It started and stopped, started and stopped. First it was maybe we'll help them with training. Then it was, why not try to upgrade their program, and then it was decided to offer an associate degree."
Dr. Moran said the plan was to begin the program in September 1994. But then in December, he said, "We got a little surprise." That was when he learned that the police academy in Puerto Rico wanted to move up the start of the program to this winter.
While a few faculty members had known about the program since its inception, the majority did not learn about it until a meeting on Dec. 22, after Dr. Lynch had signed an agreement to proceed with the program. "People were stunned," said Dorothy Bracey, an anthropology professor, who like other faculty members learned the details of the plan at a meeting on Dec. 22. "That's the best way to describe how we all felt."
There were questions about the cost of the program, about the problem of language since most faculty members do not speak Spanish and textbooks are in English, and about how applicable many of their classes would be since they are based on the legal and penal system here, and not that of Puerto Rico.
They were concerned that the classes would begin so soon, and that an associate degree would be granted after six months, which was the original plan until it was extended, when it usually takes students here two years to earn such a degree.
Dr. Lynch, the John Jay president, told them that the college would make money from the program as it would be taught by lower-paid adjuncts, with the students' tuition underwritten by Pell Grants, a Federal program for economically disadvantaged students. The other issues, he said, would be worked out.
After discussions with administrators at the central office, the program was postponed to April 19, and was extended to nine months. But it was also decided that most of the faculty members would be full professors.
With the higher cost of professors' salaries, Dr. Lynch said, the program will "break even." According to the trustees' resolution, John Jay is ultimately responsible for the cost of the program.
Four faculty members will fly back and forth through the end of this semester, at CUNY expense, to teach classes at both locations, costs that are not included in the budget submitted to the board of trustees. Seven others are either adjuncts with no classes this semester or are retired professors. Officials are still seeking two more professors for the program.
Translators will be used, or adjuncts from Puerto Rico will be used to teach the courses in Spanish, while John Jay's professors will oversee them.
"The officials and people of Puerto Rico are to be highly commended for wanting to have a college-educated police force," said Karen Kaplowitz, president of the John Jay faculty senate. "Our job now is to insure that the branch campus will be academically sound and at the same time insure that we continue to fulfill our responsibilities to John Jay's 9,300 students here in New York."
Dr. Lynch said that the critics are in the minority, and that most people at John Jay can see the noble reasons behind helping the Puerto Ricans to improve their police force.
"The reality is that Puerto Rico is almost an air bridge to New York," he said. "We have an affinity and an interest in helping them, and we were asked to help. We saw it as very compatible with our mission of combining training and education."

HEADLINE: Guarding the Image in Newark;
City Bars Local Filming of a Movie About Teen-Age Car Bandits

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 16

 BODY:
After decades of trying to claw its way out of the ranks of urban has-beens, Newark can be a bit prickly about its image. The local boosters often complain that no matter how much they rebuild their venerable but often pitied city, they cannot wipe away the stains left by a history of poverty, bad schools and rampant car theft.
So when a young director named Nick Gomez recently sought permission to shoot a movie about Newark in the city itself, municipal officialdom winced. Backed by the film maker Spike Lee, Mr. Gomez had written a screenplay, "New Jersey Drive," about the reckless teen-age car bandits who have given the city gobs of unflattering publicity in recent years. 
 "My reaction was, 'Over my dead body will they film this in Newark,' " said Pamela E. Goldstein, who as chief spokeswoman for Mayor Sharpe James reviews applications for making movies in the city. Ever eager to bury the memories of the years when Newark was proclaimed the nation's car-theft capital, Ms. Goldstein politely told Mr. Gomez to take his $4 million budget elsewhere.
Newark's rejection of the project -- despite the money it might have pumped into the limping local economy -- perhaps reflects a growing tendency among civic leaders across the country to restrict filming of movies that they feel malign their localities or institutions.
Earlier this year, the New York City Transit Authority banned the shooting of subway scenes that it considered too violent, though it later backed off after being criticized by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
And in 1990, New Jersey's Chief Justice, Robert N. Wilentz, refused to let the producers of "The Bonfire of the Vanities" film at the Essex County Courthouse in Newark because, he said, the scenes might erode the confidence of black people in the judicial system. The film makers had already met with criticism in the Bronx, where much of "Bonfire" is set.
But the icy reception of Mr. Gomez's proposal is also a fair indication that for this city of 275,000 on the Passaic River, the wounds inflicted by the sharp rise in car thefts in the late 1980's and early 1990's still sting. News accounts of the crimes painted Newark as a kind of urban badlands even as billions of dollars were being spent to revitalize its business district and to make improvements to neighborhoods that never really rebounded from the riots of the 1960's.
"Through a very sophisticated public relations campaign mounted by elected and major corporate figures, Newark had pretty much recast itself as a city on the move and a city that was solving many of its most nagging problems," said Clement Alexander Price, a professor at Rutgers University's Newark campus who specializes in local history. "The car thefts tarnished this highly buffed image of a city rising from the ashes."
Disappointed but not exactly surprised, Mr. Gomez went hunting for a city double that had some of the same feel as Newark: wide avenues lined with towering housing projects, weather-beaten specimens of Gothic architecture harking back to turn-of-the-century glory, gentle hills and a sense of inner-city isolation mingling with the nearness of suburbia. He landed in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn and Glendale, Queens.
A relatively inexpensive film by Hollywood standards, "New Jersey Drive" tells the story of two teen-agers, Jason and Midget, who have drifted into a subculture in Newark's poor neighborhoods that thrives on stealing cars and racing them on roadways and even sidewalks. The youths, some still in junior high school, taunt the police while executing breathtakingly dangerous maneuvers to impress their friends.
Mr. Gomez, 30, visited housing projects in Newark a number of times to talk with some of the youthful thieves and to find teen-agers to cast in the movie, which features little-known actors. In an interview on location the other day, he recalled that the people he met reminded him of his years growing up in working-class Boston, when he sometimes stole cars.
 
'Sense of Control'
 "It's all about cruising around and getting cars and trying to pick up girls and having a certain amount of freedom and mobility," said Mr. Gomez, whose first major film was the critically acclaimed independent film "Laws of Gravity," about two small-time hoods in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. "But we weren't as isolated, disenfranchised and poverty-stricken as the people in Newark are."
"It's a real sense of control, power and luxury," Mr. Gomez said. "It's a sense of identity. It's pretty much an all-American rite of passage, if you think about certain socioeconomic groups."
In the movie, the Newark police become so frustrated by their inability to stop the teen-agers that their tactics turn brutal. The portrayal of the police seems influenced by the case of Howard Caesar, the Newark teen-ager who was shot and seriously wounded in a confrontation with officers in 1992 after parking a stolen car. One officer was convicted of aggravated assault in the episode.
In an odd twist, Mr. Caesar, now 19, was arrested last month on charges that he and four others took part in a wild crime spree that included a carjacking, shootings, robberies and the ramming of a police car. Mr. Caesar's lawyer contends that the police framed him because of the 1992 incident.
The depiction of the Newark police was one aspect of the screenplay that angered Ms. Goldstein and other Newark officials. She criticized Mr. Gomez for demonizing the officers and presenting the teen-agers as heroes.
"It is glamorizing something that shouldn't be glamorized," she said, noting that the city had rarely turned down film or television projects in the past. She also pointed out that the script makes no reference to the sharp decline in car thefts in Newark in recent years, from 15,698 in 1989 to 11,875 in 1993, according to police statistics.
 
Heated Rivalry
 The streetwise Mr. Gomez, who has a closely trimmed goatee and shaved head, was unapologetic. "The film embraces the kids' attitudes more so that it does the cops'," he said. "It's their story, be they right or be they wrong."
At the height of the Newark car-theft epidemic, there were without a doubt enormous tensions between the police and the teen-agers, which lent an image of lawlessness to a city trying to lure back the middle class. The rivalry became so heated that officers had to be restrained because they were engaging in chases that endangered bystanders. They were permitted to speed after stolen cars only if the thieves were suspected of more-serious crimes.
"We had young policemen, and we had young people stealing cars," Donald Tucker, a member of the Newark City Council, said. "The kids wanted the policemen to chase them. They would get into a macho-macho thing. It was like 'The French Connection.' "
Though Mr. Tucker said he had not read the screenplay for "New Jersey Drive," he said he understood Ms. Goldstein's reaction. But he also maintained that some officials were so fixated on Newark's reputation that they were distracted from governing.
"I don't think it did any damage to the psyche of the city," Mr. Tucker said. "They took a phenomenon that existed within Newark and other municipalities and attempted to describe Newark as the phenomenon."
Neither of the male leads in "New Jersey Drive" is from Newark, though a few of the other actors are. Sharron Corley, 20, who plays Jason, grew up in Brownsville, Brooklyn, and Gabriel Casseus, 19, who plays Midget, is from Harlem -- neighborhoods where car theft is less common than in Newark.
But both said they understood why their characters stole cars.
 
Fake License Plates
 "Among your peers, it gives you what we call 'props' -- respect," said Mr. Casseus, who has acted in theater but is starring in his first film. "When you steal the car, you are looked upon as someone higher up. It's our way of validating ourselves. It's a way of gaining status."
Mr. Gomez originally wanted to set the film in Boston or Washington Heights in Manhattan. But after reading articles about teen-agers in Newark written by Michel Marriott, a reporter for The New York Times, Mr. Gomez changed his mind.
Mr. Marriott later wrote the story for "New Jersey Drive" together with Mr. Gomez. Spike Lee is the executive producer of the film, which is being made for Gramercy Pictures and is to be released later this year.
Though he has had to re-create Newark in Williamsburg and Glendale, forcing his producers to come up with a garage full of fake New Jersey license plates and Newark police cars, Mr. Gomez said he did not resent being snubbed. And he noted that even if he had received permission, he still might have shot some scenes in Brooklyn because it was closer to his film studio and home in Manhattan.
"They are thinking of their own civic identity, which is completely logical to me," he said. "But it's too bad. Newark is a beautiful city. It has a lot of stuff that's good for movies. You point a camera in a certain way and there's going to be something about it that's interesting."

HEADLINE: Punishing China Will Hurt the Chinese

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Chinese dissidents and their supporters in the United States want to extricate themselves from the dilemma of trying to force China to improve its human rights conditions by threatening to revoke China's trade privileges while hurting the Chinese people by inflicting damage to the Chinese economy and giving an excuse to hardliners to crack down even harder on dissent. 
 Now, in "How to Boost China's Free Market -- and Punish the State" (Op-Ed, April 7), Fang Lizhi and Zhao Haiching advocate selective sanctions, punishing only the state sector.
But the fallacy is obvious.
You cannot compartmentalize the economy. The problem is not just trying to determine what is and what is not state enterprise, which is difficult enough. It is that the people who work for state enterprises are also ordinary Chinese and consumers. And there are 1,001 links between the state and the private sector. You punish the state, and you punish the national economy as a whole.
It may be true that "virtually all of the recognized leaders of the China democracy movement active in the U.S." (that is, Mr. Fang and Mr. Zhao) agree on selective sanctions. But many other democracy campaigners disagree.
Those other democracy campaigners are for delinking trade and human rights. Not because human rights are unimportant, but because they can best be served by means other than trade, such as diplomacy and public opinion.
Many Chinese intellectuals, while dissatisfied with human rights conditions in China, are critical of some dissidents living in this country who depend on foreign governments for their political activities and their livelihood. And that is why they have little influence on developments in China, and their own future is very much in doubt.
 
SUCHU ZHANG
Flushing, Queens, April 7, 1994

HEADLINE: Autopsy Data Inconclusive In Baby Death

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
An autopsy on the baby of a Canadian couple who concocted a kidnapping hoax in New York City last weekend to conceal her death and the abandonment of her body in a Quebec woods found no signs of violence, abuse or malnutrition, but further tests will be needed to pinpoint the cause of death, Canadian officials said yesterday.
The 10-week-old baby, Muguet Bales-Lemay, was found Sunday near Eastman, 20 miles north of the Vermont line, with the aid of a map drawn by her parents, Joseph Bales, 33, and Helene Lemay, 31. The couple said they had concealed what they called her crib death on April 8 and had hidden her body because they had been accused of abusing a foster child last year and feared serious new charges. 
 While the parents were still being questioned by Canadian police officers in New York yesterday, the autopsy, performed by the Quebec coroner's office in Montreal, found nothing to contradict their account and no signs of deprivation or injury, a spokesman, Francois Houle, said in a telephone interview.
 
Body Preserved by Cold Weather
 "The medical causes of the death remain inexplicable for the moment," Mr. Houle said. He said definitive results might take weeks, after toxicological, histological and other tests. He said the child's body, in the woods for more than a week before being found, had been preserved by cold weather.
The parents, whose kidnapping claim on Saturday had unraveled within hours, were being questioned by two Quebec detectives at the 20th Precinct station house on West 82d Street last night. But it was unclear if they would face any criminal charges in the case, or even if they would be returned to Canada in custody.
New York officials said they intended to drop a charge of filing a false report. Tom McConnell, a Quebec police spokesman, said the Quebec Crown Attorney would decide today whether to file any charges. The couple could be charged with illegally disposing of a body, a felony punishable by up to five years in prison, or face other charges arising from the autopsy, he said.
Mr. Bales and Ms. Lemay, who had lived in St. Romain, Quebec, for three years but moved to Cornwall, Ontario, on the day after Muguet's death, drove to New York last Friday with their 4-year-old daughter, Priscille, and checked into a hotel on East 31st Street. They carried a doll to convince Priscille that the baby was with them.
On Saturday afternoon, they told the police Muguet had vanished 18 hours earlier from a Central Park bench while her father napped beside her. The report touched off a huge search as scuba drivers scoured the Lake, helicopters flew over the park and 100 officers covered the grounds.
But detectives -- whose suspicions had been aroused by the 18-hour reporting gap, which the couple could not satisfactorily explain -- soon discovered that the parents had crossed the American border and checked into a New York hotel with only an older child, and that they had been accused of child abuse last year.
The French-speaking couple at first tried to hide behind the language barrier, but when confronted with contradictions and misrepresentations they admitted the hoax early Sunday, saying they had tried to pass it off in New York because they thought it might be lost in the myriad woes of the city.
They also gave a dramatic new account, saying Muguet had died in her crib 10 days earlier of unknown causes and that because they feared serious charges, they did not report her death but abandoned her body in the woods near Eastman. They drew a crude map that was sent by fax to Quebec and led the police to the body. Priscille was returned to Canada yesterday in the custody of child welfare officials.
The police, quoting Canadian child welfare authorities, said that the couple had taken a severely retarded foster son about 3 or 4 years old into their home more than a year ago, but that the child had been removed after he was found to be malnourished and to show signs of abuse, including fractures.
In St. Romain, a village of fewer than 1,000 people 35 miles north of the New Hampshire line, the two-story home where the couple had lived stood empty yesterday, a desolate cinder-block structure with a sagging porch set on a barren, muddy field.
Neighbors recalled the couple as unusual -- Seventh-day Adventists in a Roman Catholic community, strict vegetarians who refused to eat any animal products, who did odd jobs, avoided visitors, did not allow toys and planned to educate their children at home.
Mr. Bales was said to be an unemployed handyman who had an unbending belief in certain dietary and religious principles, while Ms. Lemay was said to have several university degrees in psychology and to give correspondence courses in diet and other subjects to earn a living.
One neighbor, Annette Bretton, said she had invited the family to dinner not long ago and found Priscille so well behaved it seemed unsettling. She gave the girl a balloon, but was told by Mr. Bales that she did not have or play with toys and quoted him as saying, "Life is too serious -- she shouldn't get used to playing."
Mrs. Bretton said she went to visit the couple recently, but had not been allowed in the house. Mr. Bales went in and brought Ms. Lemay out to talk on the porch, she said. "It was very mysterious," she said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Corporate Communicating;
The Fax Flood Shows Little Sign of Receding

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Like kudzu, paper spews out endlessly from the office fax machine, crucial reports and rubbish alike. Missed two pages of a 40-page document? No problem -- The whole thing will be resent.
If the facsimile flood at your office seems out of control, it probably is -- as it is at most major American companies, according to a survey by the Gallup Organization. 
 A Gallup poll that will be released today found that fax transmissions account for 36 percent of telephone bills at Fortune 500 companies. And in this age of corporate penny pinching, the facsimile operation is apparently a notable exception. Of 400 telecommunications managers polled earlier this year, 62 percent said they had no policies to try to curb fax costs.
"Companies just plop down fax machines in every department, and nobody thinks about them," said Peter Davidson, a consultant on fax services in Burbank, Calif.
The results of the Gallup poll, sponsored by the facsimile systems business of Pitney Bowes Inc., also underline how little headway electronic mail has made in becoming a routine means of corporate communications.
The cost of sending a one-page E-mail message from New York to California over a commercial on-line service linked to the Internet, the worldwide cluster of computer networks, is less than 2 cents, according to Advanced Network and Services, a builder of computer networks. By contrast, a letter costs 29 cents and a fax can cost even more, the company said.
Facsimile companies question claims that E-mail has a big cost advantage, especially when companies use fax machines equipped with high-speed modems, or send faxes after 5 P.M., when phone rates decline.
But the real appeal of fax machines is that they are easy to use and are an entrenched part of the daily office regimen in a way that E-mail is not.
What the Gallup survey apparently did not explore was the cultural reasons why people are fond of faxes as a means of communication.
"Send me a fax on that," is an efficient, time-saving way to get rid of someone without being overtly rude. It is the American corporate equivalent of the British dismissal, "Let's have lunch someday."

HEADLINE: A Tunnel Waiting Two Decades for a Train;
Shafts for the Second Avenue Subway Are Maintained, in Case the Line Is Ever Built

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
The lights, strung on makeshift wires between steel girders, dimly illuminate a long shaft that seems to stretch far into the distance. As Mike Hardiman, a Transit Authority supervisor, strolls with a flashlight on the subway tunnel's floor, there is a deep rumble.
The impulse is to flee before a train comes roaring out of the darkness. But it is only an illusion. In the two decades since the section of tunnel was dug beneath Second Avenue in East Harlem, no train has disturbed the stillness. The rumble comes from a truck on the street three stories above.
 
Ambition and Failure
 The fate of the Second Avenue subway has long been part of the lore of New York City, becoming a metaphor for expansive governmental ambition followed by equally large-scale failure. The line has already died not once, but twice. 
 Yet it remains on a kind of infrastructure life support -- inspected and maintained twice monthly -- in case planners find the money some day to finish building the line. The Transit Authority spends about $20,000 a year to keep the tunnel dry and safe from vandals, both to protect its investment and, not incidentally, to keep the street above from collapsing.
The Second Avenue subway died for the first time a generation ago, when work on the first three sections of the subway tunnel, a total of about a mile of the planned 14-mile route, was halted in 1975 because of the city's fiscal crisis.
The second passing, again caused by fiscal troubles, largely escaped public notice when it occurred last year. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had tried to revive the Second Avenue line three years ago by proposing to spend $22 million to design and plan its completion. The proposal was a small but significant part of a package Mr. Cuomo offered to stimulate the city's economy by building $7 billion worth of projects.
 
Money Cut From Budget
 Although planning for some of those proposals is moving forward,the Second Avenue subway is not. Because of city budget cuts, the $22 million was removed from the Transit Authority's five-year construction plan last year.
But the short-term fiscal duress has not entirely diminished transit planners' long-range hopes for a new subway on Manhattan's East Side -- one that would alleviate rush-hour overcrowding on the Lexington Avenue subway, one of the two most congested lines in the city. And while the Second Avenue subway has been more or less forgotten by the average New Yorker, dismissed as an expensive notion from another age, it remains a potentially valuable asset to the people who run the city's subway system and who are responsible for protecting the unfinished line from the elements, both natural and human, that could reduce its potential value.
Every two weeks, teams of transit inspectors still walk the three sections of tunnel: under Second Avenue from 110th Street to 120th Street and from 99th Street to 105th Street, and a small, 700-foot section under the Bowery in Chinatown, just south of the Manhattan Bridge.
 
The Enemy Is Rust
 The inspectors make sure that the electrical circuits and the water pumps are working, fighting off the water and rust that could undermine the tunnels' structural soundness. They also check the locks and alarms that help keep out the vandals, drug addicts and homeless who occasionally make the tunnels their home.
In Chinatown, homeless people used to camp in the tunnel occasionally, transit officials said, until the locks and other security devices were upgraded. At the south end of the tunnel, an empty canister of Pringle's potato chips, an old plastic soda bottle and a few scattered pages of The Daily News from 1986 are evidence of a previous resident.
Under Second Avenue in East Harlem, used needles attest to the occasional drug abuser seeking privacy. Once, vandals removed all the copper wires from the tunnel, disabling the electrical lines and the water pumps, said Mr. Hardiman, a general superintendent at the Transit Authority in charge of subway's electrical systems.
 
Signs of Water Damage
 The tunnels' gravest enemy is natural, not human. Floods and routine water seepage can rust out the steel girders and undermine the reinforced concrete. On a recent walk through the section that runs from 99th to 105th Street, Mr. Hardiman found piles of flaking rust-colored steel at the bottom of many girders and other signs of water damage.
The agency recently paid a contractor $2 million to shore up the northernmost section, which had suffered considerable water damage over the years.
Despite the wear and tear, many sections of the tunnel appear to have held up quite well. Made of reinforced concrete and steel, the sections were basically completed before construction was halted. No tracks or signals were installed, but the basic shell of the tunnel looks finished. The shafts for each of the two tracks, which are about 20 feet high, are complete, including concrete catwalks with red metal handrails about five feet up on the tunnels' side.
 
'Supporting Second Avenue'
 The Transit Authority continues to pay attention to these most infamous holes in New York City for two reasons. The streets would collapse if the tunnels' girders and concrete were allowed to deteriorate. "You have the integrity of the street above us to worry about," Mr. Hardiman said. "We're supporting Second Avenue."
There is also a more long-range goal in spending the $20,000 a year to maintain the three sections of tunnel: it nurtures the hope that some day the line will be completed.
The Transit Authority's current five-year plan includes $1 million for a consultant's study on reducing overcrowding on Lexington Avenue trains. But for many transit planners, the most compelling solution to that congestion is still a Second Avenue subway, just as it was when the line was designed in the late 1960's.
It cost about $65 million to dig the tunnels 20 years ago. It would undoubtedly cost many times that to rebuild the three sections should they deteriorate. There are no estimates on the cost of completing the line, although it would surely run several billion dollars.
Some planners believe that completion of the Second Avenue subway is likely, though perhaps only in the distant future. The Transit Authority is busy now trying to ease congestion on the line generally judged the most crowded in New York -- the E and F in Queens -- by linking the lines with the underused Q train in Astoria.
Once that connection is completed, several planners said, the Transit Authority is likely to turn its attention in its next five-year plan to solving overcrowding on the Lexington line.
The existence of the Second Avenue sections may weigh heavily in any decision on what to do about overcrowding on the Lexington line. Jerome Forman, a senior vice president of the Transit Authority who is in charge of the capital program, said one option might be to complete the Second Avenue line from 125th Street to 63d Street, where it could connect through an unused tunnel under Central Park with the N and R lines on Seventh Avenue. "If we had the money, we would probably do that," Mr. Forman said.
"That would be two or three times cheaper than going all the way downtown," he said. The Second Avenue subway was originally to go south to the Battery.
But whether there will be enough money in the Transit Authority's next five-year plan, which is to begin in three years, is uncertain. Will the city and state make the investment? Or will they instead focus on renovating existing subway lines?
"If the price of building Second Avenue was that the rest of the system were to decline, then it probably wouldn't happen," Mr. Forman said.
Still, the prospect of finishing the line clearly appeals to many transit officials. "I don't think anybody's had a better solution for the Lexington," Mr. Forman said. "The East Side is very densely populated, it only has the 4 and 5 trains and they come down from the Bronx already crowded."

HEADLINE: Zuckerman Postpones Closing Deal for Coliseum

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Faced with a deadline yesterday for closing the deal for his purchase of the New York Coliseum, Mortimer B. Zuckerman exercised his right to another delay, this time at the request of city officials.
"The city has asked us to invoke our right to a 55-day adjournment and we did," Mr. Zuckerman said through a spokesman, Morri Berman. 
 The delay followed several days of pressure by the Giuliani administration on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the Coliseum property, to renegotiate the contract it has with Mr. Zuckerman on terms that would insure that the developer would go forward with his planned retail and office project.
As part of that effort, the administration again pressed the M.T.A. yesterday to agree to an appraisal of the property at the southwest corner of Central Park at 59th Street.
"We now are making a third request that they make an appraisal or that they join us in having an independent appraisal made," said John Dyson, Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development.
On Friday, in an effort to quiet criticism of his efforts to broker a settlement, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called for a delay in closing the deal and an appraisal of the property.
On Saturday, the M.T.A.'s chairman, Peter E. Stangl agreed to a brief delay but did not endorse the appraisal plan. Because Mr. Zuckerman invoked his right to postpone the closing, the Mayor's request for a delay became moot. M.T.A. officials argued against an independent appraisal, saying it would be difficult to get an accurate value in a rising real-estate market for a site for which there are few comparable properties.
Under the contract Mr. Zuckerman is to build a 2.1-million-square-foot complex that would include retail, residential and office space. But he has argued that because of nearly nine years of delays the site is no longer worth the contract price, $338 million.

HEADLINE: U.S. Creators Said to Abet Soviet A-Bomb

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
A new book by a high Soviet intelligence official asserts that the chief Western architects of the nuclear era acted as spies to give Moscow the secrets of the atom bomb.
The accused scientists -- Niels Bohr, Enrico Fermi, George Gamow, J. Robert Oppenheimer and Leo Szilard -- were lions of science who in the 1930's and early 1940's unlocked the atom and went on to create the world's first nuclear bomb in 1945. 
 Several historians said yesterday that some aspects of the book, including details of the secret workings of Stalinist Russia, were of historical significance. But they questioned its allegation of atomic spying by leading Western scientists as dubious at best and mistaken on some important points.
The book, "Special Tasks: The Memoirs of an Unwanted Witness -- a Soviet Spymaster," was published yesterday by Little, Brown & Company and is excerpted in the current issue of Time magazine. It was written by Pavel Sudoplatov, an intelligence chief during the Stalin era. He was aided in its writing by his son, Anatoly Sudoplatov, an economist at Moscow State University, and by Jerrold L. Schecter, a former Time Moscow bureau chief, and his wife, Leona P. Schecter.
 
Charges Against Oppenheimer
 The book charges that Oppenheimer, the scientific head of the Los Alamos laboratory in New Mexico, where the bomb was invented, knowingly shared American atomic secrets with Moscow and helped plant a number of Soviet moles deep in his top-secret organization, enabling Russia to quickly break the American monopoly on nuclear arms. Russia exploded its first bomb in 1949, four years after the United States.
The charges against the Western scientists are based on the recollections of Mr. Sudoplatov, a deputy director of foreign intelligence from 1939 until 1942 and from 1944 to 1946 a head of atomic intelligence in the Soviet Union. In these and other jobs, he said, he set up a network of spies and informants who deeply penetrated the American atomic program.
The book does not contain any documents that back up the central charge against the scientists, although it does have documents bearing on other aspects of atomic espionage.
In a forward to the book, Robert Conquest, a respected British historian, calls it "the most sensational, the most devastating, and in many ways the most informative autobiography ever to emerge from the Stalinist milieu."
Priscilla Johnson McMillan, a fellow at Harvard University's Russian Research Center who is writing a book on Oppenheimer's nuclear work, agreed that the overall work was important but questioned its revelations about atomic spying.
"The book as a whole needs to be taken seriously," she said in an interview. "It sheds a lot of light on some of the secret operations of the Stalinist era. But this nuclear chapter appears to be based on gossip and hearsay. Its weakness is an absolute lack of documentary evidence coupled with errors of fact."
An example of an error, she said, was the book's treatment of Klaus Fuchs, a German scientist who went to Los Alamos from Britain and after the war confessed to being a Soviet spy. The book charges that Oppenheimer took special steps to insure that Fuchs got into Los Alamos. But Dr. McMillan said it was well known that the British team went to Los Alamos "as a package."
 
Never Worked at Los Alamos
 Szilard, a Hungarian, was the chief physicist for the Manhattan Project, as the nation's overall atom-bomb project was known. But he never actually worked at Los Alamos, contrary to the new book.
"He never went there during the war," said William Lanouette, author of "Genius in the Shadows," a recent biography of Szilard. The new book also says Szilard, together with Oppenheimer and Fermi, helped Russian agents place moles at Los Alamos, at the Oak Ridge laboratory in Tennessee and at the University of Chicago, where the world's first reactor was built as a stepping-stone to the bomb.
But Mr. Lanouette said Szilard's heavy accent and impertinent manner with military authorities had raised their suspicions and prompted them to have him closely watched by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as well as Army intelligence. He was trailed day and night.
"Any unusual activity would have come to light," Mr. Lanouette said.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;
GORAZDE POUNDED BY SERB GUNNERS

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzego vina, April 18

 BODY:
Serbian nationalist artillery opened fire on the refugee-packed eastern Bosnian town of Gorazde again today as the top United Nations general here warned of a humanitarian catastrophe.
Today's attack marked the third day running that the Serbs have promised a cease-fire, only to break it with early-morning shelling, United Nations officials here said. 
 "The assurances given that there would be no further attacks on Gorazde are at this very moment being ignored," Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Rose, the United Nations commander in Bosnia, said at a news conference here this morning. "There are shells falling at this moment in Gorazde."
This afternoon the Serbs gave another cease-fire pledge, but aid workers in Gorazde reported heavy shelling of the town at 6 P.M.
The three-week Serbian offensive against Gorazde has gutted the credibility of the United Nations operation in Bosnia as well as the peace efforts of the United States and Russia, diplomats and United Nations officials here said.
[President Clinton's national security advisers will recommend the broader use of air power to force the Serbs back to the bargaining table, Administration officials said. The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, threw his weight behind that approach by asking NATO to give him the authority to request air strikes to protect all six United Nations-designated "safe areas" in Bosnia. Page A10.]
The United Nations Security Council declared Gorazde a "safe area" last year after a similar Serbian offensive against the nearby Muslim enclave of Srebrenica.
The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, warned two weeks ago that the Gorazde "safe area," and the 65,000 people trapped in it, might be protected by air strikes if the Serbs did not withdraw to the positions they held on March 30, the day the offensive began.
NATO jet fighters carried out two limited air strikes last week, but they were under a Security Council resolution calling for protection of United Nations personnel, not the "safe area" itself, and did little more than delay for three days the Serbian onslaught that finally brought Gorazde to its knees.
General Rose asserted that "in no way is our contribution terminated" in Gorazde. But early this morning a British pilot shot down over the pocket on Saturday afternoon and 7 of the 12 United Nations military observers in the pocket were evacuated by helicopter.
A United Nations official here said Gorazde's Mayor, Ismet Briga, wept when he heard the observers had left by night.
The observers, British special forces troops, were sent into the Gorazde pocket to provide accurate information on the military situation and act as target spotters for NATO jets, United Nations officials said.
"Their equipment is obviously powered by batteries," the General said. "Those batteries have run out, and it was pointless leaving them there."
 
Relentless Shelling
 But United Nations military officers said the evacuation was prompted by fears for the safety of the men if they were captured by the Serbs. Five United Nations military observers and a handful of aid workers remain in Gorazde.
Reports by United Nations relief workers said Serbian shells were striking Gorazde at a rate of one every 20 seconds this morning, but that rate dropped to one every two minutes by this afternoon. Fierce clashes between Bosnian Army and Serbian forces were being waged on the edge of the town, a United Nations military official said.
"After a break between 10 and 10:30, shelling of the city center started again, with hits reported on the police station, courthouse, 'Panorama' refugee center," said a report filed this afternoon by a United Nations refugee-relief worker in the town. "These are all located 50 to 100 meters from the hospital."
A Western diplomat who asked not to be identified said today that the Bosnians were using the hospital for a military purpose. The diplomat did not elaborate.
"We are on the brink of a humanitarian disaster there," General Rose said.
 
302 Killed, 1,075 Wounded
 According to an incomplete tally, the Serbian offensive has killed 302 people and wounded 1,075, the United Nations report said. More than 30,000 people, almost half of the population of the Gorazde pocket, have been rendered homeless, some for the second and third time in the war.
The Serbs launched the offensive against Gorazde as part of a campaign to uproot the entire Muslim population from the Drina River valley, which forms the border between Bosnia and Serbia and had a Muslim majority before the war.
Serbian "ethnic cleansing" campaigns cleared almost all of the Muslims from the towns of Zvornik and Bijeljina early in the war, which began in April 1992.
A year ago the Serbs struck against Srebrenica and Zepa, herding tens of thousands of Muslims into tiny pockets of land. After these attacks Srebrenica, Zepa and Gorazde were declared "safe areas" by the United Nations Security Council.
 
Full Assault Unlikely
 Military analysts here said the Serbs are not likely to carry out a full assault on the town of Gorazde itself, fearing it would lead to a bloodbath that could prompt armed international intervention.
Rather, they say, the Serbs will maintain their chokehold on the Gorazde pocket, as they have around Srebrenica and Zepa, in an effort to render the area so economically unviable that the Muslims choose to leave of their own accord.
A Western diplomat here said the Serbs' attack on Gorazde has scuttled a United States peace initiative in Bosnia.
"It is very difficult to conceive of a peace process now," the diplomat said. "The actions of the Serbs over the last week have been directed toward making war. I don't see how you can talk peace."
"The last week has seen a series of offer after offer from the United Nations and the Russians," the diplomat said. "Day by day, promise after promise was broken."
"We have to take whatever steps we can to shore up the United Nations position," the diplomat said, referring to the efforts of the United Nations to secure a 10-week cease-fire around Sarajevo, to safeguard the other United Nations "safe areas" in Bosnia and to restructure the mandate of the United Nations military force here.
 
U.N. Aides Humiliated
 "There are a lot of people in Gorazde, and we need to take care of them first," he said, alluding to the possibility that the Serbs would effectively use the people trapped in Gorazde as hostages to bind the hands of the international community if it made a decision to take more energetic action against the Serbs. "We have to be very careful on that score."
The diplomats said Serbian leaders had humiliated members of the entourage of Yasushi Akashi, the top-ranking United Nations diplomat in the region, who at least twice this week blocked calls by General Rose for air strikes against the Serbs and continued to negotiate with Serbian leaders despite being personally double-crossed at least once.
Mr. Akashi left Sarajevo today for Zagreb, the headquarters of the United Nations military force in the former Yugoslavia.
The United States' special envoy, Charles Redman, also flew out of Sarajevo this afternoon for Zagreb and eventually Washington. "

HEADLINE: FED AGAIN RAISES SHORT-TERM RATE ON LOANS, TO 3.75%

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates today for the third time in two and a half months, trying once again to slow the nation's brisk economic growth before it begins to feed inflation.
The announcement prompted swift criticism from Democrats on Capitol Hill, a sharp fall in stock and bond prices and a large increase by big banks in the rates they charge for many adjustable-rate mortgages and some credit cards. 
 With the move today, the Federal Reserve raised its target for the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, to 3.75 percent from 3.5 percent.
White House officials, who had privately maintained until recently that short-term rates above 4 percent would be unacceptable, quickly retreated from that position today as it seemed increasingly likely that the Federal Reserve would breach that level soon.
President Clinton, visiting Milwaukee today, said of the Federal Reserve move, "This is still within the range of interest rates that should not do anything to harm the economy."
Top Federal Reserve officials had signaled in interviews over the last two weeks that they planned to increase short-term interest rates again even though they perceived no signs of immediate inflation.
The Federal Reserve's concern, officials say, is that low rates have encouraged banks to make too many loans, pushing the economy to grow so fast that companies and individuals will begin to bid up wages and the price of goods and services, producing inflation.
In deciding to raise rates today, the Federal Reserve seemed to have been influenced by strong growth in employment in March and extremely high car sales. The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, is a former economics consultant who worked for Detroit's auto makers and has long followed their production figures as a signal of the economy's basic health and as a leading indicator of future inflation.
Wall Street economists expect that the next time the Federal Reserve raises short-term interest rates, possibly as early as the middle of next month, it will also increase the discount rate, which is the rate it charges on its own loans to banks. The discount rate has remained unchanged at 3 percent through the last three increases in the Federal funds rate, despite growing pressures from regional Federal Reserve Banks to raise it, too. Gradual interest rate changes have been the hallmark of Mr. Greenspan's tenure.
The Federal Reserve has already increased the Federal funds rate twice this year, a quarter-percentage point at a time, on Feb. 4 and March 22. The Feb. 4 move was the first increase in five years.
Today's increase, like the earlier increases, caused sharp moves in stock and bond prices and made yet another contribution to the steady rise in long-term interest rates, especially home mortgage rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 41.05 points today, to 3,620.42, and the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds climbed to 7.41 percent from 7.28 percent Friday.
By this afternoon, big banks, led by Citibank and Chemical Bank, had reacted by raising their prime rates half a point, to 6.75 percent. Banks once charged the prime rate to their best corporate customers, but mainly use it these days to set rates for consumer debts, including some credit cards and adjustable-rate mortgages.
The big banks did not match the Federal Reserve's first rate increase in February, so their action today means that the prime rate has risen only as much as the Federal funds rate this spring, a situation that is likely to help banks maintain their unusually large current profit margins. The difference between the prime rate and the rates at which banks borrow money -- which is the banks' profit -- has been historically wide in the last couple of years because banks never cut their rates as deeply as the Federal Reserve did in 1991 and 1992.
Mr. Greenspan made today's decision to raise interest rates after a telephone conference call with other senior Federal Reserve officials, said Joseph R. Coyne, the Federal Reserve's chief spokesman. No vote was held on the move, Mr. Coyne said.
Some Federal Reserve officials have said in recent weeks that the Fed's regional presidents want to limit the chairman's discretion to act on interest rate changes between meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve panel that sets interest rates. The 12 regional presidents attend the panel's meetings and rotate casting their five votes.
John P. Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers Inc., said that the move today -- and the willingness of Federal Reserve officials to emphasize Mr. Greenspan's responsibility -- seemed calculated to show the chairman was still in charge.
Both the Federal Reserve's rate increase and the rise in the prime rate that followed caused some annoyance today at the White House, but even more alarm on Capitol Hill among Democrats who fear that efforts to slow economic growth will hurt them politically.
White House officials expressed no criticism of the Federal Reserve today, choosing instead to offer the explanation that the latest rate increase shows the economy's strength. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen had effectively given the Federal Reserve leeway to raise interest rates further when he said on Saturday that he anticipated that target for the Federal funds rate would reach 4 percent by the end of the year.
 
An Unworried Response
 Mr. Bentsen said in a speech today in Salt Lake City that while interest rates might have risen, they had not climbed enough to become a problem. "Rising interest rates are a worry if they threaten to choke off investment and employment," he said. "That's not happening, not a sign of it."
A Treasury official who insisted on anonymity said the agency had no objection to the banks' prime rate increase because it came after months of rising interest rates in financial markets.
The Administration's muted response to recent rate increases reflects both a reassessment of the economy's strength and a political calculation.
Politically, the White House has concluded that higher interest rates will not ripple through the economy fast enough to hurt the re-election prospects this year of Democratic members of Congress. Most economists estimate that higher rates take at least a year to slow economic growth.
"Everyone knows that the impact of interest rates is 9, 12, 14 months out," said Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office. He predicted that higher interest payments on the national debt would have little immediate effect on the Federal budget deficit.
 
Revising Forecasts

 
 The White House has forecast economic growth this year of 3 percent. But Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said in an interview on Friday evening, "Right now, there is firm evidence suggesting that the economy is growing faster than 3."
Ms. Tyson has long forecast that the economy will slow to an annual growth rate of 2.5 percent in the late 1990's, once factories reach their highest sustainable level of operation and unemployment falls to a stable level.
Still, today's rate increase provoked criticism on Capitol Hill. "It seems that just as the economy is coming back up for air, the Fed shoves it back down," said two Democratic Senators, Paul Sarbanes of Maryland and James Sasser of Tennessee, in a joint statement. Both are up for re-election in November.
Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat whose term does not expire until 1998, criticized the Federal Reserve and the commercial banks. "It looks like a dose of big-bank greed -- it does not seem to me to be justifiable," Mr. Dorgan said this evening. "The large banks are profiting at the expense of the American consumer."

HEADLINE: HARTFORD SEEKING A COMPANY TO RUN ITS PUBLIC SCHOOLS

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Undermined by deep fiscal problems and poor academic achievement, the Hartford public school system is seriously considering a radical step: turning over management of all its schools, troubles and all, to a private, for-profit company.
The agreement would be the boldest step yet in a burgeoning movement to privatize elements of American public education. The company, Education Alternatives, based in Minneapolis, is negotiating a contract to manage the district's 32 schools, which serve about 25,000 students. If approved, the contract would begin this fall and could last five years. The company would manage a budget of about $214 million a year and its management fee is likely to be 3 to 5 percent a year. 
 Education Alternatives, a publicly traded company founded three years ago, runs 13 individual public schools elsewhere. It has long wanted to manage an entire school system, hoping to try an array of educational strategies that it says are difficult to enact piecemeal. It has promised school officials here to spend $20 million of its own money to improve buildings and curriculums and to introduce computers and other up-to-date technology.
Officials of the nine-member school board say six members support the plan and three are opposed or undecided. The company is to present its proposal April 19 to the board, which is expected to act on it within two weeks.
"We need major surgery," said Thelma Dickerson, vice chairman of the school board and a supporter of privatization. "We've constantly put on Band-Aids. After so many, they keep erupting and you have a serious problem. We need help."
Under any plan, the company would receive the same amount currently spent by the district: about $8,450 per student, a figure that includes not only money within the district budget but also state and Federal spending for programs like special education. That per-pupil figure exceeds both the state and national averages. From that, the company would have to pay for salaries and pensions, books, maintenance and all school services. The company says it can make money from this because of economies of scale, and do so while improving academic performance.
The company manages one school in Dade County, Fla., and a dozen more in the Baltimore City Public Schools. It is talking to the San Diego Unified School District about taking over some of its most troubled schools. School officials say it is too early to tell whether academic performance has improved in either the Dade County or Baltimore schools, which were taken over less than two years ago.
As negotiations between the company and the school continue, some parents say they see hope in the promise of sweeping change in the Hartford school district, which serves many poor Hispanic and black children in an area surrounded by affluent, largely white suburbs. This disparity is at the heart of a wrenching lawsuit, filed in state court in 1988, seeking to desegregate the district.
 
Parents and Unions Worry
 But some Hispanic parents, whose children make up 50 percent of Hartford enrollment, say they are concerned about the company's limited experience in bilingual education.
And the notion of hiring a private manager has met the full fury of the district's 12 unions, which oppose the company's profit motive and question whether Education Alternatives can deliver educational improvements in a school system that critics say entered academic bankruptcy long ago.
"If I had to give my answer today whether to hire Education Alternatives, my answer would be no," said Bill Chaffin, an English teacher at Weaver High School in Hartford. "Given the choice between real student learning and profit, profit will always win. It always does."
The opposition in Hartford reflects the fear of many school officials across the country over the wholesale ceding of school management to business.
"The posture of most urban school superintendents is some limited privatization of outside services is acceptable as long as the expenditure and the account remain under the public aegis," said Michael Casserly, the executive director of the Council of Great City Schools, an association of the nation's largest school systems. "The issue is just how tall the wall to schools should be."
 
Hiring Students
 School board members have told the company that they would reject any contract that includes layoffs of any staff members. This differs from the company's arrangement in Baltimore, where it hired college students as teachers' aides, at $7 an hour, to replace $13-an-hour union members. It also hired nonunion custodians.
Administrators and teachers say they could do their jobs better if given relief from a bureaucracy so inefficient that, in one case, a book order from one teacher during the summer was not delivered until November, three months into the school year.
Supporters of Education Alternatives and school privatization say that Hartford schools, facing a $2 million budget gap this school year, a worsening student dropout problem and internal turmoil from the desegregation lawsuit, must make radical choices now, for its students' sake.
 
The System
Troubles Mount, Resources Shrink
 Every school day, Aida Morales walks her first- and third-grade daughters through the doors of the brown-brick Kinsella Community School in the city's working-class South End. Ms. Morales, 26, said she worries about budget cuts and their effects on bilingual education. But she heard Education Alternatives officials make their pitch at the school recently, with their comments translated into Spanish, and liked what she heard.
"I'm not a business person," she said. "But they are saying everything I want to hear. My main concern is my children's education."
 
A District Adrift
 Like other parents, she said she sensed that the district was adrift. The dropout rate, 13.4 percent last year and rising, is above the national average of 11.4 percent. Hartford's fourth, sixth and eighth graders score at or below minimum state goals in math, reading and writing on statewide tests, with the district ranking at or near the bottom in student achievement.
With tax revenue declining, the school system has been forced to cut its budget, with student-oriented programs typically the first to go. A dropout-prevention program was eliminated. The district bought cheaper basketballs for physical-education classes and cheaper chalk. The chalk is of such a low grade that it does not stick to the blackboard.
"We have become a system concerned that adults have jobs, that adults have the best salaries," said Ms. Dickerson, the vice chairman of the school board, which is elected by the community. "We react by eliminating programs that are good for children. To me, it's sinful."
Of the district's $171.1 million budget this school year, $148.8 million goes to salaries. To save the district $1 million in salaries alone next year, the Hartford teachers' union has agreed to concessions totaling $4 million, and 177 employees are taking early retirement. But officials have told the school system to squeeze even more from its budget.
 
The Company
Unproven Rescuer Sells a 'Slow' Fix
 It is show time for Educational Alternatives, and company officials are eager to tell Hartford parents how the company can rescue their ailing school system.
The company's president, John Golle, stood in front of the 200 parents and teachers in one recent community meeting and tried to win over a curious and skeptical audience.
"It's not a quick fix," he said. "It's a slow process."
It has been a slow process for the company. For the fiscal year ended June 30, it reported its first profit: $1.1 million, with $300,000 of that coming from Baltimore. But all along, it has faced opposition from unions, some education analysts and school administrators and some parents over its efforts to manage public schools for profit.
The American Federation of Teachers, for instance, released a report last month criticizing the company's performance in Baltimore, saying that the test results had fallen for students in the nine original schools the company agreed to manage. A report last year by the company indicated that in the final weeks of the 1992-93 school year, student test scores actually rose.
 
Company Shares Slip
 The negative publicity has hammered at the company's shares, which once traded in the $40-to-$45 range but now languish just above $10.
"We've had our heads handed to us in the marketplace," said Mr. Golle after the community meeting was over. "But we aren't going anywhere."
Mr. Golle, a 50-year-old businessman, founded his own education and training company in the 1970's and bought Education Alternatives from Control Data Corporation, the computer company, in 1986. Control Data had formed the subsidiary in the early 1980's to study a possible role for business in school reform.
He said he and other company officials -- former school superintendents or educators from around the country -- decided 1994 would be the year the company would try to win a contract for an entire district.
 
The Critics
Which Come First, Children or Profits?
 Any management contract in Hartford would be signed only over the opposition of a coalition of 12 unions representing teachers, teacher aides, principals, food-service employees, clerical workers and others.
"Our concern is that a public company does not have a vested interest in the children or their education," said Jeanne Spencer, the president of the teachers union. "The board should be making management decisions and not abrogating their responsibility."
The union two weeks ago distributed to its members a four-page letter outlining the company's history and its experiences in Dade County and Baltimore. The letter found fault with the company's hiring of college-age interns to replace better-paid and more experienced teachers' aides in Baltimore.
 
Trying New Strategies
 The company's plans for overhauling the Hartford system are widely criticized by teachers here, but even so, many new teaching methods being tried in Hartford classrooms are also in the company's educational package.
Indeed, the company's educational strategy includes many widely touted techniques being adopted in growing numbers of classrooms around the country.
Some are familiar: greater individual attention in subjects like math and science, using blocks and other objects to convey basic math concepts to young students and more complicated theories to older students.
The company trains its teachers to adapt their styles to students' needs, devises individual lesson plans for students and conducts conferences with parents. In Dade County and Baltimore, some parents say their children read more and are more enthusiastic about attending school.
Several Hartford schools already have tried educational reform programs, and the school board has told Education Alternatives that it cannot force any school to adopt its curriculum. Company officials have agreed to keep the curriculum optional, but say they expect most schools to adopt it anyway.
If Hartford hires the company, it would spend the first year largely improving schools and schoolyards, physical plants and testing students and retraining teachers. The $20 million in capital improvements would come from investors' holdings in the company.
To calm jitters among teachers and parents who fear that the company has not proved it can raise test scores, company officials have said it takes at least three years under a new curriculum before improvement is evident. "We aren't saying this is the only way," said Mr. Golle, the company's chairman. "We're saying it's just one way."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Post a Sharp Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices plunged yesterday, pushing long-term interest rates to the highest level since just before President Clinton's inauguration.
The benchmark 30-year bond fell after the Federal Reserve said it would raise short-term interest rates to moderate the economy's growth and stave off inflation pressures. 
 The falling bond price pushed the yield on the Treasury's main 30-year bond to 7.41 percent, up from 7.28 percent on Friday. It was the highest the yield finished since a week before Clinton's inauguration when it stood at 7.47 percent.
The bond's price fell 114/32 point, or $14.375 for each $1,000 in face value. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, matched the high for the year it hit on April 4. The record low yield is 5.77 percent, set Oct. 15.
The Treasury's one-year bill yield, a benchmark for many adjustable-rate mortgages, rose to 4.87 percent as the discount rose 0.16 point, to 4.65 percent.
The Fed's increase of short-term rates mean speculators and others who had bought bonds with borrowed money would have to pay more to hold the securities. That reality encouraged selling, William Sullivan, director of money-market research at Dean Witter, Discover & Company, said.
The rise in long-term interest rates also shows doubt in the market that the Fed's action will stave off future inflation.
"There's an attitude that what the Fed has done so far in 1994 is not enough to break the economy's momentum," Mr. Sullivan said. "These modest moves are perceived as insufficient medicine."
Meanwhile, many Democrats in Congress complain that the Fed has done too much to stifle inflation without any concrete signs that consumer prices are rising.
The biggest risk faced by long-term bond investors is that their annual interest payments will be eaten up by inflation.
Yesterday's move was the third rate rise by the Fed since Feb. 4. Another short-term interest rate rise is expected after the next meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-setting board, in mid-May.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, fell 9.73, to 1,221.45.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 3.77 percent as the discount rose 0.10 percentage point, to 3.69 percent. Six-month yields rose to 4.26 percent as the discount increased 0.13 point, to 4.13 percent.
Yields are the interest bonds pay by maturity, while the discount is the interest at which they are sold.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 9017/32 point, down 28/32 point. The average yield to maturity was 6.44 percent, up from 6.37 percent late Friday.
Following are the results from yesterday's Treasury auction of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Cuts and Tax Rises Urged To Bolster Social Security

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, today proposed shoring up the finances of Social Security by reducing next year's cost-of-living adjustment, increasing the retirement age, trimming benefits for new retirees and raising payroll taxes in the 21st century.
Some of the proposals, standing alone, would provoke a political outcry. But Mr. Rostenkowski said he hoped they would be acceptable as part of a comprehensive plan to preserve Social Security for future generations. 
 Some combination of changes like those proposed by Mr. Rostenkowski has a good chance of passage. Social Security trustees said last week that unless Congress acted the Social Security trust funds would run out of money in 2029, seven years earlier than projected last year. The trustees said that Congress should worry about the problem now, when the solution is relatively painless. Bigger changes would be required in later years if lawmakers defer action, the trustees warned.
In opinion polls, young workers often say that they doubt Social Security will be available to them when they retire. Mr. Rostenkowski said his proposal would restore confidence in Social Security and guarantee the Treasury's ability to pay all promised benefits for at least 75 years. He said he hoped the proposal would stimulate debate on ways to solve the long-range problems of Social Security without drastic cuts in benefits or sharp increases in taxes.
 
Limiting an Increase
 Under Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal, all Social Security beneficiaries, about 42 million people, would receive a smaller cost-of-living adjustment in January 1995. The increase was expected to be 3 percent, but Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal would limit it to 2.5 percent.
As a result, the average monthly Social Security benefit, now $674, would rise to $691 in 1995, rather than $694. In the past, protests by elderly people have blocked proposed cuts in cost-of-living adjustments.
Mr. Rostenkowski is also proposing a tax increase for Social Security beneficiaries who are single and have incomes of $25,000 to $34,000 a year or are married with incomes of $32,000 to $44,000.
Under current law, these people must count up to half of their Social Security benefits as taxable income. Under Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal, up to 85 percent of their benefits could be included as taxable income.
The change would affect 13 percent of Social Security beneficiaries, about 5.5 million people. Single people with incomes of more than $34,000 and married couples with incomes over $44,000 are already subject to this requirement.
 
Cutting Future Benefits
 Mr. Rostenkowski would gradually reduce the generosity of the Social Security benefit formula over a 50-year period beginning in the year 2003. This would trim benefits for workers with average and above-average earnings, but not for those with low earnings.
For a person born in 1990 who earns average wages over a lifetime, benefits would be cut 8 percent. For a high earner, one who pays the maximum taxes, the reduction would be 20 percent if the person was born in 1990 and retires in the middle of the next century. High-earning baby boomers, those who pay the maximum taxes and retire early in the next century would experience reductions of 2 percent to 12 percent.
Mr. Rostenkowski's bill would also increase the age at which workers may retire with full benefits. This "normal retirement age," now 65, will rise gradually under current law, reaching 67 for people born in 1960 or later. Mr. Rostenkowski would speed up the change so it would take effect 11 years earlier, for people born in 1949 or later.
The first of Mr. Rostenkowski's proposed increases in the payroll tax would take effect in 26 years, in 2020, and additional increases would follow.
Under current law, employees and their employers each pay a tax equal to 6.2 percent of a worker's wages up to a maximum level, which is $60,600 this year. The tax rate is not scheduled to go up under current law, though the Social Security trust funds are expected to run out of money in 2029, when people born in 1964 will reach the age of 65.
Mr. Rostenkowski's bill would gradually increase the Social Security tax rate by nearly one-third over a 38-year period beginning in 2020. The tax rate would stay at 6.2 percent through 2019, then climb gradually to 7.35 percent in 2024 and remain at that level for 30 years. The tax rate would rise again in 2055 and in each of the next three years, reaching 8.15 percent in 2058.
The proposal would not affect Medicare's hospital insurance trust fund, which is expected to run out of money in 2001. Many experts say the Government will soon need to increase the Medicare tax, now 1.45 percent each for employee and employer.
Mr. Rostenkowski said the effect of the higher taxes would be more than offset by the growth of wages over the next 75 years. Even after paying the increased payroll taxes and taking account of inflation, he said, workers will still have higher incomes, with greater purchasing power, than they now have.
Under his proposal, a person who earns $32,600 in 2025 would pay a Social Security tax of $2,396, which is $375 more than the person would pay under current law.
Under Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal, all state and local government workers hired after Dec. 31 would have to pay Social Security taxes and participate in the program. Of the 21.5 million people who worked for state or local government some time last year, 5 million were not covered by Social Security, Federal officials say. Such workers may face severe financial hardship when they retire or become disabled.
