HEADLINE: At Kidder, Peabody, Where Trading Went Awry

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW YORK, NY

 BODY:
If Kidder, Peabody's allegations against Joseph Jett, its former chief Government bond trader, are accurate, he appears to have taken advantage of a bad accounting system at Kidder to allow him to report profits that did not exist.
The fiasco, which Kidder's parent, the General Electric Company, said would cost it an after-tax charge of $210 million, reflects a system that apparently allowed Mr. Jett to report as "trades" what really amounted to a stated intention to make transactions in the future. 
 Kidder officials, who spoke yesterday on condition they not be named, said the "profits" he reported reflected what amounted to accrued interest that would never be received. Those profits would vanish within months or even days. But by then, they said, he would have reported more such trades, and profits.
Whether, or to what extent, the Kidder account is accurate is hard to evaluate. Mr. Jett, who has an unlisted telephone number, could not be reached yesterday. And Kidder executives, amplifying press releases from them and from General Electric on Sunday night, said they were perplexed by some aspects of the case.
 
Bond Prices Were Down
 They said that it had appeared that Mr. Jett's department had lost $90 million to $100 million in real trades, apparently in the first quarter. But they were not sure how that happened.
"We don't even know if the losses were just bad trading," said a Kidder official. "It appeared to most people that he did not have exposure to the bond market."
In the first quarter, bond prices sank as the Federal Reserve tightened credit, and such losses would be expected if the firm had a large position in bonds. But if it did not have such a position, the losses would be harder to explain. It could have come from any of a number of complicated strategies, like an incorrect bet on the relationship of, say, interest rates on 10-year Government bonds to 30-year bonds, or on the spread between rates on Treasury securities and those issued by Government agencies.
 
Kidder Officials Unsure
 That Kidder officials were unsure, even yesterday, of the nature of the real trading seemed to indicate that the management information systems were inadequate. It appears that Kidder officials focused on the net profit of the department, not on individual types of trades, so the phony trades, asserted by Kidder, managed to obscure the other losses.
In that regard, this is not a case of a trader concealing his bad trades, a practice known as "hiding the tickets" reporting losing trades.
"He hid the effects of the tickets, not the tickets themselves," a Kidder official reported.
The purported phony trades were said to be listed as "forward" trades, in which Kidder supposedly agreed to give a basket of securities, known as "strips," to the Federal Reserve, and receive back from it an equivalent Treasury bond, at a date in the future ranging from a few days to as long as three months.
When the Government sells a Treasury bond, for example the 30-year bond sold last August, paying 6.25 percent and due in August 2023, it promises that for each $1,000 bond it will pay $31.25 each February and August, and then $1,000 in August 2023. Bond dealers can sell off the individual payments to different holders, a process known as stripping.
They can also put the bond back together -- a process known as reconstituting the bond, or simplay as a "recon" -- by accumulating rights to all the remaining payments, and trading those rights to the Fed. Kidder said Mr. Jett asserted he had agreed to make such exchanges in the future.
It is hard to see why such transactions should have been recorded at all, at least not until they were actually done. Essentially such a trade is the equivalent of giving a roll of 40 quarters to a bank and getting back a $10 bill. The bank will do that trade any time you want, and the profit, if there is one, could come only from buying quarters at a discount, which is not easy to do.
 
On Reconstituting Bonds
 Similarly, the Fed lets bond dealers strip or reconstitute bonds whenever they wish. They can tell the Fed they plan to do so at a particular date, but there is no more penalty for not doing so than there would be from a bank whose customer brought in fewer quarters than expected. "This was not a real forward trade," a Kidder official said.
The "strips," as the individual payments of principal and interest are called, will normally rise in value over time, as the actual payment grows closer. So the "forward" price for such a coupon payment -- the price that you would have to agree to pay for it to get it a few days or a few months from now -- will be a bit higher than current prices.
Kidder would record that it had agreed to sell the set of strips to the Fed for the forward prices, and take a profit because that figure was higher than the current market price for the strips. At the same time, it would record that it had agreed to "buy" the reconstituted bond at its forward price for it. There would be a small, equally phony "loss" recorded on the bond part of the trade, but the net of the two was a reported profit. In fact, nothing had happened at all.
That reported profit would vanish as the actual date scheduled for the supposed trade approached, and Kidder would then, it appears, create new "profits" by putting on more such trades in the future.
 
A Profit Would Vanish
 How small was the profit? Kidder officials told of one recorded forward trade, for an $8 million principal payment, that provided a "profit" of $2,215. That profit was to vanish over six days. To get the kind of phony profits Kidder says Mr. Jett accumulated, it would be necessary to report such trades for many billions of dollars. It is not clear why Kidder failed to pick up such huge stated positions much earlier than it did.
It is sometimes possible to make small profits buying up the strip payments and reconstituting the bonds, just as it is sometimes possible to make money doing the opposite and stripping the bonds. That depends on the relative demand for bonds and for the strips, which are sold to customers who will need money at a specific time, like retirement.
Effectively, however, if Kidder's accusations are true, Mr. Jett made it appear that he had made such profits, without having done so.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Conjuring Phantom Profits: A Scenario"
Here is how Joseph Jett, who was dismissed as chief of Kidder Peabody's Government bond trading department, was said to be using quirks of the firm's accounting systems to take credit for profits that existed only on paper..
 
STRIPPED AND RECONSTITUTED BONDS
 
A Treasury bond is promised by the Treasury to make two kinds of payments: interest twice a year before the bond matures and the principal (the face value of the bond) upon maturiry.
 
When the Treasury issues the bond it is all in one piece, but the two components are often traded separately later: as a "strip" of coupons and the principal payment. The pieces can also be put back together, in a move called a recon.
 
Sometimes the bond trade for slightly more in pieces than together, or vice versa; brokers routinely strip or reconstitute bonds to make arbitrage profits out of the small price difference.
 
FORWARD TRADES AND EPHEMERAL PROFITS
 
A strip's principal payment component trades at a discount to face value that gradually shrinks in a predictable way as maturity approaches. Kidder, Peabody's accounting system allows for this when assessing the value of forward trades.
 
When a broker records a forward sale - a deal struck today to sell a strip for a set price on a date in the future - the system notes that the forward price is higher than today's spot price, and books the difference as a profit. That profit is reduced each day as the spot price rises closer to the forward price, disappearing entirely the day the deal is completed.
 
If the deal were reversed and the broker was buying rather than selling, this temporary paper profit would be a paper loss instead.
 
OFFSETS THAT DIDN'T OFFSET
 
Apparently, Kidder's accounting system used different formulas to calculate the temporary gain or loss for different kinds of transactions.
 
Mr. Jett is said to have booked forward recon transactions with the Federal Reserve that offset each other exactly, leaving his net position in the market neutral and risk-free. The "trades" with the Fed were accounting fictions, since no money changes hands. But the complexities of the Kidder accounting system had the effect of crediting him with temporary paper profits on some of the trades that were larger than the paper losses on the offsetting trades. That made it appear the Mr. Jett was making profits for the firm without running any risk.
 
The paper profits on ant one set of forward trades soon diminished to zero, but by then Mr. Jett booked yet more phantom profits on new trades.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Nationsbank Net Falls; Chase Has a Big Rise

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:
Nationsbank said yesterday that its net income for the first quarter fell 13 percent, largely because of an accounting change affecting the first quarter of 1993, while Chase Manhattan Bank said its earnings more than doubled in the first quarter, helped by a continued evaporation of its problem real estate and strong trading results.
The results were another sign that the first quarter, with rising interest rates and volatile bond markets, were not as bad for banks as many people had expected. 
 Excluding the accounting charge last year, Nationsbank's net income in the first quarter of 1993 would have been $281 million, leading to a 48 percent increase in the most recent quarter. Nationsbank, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., is the third-largest bank in the United States, providing retail banking in nine states. It said its results benefited from the purchase last year of MNC Financial Inc., a Baltimore-based banking company; Chicago Research and Trading Ltd., a firm specializing in currency and bond trading, and Corpus Christi National Bank.
 
 
Gain in Interest Income
 Interest income rose 19 percent, to $1.3 billion, while noninterest revenue, which includes the trading by Chicago Research and Trading, climbed 41 percent, to $680 million.
The impact of the acquisitions was also apparent in Nationsbank's net loans and leases, which rose 25 percent, to $91.6 billion; total assets, up 36 percent to $165.1 billion, and the bank's full-time payroll, which increased 12 percent, to 58,122 people.
Nationsbank said it had lowered its provision for bad loans to $100 million, from $120 million in the first quarter of 1993.
Shares of Nationsbank rose 12.5 cents, to $52.25.
Chase Manhattan, the nation's sixth-largest banking company, said its profit for the first quarter was $364 million, or $1.80 a share, compared with $153 million, or 74 cents a share, a year earlier. That was well beyond analysts' expectations; the consensus was that Chase would have earnings of $1.14 a share.
Chase shares closed at $34.375, up 62.5 cents, on a day when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 41 points.
 
 
Provision for Bad Loans
 Chase said its provision in the first quarter for bad loans was $160 million, less than half the $360 million it set aside a year ago.
The bank reported that noninterest revenue rose 30 percent, to $853 million, largely because fees and commissions rose 22 percent, to $446 million.
Total trading revenue, which includes foreign-exchange income and trading account income, rose 2 percent, to $179 million from $175 million. Foreign-exchange revenue dropped to $85 million from $103 million, but trading account revenue rose to $94 million from $72 million, and the bank said its income from investment securities gains rose to $79 million, from $6 million a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Pep Boys (Manny, Moe and Jack) see their stock climb.

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne 

 BODY:
THE Pep Boys -- Manny, Moe and Jack -- have a lot to be smiling about these days. These cigar-chomping characters, who look like they populate a Dick Tracy cartoon, are the advertising symbols of the Philadelphia-based auto parts retailer that's been bucking the downward push of the market. Just this month, as the market was tumbling by 30 to 50 points a day, Pep Boys shares were hitting new highs.
What's got the Pep Boys smiling? The stock has risen by nearly 9 percent since the mid-March, while the stock market in general has fallen by more than 10 percent. Yesterday, Pep Boys closed at 29 3/8, off 1/8. What's behind this rise is a company whose fundamentals are, at last, falling into place. In fact, analysts say Pep Boys' shares, even at these levels, still have upward potential. 
 "Never before have the fundamentals been so strong at Pep Boys," said William Julian, an analyst at the Mabon Securities Corporation. "The company is still a buy: There's more room for upside support and there's plenty of protection against downside risk. This is a stock that's got plenty of room to go north."
Pep Boys is a leading national chain of auto parts and servicing stores. With 371 stores in 25 states, and more opening each month, Pep Boys competes in a highly fragmented market against mom-and-pop auto parts distributors, smaller chains, auto dealerships and independent garages. Since the late 1980's, when new management was put into place, Pep Boys has been streamlining and improving its operations. Now that effort is paying off.
Fourth-quarter 1993 earnings of 25 cents a share exceeded most analysts' expectations and indications are that the 1994 first quarter will be even stronger. Store sales, which had flattened during the last recession, are now growing by about 7 percent a year. Gross margins have been rising as the company's strategy of pushing "hard" auto parts -- things that go under the hood as opposed to car accessories -- is paying off. "Hard" parts have high profit margins.
Tire sales, also a high-margin business, have picked up as the economy improves. New stores in new areas, like New England and Chicago, have opened and been immediately successful. In addition, Pep Boys' car servicing department is giving auto dealerships and independent garages stiff competition with prices 20 to 50 percent lower. And the decision by Sears, Roebuck to cut back on car servicing has left a clear path for Pep Boys.
"In the past few years, Pep Boys management team has reinvigorated its merchandise, improved its systems and expanded aggressively," said Peter Caruso, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. "In the auto parts after-market, they are a killer. I'm always pounding the table on this stock. It's got a great growth story and not a lot of competitive challenges."
Pep Boys currently trades at about 29 times current earnings of $1.06 a share. Analysts generally say it will earn $1.30 in 1994 and $1.60 in 1995. There is consensus among analysts that the stock will rise -- barring a complete market tumble. The only question is by how much. Mr. Caruso, for instance, sees the stock going to $37 a share in a year, Wertheim Schroder's John Casesa predicts $34 and Mr. Julian sees Pep Boys at $40 a share.
"The economy has improved and people have stopped deferring car repairs," said Ginnanne G. Long, an analyst at Stephens Inc. "They've got a fantastic format for their stores with an attractive layout and they are beginning to advertise nationally. I see no reason to back off of this stock, even if the market gets iffy."
Of course, as with any rising stock, the time to have bought was yesterday. "Six months ago, the stock was cheap when it was at $20 to $22 a share," said Barry Bryant, an analyst at Ladenburg, Thalmann. "These shares are no longer dramatically underrated. But everything is turning in their favor."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Down on Wide Front As Stocks and Bonds Drop

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against major currencies yesterday after an increase in American interest rates sent stock and bond markets into a tailspin.
Traders bought dollars in the morning after the Federal Reserve said it was raising interest rates on overnight bank loans for the third time this year. Higher interest rates make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive. 
 The Fed signaled that it had lifted its target for the Federal funds rate to 3.75 percent from 3.50 percent. But the dollar gave up its gains when stocks and bonds in the United States tumbled, traders said.
Concern about weak American markets has kept the dollar from gaining this year, even though rates are rising.
"Declining stocks and bonds really hurt the dollar today," said Karl Halligan, a trader at ING Capital Markets. "Higher rates will help the dollar in the future" but won't do any good until investors are more willing to buy American securities.
 
Third Increase of Year
 The dollar was quoted at 1.7075 marks late yesterday, down from 1.7137 Friday. It fell to 103.30 yen, from 103.45 on Friday.
"Today's move came sooner than many people expected," said Hunt Taylor, managing director of the Reynwood Trading Corporation, a Short Hills, N.J., currency-trading fund with $100 million under management. "We like the look of the dollar."
The Fed had raised interest rates twice this year, pushing the Federal funds rate to 3.50 percent from 3 percent. This year's increases are the first in five years. The Fed raised rates to control the inflation that often accompanies economic expansion.
Gold prices fell in trading in New York after rising overseas. The gold contract for June delivery fell 90 cents, to $378.50 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Traders pushed gold prices down as higher rates make borrowing to buy the metal more expensive, and gold becomes less attractive than interest-bearing investments such as bank deposits.
"Gold does not like higher interest rates," said Daniel Weissman, head precious metals trader with MTB Bank in New York. Traders have little conviction which direction prices are moving, he said, and gold will probably trade between $375 and $385 an ounce for the foreseeable future.

HEADLINE: State Workers Strike in Hawaii

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, April 18

 BODY:
More than 13,000 state and county workers went on strike today, delaying the processing of unemployment claims and closing libraries.
Picket lines went up around the state this morning as the Hawaii Government Employees Association began its strike. The state's tourism industry was not expected to be affected, officials said, because all employees vital to airport operations were declared essential workers and forbidden to strike. But people flying to the mainland were advised to be at the airport as much as two hours early. 
 Others deemed essential were police dispatchers, lifeguards, security guards, school health aides and hospital X-ray technicians.
The union is seeking a minimum 8 percent pay raise over two years. The state and its four counties have offered a 4 percent increase. Negotiations ended early Monday, and no new talks are scheduled.
"We have told the membership the success of the strike depends on solidarity, but they should be prepared for a long strike," said the union's director, Russell Okata, as he joined the picket line outside the Honolulu Municipal Building. The strike was the first in the 60-year history of the union.
Gov. John Waihee 3d, a Democrat, said he regretted the walkout. "There are rarely winners in any strike," he said.
The strike closed public libraries and three public golf courses on Oahu and curtailed many services. The state stopped issuing licenses and permits and said the processing of unemployment compensation claims would be delayed.
Public schools remained open, and police officers and firefighters were not striking, after unions representing those workers accepted the 4 percent offer. But 6,700 other workers, many of them in nonteaching positions at the University of Hawaii, were expected to join the strike on Friday, when they will have met the requirement of giving 10 days notice.

HEADLINE: Slaying in St. Thomas Stains Image of an 'American Paradise'

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., April 16

 BODY:
According to the license plates on the cars and buses that haul tourists around this bustling port, the Virgin Islands are still an "American Paradise." But a surge in violent crime over the last year, including the slaying of a San Diego swimming instructor this week, has put that image in jeopardy.
Cruise ships are warning visitors to be cautious, the Navy has canceled port calls here on St. Thomas, and territory officials are promising drastic steps to combat what they call a full-fledged, mainland-style "crime crisis." 
 In the latest incident, which quickly became a symbol of that crisis, Murray Callan, 69, who became known around the world for developing a system to teach infants to swim, was shot to death on April 10 when he went out to rent a movie video here. Mr. Callan and two friends were walking late at night on Long Bay Road, a main thoroughfare that is the only link between downtown and an area where cruise ships daily disgorge thousands of passengers, when two armed men demanded their money but then fired a single shot and fled before the visitors could comply.
Late last month, a 26-year-old police officer, Steven Hodge, was shot to death by four assailants outside his parents' home. So far this year, 11 people have been killed in this Caribbean island territory of 110,000 people, putting the Virgin Islands on a pace to break the record of 27 homicides set in 1989.
 
Plea for Federal Help
 The spate of attacks has shaken the tourist industry more than any incident since the "Fountain Valley Massacre" on St. Croix in 1972, when eight people, including four tourists, were slain while playing golf. Two-thirds of the territory's income comes from the visitors who seek out the islands' white sands, colonial-era charm and duty-free shopping, all to the rhythms of reggae and calypso.
In an April 13 letter to Attorney General Janet Reno, Ron de Lugo, the Virgin Islands' nonvoting delegate to Congress, asked the Justice Department to help "combat the escalation of violent crime in my district." Citing the murder rate, Mr. de Lugo warned Washington that "the resources of our local law-enforcement officials cannot cope with this situation, and the community is increasingly apprehensive."
Government officials acknowledge the seriousness of such concerns but say that the Virgin Islands are still safe for tourists. They also assert that new security measures, including more police and a virtual ban on new handgun sales, should deter criminals.
"We intend to fix the situation so this never happens again," said Eric Dawson, who as Commissioner of Economic Development oversees tourism. "This is a situation we cannot tolerate and that we know we can control. We have to be as hard as the law will permit."
 
T.V.'s Influence
 Of the nearly two million people who visited the United States Virgin Islands last year, 244, or about one hundredth of one percent, were reported to have been victims of crime, the government says. Of them, two tourists were murdered, one was raped, 73 were robbed, 66 were victims of burglaries and 86 were victims of grand larceny.
Government officials attribute most of the increase in violence to an influx of guns and drugs, both difficult to control in a string of islands halfway between the United States mainland and South America. With the growth of tourism and improvements in communication, traditional values are also giving way to the more materialistic standards of the continental United States, especially among young people.
"The influence of the mainland here is very prevalent," Mr. Dawson said. "You can get 40 to 50 cable channels, and all the violence and antisocial things on television are beamed into the Virgin Islands. Young people in particular like to emulate other young people." They do that, he said, by drifting into gangs, imitating the tough talk and look of rap stars and trying to get rich quick.
The killing of Mr. Callan came just four months after an Italian visitor to St. Croix was shot to death in a robbery attempt in downtown Christiansted. Here in the territorial capital late last month, a tourist from Bonn was grazed by a bullet as he was riding in an open tour bus.
 
Attack on Sailors
 Last October, the United States Navy canceled all port calls to this island, citing what it described as "a disproportionate number of violent crimes against U.S. sailors in St. Thomas compared with other ports routinely visited by Atlantic Fleet ships." A statement issued by the Atlantic Fleet from its headquarters in Norfolk, Va., said "the Navy may resume port visits on a limited basis initially," but only if "security conditions improve."
Ted Brown, a spokesman for the Atlantic Fleet, said that in 19 port calls in St. Thomas in the first 10 months of 1993, there had been 12 violent crimes against sailors, including robberies, assaults and one murder. That compared with two crimes in 15 port calls in St. Croix and one violent crime in 40 visits to Naples in the same period.
In the worst attack on Navy visitors here, three sailors waiting to use a public telephone last June were beaten with bats and two of them shot in what was described as an attempted robbery. One sailor, Lieut. Robert D. Bartlett of the U.S.S. Yorktown, eventually died of his injuries.
Arguing that most tourists were perfectly safe, government officials said that some of the attacks appeared to have been a result of American sailors' trying to buy cocaine and marijuana in unsavory areas. Foreign navies, the officials noted, have had far fewer problems when coming to call.
 
No Warnings at Hotel
 Most of the big commercial cruise lines, which bring more than 1.2 million visitors annually to the Virgin Islands, make brief stops to this mountain-fringed port; passengers debark for shopping excursions and are back on board by sunset. But they have felt it necessary to urge their passengers to stick to escorted shore tours.
"We are aware of the recent events in St. Thomas, and we are, in our port lecture, apprising our passengers of the situation," said Jennifer L. Schott, director of public relations for Costa cruise lines. "For those passengers choosing to go off on their own, we provide all the information as to what has happened and encourage them to take cabs instead of walking, and to stay in heavily populated areas."
But tourists arriving by air, who numbered 730,000 last year, said there was no systematic effort to provide them with such advice. Greg and Donna Ryan, residents of Rego Park, Queens, who flew here this week for their honeymoon, said their travel agent had actually denied to them that a Navy warning was in effect. Nor, they said, did their hotel advise them to take any safety precautions.
"Some of the areas here are a little desolate at night, so we have been a little more fearful than we normally are when we travel," Mrs. Ryan said.
 
Banning Some Gun Sales
 In a burst of activity intended to reassure local residents as well as visitors like the Ryans, the territorial Legislature this week passed a measure that would increase the size of the territory's police force, now limited to 450 officers, by about 15 percent. The lawmakers also established a separate force to police certain housing projects and strengthened penalties for juvenile offenders and for illegal gun possession. The government is also preparing a safety pamphlet for distribution to arriving tourists.
In addition, Police Commissioner Anthon L. Christian used his authority this week to declare that residents of the Virgin Islands could no longer legally buy handguns for home protection. Though people who already have permits will be allowed to keep their weapons at home, the police will no longer issue gun registration licenses for new handguns unless they are bought for protection at a business. Less concealable weapons like rifles can still be legally bought for keeping at home.
"We are not trying to disarm law-abiding citizens," Mr. Christian said in an interview here. "But most incidents of violence in this territory involve handguns, and a look at our statistics shows that over 90 guns are stolen each year when criminals break into innocent people's homes."
Officials of the territorial government said there were limits to what they could do by themselves. They complained that their requests to Washington for more customs, immigration, Federal Bureau of Investigation and drug-enforcement officers have gone unheeded at a time of budget cuts.
"Because this is a U.S. territory, we must follow U.S. laws," Mr. Dawson said. Sometimes guns are smuggled in because the territory does not require all people who enter to go through the customs checkpoints that exist in foreign areas of the Caribbean, including the British Virgin Islands just east of here. "After dark," he added, "when the customs people go home, this is effectively an open port, and any kind of guns and drugs can come in."
The government's actions, however, come too late to satisfy Glenn Callan, a San Diego schoolteacher who came here this week to claim his father's body and investigate his slaying. "They've known for a long time they had a bad situation along Long Bay Road, and they've done nothing to correct it," he said. "There has to be more accountability in order that what happened to my father not happen again."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Falls on Concerns Over Mortgage Rate Rises

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Lumber prices fell their daily limit yesterday amid concern that the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates for the third time since Feb. 4 may reduce demand for housing.
"People are worried about mortgage rates," said Bill O'Neill, chief futures strategist at Merrill Lynch, of the drop in lumber prices. "Rates are steadily increasing, up about 1 1/4 percent or more from their lows. That's a healthy amount. It could dissuade some people who might have gone into buying homes." 
 Lumber for May delivery, the most active contract, fell $10, to $334 for each 1,000 board feet on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
On other commodity markets, cattle fell to a six-month low amid abundant supply. Oil was little changed.
Traders said the slide in lumber prices may end soon. Lumber plunged 26 percent since mid-February as interest rates rose.
 
Fed Raises Rate
 Yesterday the Fed raised the rate banks charge one another on overnight loans. The move is intended to ward off inflation that often accompanies an expanding economy. Rates on Treasury bills and notes, the benchmarks for mortgage rates, rose as much as 21 basis points as the Fed moved.
To be sure, the rise in rates could increase demand for lumber in coming weeks as buyers rush to lock in mortgage rates before they rise, prompting more building, traders said.
"People who have been postponing and step up to the plate" could create more demand for lumber, said Bud Merrill, an analyst with Smith Barney Shearson in Eugene, Ore. Housing demand over all should be strong this year, he said, as the economy recovers.
"I think housing starts are going to continue to look decent," Mr. Merrill said. "People have held back and held back because of weather and concerns about other things," such as rates, and the threat of rising rates will bring out buyers, he said.
Cattle futures slid to a six-month low amid near-record supplies and lackluster wholesale demand, traders said. Live cattle for June delivery fell 1 cent, to 72.175 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. May feeder cattle dropped 0.60 cent, to $79.875.
An estimated 123,000 head of cattle were slaughtered today, up almost 7 percent from a year earlier, traders said, leading meatpackers to lower their bids for cattle.
The Department of Agriculture will release its monthly cattle-on-feed report on Friday. Traders expect it to show the number of cattle being raised for slaughter, placed in feed lots and sold for slaughter are all about 3 percent to 4 percent higher than a year ago.
Crude oil was little changed on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: Review/Dance;
The Pennsylvania Ballet Looks Back on 30 Years

BYLINE: By JACK ANDERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 17

 BODY:
The Pennsylvania Ballet has faced various economic and directorial crises since Barbara Weisberger founded it 30 years ago. But it remains alive and kicking.
On Sunday afternoon at the Academy of Music here, the Philadelphia-based troupe gave itself a well-deserved birthday present with "Directors' Retrospective," a program devoted to works by Christopher d'Amboise, who became the company's artistic director in 1990, and by two previous directors who are also choreographers: Robert Weiss, artistic director from 1982 to 1990, and Richard Tanner, associate artistic director from 1985 to 1990. 
 The occasion was an opportunity to renew acquaintance with this group, which in the 1960's and 70's appeared regularly in New York but has not had a New York engagement since 1985. The company's dancing at the academy was neat and lucid. Occasionally it seemed that clarity of movement had been achieved at the expense of passion. Nevertheless, the members of the ensemble, as well as the soloists, were good-looking and technically strong.
Two of the matinee's four ballets were unfamiliar to New Yorkers. Both were by Mr. d'Amboise, a former member of the New York City Ballet and the son of Jacques d'Amboise, a former principal dancer of that company.
The more imaginative of these pieces was "Franklin Court," which dates from 1990. It honors one of Philadelphia's most famous citizens, Benjamin Franklin, yet is in no way a biographical sketch. So, too, although the accompaniment is a medley of compositions by Bach, the choreography never imitates 18th-century dance forms. Rather, Mr. d'Amboise pays tribute to Franklin's ingenuity. The contrapuntal opening and closing movements for large ensembles convey a sense of 18th-century pomp. Other sections celebrate Franklin's talents as a scientist and inventor.
Two duets reflect his fascination with electricity. In the first, Dede Barfield entered alone, performed a solo and left, only to be replaced by William DeGregory, who also danced a solo and left. Eventually, both dancers entered and drew near to each other, as if magnetized. But they never touched. Later, in their second pas de deux, they did, and it generated emotional electricity, signaling the beginning of a tender adagio.
Some group scenes were inspired by Franklin's inventions. In a section called "Bifocals," two couples -- Patricia Tomlinson and Jeffrey Gribler and Corinne Neenan and Matthew Neenan (who are sister and brother) -- were placed in different parts of the stage. When the movements of one couple broadened, the other couple's movements dwindled in scale, as if being seen through two different lenses. The equally clever "Swim Fins" featured Roseanne Germer, who kept plunging her way through a sea of men, making swimming gestures as she did so.
Mr. d'Amboise's "Da Mummy, Nyet Mummy," which received its premiere last year, was a ballet of mysterious adventures to an electronic arrangement of Shostakovich's Suite for Two Pianos, Op. 6. Mark Stanley's setting resembled a catacombs, and it was ruled by three women (Jennita Russo, Anne White and Leslie Carothers), who wore identical black wigs. Timour Bourtasenkov, Mr. Gribler and Mr. de Gregory portrayed men enamored of them and, from time to time, four other figures slipped in and out of the shadows like phantoms.
The women were sometimes icy, sometimes ethereal and sometimes alluring. Mr. d'Amboise devised effective sequences in which the women proved elusive, and visually striking groupings in which clusters of people raised individuals in exaltation. But he was unable to sustain a sense of wonderment throughout the ballet.
The contributions by Mr. Weiss and Mr. Tanner have previously been presented in New York. Mr. Weiss's "Awakening," a lyrical pas de deux to music by Craig Steven Shuler, was first performed by American Ballet Theater in 1975. In the Philadelphia company's staging, Ms. Germer looked delicate as she skimmed across the stage, and Alexei Borovik combined precision with impetuosity.
Mr. Tanner created "Sonatas and Interludes" for the Eglevsky Ballet in 1982 and it is now in the repertory of the New York City Ballet. Some interpretations of this pas de deux suggest that there is an implicit tension between the man and the woman. But at the Academy, Dalia Hay and David Krensing moved with total serenity while Martha Koeneman played John Cage's piano score and the dancers' bodies formed constantly changing geometrical shapes in space.
Richard Rosenberg conducted.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Salary Cap Is Misguided Medicine

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
Considering some of the comments emanating from major league club owners, it seems that the salary cap they want the players to accept would cure not only their economic problems but also the problems of health care, secondary smoke and the succession to the British throne.
Bill Giles, the verbose owner of the Philadelphia Phillies, was the latest to register his views. Speaking on a sports business panel last week, Giles said, among other things, that if the owners don't get a salary cap in the current but stagnant labor negotiations, "a lot of teams" will have to move. He predicted that these teams, which could number six or seven, would include the San Diego Padres, the Montreal Expos and the Pittsburgh Pirates. 
 Giles's view raises two questions: Should the players care so much about the location of teams that they would submit to the owners' will and accept an idea they consider onerous and unnecessary? And so what if some teams would have to move; far from hurting major league baseball, wouldn't moves from weaker cities to stronger cities strengthen it?
In some instances, players do care about their teams' location. Tony Gwynn, for example, has forsaken greater wealth and possible World Series rings to remain in San Diego, his home and a place he loves. He made a decision that being happy in San Diego was more important to him than being a winner in Atlanta or Oakland or anywhere else.
For the most part, though, players don't become so attached to the cities where they play. They could play just as easily for the Padres or the Pirates, the Reds or the Royals. Does that mean they are insensitive to the feelings of the fans in the cities where they are employed? No, but they don't think they should put an artificial ceiling on their potential earnings either.
If a team playing in, say, Phoenix, could pay a shortstop more handsomely than that same team playing in Pittsburgh, most players would opt for the southwest. That preference does not make baseball players any different from any other group of employees.
The Players Association long has resented the owners' asking or expecting their employees to subsidize them. Sometimes companies ask employees to accept a temporary pay cut or a wage freeze, but that generally occurs when the company is on the verge of going out of business.
No teams have announced that their economic plight is so serious that they face the possibility of going out of business. Before an owner reached that point, he would sell the team -- for a hefty profit at that.
Rather than ask them to subsidize a team in trouble, the players feel, the owners should do that themselves if they want to keep a team in a certain city.
In 1992, the Giants were on the verge of moving to St. Petersburg, Fla., at what would have been a terrific profit for the selling owner, Bob Lurie. A local group of businessmen, however, jumped in at the last minute, made Lurie slightly less wealthy than the Florida group would have and kept the team in San Francisco.
The players didn't have to subsidize Peter Magowan and his partners. Instead, the Magowan group transformed the Giants into an exciting, winning team that attracted a record attendance at Candlestick Park last season.
At the same time, the Padres' owners decimated their team by purging it of its best (most expensive) players, and the Padres wound up with their lowest full-season attendance since 1980.
So what if the Padres have to move? If Phoenix or St. Petersburg, or Orlando or Buffalo, could support them more capably than San Diego, major league baseball would be better off.
Major league baseball generally prefers to keep its teams stationary. That's an admirable stance, but maybe there comes a time when change becomes not only necessary but good.
The Padres and the Expos each are a quarter of a century old, having joined the majors as expansion teams together in 1969. The Pirates have been in Pittsburgh forever. The departure of any of those teams would leave a void in each city's life but most severely in Pittsburgh because the Pirates long have been one of the city's treasured institutions.
But if any or all of those teams moved, presumably they would move to cities that could support them in economically better fashion. That improved support, in turn, would only strengthen the major leagues.
There is, on the other hand, another possible solution. Instead of moving, the present owners could sell those teams to people who would provide stronger, more creative management. If Magowan could do it in San Francisco, others could do it in Pittsburgh and elsewhere.
The Pirates have a hybrid ownership of public and private groups. That ownership deserves credit for buying the team from the Galbreath family and keeping it in Pittsburgh, but its time has passed. The Pirates could thrive under a new, aggressive, imaginative owner.
Contrary to what Giles and his fellow owners believe, a salary cap would not be the panacea for what they think ails baseball. It's simply the easiest and least challenging solution for them. Marvin Miller, the former head of the players' union, used to say the owners always asked the players to save them from themselves. The salary cap is their modern version of that theme.

HEADLINE: U.S. Diplomat's Speech on Extremism in Germany Stirs Storm

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BERLIN, April 18

 BODY:
An unusually frank speech by a senior American diplomat about right-wing extremism in Germany has stirred a tempest here.
The diplomat, Douglas H. Jones, who heads the American diplomatic mission in Berlin, told an audience last week that many foreigners believe that Germany "lacks the will to confront its extremism problem pragmatically." 
 "It is not reassuring, for example, that more progress is not being made toward guaranteed civil rights for foreigners in Germany," he said.
Mr. Jones said at the beginning of his speech that his views "do not necessarily reflect any policy of the United States Government." Soon after he delivered it, the United States Embassy in Bonn issued a statement saying "it was inappropriate for him to make remarks so at variance with U.S. policy while working as an American official."
A German Government spokesman said later that the charge d'affaires at the United States Embassy in Bonn, Donald Kursch, "wrote to the chancellery on Friday, after the speech became known, to deeply regret the incident."
Mr. Jones, a 21-year-member of the Foreign Service who has served in his present post for five years, had previously announced that he would retire this year. He delivered his speech to a human rights group in Oranienburg, near Berlin.
Nearly all the points contained in the speech had already been made repeatedly by journalists and other commentators. What attracted attention was not the speech's content, but the identity of its author.
 
Suggestion of Racism
 At one point, Mr. Jones noted that Chancellor Helmut Kohl was among many German politicians who often say Germany "is not an immigration country."
"If I were a skinhead, I would take a certain amount of comfort in hearing that Germany was not a country of immigration," Mr. Jones said. "That would signal to me that the nearly seven million foreigners who live here legally do not belong here, and that I am justified in wanting them out. And to be honest with you, this sentiment is by no means limited to skinheads."
Mr. Jones also criticized German citizenship laws, which place paramount importance on German ancestry rather than on place of birth or residence.
"How can those minorities remain anything but conspicuous, underprivileged targets of anger and frustration if they have no chance to become assimilated on an equal basis with Germans if they so choose, or to have their own cultural distinctiveness protected from attack if they do not?" he asked. "If Germany is not a racist society, why is its nationality law, which was written in 1913, predicated upon race? Public attitudes toward minority communities in Germany are ambivalent at best."
Mr. Jones also criticized a recent proposal made by Wolfgang Schauble, the parliamentary leader of Mr. Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, that the German Army be used to maintain civil order in the country.
"I can think of nothing that would bring to mind worse associations or that would give more of an impression of a state in crisis than this blurring of the distinction between internal and external security," he said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Attacks Drop Slightly
 BONN, April 18 (Special to The New York Times) -- Right-wing acts of violence in Germany dropped slightly last year compared with 1992, according to a report by the German Government. But there were still 1,609 stabbings, beatings, arson attacks and the like against foreigners that took the lives of 7 people in 1993. A total of 727 were wounded, compared with 585 the year before.
The Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution, which issued the report last week , also said that in the first three months of this year, right-wing violence continued to decline, with a total of 349 incidents, including the bombing of a synagogue in Lubeck last month and five attempted murders, but no deaths.
Right-wing violence peaked in 1992, as did a wave of foreign asylum-seekers. The German Constitution was changed last summer to impose qualifications for the first time on the right to claim political asylum.
The report put the total membership of right-wing and extremist groups at 42,450, about the same as last year, and said more vigorous prosecution and heavier sentences in cases of violence had lessened the appeal of the groups.
The report also made clear that prosperous western German states, not the formerly Communist eastern areas now afflicted by unemployment, had the highest per capita incidence of racial violence in 1993.

HEADLINE: Cracking Down on Corrupt Cops

 BODY:
The dramatic arrest of 14 officers in the 30th Precinct on drug-dealing and other charges -- plus evidence that many of their fellow cops knew what they were up to -- is further proof that New York City has a serious police corruption problem. It also argues strongly for bringing back the defunct office of the Special State Prosecutor for Criminal Justice.
Only months ago, witnesses before the Mollen commission on police corruption painted a frightening picture of a see-no-evil, hear-no-evil departmental culture in which felonious misconduct of the kind uncovered in Harlem's 30th Precinct easily flourishes. The crimes involved are neither trivial nor subtle. One officer charged last week is said to have shot and seriously wounded a drug dealer while stealing a bag of cocaine. 
 Officials say there will be arrests in as many as 10 other precincts over the next few weeks. The corruption may well be limited to isolated "pockets," as the Mollen commission concluded last December. But that is of little solace to people in poor, drug-infested neighborhoods. Living with police corruption means living without protection.
Both Police Commissioner William Bratton and his boss, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, have made clear they will not tolerate corruption or cops who protect their crooked colleagues. Acting on information gathered during two years of investigations and sting operations, Mr. Bratton is adding investigators to his Internal Affairs Division. To break the force's "blue code" of silence, he will also allow officers to report their suspicions anonymously. Such tips can be invaluable, provided care is taken to protect informants and to secure the corroboration needed to make a case.
Commissioner Bratton also hopes that the arrests and his own strong statements have already had "a chilling effect" on police corruption. In this he may be too optimistic. Fighting corruption over the long haul will take more than the department's newfound vigilance, welcome as it is. The time has come to revive the office of the Special State Prosecutor for Criminal Justice, an idea previously endorsed by Mayor Giuliani.
The job was eliminated four years ago in the face of dwindling indictments and an economic crunch. But given sufficient funding, and led by an experienced, nonpolitical prosecutor, the special prosecutor's office could help make corruption a riskier business for bad cops.

HEADLINE: True 'Skinheads' Are Not the Racist Thugs of Media Fame

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Dominick Bruno Jr., whom you profile in an April 4 news article, certainly deserves lauds for his work in reporting on neo-Nazis and their cohorts in New Jersey. However, Mr. Bruno does not and never did deserve the name "skinhead." 
 The majority of skinheads are not racists. The skinhead movement itself was started in the mid-1960's by working-class youths in England. Instead of opting for the flamboyant, fancy-dress escapism of the Mod and Teddy Boy youth cults before them, the skinheads embraced working-class fashion: cropped hair, meant-to-last shoes and boots, white T-shirts and worn Levis.
They also borrowed from their working-class West Indian neighbors, adopting trilby hats and crombie jackets, peg-legged striped suits and love for ska, the Jamaican music that mixed Latin beats and American jazz melodies and was the forerunner of modern reggae. The original skinheads loved to dance to these ska beats, often frequented all-black nightclubs and had, by the end of the decade, several Jamaican "skinhead reggae" records and bands they loyally supported.
Racism appeared on the scene in the 1970's because of the poor economic climate in England. Many neo-Nazi groups began recruiting the skinheads, most of whom were in low-paying jobs or on the dole. Playing on the traditional nationalistic ideas of the working class, the fascist groups did their best to turn the skinheads against their immigrant neighbors. Unfortunately, many confused souls left the skinhead movement and joined the National Front and other neo-Nazi groups in England.
The skinhead movement never ended, although for a time in the 70's it was nearly nonexistent. This was mainly due to the bad rap skinheads received for their perceived violent ways. The violence often arose when true skinheads were threatened by the racist groups. There was a huge skinhead revival in the late 1970's and early 1980's with the advent of punk rock and oi, as well as with the Two Tone ska revival.
It was this second wave of skinheads that saw the beginning of Skinheads Against Racial Prejudice, or Sharp, which has chapters in every state in the United States as well as in nearly all Western European countries. It is dedicated to upholding the traditions of the skinhead movement, as well as battling racism.
Real skinheads are not the neo-Nazi fools one so often hears, sees and reads about in the media. Many skinheads, especially in New York City, are of Asian or African-American descent. They choose to be skinheads because they believe in the values of the working class, they believe all races should come together and they like to groove to the ska beat.
I ask that you please refer to neo-Nazi skinheads as fascists or racists or just plain ignorant slobs, but not as skinheads alone. They are not true skinheads, for they do not connect to the roots.
 
JENNIFER ABBOTS
New York, April 8, 1994

HEADLINE: Observer;
Excuses For a Shame

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
It's mean out here. Half the country is cheering for a foreign government to go ahead and beat an American, age 18, to bloody pulp because he vandalized cars and signs in Singapore.
This was rotten of him, no doubt, and he is also sentenced to do jail time for it, but it says something about the collapse of American ego when half the country starts cheering for foreign powers to beat up our fellow citizens. 
 Inside the Beltway where I ventured recently there was deep philosophical calm about this apparent onset of national self-loathing. They are thoughtful inside the Beltway. So thoughtful. It must have something to do with the famous Beltway's power to concentrate the mind even as it deadens the emotions.
"You must understand about the bloody-pulp beating," these thoughtful people explained -- all in more or less the same words with that same philosophical calm so easy for a person to maintain about a bloody beating when he is not the party about to receive it -- "you must understand, there are a lot of people out there angry about crime."
"Out there," when spoken by people inside the Beltway, means "outside the Beltway," a vast space that exists mostly to be polled. Occasionally a reporter travels there and, on returning, is said to have been "out in the country." It's a little like those old movies about British India in which minions of the Raj sit around Delhi drilling the regiment and occasionally welcoming back some chap from the Blues who's been "up in the Punjab."
So the anger about crime "out there" is submitted to explain the mean public mood. In a place less richly equipped with polls, people might theorize that there are good economic reasons why meanness might be souring the American spirit. Its most revered corporations, for instance, have made a boast of being "lean and mean" as they betray years of employee loyalty by cutting thousands of workers and managers off payrolls.
In a secular nation the corporation is the closest thing we have to an idol worthy of worship. If meanness leads to corporate success, a citizen might be sensibly persuaded by the example.
Many people now live in fear of being wiped out in onsets of meanness required for the higher good of corporations and country. Economically therapeutic though such meanness surely is, the individual vulnerable to its salubrious savagery might naturally feel tempted to kick somebody even more helpless than himself. Or, as in the present case, to cry, "Lay on with a will, Singapore!"
Such theories receive no hearing inside the Beltway. It is too charmed right now by crime to entertain dull economic theories for human behavior. Everybody has polls showing all America is absolutely terrified by reports of inner-city crime whose victims are overwhelmingly black.
The Congress hasn't an idea of what to do to improve life in the inner cities. Even if it did know, unless it was cost-free it wouldn't do it anyhow, since Congress's chief constituency is suburban, not the inner city.
Voting "tough" on crime is easier for Congress than facing intractable urban problems. And so drug-inspired criminals, who deal out capital punishment to each other daily, will soon be subject to official capital punishment by the Federal Government!
There seems little disposition inside the Beltway to deal with the economic roots of American uneasiness. The news industry is besotted with the incomprehensibilities of Whitewater and the White House talks happily about statistics pointing to an economic recovery, but none of this has much to do with the depressing problem the polls keep hinting at.
That is, an awful lot of Americans are disappointed with their lives, think they are moving down the economic scale and are pessimistic about moving up again. There isn't much in Clinton economics to encourage their optimism. As a "new Democrat," he is basically a pre-Reagan Republican, which is to say a trickle-down fellow.
He is betting on those lean and mean corporations to do well, thus creating enough new jobs to improve the nation's mood. It isn't clear how this is going to stop the relentless march of electronic automations which makes it easier and easier to produce more and more while putting more and more people out of work.
It will probably get meaner out here -- or out there as they say inside the Beltway.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Ethanol's Cost Far Outweighs the Benefit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As leaders of energy and transportation research groups, we respectfully suggest that Gov. E. Benjamin Nelson of Nebraska needs to watch out for mixing his fuels ("For the Air and the Economy, Try Ethanol," letter, April 7). Ethanol made from grain requires significant inputs of diesel and gasoline, as well as boiler fuels, for harvesting and processing, inputs that are almost the same as the energy in the gasoline displaced! 
 Ethanol "competes" with gasoline only because of generous Federal subsidies and tax forgiveness worth 54 cents a gallon of ethanol, plus additional state subsidies. Governor Nelson's own state gives an additional present equal to 10 cents a gallon of the ethanol used in the gasoline blend sold. For Nebraska, the subsidies exceed the wholesale price of gasoline!
While no one questions the small benefit ethanol blend gives to gasoline, few believe the blend is worth anywhere near these kinds of subsidies. And the Governor seems to have forgotten that in more than 20 years of debate, no Congress has refused to do anything about foreign oil except subsidize alternatives. Apparently Congress continues to believe in free lunches, or at least free drinks. While there may be some benefit in reducing oil imports, subsidizing ethanol is an expensive way to do it.
The jobs "created" in making ethanol are paid for by tax revenues from treasuries. Since ethanol is more expensive than oil, it reduces overall productivity, hurting employment. The oil industry has lost jobs, but consumers have billions more to spend from lower fuel prices, creating more jobs in other sectors. Ethanol requires a large transfer from tax coffers to ethanol producers, for small benefits. If only we got such tax treatment when buying wine!
We'll believe the Governor's Ethanol Coalition when it advocates a stiff gasoline tax to compensate for the real problems associated with importing and using gasoline, instead of robbing the public till for a second-rate fuel. Would not ethanol be better in French Burgundy or California zinfandel and not mixed with driving?
 
LEE SCHIPPER
DANIEL SPERLING
Berkeley, Calif., April 8, 1994
 
The writers are, respectively, co-leader of international energy studies, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, and head, Institute for Transportation Studies, U. of California, Davis.

HEADLINE: Split Coalition In Japan Picks A New Premier

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 19

 BODY:
Leaders of Japan's ruling coalition settled today on Foreign Minister Tsutomu Hata as the next Prime Minister but remained divided over policies to end the recession and reopen trade talks with the United States.
Mr. Hata's selection was assured when his remaining rival, a former Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, withdrew. 
 But the continuing disputes between the conservative members of the coalition and the Socialists over economic policy could delay the formal naming of Mr. Hata, 58, a conservative and pragmatist who has refused even to declare his candidacy.
Even worse, the failure to agree on basic issues could presage more of the paralyzing infighting that characterized the last months of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's Government, which was toppled 11 days ago because of Mr. Hosokawa's involvement in a financial scandal.
Mr. Hata defected from the Liberal Democratic Party last summer and was a founder of the current coalition. He favors a strong relationship with the United States but has opposed some of Washington's demands for greater access to Japanese markets.
Though he has operated near the corruption-tainted center of power for a decade, Mr. Hata is an approachable man with a common touch. He has also demonstrated an inclination to compromise and side with Japan's conservative bureaucracy. His greatest political achievement was his defection with a group of rebels from the Liberal Democratic Party, which ended 38 years of one-party rule. He and the others insisted it was time to clean up Japanese politics and put Japan on a path toward economic deregulation.
The divisions within the coalition could be bad news for Washington, which has been eager for a strong Government in Tokyo to deal with issues ranging from Japan's yawning trade surplus to North Korea's suspected nuclear weapons program.
Indeed, the infighting that surrounded Mr. Hata's selection made it clear that the new Government will not be able to quickly solve the problems that have brought relations between the world's largest economies to their lowest ebb in years.
The succession process has offered a peculiar spectacle. Under the one-party rule of the Liberal Democrats, prime ministers were generally selected in back-room bargaining and then formally named without delay. Even when the coalition ousted the Liberal Democrats, it moved quickly to pick Mr. Hosokawa.
This time, however, the process has been slowed by a broad party realignment in which the left-right polarization of the cold war has broken down and the parties have moved toward the political center. The attempts to reshape the coalition and its policies explain why Mr. Hata, an obvious successor to Mr. Hosokawa, has yet to win formal endorsement.
Mr. Hata made it clear today that he would keep Mr. Hosokawa's Cabinet almost intact, which would perpetuate at least some policy divisions. He said the reason for keeping many of the ministers would be to pass the long-delayed budget swiftly; the fiscal year began April 1.
"I'm not in a position to talk about the lineup of the new Cabinet, but common sense suggests the key positions will go to those who compiled the current budget," Mr. Hata said.
In addition, Mr. Hata is expected to move quickly to prepare measures to lessen Government regulation of the economy. He has said Japan would offer such a package before the summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial countries in July.
The Clinton Administration has been seeking relaxation of Japan's regulatory process as a way of opening the economy to foreign companies. But this would be the third such package assembled in the last year, and most analysts have been disappointed with the previous efforts.
Because Mr. Hata has supported the bureaucracy, which jealously controls the regulatory apparatus, few expect bold new measures.
The biggest policy dispute today was over a proposal by Mr. Hata's party to alter the tax system. Finance Ministry bureaucrats have proposed a reduction in income taxes, to be offset by a large increase in the national sales tax, and Mr. Hata has accepted the plan.
The Socialists bitterly oppose this, in large part because the sales-tax increase would fall heavily on wage earners, the core of the party.
The Clinton Administration has also argued against the plan, saying it would stifle the chances of recovery from the two-year recession. Washington is encouraging faster growth because an expanding economy could absorb more imports and reduce Japan's trade surplus.
Still, Mr. Hata and the coalition's main strategist, Ichiro Ozawa, remain firmly in favor of the tax increase.
The group's leaders could only agree today that they would meet again Wednesday to resume debate.
In foreign policy, the coalition supported the United States-Japan security treaty, which the Socialists, the largest party in the coalition, had rejected for years.
The coalition also agreed on a vague statement promising cooperation with Washington on North Korea's nuclear weapons program. The Socialists have had moderately friendly relations with North Korea.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Continues To Widen

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit soared in February to its worst level in six years, as the United States, with a strong economy, went on a worldwide buying binge while its weaker trading partners bought less merchandise off American shelves.
The Commerce Department reported today that the trade deficit in goods and services was $9.71 billion in February, up sharply from January's imbalance of $6.64 billion. The deficit in goods alone rose by one-fifth, to $13.89 billion, while America's traditional surplus in services like tourism, brokerage, investment banking, insurance and film rentals dipped about 11 percent, to $4.18 billion. 
 The widening American trade imbalance underscores the failure of the Clinton Administration's efforts to spur the nation's leading economic allies to cut taxes and lower their interest rates enough to stimulate more consumer spending in Japan, Germany and Western Europe.
 
Vow Not Fulfilled
 The Clinton Administration came into office vowing to reinvigorate the Group of Seven industrial democracies -- Germany, Japan, Canada, Britain, France, Italy and the United States -- in part to make it a more effective instrument for coordinating economic growth. But thus far it has nothing to show for its efforts, and today's trade figures underline that point.
The Group of Seven, whose finance ministers will meet in Washington this weekend, has focused on aid to Russia and securing the global trade agreement signed in Morocco last Friday, but it has accomplished nothing on its primary mission of promoting economic growth among the industrial democracies. One result is that United States continues to expand much faster than its allies. While the American economy grew at a 7 percent clip in the final quarter of last year, Japan and Europe were either in recession or just beginning to climb out of it.
 
 
'Dead in the Water'
 "The G-7 is dead in the water," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics. "It has become totally ineffectual in achieving its primary purpose of maintaining a growing and stable world economy. The Administration has nothing to show for its policy of trying to reinvigorate the G-7 with quiet, behind-the-scenes coaxing."
This is a major element in the current trade deterioration, which is a drag on the American economy, Mr. Bergsten said, adding: "Of course, I would lay most of the blame on the Japanese and Europeans for their recalcitrance. Japan is in its third year of recession, has a budget surplus, its growth prospects are flat but its Government will not cut taxes without an offsetting tax increase."
As for the Europeans, Mr. Bergsten said, their behavior is "equally puzzling." The Europeans, led by the Germans, have been very slow to lower interest rates, even though their economies are stagnating. The Germans are worried about inflation and weakening their own currency by lowering interest rates. The French and other Western Europeans nations are reluctant to get out ahead of the Germans on interest-rate policy for fear of weakening their currencies as well.
Consequently, there is slow growth everywhere in the Group of Seven, except in the United States. American exports of merchandise dropped 3.5 percent, to $37.17 billion, while merchandise imports jumped 2.4 percent, to $51.05 billion, the second-highest level on record. American imports of foreign cars were also up sharply, rising 4.2 percent, to $8.82 billion in February, while foreigners bought fewer American aircraft, data processing equipment and industrial engines. These are the sort of large capital goods that foreigners need to buy from the United States if there is any hope of balancing out the trade figures.
These figures have economic consequences for the United States. For instance, when the trade deficit grows, it subtracts from the gross national product, because it means that an increased part of American domestic consumer demand is being satisfied by goods and services produced abroad and not in the United States. It hurts American workers as well, because Japan is, in effect, exporting some of its unemployment, by exploiting demand in the United States to fuel Japanese industry rather than by generating more of its own domestic demand.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Balance of Trade" shows the amount of imports and exports in 1992 and 1993. (Source: Commerce Department) (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: Rodney King Is Awarded $3.8 Million

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 19

 BODY:
A jury told the City of Los Angeles today to pay Rodney G. King $3.8 million in damages in compensation for his beating by police officers in 1991.
In the next phase of Mr. King's civil suit, to begin immediately, the jury will hear more testimony to determine whether any of 14 current and former police officers who were at the scene are liable for punitive damages in addition to today's award. 
 The award -- $3,816,535.45 -- was three times the $1.25 million the city had offered to pay Mr. King before the trial when it accepted liability for the beating. But it was far less than the $9.5 million Mr. King had sought. In closing arguments last week, his lawyer raised the ante and asked for $15 million.
"We think that this is a satisfactory result," City Attorney James K. Hahn said today, indicating that the city is unlikely to appeal the outcome. It had conceded liability in the beating in an effort to resolve the case and avoid a review of police procedures.
Mr. King's lawyer, Milton C. Grimes, said his client was "somewhat pleased" with the verdict. The lawyer said he would fight to win more money in the second phase of the trial.
 
'The Case Is Not Over'
 "I told him what the verdict was," Mr. Grimes said of Mr. King. "He was somewhat pleased with the verdict, and I told him we have not finished. He understood that. The case is not over."
Joseph Duff, who heads the local chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., also said the award seemed fair. "I think that passes the test of reasonableness," he said. "It is a measure of the depth of pain and suffering and the understanding that there is a permanent injury to him."
An unemployed construction worker at the time of the beating, Mr. King, now 29, has not worked in three years. Experts at the trial estimated his lost earnings from his injuries at $500,000 to $1 million over his lifetime.
The compensatory damages from the city are intended to cover lost earnings and expenses for treatment of broken bones and neurological and psychological damage. Mr. King's lawyer has said his client will never be able to work again.
Legal experts said Mr. Grimes might receive about one-third of the amount awarded, although the details of his arrangement with Mr. King have not been made public. Mr. King's previous lawyer, Stephen Lerman, is reportedly also owed several hundred thousand dollars.
The defendants in the second phase of the trial include the four police officers who were tried twice for the beating, in which Mr. King was repeatedly struck with a police baton, kicked and shocked with a stun gun.
In a state trial in 1992, the officers' acquittal on assault charges promoted a riot that took more than 50 lives. In a Federal trial last year, two of the officers -- Stacey C. Koon and Laurence M. Powell -- were convicted of violating Mr. King's civil rights and are now serving 30-month prison terms.
After the verdict, the city was quiet today, with the April 1992 riot a fading memory. Vacant lots now mark the sites of many burned buildings in South-Central Los Angeles, the neighborhood most damaged by the riots. Rebuild L.A., the consortium formed to help put the area back on its feet, has been substantially reduced in size after only limited success, and crime, poverty and gang conflicts continue as before.
Since the beating, Mr. King has been arrested several times on accusations of drunken driving and spousal abuse and has been released each time. The police also said he had attacked an undercover officer who approached him as he was sitting in a car with a transvestite prostitute.
Witnesses at the trial described him as still shaken by his beating and its aftermath, fearful in the streets and shying away from the police.
Mr. King himself gave his most graphic account of the beating. "I felt like I had been raped," he testified. "I felt like I had lost half of my face."
He also asserted that his assailants yelled racial epithets, a point disputed in all the trials stemming from the beating. His lawyers portrayed him as a victim of racism, beaten by the white officers because he is black.
In an effort to limit damages, the city focused on Mr. King's character before the beating, including his imprisonment for robbery and troubles with alcohol and drugs.
In the second phase of Mr. King's suit, for punitive damages, the legal travails resume for the police officers who were tried in the beating.
The two convicted officers, Mr. Powell and Mr. Koon, were dismissed from the force are serving their time in a prison camp in Dublin, Calif.
"He cleans toilets eight hours a day, oh, it's terrible," said Ira Salzman, Mr. Koon's lawyer, in an interview before the civil trial.
The two other officers, who were tried and acquitted, were Theodore Briseno, who remains suspended without pay from the force awaiting a hearing, and Timothy E. Wind, a rookie who was dismissed.

HEADLINE: NATO Weighs a U.N. Plan To Strike Six Bosnia Sites

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, April 19

 BODY:
NATO officials today began urgent consideration of a request by the United Nations Secretary General to authorize air strikes in defense of all six United Nations-designated "safe areas" in Bosnia, with the allies divided on a step many of them fear would make NATO a combatant in the war.
With one previous strategic success, in forcing an end to the siege of Sarajevo by Bosnian Serb fighters two months ago, NATO military planners in Brussels began considering whether allied air power should be used to protect the five other "safe areas," including beleaguered Gorazde, from Serbian attack. 
 Currently, NATO has accepted responsibility only for air strikes to defend United Nations forces in Bosnia. When American warplanes under NATO command attacked Serbian targets near Gorazde last week, it was not to prevent them from taking territory but to protect United Nations troops.
 
A Step Further
 Mr. Boutros-Ghali's overnight request for authorization of NATO air strikes to protect the Bosnian Government-controlled "safe areas," if he requests them, would take the alliance's involvement a step further.
"What the U.N. is asking us to do is to act against artillery pieces, mortars, or tanks in protected areas which U.N. forces there determine are responsible for attacks on the zones," a NATO official said. "Obviously it will be very difficult to determine where they are and to coordinate with the U.N. to call in strikes against them, and the military are now looking at the possibilities."
NATO officials said it was doubtful that the study would be completed in time for ambassadors from the 16 member countries to decide on an answer to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali's request at their regular weekly North Atlantic Council meeting on Wednesday.
But in the NATO capitals, where the real decisions are made, the allies are split about the wisdom of taking the fateful next step down the road toward direct military involvement to stop a war that has made the alliance appear impotent in the face of Serbian aggression in Gorazde.
 
British Most Skpetical
 The British, with more than 3,000 troops in the lightly armed United Nations peacekeeping force in Bosnia, remain the most skeptical because of fears of Serbian retaliation against their soldiers in case of NATO air attacks.
Some British officials are also growing increasingly critical of the Clinton Administration's reluctance to become involved on the ground in Bosnia until after a peace settlement is reached.
"Some have had quite unrealistic expectations about what can be achieved by the use of air power alone or by ground forces that are not equipped or organized to operate in a combat role," Defense Secretary Malcolm Rifkind said in a House of Commons debate on Monday.
But the French, with more than 4,000 troops in Bosnia, support the U.N. request for broader authorization of the use of NATO air power, according to a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry in Paris.
 
'Carrot-and-Stick Approach'
 France's Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, has also called for intensified diplomatic coordination by American, Russian, and European Union negotiators to push Bosnia's Serbs, Croats and Muslims toward peace.
"We support a carrot-and-stick approach," a French spokesman said, "with the threat of air strikes and the carrot of progressive lifting of international economic sanctions against the Serbs if they agree to peace."
The United States and France brought their NATO allies around in February to issuing an ultimatum to the Serbs to withdraw their heavy weapons from a zone around Sarajevo. But they remain divided on the wisdom of talking about possibly lifting sanctions at a time when the Clinton Administration believes the Serbs have done nothing to deserve relief.
Germany, which supported the NATO ultimatum in Sarajevo, is far more reluctant about extending the threat of violent intervention to other "safe areas."
 
Political Solutions Pressed
 A German spokesman said that Chancellor Helmut Kohl told President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia by telephone today that "every effort should be made to put an end to bloodshed in the region and bring about a lasting peace."
In telephone talks with President Clinton and Mr. Mitterrand on Monday, Mr. Kohl also emphasized the need for political solutions over intensified military measures, said the spokesman, Dieter Vogel. "It is the view of the German Government that we should not be urging stronger military steps on others when we can't become militarily involved ourselves," Mr. Vogel said.
