HEADLINE: Prices Rise for 30-Year Bond as Traders Reconsider Fed's Move

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The ripples in the pond began to subside yesterday, one day after the Federal Reserve raised short-term rates for the third time this year. But investors remain mindful that the central bank may have more stones to throw.
Short-covering in early trading helped to move Treasury prices up off their early lows, as the release of February merchandise trade data caused some economists to shave their estimates for economic growth in the first quarter of this year. 
 The Government said that the February trade gap widened to $12.36 billion, from a revised $10.17 billion in January. Including a surplus in services exports, the total trade gap expanded to $9.71 billion, from a revised $6.64 billion shortfall in January, the report showed.
Some economists said the bigger deficit suggested that the net export sector could turn out to be more of a drag on first-quarter growth than people were expecting.
"I think there will be considerable slowing going into the second quarter," Peter J. Canelo, chief investment strategist at NatWest Securities, said.
By late in the day, the 30-year bond was up 17/32 , to 8622/32 , while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 7.36 percent, from 7.41 percent on Monday. Shorter-maturity bills were mixed, with a three-month bill rate at 3.74 percent, down from 3.76 percent the previous day, and a six-month bill 4.20 percent, down from 4.21 percent. A one-year bill rose to 4.66 percent from 4.63 percent.
Traders think the overall bearish sentiment will continue to weigh on bond prices ahead of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee meeting on May 17, when most market participants expect another credit tightening and possibly an increase in the Fed's discount rate, which is now 3 percent.
"As you get close to 4 percent, 4.50 percent, people will begin wonder how far you have to go," Mr. Canelo said.
Comments by Robert T. Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, were taken by many traders as another indication that the Fed would raise its target for short-term interest rates again in the near future. Monday's move raised it a quarter of a percentage point, to 3.75 percent.
Traders and analysts said Mr. Parry mentioned that the Fed's goal was inflation near zero, and that the economy was likely to keep growing above long-run potential.
While Mr. Parry had made similar comments in the past, analysts said the impact was greater because they were the first words from the Fed after its latest interest-rate move.
The market's rebound was helped by a realization that second-quarter borrowing needs by the Government are much lower than originally thought. Traders said the Treasury cut the size of the weekly bill auctions by $800 million, to $22.8 billion. It was the third straight cut of this size, reflecting greatly reduced second-quarter borrowing needs and possibly stronger-than-expected tax receipts. The Government will announce today the size of next week's auctions of two- and five-year notes.

HEADLINE: Poor and Black Patients Slighted, Study Says

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE 

 BODY:
Seriously ill Medicare patients who are black and poor receive worse care than other equally sick Medicare patients in every type of hospital in America, a new study has found.
But the disparity is far less serious in big city teaching hospitals, where a majority of elderly black Medicare patients go for treatment, the researchers said. Because those hospitals provide better care than other types of hospitals, poor black patients paradoxically end up getting care that is just as good as that provided to other groups over all. 
 But the finding suggests that the quality of care may vary tremendously with a patient's race, and not, as other studies have suggested, with whether a person has insurance.
A second study found that in Veterans Affairs hospitals, blacks who suffered heart attacks received less medical treatment than whites, even though both groups have identical access to care. But surprisingly, 30 days after their heart attacks, blacks had an 18 percent higher survival rate than whites. Two years later, both groups had equivalent rates.
 
A Call for Soul Searching
 Although black and poor patients did not experience higher death rates in either study, said Dr. John Z. Ayanian, a medical instructor and health care analyst at Harvard Medical School, their quality of life after receiving medical treatment was lower than that of white patients with similar conditions.
Medical experts said the nation's doctors and nurses had some soul searching to do. "These studies should encourage all medical professionals to reflect on and explore the quality of care they provide" to black and poor patients, Dr. Ayanian said.
The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, Jesse Brown, said he was concerned about the possibility of "a racial bias in the delivery of care at V.A. hospitals."
The two studies appear today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
The first examined the quality of care given to 9,932 Medicare patients who were taken to the hospital for congestive heart failure, heart attack, pneumonia or stroke. Eleven percent were black, 10 percent poor and 5 percent both black and poor.
The patients were treated at 297 hospitals in 30 cities and towns in five states. Half of the hospitals were in large cities, 15 percent were in rural towns and 35 percent were advanced teaching hospitals in major cities.
Based on advice from panels of physicians, the researchers looked at the quality of care in each hospital. This included speed of admission to intensive care, how doctors and nurses performed on 241 clinical practices, length of stay, whether patients were sent home or to nursing homes and death rates one to six months after admission.
"Within each type of hospital and even within each individual hospital, patients from black or poor neighborhoods got less care," said Dr. Katherine L. Kahn, the study's lead author, who is an internist at U.C.L.A. and an analyst at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif.
Only 47 percent of the very sick black and poor patients were put into intensive care units, as opposed to 70 percent of other, similarly ill Medicare patients, Dr. Kahn said. Doctors and nurses conducted less thorough interviews and physical exams with black and poor patients and tended to discharge them from the hospital earlier and with unstable conditions like rapid heart beats.
Over all, Dr. Kahn added, the survival rate of blacks and whites was the same. This is because many more blacks went to urban teaching hospitals where the quality of care is much higher than at the other types of hospitals, she said.
In the second study, researchers examined data on 33,641 veterans who went to the nation's V.A. hospitals from 1988 to 1990 for treatment for heart attacks.
The 4,522 blacks treated were 33 percent less likely than whites to have catheters inserted into their hearts to look for damaged arteries, 42 percent less likely to have blocked arteries reamed with balloons or similar devices, and 54 percent less likely to undergo heart bypass surgery, said Dr. Eric Peterson, a Duke University Medical Center cardiologist who helped conduct the study, which was analyzed at the West Roxbury V.A. Hospital in Massachusetts.
In the Veterans Affairs system, black and white veterans have the same health care insurance and tend to come from similar socioeconomic backgrounds, Dr. Peterson said, so the disparity in treatment has to be explained in other terms.
While racism could be a factor, he said, the way the data were collected could also bias the picture. The study relied on brief descriptions of each patient's treatment noted at the time of hospital discharge and did not reflect the severity of each person's disease, he said.

HEADLINE: Tire Factory Shuts Doors In Dispute Over Safety

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

 BODY:
In an unusual legal tussle that temporarily threw 1,100 employees of an Oklahoma tire factory out of work, the owners of the plant abruptly closed it yesterday rather than follow a Labor Department directive to improve safety procedures there.
But tonight, after obtaining a judicial restraining order that for the moment blocked the directive from taking effect, the company reopened the plant and told its workers to report for the regular 11 P.M. shift. 
 The directive, issued to the Dayton Tire Company of Oklahoma City, included a $7.4 million fine, one of the largest ever issued by the department. Labor Department officials cast the action as part of a broad effort by the Clinton Administration to step up enforcement of Federal safety regulations. It came after one worker was crushed to death by a tire assembly machine last fall, several others were maimed and the company did nothing to improve safety conditions, the officials said.
The company's response to such enforcement -- simply shutting its doors -- was called outrageous by Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich in an interview today. He said it was the first time a company had responded in that way, and he threatened to challenge it in court.
 
A High-Stakes Test
 "If they are retaliating against their workers for complaining about safety violations, they are potentially breaking the law," Mr. Reich said in a telephone interview. "I do not want the factory shut down."
Mr. Reich had traveled to Oklahoma on Monday to personally issue the department's citation for "willful violations" of safety rules and notice of the fine, which the company is contesting.
In effect, the wrangling between labor officials and the tire company over the past day and a half quickly turned into a high-stakes test of the aggressiveness of the department's enforcement, with the fate of the workers' jobs hanging in the balance.
Even though the plant was operating tonight, both sides said they expected to be back in court later this week. Company officials reiterated vows to close down again if the directive stands.
The company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bridgestone Corporation, based in Japan and the second-largest tire manufacturer in the world, cast the Labor Department's directive as onerous and excessive and said it had been issued by overzealous bureaucrats.
 
Unplugging of Machinery
 The safety practices in question are technically known as "lockout-tagout" procedures, involving the service and maintenance of machinery. Federal safety regulations require that all such machinery be unplugged before any repairs are done.
Trevor C. Hoskins, a vice president for public affairs for the company, said from his office in Nashville that the company had its own procedures for servicing the machinery and that they were adequate. The death last October of 53-year-old Bob L. Julian, who was crushed when a tire assembly device started operating while he was servicing it, was an unfortunate accident, company officials said.
Other workers at the factory, which produces 35,000 tires a day in round-the-clock shifts, have ended up with mangled arms or lost fingers in the last several months, according to Labor Department records.
"This company is simply refusing to protect its workers," Mr. Reich said. "It is not difficult in our judgment, or expensive, to protect its workers and come into compliance with the law."
 
Changing Priorities?
 Union groups praised the Clinton Administration for taking such an aggressive stand. "I think it does represent a commitment to strong enforcement of job safety laws, which we welcome and think is long overdue," said Margaret Seminario, director of safety and health for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in Washington.
She and other union officials cast the enforcement action as symbolic of the change of priorities over those of the Reagan and Bush Administrations, which the union officials argued were very reluctant to prod companies into obeying safety laws.
But Joseph Kinney, executive director of the National Safe Workplace Institute, a private research group, said the move might be more a function of stronger economic times.
In the first year of the Clinton Administration, when politicians were primarily concerned about creating and retaining American jobs, the Labor Department collected $90 million in safety-related fines, $20 million less than in the last year of the Bush Administration, he said.
"The history of this is that when the economy is soft, the regulators back off," Mr. Kinney said. "And when it's strong, they turn the screws back on."

HEADLINE: Mayor to Offer Plan to Assist Minority Firms

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Three months after eliminating the most powerful part of an affirmative- action procurement program intended to aid companies owned by women and members of minority groups, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to announce a new, more modest initiative today to aid the same companies and other small businesses.
Under the plan, to be administered by the Department of Business Services, city procurement officials are to solicit bids for all city work from small companies and from those owned by women and members of minority groups. The work put up for bids is to include jobs that in the past have been deemed too small to warrant bids from more than five companies. 
 Because of the potential of broader participation in the bidding process, especially for smaller jobs, Mr. Giuliani's economic advisers say that hundreds of millions of dollars in city contracts will be available to small companies, many of them owned by minority-group members, that had previously been overlooked.
 
No Guarantees
 The new approach will replace the so-called 10-percent preference, an affirmative-action rule adopted under Mayor David N. Dinkins that allowed city agencies to accept bids that were as much as 10 percent higher than the lowest bid if it meant the winner would be a woman or a business owner from a minority group.
Although the new approach clearly lacks the financial leverage of the price preference rule, and provides no guarantees that more work will go to women or members of minority groups, it is designed to make the bidding process more accessible to small companies.
A "bid-match system," is to be set up, operated by the Department of Business Services and linking businesses to a computer; the system, officials said, will make information about small contracts available to more bidders. It will also match qualified companies with a contract being awarded, assuring that many more businesses are contacted and encouraged to bid.
"Small and minority- and woman-owned businesses will be able to find out, at the push of a button, about available procurement opportunities," said Rudy Washington, the city's Commissioner of Business Services, in a news release distributed late yesterday.
Officials said the most immediate change in the system would be to expand the procurement process for goods and services. The news release, which provided only a broad outline of the program and which officials declined to elaborate on, said $145 million in contract awards for goods and services would be made available to companies owned by women and members of minority groups that had previously been bypassed in the bidding process.
Under current policies, city contracts to buy goods that cost under $10,000 and to pay for services under $15,000, are offered to no more than five bidders, who are picked by city procurement officials.
 
Construction Work
 More changes are to be made within three months, yesterday's news release said, when the bidding process is amended for construction work. The release said small companies and those owned by women and minority-group members would be solicited in the bidding process for as much as $400 million in city work that has not in the past been available to them.
During his campaign, Mr. Giuliani said he was not eliminating the goal set under Mr. Dinkins of steering as much as 20 percent of the city's contracts to companies owned by women and members of minority groups. But it was clear that Mr. Giuliani was approaching that goal with less enthusiasm than his predecessor.
The procurement process, he said, "has to become an ethnic-, race-, religious-, gender- and sexual-orientation-neutral program."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Bankers Trust and Citicorp Report Large Trading Losses

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Traders at Bankers Trust and Citicorp bet wrong in world markets in the first quarter of 1994 -- a rough period for many investors -- and posted large losses in their trading activities for their own accounts, according to earnings reports released yesterday. The specific numbers were not disclosed, but analysts estimated each bank's loss at about $150 million.
While Bankers Trust had confirmed market reports of trading losses, the large losses at Citicorp were a surprise. 
 Profits from trading with customers helped both banks post small positive numbers for overall trading revenue. Trading revenue at Bankers Trust was $14 million in the first quarter, down from $346 million a year earlier. At Citicorp, trading revenue fell to $71 million, from $386 million in the first quarter of 1993.
In total, however, operating earnings were up sharply at Citicorp, and down substantially at Bankers Trust, compared with the corresponding quarter of 1993.
Other banks posted more modest trading declines than Citicorp and Bankers Trust, which are two of the most active traders among American banks.
The Chemical Banking Corporation, which also released its first-quarter results yesterday, said its trading revenue fell by 25 percent, to $185 million. J. P. Morgan & Company, also one of the most active banks in trading, said last week that its first-quarter trading revenue was down by 25 percent.
Traders were surprised by the rise in European interest rates, the yen's rise against the dollar and the speed of the rise in interest rates in the United States.
"It wasn't bad; we just didn't get it right," the chairman of Bankers Trust, Charles S. Sanford Jr., said after the bank's annual meeting yesterday.
Analysts said that they were encouraged that despite the turbulent markets the trading losses were not higher.
 
 
Citicorp's Results
 At Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, various accounting changes caused the reported profit to fall to $553 million, from $670 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. But excluding the charges, the bank's operating profit increased by 64 percent, to $609 million from $370 million.
The sharp increase was due mainly to a decrease of $424 million in the charges for bad loans and increased profits from banking business in Asia and Latin America.
Despite the trading losses, Citicorp's profitability -- as measured by its return on common equity -- rose to 20.1 percent, a high figure for a banking company, from 14.3 percent a year earlier.
"The bank's business did fine," John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, said in a brief interview after the bank's shareholder meeting yesterday. "We had a good quarter. Trading is a piece, but not an important piece."
He said Citicorp lost money in the first quarter trading for its own account in European and Latin American bonds. These losses were offset by profits from trading with customers.
Mr. Reed added that the trading losses might actually have some benefits for the bank: "I feel good about this. If one part of the bank goes up, up, up forever, you are going to lose your sense of perspective. We had a tough trading quarter that will probably help us be better in the future."
 Bankers Trust said its reported profits increased slightly, to $164 million from $155 million. But since the 1993 quarter included a $75 million charge for accounting changes, the bank's operating profit declined by 29 percent.
Bankers Trust, which has been the most profitable of the country's big banks, posted a modest return on equity of 15 percent for the quarter, down from 24 percent a year earlier.
The bank also said interest it earned on the bonds in its trading portfolio increased to $177 million in the first quarter from $117 million a year earlier, partly compensating for the trading losses.
Also partly offsetting the trading losses were higher revenues from trading derivatives. Bankers Trust mainly trades derivatives with its customers, corporations and investors that use them to hedge or take additional risks. The bank uses bonds and currencies, rather than derivatives, to trade for its own account.
The bank also engages in a number of less volatile businesses, including money management and various operating services. These businesses helped provide a base of $491 million in fees and other noninterest revenue.
Bankers Trust resembles a brokerage firm more than a traditional bank because it shuns lending money and instead specializes in underwriting and trading of securities and derivatives. Unlike most banks, Bankers Trust had no charges for bad loans last quarter, and indeed recovered $21 million from loans it had previously charged.
Chemical, the nation's third-largest banking company, reported first-quarter profits of $319 million, down from $374 million. Chemical said its 1993 results were increased by a $35 million gain related to accounting changes and $63 million in tax benefits. Taking those into account, Chemical's operating earnings increased 16 percent.
Chemical took a pretax charge of $48 million to cover the costs associated with closing 50 branches and eliminating 650 jobs.
The bank said its trading revenue fell 25 percent from a year earlier, mainly because of "a small loss" in trading securities issued in emerging markets.

HEADLINE: Environmental Factors to Be Calculated in G.D.P.

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
In a bow to Earth Week, the Commerce Department announced today that it would publish in early May the first results of its long-gestating effort at environmental accounting: a "green" tabulation of gross domestic product.
The project, believed to have been first proposed in the Ford Administration and formally under way since 1992, seeks to show the interaction of the economy and the environment and to ultimately allow better assessment of the country's standard of living and its sustainability. 
 Critics have contended that current G.D.P. figures are misleading because, in measuring the total output of goods and services, the broadest gauge of economic activity, they make no provision for factors like air pollution from factories or the depletion of mines and forests.
Many economists had assumed that the current system of calculation overstated G.D.P. But it appeared today that the system might actually push up G.D.P. estimates. Officials repeatedly avoided comment today on the release of preliminary figures for the project's first phase, which dealt with underground minerals. But if the findings show, for example, that American oil companies found more oil than they extracted, an upward adjustment might be made.
Such an outcome is plausible considering that the country relies on imported oil for more than 50 percent of its supplies and the fact that constantly improving technology makes more oil economically recoverable.
According to the American Petroleum Institute, the United States had proved reserves in 1992 that would last 9.7 years at that year's rate of production, up from a low of nine years in 1980.
"We do not have a sustainability problem, at least not in the near future," one department source said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Under the supplementary, or "satellite," G.D.P. accounts, natural and environmental resources are considered productive assets. Their depletion and degradation are treated like depreciation, subtracted from G.D.P. to arrive at net domestic product.
Conversely, additions to stocks and these assets are treated as capital formation in structures and equipment, and are added to G.D.P.
The department said it planned to publish its subsoil minerals results in the April issue of its Survey of Current Business, which is expected to be available on May 10. A minerals satellite account will be constructed retroactively for several decades, some data being available back to 1947.
The project, with an annual budget the department hopes to increase to $1.5 million from the current $400,000, does not involve expanded data collection.
The second phase of the project deals with renewable, above-ground resources like timber and fish. The initial estimates are expected sometime in 1995.
Then, perhaps in 1996, will come estimates for what the department described as "a broader range of issues, such as those related to the economic impact of degradation in air and water quality."
The satellite accounts, to be published once a year, will not replace the present G.D.P. compilation, which is published quarterly and revised in the subsequent two months. The formal designation of the new accounts is integrated economic and environmental satellite accounts, or Ieesa's.
When fully put into operation, the department said, "Ieesa's would permit identification of the contribution of natural and environmental resources by industry, by type of income and by product. Ultimately, accounts by region would add an important analytical dimension."
The department's Bureau of Economic Analysis was a pioneer in the environmental area in the mid-1970's, when it introduced estimates of the amount spent on pollution abatement and control.

HEADLINE: Zuckerman to Sue Transit Agency and the City

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Despite his decision on Monday to postpone closing on the sale of the New York Coliseum, Mortimer B. Zuckerman moved ahead yesterday with a court suit against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the city, saying the contract was not valid because they had failed to satisfy contract conditions.
Mr. Zuckerman, who has a contract to build a 2.1 million square-foot complex on the Coliseum property, said yesterday that he did not withdraw his suit because the postponement on Monday made no difference in the matters before the court. 
 "We still don't have an agreement," Mr. Zuckerman said, referring to his efforts to negotiate a reduced price for a smaller development on the site. "And as far as we are concerned we don't have a valid contract. We are just trying to protect our legal position."
On Monday, which had been the deadline for a closing on the property, Mr. Zuckerman exercised his right to a 55-day delay at the request of the Giuliani administration. Mr. Zuckerman stands to lose a $33.8 million down payment if he does not close.
State Supreme Court Judge Ira Gammerman yesterday set the start of a trial for June 1, a little more than one week before the 55-day postponement is up.
Among Mr. Zuckerman's concerns are that because of neglect, the garage on the property cannot be delivered in the condition specified in the contract.
The suit also charges that the city's Industrial Development Agency, the agency through which the developer is to receive certain tax benefits, cannot legally participate in the transaction because the project has a residential component.
John Cunningham, an M.T.A. spokesman, said there is no basis for the lawsuit.
"We were ready to close last Monday, we are ready to close today," Mr. Cunningham said.
The spokesman said the issue concerning the condition of the garage is not substantial because repairs could be made in a few days.
Speaking on the development agency's legal position, Mr. Cunningham said it was a point on which the M.T.A. has been challenged in the past.
"These are some of the same claims made by Coalition Against Columbus Circle when it tried to prevent the project from being built," Mr. Cunningham said. "They maintained that the I.D.A. was not authorized to participate because the project was mixed-use. We won in court on that point and expect to do so again."

HEADLINE: Stocks End Day Mixed; Dow Off 0.60

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In seesaw trading and with heavy volume, the stock market closed mixed yesterday as traders persuaded themselves that another rate increase by the Federal Reserve Board was imminent.
Traders had some basis for believing so. In a California speech reported around 1 P.M., Eastern time, yesterday, Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank in San Francisco and a proponent of higher rates, said, "We still have a way to go" in fighting inflation. 
 Mr. Parry gave his speech the day after the Fed raised short-term interest rates for the third time in less than three months.
The bond market, whose securities lose value when rates rise, understandably reeled from the news. But the stock market plunged even more steeply. Shortly before 1:45 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen 31 points. Then traders took less than an hour to bid up the Dow industrials to recover the lost ground. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 had a similar recovery.
Generally strong first-quarter earnings ought to have sustained the rally but did not. Chrysler, Philip Morris, Citicorp, GTE, Lockheed and Sprint all reported higher first-quarter profits. But after gyrating wildly, two stocks closed down and two closed up, but only feebly. The exceptions were Philip Morris, which closed up 1 3/4, to 51 7/8, and GTE, which closed up 1 1/2, to 31 5/8.
 
Dow Industrials Down
 Over all, the Dow and the S. & P. 500 were essentially unchanged yesterday and the Nasdaq composite index continued its decline. The Dow industrials fell 0.60 point, to 3,619.82, and the S. & P. 500 rose 0.08 point, to 442.54. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 7.60 points, to 712.85.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.33 point, to 245.37. Declining stocks outnumbered advancing stocks by 1,491 to 749. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 2.90 points, to 431.10.
Many traders took advantage of the lower prices for stocks and came in from the sidelines to buy. Volume yesterday for the New York Stock exchange totaled nearly 324 million shares, or more than 6 percent above this year's average of about 304 million shares.
Stock traders may deepen their concern about the effect of higher interest rates on housing. The Government is scheduled to report March housing starts today and the consensus estimate of Wall Street economists is for a 7.9 percent rise.
"There'll be a tremendous amount of interest in the housing numbers," said Mary C. Farrell, an investment strategist for Paine Webber. If the housing figure is higher, it will confirm traders' fears of inflation. If it is lower, the figure may accelerate some worries about an economy slowed by rising interest rates, Ms. Farrell said.
The new interest-rate arithmetic so far is painful for home buyers. One of the cheapest mortgages available goes for 8.26 percent, up from 7.13 percent in January. That means on a 30-year, $100,000 mortgage, the monthly payment has risen almost $80, to $750.
Yesterday, lumber prices fell for the 14th time in 16 trading sessions. Lumber futures, for May delivery, fell $7.10, to $326.90 for 1,000 board feet. The National Association of Home Builders, a trade group, reported yesterday that the percentage of home builders who said they had seen "good" sales so far this month had fallen to 43 percent from 45 percent in March.
Whirlpool, the appliance maker; Wickes Lumber, a retailer of building-materials products; Lennar, a home builder, and Armstrong World, a maker of floor coverings, nearly all fell in price. The exception was Wickes, which rose feebly, up 1/4, to 16 3/4, after reporting a quarterly loss last week.
The most active stock yesterday, at 10.9 million shares, was Intel, which has fallen for six straight sessions on a poor competitive outlook. It fell 1, to 57 1/2.

HEADLINE: More Banks Lift Prime

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
More banks raised their prime lending rates by half a percentage point yesterday, following the lead of some of the nation's largest banks after the Federal Reserve pushed up short-term interest rates.
On Monday, Citibank, the nation's largest bank, the fourth-ranked Chemical Bank and other big banks raised their base lending rates to 6 3/4 percent from 6 1/4 percent. 
 Yesterday, Bank of America and Chase Manhattan raised their prime rates to 6 3/4 percent from 6 1/4 percent, effective immediately.
 Wells Fargo of California, Crestar Financial of Richmond and Continental Bank of Chicago announced similar moves, as did Norwest in Minneapolis.
First Union said it lifted its prime rate in three states to 6 3/4 percent from 6 1/4 percent, affecting its home state of North Carolina as well as Georgia and Florida.
Other banks raising prime rates included Comerica Bank of Detroit; Corestates Financial of Philadelphia; First Fidelity Bancorp of New York; City National Bank of Beverly Hills, Calif.; Republic National Bank of New York, and Bank South of Atlanta.
The higher lending rates are effective immediately.
The prime rate is generally regarded as the rate at which banks lend to their best commercial customers. The rate also serves as a benchmark for credit card and other consumer lending rates.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chrysler Profit Surges to $938 Million

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 19

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation said today that it earned record profits on record revenues in the first quarter as sales of pickups, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles soared.
Narrowly exceeding the expectations of increasingly bullish auto industry analysts, Chrysler's earnings jumped to $938 million, or $2.55 a common share, up 77 percent from the quarter a year ago, excluding one-time charges. 
 The No. 3 auto maker's previous record profit for any quarter, $801 million, was in the second quarter of 1984.
For the quarter, Chrysler's revenue rose 21.1 percent, to $13.2 billion. The company's previous record was $12 billion, set in the fourth quarter of 1993.
 
 
Stock Falls $2.375
 But investors pummeled Chrysler shares today, along with other auto company stocks. The most heavily traded stock on the Big Board, Chrysler closed at $48.50 a share, down $2.375, perhaps a victim of great expectations. Shares of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company also closed down in active trading on the Big Board. G.M. closed at $55.25, down $1.625, and Ford finished trading at $56.375, down $1.50.
"No failure to generate a positive earnings surprise goes unpunished," said David Healy, an auto industry analyst with S. G. Warburg in New York, who saw little bad news in Chrysler's report. "Lord knows what it would have taken to remain unchanged."
Rising interest rates may have also frightened investors in the auto stocks, although automobile executives and many industry analysts contend that rates would have to soar more than two points before crimping sales. Gary C. Valade, Chrysler's chief financial officer, said that even a 1 percent jump in rates would raise the monthly car payment on a $15,000 vehicle by only $7, an amount that he said would not deter buyers.
In the first quarter last year, Chrysler earned $530 million after taxes. But after accounting for a one-time charge for future retirees' health benefits, Chrysler lost $4.4 billion. This year, there were no special charges, the company said.
Because fierce winter weather shut down some factories, Chrysler produced fewer vehicles than expected in the first quarter, Mr. Healy said. While the plants were able to operate, however, Chrysler was running them at about 111 percent of capacity -- in part by paying overtime.
"It's a struggle to produce as many popular vehicles as the market wants right now," Mr. Healy said. Chrysler reported that its dealers had already ordered almost as many trucks as it could make during the 1994 model year, which ends in August.
While production was somewhat constrained, the average pretax net profit per unit jumped 55 percent, to $1,980 in the first quarter of 1994, up from $1,280 in the first quarter of 1993 and $1,730 in the fourth quarter of 1993, Chrysler said.
In general, the growth in Chrysler's car sales trailed the industry average during the quarter. The company's car sales climbed 7.6 percent in the United States in the quarter, compared with a 15 percent jump for the industry, a lag that analysts attributed to production constraints on the new Neon subcompact.
Chrysler's light-truck sales increased 27.5 percent, compared with an industry average of 19.8 percent.
During the quarter, Chrysler gained a tenth of a point of market share in the United States, to 15.3 percent, on total vehicle sales of 565,215, the company said.
In a statement, Robert J. Eaton, the chairman and chief executive, said: "We see the steady improvement in industry sales continuing, and this, combined with the underlying strength of our car and truck business, has persuaded us to approve capacity increases and significant new hiring over the next three years."
Ford and G.M. are expected to report strong first-quarter earnings next week.
One lingering problem for Chrysler has been its failure to set aside enough cash to cover the pensions of future retirees. At the end of 1993, Chrysler had an unfinanced pension liability of $2.2 billion. During the first quarter, Chrysler set aside an additional $684 million, almost twice as much as it had planned. That puts the company ahead of its plan to finance its pensions fully by the end of 1995, Mr. Valade said.
Chrysler's cash on hand also surged in the quarter to $5.2 billion, from $3.5 billion a year earlier.
 
 
Less Money for Rebates
 As demand rose last year and new Chrysler cars and trucks appeared, the company cut its rebates and other incentives to customers. For the first quarter, the average incentive was $710, down from $970 a year earlier, but up from $650 in the fourth quarter of 1993.
Chrysler attributed the rise in incentives from late last year to its "National Mini-Van Sale." Chrysler has been offering rebates of at least $500 -- and in some cases as much as $2,600 -- on its mini-vans, to undercut the introduction of a rival van, the Windstar, by Ford. During the first quarter, that program gained Chrysler 4.1 points of mini-van market share, to 48.3 percent in the United States and Canada, according to the company.
Chrysler sold the wiring harness operations of its Acustar parts-making division on March 31. But its pretax gain on the sale of $196 million was deferred, to be recognized over five years, and so was not reflected in the first-quarter earnings.
On rising financing volume, the Chrysler Financial Corporation, Chrysler's finance arm, reported first-quarter earnings of $47 million, up from $37 million in 1993, before accounting changes.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metals Prices Fall On Latest Interest Rate Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Precious metals prices fell yesterday as the latest rise in American interest rates damped prospects that inflation will accelerate as the economy grows.
Prices were also pushed down after Zulu nationalists in South Africa agreed to join the country's first multiracial elections next week. South Africa is a top producer of gold and platinum. 
 Still, "the predominant thing is the higher interest rates curtailing the outlook for inflation," Leonard Kaplan, vice president with Imperial Bank in Los Angeles, said.
 
 
Gold Is Down $5.30
 Gold for June delivery, the most active futures contract, fell $5.30, to $373.20 an ounce, and May silver fell 5.5 cents, to $5.212 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange. July platinum fell $5 an ounce, to $388.60, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Commodity prices over all fell, also dimming prospects of renewed inflation. Lumber and wheat both fell, sending the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodity prices down 1.93, to 220.21, a four-month low. Oil prices also dropped.
On Monday, the Federal Reserve pushed up short-term interest rates for the third time this year in an effort to cool inflation that comes with economic growth. Investors often buy gold when inflation threatens the value of stocks and bonds.
And the reports from South Africa that tensions had eased over next week's elections "has been read by the market as to imply there are no problems in South Africa at all any more," George Milling-Stanley, an analyst with Lehman Brothers in New York, said.
On other commodity markets, lumber prices slid, extending a 20 percent decline in the last month, amid growing concern that higher interest rates will short-circuit an expected boom in housing.
May lumber fell $7.10, to $326.90 for 1,000 board feet, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the 15th decline in 17 trading days and the lowest price since Oct. 19.
 
 
Mortgage Rates
 Traders said they expected mortgage rates to rise further, depressing demand for new housing. Today, the Commerce Department is to report on housing starts during March.
Meanwhile, wheat futures fell to a six-month low amid perceptions that export demand is weak and that this year's crop will cover shortfalls caused by flooding last year in the Midwest. July wheat, the most actively traded contract, closed down 4.5 cents at $3.1425 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Oil prices fell on speculation that supplies were rising. At the New York Mercantile Exchange, May crude oil fell 16 cents, to $16.49 a barrel, while unleaded gasoline lost 1.27 cents, to 48.80 cents a gallon, and heating oil slipped 0.86 cent, to 46.17 cents a gallon.
Today's expiration of the May crude oil contract helped push prices lower, traders said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Its Drop In Stock and Bond Volatility

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday as stock and bond prices seesawed, raising concerns about the stability of American financial markets.
Stocks slipped for a second day after the Federal Reserve raised its rate on overnight bank loans for the third time this year, while bonds recouped some of yesterday's losses. Investors sold equities amid speculation that higher rates would hobble the economy and hurt corporate earnings. 
 "As long as the Fed is raising rates, the asset markets will be under pressure, and so will the dollar," said Peter Michaels, assistant vice president at Fuji Bank.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.7005 German marks, down from 1.7080 marks on Monday, after trading as low as 1.6957 marks.
 
Little Change vs. Yen
 Speculation that the Federal Reserve bought dollars for Japanese yen on behalf of the Bank of Japan lifted the dollar from the day's lows against the Japanese currency. It was little changed at 103.20 yen, down from 103.30 yen on Monday. The Fed declined to comment on whether it was active in the market.
Higher interest rates usually buoy the dollar by making dollar-denominated assets more attractive. This year's slump in American stocks and bonds kept the dollar from following rates higher, traders said. The rate on overnight bank loans is now 3.75 percent, up from 3 percent on Feb. 4, when the Fed raised the rate for the first time in five years.
But the dollar's failure to rally after the rate increase also prompted traders to sell it against the mark.
"People sold the dollar today because buying it yesterday didn't work," said Jerry Egan, managing director of foreign exchange at MTB Bank.
Similarly, the dollar did not rise last Thursday after Germany's Bundesbank cut its discount rate to 5 percent from 5.25 percent. The discount is the lowest rate banks pay to borrow from the German central bank.
"The Bundesbank cut rates, and the Fed raised them, but the dollar fell," said Chris Widness, an international economist at the Chemical Bank. That does not bode well for the dollar, he said.

HEADLINE: AT DINNER WITH: Katarina Witt;
Firepower Off the Ice

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

 BODY:
The moment arrived during dinner at our table for two when I looked across to Katarina Witt and said, "Katarina, tell me, what kind of man do you like?"
The figure skater, who has captivated judges and spectators alike with her both sizzling and poignant programs, met my eyes. 
 "Someone who I can steal horses with," she said.
Steal horses?
"It is a German expression," she explained. "Means someone you can share everything with, that you can share all sides with. Someone that is honest, trustworthy, funny -- a little bit of everything. He doesn't have to be handsome, doesn't have to be macho man. I hate macho man. I like a man who has weakness, who can cry. Men are taught not to cry. It is so stupid."
We had finished the main course at the Union Square Cafe -- she had salmon, having decided against tuna since the nets that tuna fishermen use often snare dolphins. It is a problem that concerns her.
During dinner, other patrons walked by, looked, and then whispered to one another. Discreetly, a couple at another table stole glances. "Are you often recognized on the street?" she was asked.
"Not always," she said. "I mean, I don't walk around with my skates."
Her tartness is softened with a smile. At one point, a couple came over and the woman politely said: "We were happy to see you in the Olympics, Katarina -- you did so well. Would you sign our napkin?" Obliging, Ms. Witt said, "Thank you."
Ms. Witt said that she especially enjoyed women showing appreciation for her skating. "Too many times women try to be competitive with each other," she said. "We should help support each other, rather than try to be better than each other."
She took a sip of her cappuccino. Her brown hair was pulled back into a ponytail. Her eyes are direct, her laugh quick and full, and there also lurks the substance of a highly competitive athlete -- she has won four world figure-skating championships and two Olympic gold medals -- and a woman confident in handling herself. She wore a black turtleneck sweater with a bright Versace vest of purple and green and yellow and red, and black designer jeans.
Ms. Witt was in New York between stops of the skating show Stars on Ice, in which she performs. But she is still buoyed from her achievement at the Winter Olympics in Lillehammer, Norway, in February.
Her performance in Lillehammer was unlike her presentations in previous Olympics. In Calgary in 1988, she skated to "Carmen" and, she admitted, "flirted my way through the program." On the ice in Lillehammer she exuded a different kind of passion when she skated to the anti-war song "Where Have All the Flowers Gone?" in the freestyle program.
Ms. Witt, at 28, is the virtual grande dame of the sport. Her stature seemed illuminated in a practice session in Lillehammer when two 16-year-old skaters, Oksana Baiul and Tanja Szewczenko, collided, and Ms. Witt hurried over to help. "I picked them up," she said, "and they were light as feathers."
In the technical program in the Lillehammer Olympics, she skated in what was for her an unusual guise. "I wore the Robin Hood -- like a man's costume -- because I didn't want to be accused of seducing the judges this time," she said. "And I like the Robin Hood character. So I wore an outfit up to my neck." She paused and, with a paradoxical smile, added: "But I think that leaves more to the imagination. Sexier than cleavage, no?"
But the freestyle program was different. Ms. Witt was the last skater to appear on the program. In her blood-red costume, before the 6,000 spectators in the arena and millions more watching on television, Ms. Witt delivered what she called her "message of peace" for war-torn Sarajevo.
It was in 1984 in Sarajevo, then a pretty, gaily-bannered town, that Ms. Witt, as an 18-year-old East German, won her first Olympic gold medal. "Now when you see the pictures on television of the people killed there, and houses bombed and children crying in pain, it breaks your heart," she said. "I wanted to say something about this. Send some message."
She had worked diligently for that opportunity in Lillehammer. "I did all those boring jumps in practice, week after week, over and over and over again," she said. "It was very hard on my body."
She knew she couldn't skate with the athleticism of some of the younger competitors. "It is a new generation of skaters," she said.
She believed, though, she could compete from an artistic standpoint. And while she felt she had little chance for a medal, she was skating, she said, for a "bigger purpose."
Though skating with customary grace, she missed the triple loop when her hand touched the ice, and turned her triple salchow into a double. When finished, she turned to the crowd with a wan smile. She spoke the words, "I am sorry." She felt she had failed. But the crowd thought otherwise; they were cheering.
"The whole building was clapping," she said. "I thought, 'Oh my God, they all understood what I wanted to say.' " She finished seventh in the competition, but was grateful for having achieved a goal.
She had come a long way from the grimness of Communist East Germany, and the sudden changes in her life precipitated by the collapse of the Berlin Wall and the end of Communism in East Germany in 1989. She had made the transition from the ice princess whom the Stasi, the East German secret police, monitored closely, to the "older, more mature" woman who now lives "spontaneously," and with, she says, "bewusst."
" 'Bewusst' is a German word, I don't know how you translate, but it is living with a full mind, that you are aware of the moment and enjoying it," she said. "When I was younger, I thought of winning the competition and going on to another. I did not fully appreciate the experiences. But when I skated in Lillehammer, I wanted to be conscious of everything I was doing, and soak it in."
For all her accomplishments, some in Germany believe that she was once a spy, some a Communist apologist, some a seeker of faded glories.
"One day my father calls me in my apartment in Berlin," Ms. Witt said, "and he says, 'Katarina, did you see the newspaper this morning?' I said no. He said, 'It says you were a spy for the Stasi.' Never! I was followed constantly. They even bugged my hotel room, and in a report, said that I had sex with an American from 9 to 9:07. I was just talking with the man in English, but people who were monitoring this didn't speak English, didn't know what to report. So they said sex. I laughed when I heard this. It was so stupid. But they had contacted me to spy. I said, 'I am no spy, I am a skater.' "
Her privileged position in East Germany sometimes resulted in her being sniped at and booed in the West. "Some said I defended the old way because I had had special advantages," she said. "Sometimes I even now feel like a stranger in my country. But I knew there would be problems because I had seen the world as a skater. And now? A lot of people in eastern Germany have lost jobs, rents went up, food costs went up, unemployment went to 20 percent. Freedom is good, but it is not easy."
At the Olympics in Lillehammer, Ms. Witt had an opportunity to observe the other skaters. About Nancy Kerrigan, she said: "She needs to learn a lot. She's now a celebrity, not just a skater. She's stepping out of sports, and she meets the yellow press, who haven't followed the sport. It happened to me. They don't know me totally like the sports writers, and don't respect what you have done. They don't look at you so much as a skater, but as a person."
Ms. Witt said she couldn't believe it when Tonya Harding made the tearful appeal about her laces to the judges at rinkside. "I thought, 'Girl, get real,' " she said. "I was not sympathetic to her. She has now had three or four incidents in competition when something breaks -- a blade, a dress, something. I know she has had a tough life, but a lot of people have had a tough life. I grew up, it wasn't a free country. I hope she gets with people who care about her, and help her make a new environment for her."
When Miss Baiul finished her freestyle program and came backstage, she was in tears. "I asked someone, 'What's wrong with Oksana?' They said, 'She just won the gold medal.' When I won the gold medal in '84 and '88, I was laughing for joy. Oksana, though, is a good skater for her age -- no, an incredible skater. But maybe she will find she will need more personality. She is so young. She can be wonderful."
Ms. Witt's life now includes activities ranging from lending her name to save endangered animals to anti-war groups, to, well, the social whirl. For awhile, she dated Richard Dean Anderson, star of the former television series "MacGyver." "But he lived in Los Angeles, I lived in Berlin, and it was very difficult," she said. Of the other men she has been linked to, like Boris Becker, the German tennis star, she said: "It was just yellow press. Not true."
As for Alberto Tomba, who first sought her attentions at the Olympics in Calgary, she recalled: "He came backstage during the skating and I didn't know who he was, but he was wearing two gold medals around his neck. It was ridiculous. Nobody wears medals to another sport. I said, 'Wow, in which sport did you win those?' It was like shooting him with a gun. He was a big Italian hero, but I am not too interested in ski sport." She laughed. "We became friends. Not romantic friends, just friends."
Ms. Witt lives for most of her non skating year in Berlin, with two roommates -- both men. "It is like something I would have done 10 years ago, if I was in college and not skating and the Government would have allowed it," she said. "We are just friends, these guys, and when I'm not training, I'm going to the ballet, or a concert, or the movies. Like normal people."
She has also been looking for a part-time apartment in Manhattan and thinks she's found one overlooking Central Park. "You wouldn't believe the view -- spectacular, right above the trees," she said.
A platter of cookies arrived at the table and Ms. Witt broke off a piece of the lone chocolate chip cookie -- only a piece, ever mindful of her figure.
Over the last few years, she has skated in touring shows -- her television version of "Carmen" with Brian Boitano won an Emmy -- and has done figure-skating commentary on television. She plans to skate in shows for perhaps two more years. Then?
"I have some things on the table," she said cryptically. "I will let you know."
Ms. Witt says she will now leave the competitive stage to the younger skaters. "I don't want to compete," she said. "I want to skate for the joy. I get so nervous in competition. I get always sick. I had pressures enough in my life from skating."
She retains ambitions, to be sure, and dreams. "I want to see sunrises in the mountains," she said. "You never get to see such things enough in a lifetime. I want to see more.
"But right now, in the show I'm in, one of the programs I skate is my Sarajevo message, and the crowds go bananas. I know this is maybe naive, but one day I hope will be peace in the world. Maybe one day the flowers will come back."

HEADLINE: Reviews/Music;
Old, Old Orchestra Steps Out With a New Face

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
When the Dresden Staatskapelle went on its first concert tour, Shakespeare was 11 years old and Kepler had yet to discover the laws of planetary motion. But the orchestra's current tour, in more mundane times, is no mere road trip. It is the Dresden's first visit to the United States with its current music director, Giuseppe Sinopoli; it is also an attempt to reaffirm the orchestra's achievements as it adjusts to life in post-Communist Germany.
So there was a certain gravity to its first concert in Carnegie Hall on Monday night (its second was last night). The curious thing was that though the Dresden is probably the oldest organized group of musicians in the world, it seemed to be seeking its voice. In fact, under Mr. Sinopoli's direction the orchestra sounded much less experienced and coherent than either the Vienna or the Berlin Philharmonic, merely striplings by comparison, which have also passed through town in recent months. 
 Of course, there was that characteristic Middle European string tone -- sleek and warm -- and a love of legato that seems to be an infallible sign of long performing traditions in Europe. But Brahms's Second Symphony seemed in need of polish. The Allegretto lacked both the pristine attacks that can give that movement an edge and the supple dance pulse Brahms emphasized with his grace notes. The horns and woodwinds sounded a bit thin-bodied and overly exposed, as if they had not yet worked out textures and balances for their chordal proclamations. Even in a much more impressive performance of Schoenberg's "Verklarte Nacht," the interpretation had a detachment that made for a peculiar evening of music making.
It was impossible to sense in these sounds the imposing tradition of an orchestra founded in 1548. Heinrich Schutz was once Dresden's music director. So were Wagner and Fritz Reiner, Praetorius and Herbert von Karajan. Beethoven referred to theDresden orchestra as the best in Europe; so did Jean Jacques Rousseau. As the orchestra of the Dresden State Opera, the ensemble also presented premieres of "Tannhauser," "Salome," "Elektra" and many works that have been lost to the changing tastes of previous centuries.
There was some fear, a few years ago, that the orchestra's great heritage would fall prey to the changing economy in a united Germany; players' wages were then just 60 percent of their colleagues' from former West German terrain. But an orchestra spokesman said only 15 players had been replaced during the last five years and the comparative wage level had risen to about 80 percent. The tradition has not been seriously disrupted.
So some responsibility for the playing has to be placed at the baton of Mr. Sinopoli. He is so clearly an intelligent musician, so intent on stripping away expressive excess and so interested in laying bare the procedures at work in a composition that it was exasperating when he showed fragments of skeletons without putting the flesh back on them.
Mr. Sinopoli was trained as a doctor and a psychiatrist before becoming a composer and conductor, and he has said that he seeks to make sense out of music's psychological complexities. There are times -- in his recordings of Bruckner, for example -- when he gives coherence to unusual contrasts and sudden shifts in character.
But somehow the Brahms symphony lost all of its mystery under the light of this kind of examination; the music's contrasting timbres and its accumulation of themes seemed almost commonplace. There actually seemed to be less detail because everything assumed the same importance. The approach worked better in "Verklarte Nacht," an unimpeachably neurotic work. For here the swells and gentle attacks of the strings had an almost organic quality. And Mr. Sinopoli gave the phrases the character of hushed, melancholic dialogue. There was not much transfiguration, but that seemed to be Mr. Sinopoli's choice: he was presenting a portrait rather than a drama.
As for the orchestra itself, it seems to be in a time of transition that one day may be remembered as just a passing instant in a distinguished history. (Chris Lee)

GRAPHIC: Photo: Giuseppe Sinopoli conducting the Dresden Staatskapelle on Monday night during a concert at Carnegie Hall. (Chris Lee)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
G.E.'s Bright New Idea: A Seven-Year Light Bulb

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
A long-life household light bulb designed to last about seven years in normal use will soon reach the market, the General Electric Company's lighting division said yesterday.
The bulb, known in the industry as an E-lamp because it uses electronic controls, will go on sale in Europe within weeks and in the United States before the end of the year, G.E. said. 
 Producing the light of a 75-watt regular incandescent bulb but consuming only 23 watts of power, the household version of G.E.'s Genura E-lamp will probably be priced around $20 at retail in the United States, the company said.
 
Decades in Development
 The technology, called a compact-reflector lamp, has been in development for decades, and smaller companies have attempted to bring versions to the market over the years. But G.E.'s introduction is the first by a company with mass-market reach.
"The concept has been around for a long time," said John E. Breen, vice president for technology at G.E. lighting. "The problem was to turn it into a reality. We have had a lot of breakthroughs in the past nine months to make this happen."
Although E-lamps look similar to common incandescent bulbs, they work much differently. An incandescent provides light by forcing electric power through a thin wire filament until it glows brightly.
The E-lamp has no filament. Instead, electronic components in the base convert ordinary household current into high-frequency power that is fed to an electrical coil. The coil excites a gas in the bulb to make invisible ultraviolet light, which a phospher coating inside the bulb, similar to the inner coating of a fluorescent lamp, converts into visible light.
The advantages of the E-lamp are supposed to be its low electricity consumption and long life -- about 10,000 hours, in ordinary use, G.E. said. That would be about 10 times the life of a standard bulb. G.E. officials said the E-lamp technology was still evolving and that it might be possible to double or triple the bulbs' operating lives.
Unlike compact fluorescent lights that have been developed as an economical, low-energy alternative to incandescent bulbs, the E-lamp is about the same size and shape as a conventional bulb. This means it will fit into lamps too small for the longer fluorescent bulbs.
 
Spotlight to Be First
 The first model E-lamp will be a reflector spotlight for use in commercial applications, where the cost of changing bulbs is a substantial expense. Household sizes are expected to be introduced subsequently.
The Genura E-lamp bulbs will be manufactured at a plant in Nagykanizsa, Hungary, which G.E. acquired in 1990 when it purchased the Tungsram Company, one of Hungary's largest industrial companies.
G.E., with annual sales of $60 billion, traces its corporate history to 1878, when Thomas A. Edison established the Edison Electric Light Company, based largely on his invention of the light bulb. It was renamed General Electric in 1892.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The electronically controlled E-lamp is designed to last seven years. A bulb equal to a 75-watt incandescent light will cost about $20. (General Electric)

HEADLINE: Wrong Way to Control Spending

 BODY:
An "entitlement cap" -- putting a tight ceiling on spending for huge programs like Social Security and food stamps -- has been approved by the Senate in an amendment now before House-Senate conferees. Though non-binding, the vote is nonetheless important because the idea is gathering political momentum. It is likely to come up for a vote in the House later this year and be reviewed by a bipartisan commission that will report to the President by Dec. 1.
The impetus for the cap is understandable. Entitlement spending is the fastest-growing part of the Federal budget. But a cap is ill advised. The one embraced by the Senate would apply a hatchet where a scalpel would do better. The misdirected whacks would knock out health-care bills that promise universal coverage and needlessly threaten programs that are not pushing up the deficit. 
 Entitlement programs pay benefits to eligible applicants according to established formulas. Under the 1993 deficit reduction law, they are permitted to grow with impunity as long as Congress does not alter the underlying formulas that govern them. Indeed, they are the only programs that are expected to rise quickly over the next several years.
Just two entitlements, Medicaid and Medicare, account for almost all the projected increases in the deficit. All other entitlements are expected to stay relatively constant over the next 10 years. The way to fix the deficit is thus to pass health care reform -- not blindly chop every entitlement in sight.
Under the cap, sponsored by Senators Sam Nunn and Pete Domenici, entitlement spending would be allowed to rise along with inflation and natural increases in the number of eligible beneficiaries. If spending exceeded the caps, entitlements other than Social Security would be cut back.
A perverse fallout is that health-care reform would be ruled out. Universal coverage costs a lot of money. President Clinton would raise part of the money with taxes. But under the Nunn-Domenici cap, entitlement spending could not exceed pre-set caps no matter how much revenue Congress was willing to raise.
Because health-care costs are spiraling, Medicare and Medicaid costs are doing the same. That problem calls for a targeted solution. A broad assault on all entitlements is unwarranted.

HEADLINE: One Mexican, One Honest Vote

BYLINE: By Bernard Aronson; Bernard Aronson was Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs from June 1989 through July 1993.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The most critical challenge facing Mexico is to insure that the presidential election in August is considered legitimate.
A crisis of confidence in the election could lead to significant capital flight and pressure on the peso, putting economic recovery at risk. If the election is deemed fraudulent, moreover, the implicit threat of renewed civil violence, present since the Zapatista rebellion in Chiapas in January, could materialize. 
 Finally, the next president must lead the nation through simultaneous economic and political revolutions. Their outcome will determine Mexico's future. He cannot succeed if his mandate to govern is permanently in doubt.
Coincidentally, both revolutions, though gathering force for years, were launched formally on Jan. 1. On that day, the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect and the Zapatista rebellion erupted in Chiapas, the poorest state. Ironically, both have been propelled by the pioneering reforms of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's administration.
Mexico's long-term bet is that Nafta -- and the open-market reforms the treaty institutionalizes -- will attract the foreign investment necessary to modernize quickly enough to meet the needs of a rapidly growing population, half of which is under 25. Already in the first two months of 1994, foreign investment has increased 143 percent. And Mexico just became the first Latin American country to join the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
But integration into the global economy will also accelerate the social dislocation that rapid modernization inevitably brings to a developing economy. More then 25 percent of the population still makes its living from agriculture; many barely subsist on unproductive, quasi-collective farms that cannot compete with U.S. agriculture.
As tariffs on U.S. farm products fall, the inevitable migration of millions of rural Mexicans to the overburdened cities will accelerate. This will create new demands for clean water, sanitation, housing, electricity and urban employment. This economic and social transformation cannot be managed successfully within Mexico's traditional political order.
The Chiapas uprising started as a local, indigenous rebellion. It soon touched, and came to symbolize, widespread popular demands for greater democratization. To insure stability, Mexico must evolve rapidly from a one-party system dominated by a powerful president into a full-fledged multiparty democracy with an independent congress, judiciary, and state and local governments.
The governing and opposition parties have agreed on reforms to strengthen the independence of the Federal Electoral Institute, which organizes national elections, and to commission an independent audit of voter rolls. And Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, the candidate of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, called this weekend for greater democratization of the political system. Still, deep distrust remains because of past election irregularities, including suspicions left over from the 1988 election. And dangers loom.
The old guard of the PRI, threatened by the Salinas reforms, may try to preserve the option of fraud if they fear their party will lose the presidency. Even if the elections are honest, radical forces in the opposition may cry "fraud!" if they lose. Unless refuted persuasively, such charges will be like dropping lighted matches into political gasoline.
A door to a solution was opened when the Government and opposition agreed, for the first time, to invite foreign observers -- or "visitors," as they are called. The Congress, which met yesterday on electoral reforms, is expected to endorse this initiative soon. Mexico needs more than a group of "notables" arriving on election day. As soon as possible, it needs to establish an agreed-upon process of international oversight that will guarantee the electoral rules, mediate grievances and build legitimacy into the process each step of the way.
The United Nations, the Organization of American States or both are best equipped to play such a role. If their presence cannot be negotiated, an independent group -- Mexican, international or mixed -- should be selected by the political parties and given the mandate, funds and technical means to scrutinize the electoral process and make a final judgment.
The United States must come down squarely -- but carefully -- in support of democratization. If Washington appears overbearing, it will touch off a nationalist reaction that will make it more difficult for Mexicans to press for a political opening.
The Clinton Administration must not give the electoral process an uncritical stamp of approval out of deference to the Government. Nor should powerful figures in our Congress imply falsely that only the defeat of the PRI will prove the election legitimate. Instead, the U.S. should strongly support independent oversight and make it clear privately that our judgment of the outcome will be decisively guided by the observers' verdict.
Mexico's turmoil represents the birth pangs of a complex and proud developing nation struggling to enter the 21st century as a modern democracy. The U.S. can neither dictate the outcome of the twin revolutions nor remain aloof from them. Striking the proper balance is the principal challenge in our policy toward Mexico.

HEADLINE: CLINTON SUPPORTS WIDER AIR STRIKES AGAINST THE SERBS

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
President Clinton today approved a proposal for the wider use of NATO air power to protect Gorazde and other United Nations-designated "safe areas" in Bosnia and Herzegovina, senior Administration officials said. They said the President had directed his advisers to begin consulting immediately with European allies.
The United States will also explore ways to tighten economic sanctions against Serbia, which is supplying the Bosnian Serbs who are threatening Gorazde, the officials added. The harder look at sanctions comes even as the Russians and Europeans are calling for a meeting with the United States and the United Nations on a timetable for eventually lifting them. 
 And in a concession to the Europeans and the Russians, who have sought a larger role in devising a peace plan for Bosnia, the Administration has agreed to discuss the merits of a high-level international conference and a more coordinated approach.
In Bosnia, the Serbs seized weapons today from a United Nations-guarded site, but returned most of them after threats from Moscow. [Page A13.]
The proposal for broader air strikes will begin to be discussed informally at a regular weekly meeting of NATO representatives in Brussels on Wednesday and will be formally presented as part of a package of military and diplomatic initiatives to the North Atlantic Council, NATO's governing body, in the next few days. It calls for NATO to demand that the Serbs withdraw heavy weapons from an area around five of the six Muslim enclaves -- Gorazde, Srebrenica, Tuzla, Zepa and Bihac -- or face punitive air strikes, just as they did in the Bosnian capital, Sarajevo, after NATO issued a similar ultimatum.
The situation in the sixth enclave, Sarajevo, and how to enhance NATO protection there will also be reviewed.
Gorazde may be treated as a special case under the proposal, because Gorazde is in imminent danger of falling to the Serbs. But even some senior Administration officials were unclear about whether that meant that the United States would push an urgent plan to save the town of 65,000 people or essentially regarded it as a lost cause.
Bosnia's Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic, telephoned Secretary of State Warren Christopher today to tell him that NATO must take "immediate and decisive action" to prevent a massacre in Gorazde, which he said might fall tonight, Bosnian officials said. Mr. Christopher reportedly offered no assurance that help was on the way, telling Mr. Silajdzic that he would convey the message to Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Clinton declined today to spell out exactly what the new plan would entail, but he told reporters that his extensive discussions with his advisers today had dwelled on "exactly how" the allies should enlist more military force to put pressure on the Serbs. He said he and his aides had also reviewed "whether the other NATO allies would be willing to do it and what the ups and downs would be and what else we could do to get this thing going."
 
A Shift in U.S. Policy
 The proposal for broadening the air strikes is a shift in American policy toward Bosnia and reflects the Administration's response to sharp criticism over NATO's failure to halt the Serbian offensive against Gorazde. NATO has made two largely symbolic air strikes near Gorazde in response to requests by United Nations commanders as a means of slowing the fighting and coaxing the Serbs back to peace talks. The strikes were too modest to make an impression on the Serbs, who continued their assault on the town.
The White House wants to find a way to revive a peace initiative that has been frozen by Serbian intransigence and to restore the credibility of American leadership without getting drawn into a complicated ethnic war.
The United States is limited in how much it can ask NATO to do in Bosnia. Mr. Clinton has refused to send American peacekeeping troops to Bosnia, saying he did not want Americans to be involved in a "shooting gallery." Last month the United States opposed a United Nations request for full financing of 8,500 additional non-American troops.
But on Monday, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali asked NATO to authorize air strikes to protect all the safe areas in Bosnia. The American proposal will build on Mr. Boutros-Ghali's proposal, senior Administration officials said.
 
NATO Has Acted Narrowly
 Although NATO already has the technical authority to stage air strikes against Serbian forces to protect the Bosnian enclaves, so far it has acted only narrowly, to protect United Nations peacekeepers. Senior Administration officials have said they believe that it is politically necessary for NATO to give formal approval to an expanded mandate.
In a letter on Monday to the NATO Secretary General, Manfred Worner, Mr. Boutros-Ghali proposed a broadening of the basis for using force to prevent attacks against civilians.
But in military terms it is still a relatively narrow tactical rather than strategic approach, both with regard to what military targets can be hit and what geographical areas can be included. Strikes would be limited to the safe areas, and targets would be restricted to artillery, mortars and tanks, not secondary targets like supply lines, command centers, ammunition dumps and communications installations.
But Administration officials suggested that they would like to see a broader use of air strikes that might involve some strategic targets.
On the diplomatic front, the United States is eager to seize upon Russia's deep humiliation over winning Serbian cease-fire pledges only to be double-crossed. The Administration hopes to devise a high-level approach with Moscow that might help press the Serbs to return to the negotiating table.
 
Yeltsin Urges Summit Talks
 With Russia's leaders joining the West in condemning Serbian aggression, Mr. Clinton told reporters that he was "intrigued" by a proposal by President Boris N. Yeltsin to hold a summit meeting of Russian, American and European leaders aimed at bringing an end to the two-year-old war.
"It deserves serious consideration, and I want to discuss it with him and with the other nations that would be involved," Mr. Clinton said.
The United States consistently rejected earlier Russian suggestions for such a meeting, both to keep Russia on the periphery of the policy and to avoid engaging in a high-profile meeting that might not produce a unified and decisive approach.
Later in the day, senior White House and State Department officials said Mr. Clinton was not considering a meeting of heads of state.
 
Clinton Just 'Being Polite'
 "I think what the President was doing was being polite," a senior Administration official said. "This is something you can only do once at the heads of state level. I don't think anyone believes this is the moment to do it when we're so far away from a peace agreement."
Officials added that American attention to Russian and French proposals for an international conference would during the next few days remain secondary to the efforts to win approval from the Europeans for wider NATO attacks.
The Yeltsin idea was also met with skepticism by other NATO governments. "To be successful it has to be well prepared," Spain's Foreign Minister, Javier Solana, said in a telephone interview from Madrid. His country has 1,500 troops in Bosnia. He added, "We can't risk that it would fail."
Mr. Christopher telephoned the French Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, today to ask him about the French view, senior French officials in Paris said.
Mr. Juppe, who was the architect of the initiative on safe areas, told Mr. Christopher that his Government strongly supports the use of more aggressive air strikes to protect the besieged enclaves.
 
Britain and Canada Reluctant
 By contrast, officials of Britain and Canada expressed reluctance to authorize NATO air strikes to protect all six safe areas in Bosnia.
The tougher American position comes amid calls by a number of key Democratic lawmakers to use more American air power -- but not commit American troops -- to press the Serbs on the battlefield and persuade them to return to the negotiating table.
"It's time to use the full weight of U.S. and NATO warplanes in Bosnia," said the House Democratic Whip, David E. Bonior of Michigan. "It's time to pound the Bosnian Serbs into submission."
Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said: "I think almost certainly you have to have a more robust reaction by NATO and the United Nations here. There's been a real humiliation of both organizations, and we simply cannot take the kind of brutality that we have seen from the Serbs in Gorazde without some kind of response."
