HEADLINE: Toys Now, Computers Tomorrow?

BYLINE: By John Markoff, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: San Francisco, April 19

 BODY:
Will video-game machines be the supercomputers of tomorrow? Or, put another way, will Microsoft's software hegemony be supplanted by Sonic the Hedgehog software?
 Questions of that sort are troubling some computer designers and executives, who are wondering whether the personal computer industry may be ripe for a fall -- soon to be overtaken by $250 video-game players and computerized boxes for the television set-top. Consumer devices that Nintendo, Sega and Sony plan to introduce over the next year will outstrip the processing power of the fastest desktop computers from Apple and I.B.M., and the speediest personal-computer chips from Intel and Motorola.
 Most personal computer makers scoff at the notion that they could be unseated by such consumer gadgets.
 'The personal computer industry isn't going to slow down any time soon,' said Bob Metcalfe, publisher of Infoworld, a personal computer newspaper. 'They're all in the business of slitting each others' throats while performance skyrockets.'
 But some industry experts recall the hubris of the big mainframe computer companies 15 years ago. In those days, most mainframe giants dismissed the PC as a hacker's toy unsuitable for business use -- only to watch brash new personal computer makers win the hearts and desktops of Corporate America and a college dropout from Seattle named Bill Gates ascend to the industry summit.
 Most mainframe makers have since failed or withdrawn from the field, and the remaining leader, the International Business Machines Corporation, is making money from its PC's while trying to wring profits from a mainframe business that seems to be drying up quickly. But now, personal computer makers may be no more able to take advantage of the fastest computing technologies than were mainframe computer vendors a decade ago.
 'I'm struck by the quandary personal computer makers are in,' said Howard Lincoln, chairman of Nintendo of America. His company plans next year to offer its $250 Project Reality video-game player, which will surpass the computing performance of even the most powerful personal computers. Besides games with interactive, TV-quality video and sound, the Project Reality player will also act as a communications device, over cable television networks.
 And in terms of its ability to manipulate large amounts of data, the Project Reality player will be able to operate more powerfully than the original Cray 1 supercomputer, which astounded the computing world with its speed in 1976.
 'If you put something this powerful and this cheap in the market,' Mr. Lincoln said, 'what happens to everybody else?'
 
Applications Raised Demand
 Demand in the personal computer industry was heightened by the creation of new applications -- spreadsheets, word processing, electronic mail; it did not simply take over old mainframe functions like payroll processing and customer billing. And now consumer electronics companies, which have already sold millions of video-game machines, are developing systems that they hope will soon offer a broad range of consumer applications for which personal computers hold no particular edge. And this home market is potentially much larger than the $66 billion annual market for personal computers.
 'This is the last frontier,' said Jim Clark, the former chairman of Silicon Graphics Inc., a leading maker of powerful computer-graphics work stations that can cost $10,000 or more. Mr. Clark recently left Silicon Graphics to form his own company, which is seeking alliances with consumer electronics companies to make computerized devices that would sell for a few hundred dollars. 'We're talking about creating true consumer computers,' he said.
 These new consumer machines go beyond being faster and cheaper to represent a much more fundamental transformation.
 'The trend is for the fastest to also be the smallest and cheapest,' said John Moussouris, cofounder of Microunity, Inc., a Silicon Valley chip maker. 'This will continue to disrupt the computer industry to a greater degree than the auto disrupted the horse and buggy, or the calculator disrupted the slide rule.'
 Personal computer executives deny that the new class of video-game machines and set-top 'interactive TV' players will be a threat, contending that they are highly specialized machines without the flexibility of the personal computers and without the range of software applications that suits PC's for a variety of professional, home-office and leisure activities.
 But the new technology renegades say that increasingly, like its mainframe predecessor, the personal computer industry is too bound to its huge installed base of products to make radical shifts toward new technology. Indeed, today's personal computer industry is even more wedded to a narrow set of 'architectures' than was the mainframe business.
 There were seven competitors to I.B.M. in the 1960's and 1970's; today there are only two basic personal computer designs: machines based on Intel chips and Microsoft operating systems, and machines based on Apple Computer designs.
 Today's consumer-oriented computing devices, by contrast, are free to follow where computing technology wants to lead. In the past computers were used almost exclusively for calculation and control. Now a new wave of computing is shifting the focus to communications. Supercomputing power is being harnessed to make home machines simple to use and to make it easier for people to communicate with each other through video, sound and data.
 
Long Learning Curve
 That will represent a departure from the personal computer, which despite great strides toward 'user friendliness,' still requires considerable time and effort to learn to use.
 'The conventional computer industry is going to be the funky, behind-the-times part of the business,' said Charles Ferguson, a consultant based in Cambridge, Mass.
 He predicts that the transition will present a new opportunity for Asian electronics giants. 'The design and software will be overwhelmingly America,' he said. 'But it's also going to be the Japanese and Koreans who will manufacture this stuff.'
 Also helping drive computing into the consumer-products realm is the inexorable trend in chip technology. For more than three decades, the number of transistors squeezed onto a single silicon chip has doubled approximately every 18 months. In the 1970's the world's fastest computers had more than 100,000 chips; by the end of the 1990's the fastest machine will be on a single chip.
 All of this can make for strange chip fellows. Several years ago, when designers at Kendall Square Research, the supercomputer maker, set about manufacturing their newest processor chip, they chose the same Sharp Electronics factory line in Japan that produces the control chips for the Sharp Wizard 'personal organizer' which sells for less than $500.
 And currently, looking to stay at the top of the supercomputer race, Cray Research has secretly turned to Microunity to provide microprocessors for its fastest massively parallel supercomputers. But Cray will have to share the chips with makers of television set-top boxes and videophones. Microunity's superchip is planned to execute a billion operations a second, more than 10 times Intel's fastest Pentium processor.
 On the software side, economics seems to be pulling toward the consumer market. In 1993 Sonic the Hedgehog II, the standard bearer for Sega's line of home video games was a $400 million software best seller, dwarfing almost all of the most popular business software titles for personal computers.
 Does this mean that the likes of NBA Jam will be the 'killer application' of the 90's, as Lotus 1-2-3 was for personal computing in the 80's? It is too early to say.
 But certainly, big money-makers like these are providing the financial wherewithal for creating a new industry, said Bruce Lupatkin, a financial analyst at Hambrecht & Quist, a San Francisco-based investment firm.
 'The next 10 years in computing,' Mr. Lupatkin said, 'are going to be driven by automating the consumer experience.'

HEADLINE: Defense Chief Says North Korea Could Soon Build 4 A-Bombs

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, April 21

 BODY:
Secretary of Defense William Perry said this morning that North Korea was "within weeks" of removing enough fuel from its largest nuclear reactor to make four or five new nuclear weapons. He added that "it is critical" that international inspectors be permitted into the country to monitor the operation.
For more than a year American officials have been closely watching the reactor, fearful that a new harvest of spent fuel could give the North the raw material to turn the few weapons it may now possess into a much larger arsenal. 
 Inspectors who were allowed into North Korea last month for a partial inspection of the sites said the North was adding capacity to its reprocessing plant, which would convert the spent fuel into weapons-grade plutonium.
Mr. Perry did not say what kind of evidence United States officials have to make them think that the removal of the fuel is imminent. But replacing the fuel rods in the reactor would require shutting the site down, and that could be observed by surveillance satellites.
Mr. Perry's comments came on the second day of a tour to inspect American military readiness in South Korea. And while he warned of the long-term nuclear threat, he and the usually hawkish-sounding South Korean Defense Ministry made a clearly orchestrated effort to lower the level of threatening rhetoric.
"This is a time of high political tension, but I want to emphasize that there is not high military tension," he said this morning. "There is no imminent danger of a military conflict on the Korean Peninsula."
"The U.S. will not provoke a war by any rash act," he said, but he added that it would also not "invite a war" by "showing a lack of commitment to South Korea."
Mr. Perry's visit coincides with the arrival here of Patriot antimissile batteries to protect American air bases from North Korea's growing arsenal. While the South Korean Government has officially welcomed the arrival of the weapons, they have been a hot political issue in Seoul, with opposition parties and student demonstrators denouncing their arrival as a provocation to the North Korean Government of Kim Il Sung.
In recent days, both South Korea and the United States have gradually scaled back the demands they have made to the North, in hopes of creating a face-saving way for Mr. Kim to allow inspectors into the country and move ahead with another round of high-level talks with the United States. American officials have said that those talks, which have been delayed since last summer because of the North's refusal to submit to even a limited inspection of nuclear sites, would lay out a package of economic and diplomatic incentives for the North if it halts its nuclear program.
South Korea has dropped a demand that the North move ahead with an exchange of envoys on the nuclear issue before talks with Washington proceed.
On Wednesday, Mr. Perry and South Korean officials also said they would delay, until at least next November, the staging of this year's military exercises. South Korean officials have said that the exercises are more useful as a carrot than as a training maneuver, but the offer to suspend the exercises has been dangled before, to little avail.
The removal of fuel from the North's 25-megawatt reactor -- a 200 megawatt reactor is scheduled to go into operation next year -- is a critical step because it is the International Atomic Energy Agency's only chance to measure exactly how much nuclear material the North possesses.
The last batch of North Korean fuel was removed several years ago, and because inspectors were not present the United States can only guess about how much nuclear material North Korea now has. Mr. Perry repeated his estimate today that "it was enough to do one or two bombs."

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS PRESS FOR A COMPROMISE ON CHINESE TRADE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
The leading Democratic advocates of a tough policy toward China are working with the White House on a compromise that would include limited sanctions but allow a considerable amount of trade to continue if China fails to meet all the human rights objectives laid down by the Administration.
This approach could be critical in helping President Clinton find a face-saving way to salvage his China policy. The President is reluctant to choke off commerce with the world's fastest-growing economy by totally withdrawing Beijing's most-favored-nation trade status. But he is equally loath to back down on his threat to do so if China does not satisfy the human rights demands the Administration set as its condition for renewal of the trade status on June 3. 
 The use of limited sanctions has become the centerpiece of the new debate on China.
The debate is no longer primarily between those who want to withdraw all trade benefits, which allow Chinese goods to enter the United States with the lowest possible tariffs, and those who want to renew them unconditionally.
It is now between those who would renew China's trade privileges while also imposing some sanctions to keep the pressure on Beijing, and those who would renew the privileges while looking for other ways to influence Beijing.
China gained most-favored-nation trade status during the Carter Administration. Its exports to the United States reached $33 billion last year, and it imported $9 billion worth of goods from the United States, yielding Beijing a surplus of $24 billion.
It is a measure of how seriously the Administration takes the debate that Mr. Clinton, in between all his meetings today on Bosnia, met with the leaders of both sides of the debate.
In the morning, he conferred with those ready to consider limited sanctions -- the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine; the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, and Representative Nancy Pelosi of San Francisco. In the afternoon he met with the proponents of non-trade sanctions, led by Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana.
The Democratic lawmakers clearly do not want to put Mr. Clinton in a corner or end all trade with China, a move that would harm both American businesses and the Chinese reform process, which depends in part on such trade. They also recognize, as do many Administration officials, that China might make progress on some issues while falling far short on others.
As a result, many of the important voices who had been advocating a blanket revocation of China's trade status are now ready to consider a more nuanced approach.
"There has definitely been a shift," said Mike Jendrzejczyk, the Washington director of Human Rights Watch/ Asia, an organization that monitors human rights violations. "Even before Secretary of State Warren Christopher's disastrous trip to Beijing, the Administration realized that they might not succeed in getting China to fully meet the conditions of the President's executive order. Therefore, there was a need for partial sanctions to be imposed, if there was only partial progress in meeting the conditions."
"This would maintain the President's credibility," he said. "The alternative would be for the President to lie, and exaggerate the progress, or totally revoke M.F.N., which he doesn't want to do."
 
The Chinese Dig In
 The need for an alternative has become even more urgent as China's position has become entrenched since Mr. Christopher's trip. What Mr. Clinton is now hearing from the Democrats who strongly support him is that they would be willing to go along with this alternative strategy.
"They don't want to hurt Clinton or appear soft on human rights," Mr. Jendrzejczyk said. "It is a way to get everyone off the hook. It also may be more effective. It is doable.
"The Chinese would pay a price for continuing human rights violation, and it gives the Administration maneuvering room for a longer-term strategy. Targeted sanctions also have more credibility since it is much more likely that they would be used than a blanket revocation of M.F.N."
Mr. Gephardt said in an interview that there was still time for China to meet the President's demands, but if it fell short, maybe there should be an extension of the trade benefits "with conditions." For example, trade benefits for state industries could be revoked, while private enterprises could keep them.
The idea, Mr. Gephardt said, is to try to find some way that would keep the pressure on the Beijing Government "but not totally removing M.F.N. so there can be no trade."
 
'A Real Answer'
 Since it is clear that China is now in flux, and may meet some American conditions by June 3, Mr. Gephardt said, United States policy may also be in transition for a while.
Ms. Pelosi said: "I would hope that President Clinton would consider targeted revocation of M.F.N. as another option. Among those in our Congressional working group on China, we are reviewing the options, ranging from total revocation to targeted revocation.
"One view that is emerging is that we could recommend revocation that is targeted to products made by the Chinese military, as well as targeting other products which are for the most part made by the state sectors. The United States has an opportunity to initiate sanctions which impact the Chinese Government the most, the Chinese private sector to a lesser degree and the American consumer the least."
Lawmakers and Administration officials say limited sanctions could be a legal and administrative nightmare. Nevertheless, they are now studying several paths. One method would be to use the recently revived Super 301 trade law, which empowers the President to impose trade sanctions on a country, a specific sector of that country's exports or a particular product, if the country is engaged in an "unreasonable denial of worker rights."
Senator Baucus's counterproposal assumes China will somehow meet the President's demands that it account for political prisoners and the use of prison labor, stop jamming foreign radio broadcasts and allow freer emigration. If it does, he argues, the Administration and Congress should permanently renew most-favored-nation status for China and then seek a long-term alternative to the annual threat of sanctions, which no one really wants to carry out.
 
Senator's Other Proposal
 He proposes sending more diplomats to China to monitor human rights and meeting more frequently with dissidents there, enforcing United States restrictions on imports of prison-made products, and using leverage to condition China's loans from the World Bank on its human rights behavior.
Senator Baucus also suggests using State Department travel advisories to promote human rights by informing American tourists which Chinese provinces have the worst human rights records and which the best.
He would also have United States businesses consider "codes of conduct" or human rights guidelines like the "Sullivan Principles," which were used in South Africa in the days of apartheid, "to make sure our firms meet basic labor standards like the minimum wage, and do not use child labor, slave labor or allow political surveillance."

HEADLINE: Where Earth Tones Are the Music of Design

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY JACK WARD 

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
AS Earth Day approached, Fabien Baron, a graphic designer and the creative director at Harper's Bazaar, sat back in his Corbusier-furnished penthouse office on West 57th Street, put on a tape of Van Morrison's "Hymn to the Silence" and leafed through a large box of photographs, nature studies and views of a desolate landscape. In just a few weeks, he will pack his bags and go there, leaving behind his drafting tables, his layouts and clients like Calvin Klein and Issey Miyake to fend for themselves for a few weeks.
Twelve hours from Manhattan, he will watch from a lumbering prop plane for the twin volcanos that dominate the barren topography of Pantelleria, a nine-mile-long speck in the Mediterranean between Sicily and Tunisia. 
 After a sudden, harrowing descent between the twin peaks and a bone-rattling ride in his World War II Willis Jeep over a lunar-like landscape, he will follow a lava path to what he calls home: a series of 18-foot-square rooms made of stacked volcanic rocks and built into the hillside. From above, one sees only two swelling mounds in the earth.
This house is called a dammuso, built in the 19th century with thick stone walls, smoothly finished inside with graceful vaulted arches in smooth stucco and with ingenious convex roofs that collect precious rainwater and funnel it to underground cisterns. The design is as pure, stark and clean as Mr. Baron's own graphic style, although the form originated in North Africa 3,000 years ago.
From the Mediterranean to Miami, Guatemala to the Yukon, a handful of pioneering architects and designers are going back to the earth with what the critic Vincent Scully calls a "reverent appreciation for the landscape." Increasingly, they are turning to less technologically advanced cultures in which harmony with nature is the starting point for creative expression and are seeking inspiration in indigenous forms simply built of available materials. Such a sustainable "world architecture," says Christopher Alexander, a builder, architect and professor at the University of California at Berkeley, may represent the pursuit of a "spiritual purity of maker and artifact."
Mr. Baron said of Pantelleria's vaulted structures and barren hillsides: "It is very mystical and biblical. I feel like I knew the place, like I belonged there."
Mr. Baron bought his dammuso (pronounced dam-MOO-soh) in 1989 while visiting Pantelleria for Italian Vogue with the designer and photographer Fabrizio Ferri, who is now his neighbor. "I said, 'I love this house,' and boom!" he said, with Gallic affect. "I'd bought it right there, right like that!" The house with almost 15 acres of land cost $80,000.
Mr. Baron has been renovating his ruin ever since, said Gabriella Giuntoli, a Milanese architect and urban planner who specializes in the preservation of Pantelleria's venerable dammusi. The house, a progression of interconnected vaulted cubes, was abandoned and overgrown when Mr. Baron purchased it. Ms. Giuntoli's work on the house seems invisible. "I simply changed the function of these rooms, not their structure," she said. "All we did was open a few windows to allow more light. Fabien and I just underlined the important features unique to the dammuso: light, sculptural quality, watery or evanescent color."
There will be a big bag of capers, the island's principal crop, waiting on the table as a gesture of welcome for Mr. Baron, his wife, Sciascia, and his children, Ariel, 2, and Matthew, 6. The waxed cement floors will be cool underfoot. Local craftsmen made new arches and terra-cotta and stone terraces that are indistinguishable from original ones. Mr. Baron has installed electricity but prefers not to use it. He relies on his large collection of oil lamps and cooks over a butane stove. "When we have dinner, we put lots and lots of lamps and candles -- maybe 50 -- on the table. When we started, the light was so beautiful that we decided not to use electricity."
If the world of fashion is the yin, then Mr. Baron's simple life at his home on Pantelleria is certainly the yang. "You drink a little wine from the place, you eat pasta, you fall asleep and wake up around 3 in the morning," he said. "Far away you hear the sea. It's authentic, not superficial. It's not political, it's not fake, nothing. Every word you could say about fashion, it is not."
Travis Price, an architect in Takoma Park, Md., also migrates to multiculturalism -- on the opposite side of the world. Last summer at sunrise you could find him 1,000 miles north of Vancouver, British Columbia, in the Canadian Yukon. There, at a tent encampment on Ealue Lake at Wolf Creek Lodge, Mr. Price, a wiry man in a rumpled navy blue sweatshirt, was leading 12 architecture students in kojasho, a series of exercises and movements, based on a Japanese martial art, in which the participants take on the identity of animals, the better to commune with nature.
Mr. Price, 45, designs in both the spiritual and material worlds. He is an architectural critic and a lecturer at the University of Maryland and at Catholic University in Washington. His firm, Travis Price Architects, is currently designing a library for St. John's College in Annapolis, Md.; a spiritual retreat center for Jewish adults near Camp David, Md., and a training center in Sarasota, Fla., for teachers of aikido, a martial art in which he has a black belt.
Mr. Price spends two weeks each summer running an Outward Bound-style wilderness camp for architecture students that he calls "Spirit of Place, Spirit of Design."
"Architecture study has been urban based," said Wade Davis, 40, who is Mr. Price's colleague at the camp and has degrees in anthropology, biology and ethnobotany. "Travis wanted to know what happens to a group of students from the urban East when put into a landscape so wild that it sweeps over the imagination, where within a mile there are far more grizzly bears and wolves than people."
Last August, the group, in a creative response to the landscape, designed and built a Zen meditation temple that married the abstract and the rustic. They used only the simplest of hand tools to build a raised platform. The students felled, stripped and lashed 85 trees gathered from the site, made a raked roof to suggest a flying eagle's wing and decorated it with a colorful pattern in its shingles, recalling the northern lights that dazzled their city eyes.
On the platform, the group built a cube-shaped inner sanctum of milled lumber and sheet metal. "Geometry is a universal way artists through all the cultural traditions talk about perfection," said Mr. Price, who added, "The group also learned how hard it is to skin a tree."
Mr. Davis, who has spent a part of his adult life living with Indians in the Spatsizi wilderness, the most remote area of British Columbia, bristles at the suggestion that he is advocating that his students live like Indians or appropriate Indian culture.
"You can celebrate the poetics of cultural diversity without sentimentality or nostalgia," Mr. Davis said. As builders, he added, the members of the group are seeking "the conduit to a culture, the points of commonality, such as water, forest and leaves, and a shared spirit of place."
In his residential work, Mr. Price often explores the collision of cultures. In the design of an ecologically sustainable house that he will build this summer on Vargas Island on Cloquot Sound, near Vancouver, for Ian MacKenzie, a Scottish environmental photographer, he conceived a "cultural environmental billboard." Japanese elements include raised platforms, exposed wooden beams, shoji panels of a translucent insulation material called Kalwal and stone footings. There will be a gutter-to-cistern water system, and the house will rely on secondary wood for its stove; the main structural logs will be driftwood refuse from the logging industry, and carpenters will use wood from the cleared site. "The message is that the primary wood economy is the destruction of the forest," Mr. Price said.
The house's exterior's design calls for enormous graphic decorations in the style of the region's Kwakiutl people, who paint their houses with identifying masks. Mr. Price distinguishes himself from many in the eco-architecture movement by his irreverent humor: local flora and fauna inspire salmon- and whale-shaped joists and beams, while other exterior images, including a sassy depiction of the Loch Ness monster, represent the client's Scottish heritage.
At the University of Miami School of Architecture, a coalition of about a dozen faculty members, many of them Latin American, has organized a method of study similar to that of the Ealue Lake adventurers. Led by the brothers Jorge Trelles, 35, and Luis Trelles, 38, Cuban-born architects, and 40-year-old Teofilo Victoria, who was raised in Colombia, students explore architectural sites primarily in Guatemala, Mexico and Colombia in a six-week program designed to help them understand the roots of colonial architecture and recognize the settlers' wonderment at the wilderness they found.
"The Europeans found an extraordinarily, urgently, pressingly abundant landscape, wilder than their knowledge of wilderness could possibly have been," said Mr. Victoria, whose teaching method also begins with the landscape. Students start by drawing leaves and flowers indigenous to South Florida and Central America, not for sentimental reasons but to remain close to nature and the regional roots of architecture.
"It's analagous to Mies's students drawing every brick in detail to study existing structure," said Mr. Scully, who is a visiting professor at the architecture school and is completing a book on the approach of the Miami School, as this coalition has come to be called, to the study of architecture through nature. "I really believe that these people are going after architecture in an entirely new way that is unique to the way architecture is taught almost everywhere else."
Many of the new Miami School architects identify themselves as Magic Realists, in the tradition of artists and writers like Frida Kahlo, Fernando Botero and Gabriel Garcia Marquez. "In Magic Realism, the scale of nature is exaggerated," Mr. Victoria said, "and nature itself is often the protagonist, as big as the American West, or the wilderness of the Amazon jungles, or the amazing colors of its birds."
In South Beach, Fla., a partnership that includes Mr. Victoria and the Trelles brothers recently completed a building that is emblematic of the Miami School approach. Azul (the word means blue in Spanish), a women's clothing store, is a modest row building that the architects hope will be an urban model. The facade of the two-story stucco building is colored in a remarkable watery blue lime paint devised by Emilio Cianfoni, the renowned Roman colorist brought to Miami to restore the landmark monument house Villa Viscaya. (Lime painting is an ancient technique; as it absorbs moisture, colors intensify, giving walls a timeworn, patinated effect.)
The expressive silhouette with its elongated pediment was inspired by 16th-century Baroque churches in Guatemala, but here it is "imbued with a feminine quality, a delicacy of curve like a pendant around the neck," Jorge Trelles said. To the east, a striking geometric rose window casts morning sunlight through the store in brilliant facets.
"This is not a romantic primitivism," Mr. Scully said of the new Miami esthetic. "We look through Anglo eyes and see the buildings and bright color and think thus. This is a bright and powerful urbanism."
The passion for the landscape of Central and South America is deeply personal for Latin American architects in Miami, who Mr. Victoria said are "inextricably linked to a longing for a more pure time, the eternal return."
These days they gather at the recently completed home of Jorge Trelles and his partner and wife, MariTere Cabarrocas, in the neighborhood of Coconut Grove. The two-story home, built around an old black olive tree that the Trelleses wanted to preserve, has stucco walls the color of mamey, a brilliant orange-red fruit. Mr. Trelles, a burly, intense man in wrinkled khakis and a polo shirt, slouched deep into a wicker chair and filled the night air with wistful memories of life in Cuba -- "longing stories," he calls them -- before 1961. That was when "anything of any value was removed -- family, church, culture," he said, and his family left for Miami.
Such stories are a reminder that world architecture begins with the spirit of place and is a mediation between nature and the needs of humans. Summing up the growing fascination with this new estetic, Christopher Alexander of Berkeley, who is writing an essay on the art of building called "The Nature of Order," said: "While it seems quite reasonable that we would pursue expeditions, there is a simpler journey. It is more important that you find this spiritual purity in your own soul."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
BELL ATLANTIC CORP. (BEL:N)

 BODY:
Fueled by a rebounding economy and strong demand for cellular telephones, the Bell Atlantic Corporation reported yesterday that net income jumped 17.1 percent in the first quarter to $389.2 million, or 89 cents a share.
After excluding one-time expenses for the first quarters of 1993 and 1994, the Philadelphia-based regional Bell company said that its net income had climbed 12.3 percent while revenues rose 6.6 percent, to $3.37 billion. 
 The results were somewhat higher than Wall Street estimates, and Bell Atlantic's stock price jumped yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. But analysts warned that the company's earnings in the second quarter would be weakened by dilution from Bell Atlantic's purchase of the Mexican cellular company Grupo Iusacell.
Bell Atlantic's core local telephone business grew, increasing the number of lines in use by 2.6 percent. But the cellular businesses added nearly 300,000 new customers over the first quarter of 1993, pushing up cellular revenues by 42 percent.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Words: Renew the Momentum for Peace

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:

 Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference today on potential action in Bosnia, as provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company:
 
Opening Statement:
Over the last several days, the situation in Gorazde has become increasingly grim. The Serb forces have broken their own truce agreements, persisted in brutal attacks on civilians, United Nations personnel, and NATO forces protecting those personnel. 
 These events are clearly a setback for the momentum achieved in recent months. The NATO ultimatum brought a reprieve to Sarajevo. Humanitarian routes were reopened. Agreements between Muslims and Croats changed the balance of power on the ground and offered new diplomatic opportunity.
There are reports that the Serbs have released more U.N. personnel and returned heavy weapons seized from U.N. control near Sarajevo. And they are welcome. But the imperative now is not only to address the latest Serb transgressions; it is to renew the momentum toward peace.
Let me be clear about our objective. Working with our allies, the Russians and others, we must help the warring parties in Bosnia to reach a negotiated settlement. To do that, we must make the Serbs pay a higher price for continued violence so it will be in their own interest more clearly to return to the negotiating table. That is, after all, why we pushed for NATO's efforts to enforce the no-fly zone and the Sarajevo ultimatum and to provide close air support for U.N. forces who come under attack.
In pursuit of that policy, we must take further action. Therefore, the United States has today undertaken the following initiatives.
First, we are proposing to our NATO allies that we extend the approach used around Sarajevo to other safe areas, where any violations would be grounds for NATO attacks. I have insisted that NATO commit itself to achievable objectives. NATO's air power alone cannot prevent further Serb aggressions or advances or silence every gun. Any military expert will tell you that. But it can deny the Serbs the opportunity to shell safe areas with impunity.
Second, we will work with others to pursue tighter sanctions through stricter enforcements. The existing sanctions on Serbia have crippled Serbia's economy. In light of recent events, there must be no relief.
 
 
Additional Peacekeepers
 Third, we are taking other steps to relieve suffering and support the peace process. We are offering the United Nations assistance in addressing the humanitarian crisis that is now severe in Gorazde, and we expect the Security Council to take up a resolution authorizing additional U.N. peacekeepers, which we will support. These steps support our intensive work, along with others, to secure a negotiated settlement.
I have just spoken at some length with President Yeltsin, as well as with President Mitterrand. I spoke earlier today with Prime Minister Chretien. . . . President Yeltsin and I agreed to work closely together to pursue peace in Bosnia. President Mitterrand expressed his agreement with the general approach. I was very encouraged by President Yeltsin's statement yesterday calling on the Serbs to honor their commitments, insisting that they withdraw from Gorazde and that they resume talks and that they permit U.N. personnel to return to Gorazde.
 I think you can look forward to a major diplomatic initiative coming out of our common efforts, but I cannot discuss the details or the outlines of that with you at this moment because we have agreed, all of us, that our Foreign Ministers need to talk and flesh out the details before we say exactly what approach we will take. The telephone conversations themselves were an insufficient basis for the kind of specific detailed approach that I think would be required.
In any case, it is clear that our test of Serb intent must be their actions, not their words. Those words have often proved empty. . . .
 
U.S. Interests at Stake
 The United States has interests at stake in Bosnia -- an interest in helping to stop the slaughter of innocents, an interest in helping to prevent a wider war in Europe, an interest in maintaining NATO as a credible force for peace in the post-cold-war era and in helping to stem the flow of refugees. These interests justify continued American leadership and require us to maintain a steady purpose, knowing that there will be difficulties and setbacks and that in this world, where we have a set of cooperative arrangements not only with NATO but with the United Nations, there will often be delays that would not be there were we acting alone or in a context in which our security were more immediately threatened.
Ultimately this conflict still must be settled by the parties themselves. They must choose peace. The agreement between the Croatians and the Muslims was a very important first step, but there is so much more to be done. By taking firm action consistent with our interests, the United States and our NATO allies can and must attempt to influence that choice.
 
Questions and Answers:
Q. Nothing that you are proposing today is intended to deal specifically with Gorazde, is it? And just a second thing is, have you thought through what you would propose to do if your attempt to recreate the Sarajevo model elsewhere does not deter the Serbs and they keep coming, much as they did at Gorazde?
A. Let me answer your first question first. Our proposal would create Sarajevo-like conditions, that is, sort of safe zones around all the safe areas, including Gorazde. So we would assume that as a part of this, if our allies will agree with us, that any heavy weaponry, any firing in and around that area would be subject to the same action as Srebrenica or any other safe zone. So that's that.
The second question is have I thought about what would happen if this doesn't work. I have. But I think we should stick with this policy. And if the Serbs continue their aggression in an irresponsible way, then there is -- there are other things that can be done. I have given a lot of thought to it, but I don't want to talk about it now.

HEADLINE: Apartment Workers Pass Strike Deadline As Talks Continue

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
Negotiators for the owners of 2,800 residential buildings and the union representing their service employees resumed bargaining last night and continued talking past a midnight strike deadline.
Dennis Sheehan, the spokesman for Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, said shortly after midnight that both sides had decided to keep negotiating. The union did not set another deadline. 
 His announcement came several hours after the spokesman for the landlords' group, Jim Grossman, said, "The way these things go, if they settle, it'll probably be sometime in the middle of the night."
Mr. Sheehan agreed with that judgment before the two sides resumed their talks at the Sheraton New York Hotel shortly after 10 P.M.
Union leaders and officials from the owners' bargaining group, the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, said wages and other economic issues were the main sticking point. They refused to provide details about raises the union had demanded.
The local's 30,000 members open doors, run elevators and perform similar duties in rental, cooperative and condominium buildings in New York City except for the Bronx, where there is a different local.
The contract that expired last night, negotiated in 1991 after a 12-day strike, provided annual increases averaging about 4 percent, after splitting the difference on wages, then as now the chief issue.
Under the 1991 contract, doormen earn $518 a week and handymen $568 a week, the owners said. That comes to $27,981 a year (including employer payments for sick days, 10 of them under the contract). Tips add an indefinite amount to income, and individual buildings can reward merit in various ways, with bonuses, higher base wages or time off.

HEADLINE: City Begins Enforcement Of Food Cart Restrictions

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
In a clash that led an army of food vendors to marshal their carts along Fifth Avenue yesterday, New York City has begun a new crackdown on vendors operating in areas that the city has declared off limits.
Officials say that they are simply stepping up enforcement of a 10-year-old rule, and that they began with consultations with vendors and other business owners last year. The rule bans food vendors from certain congested areas, including swaths of Fifth Avenue, while permitting them in others. 
 But many food vendors say they think the city and business groups are bent on their destruction. About 500 vendors -- pushing 100 food carts, empty of their cargo of doughnuts, hot dogs, ice cream and gyros -- marched along Fifth Avenue in protest yesterday, chanting slogans and waving placards. "Save cheap lunch," their signs proclaimed. "We sell food, not drugs!" they shouted.
It differed from most demonstrations in the city, in that the effect was stark and immediate: it was impossible to find a quick snack on Fifth Avenue. "A lot of guys in my office missed their morning coffee," said Richard Thornton, an accountant.
 
'Quality of Life'
 Officer Scott Bloch, a police spokesman, said enforcement of the law had been intensified in the last three or four weeks, with many warnings issued and a few summonses. The highest penalty for repeated infractions is confiscation of carts.
The administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani views enforcement of such laws as part of a campaign on "quality of life" issues. The laws are for safety and convenience, intended to prevent obstruction of walkways and to lessen congestion.
Allan J. Fromberg, a spokesman for the Mayor, said: "The Mayor and Police Commissioner have agreed to begin enforcing a law that simply has not been enforced. The decision is rooted in public safety and economic reality."
City Hall has the support of business groups in midtown Manhattan. "The Mayor is trying to reverse decades of ignoring regulations that should have been enforced," said Daniel A. Biederman, president of the Grand Central Partnership. "It's very much of a piece with truancy and squeegee enforcement."
 
Enforcement Recommended
 The vendors, most of whom are employees, not business owners, say the 1983 changes are simply too onerous. They even point to a statement from Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1984 saying he would not enforce the new rules because they would drive out all food vending.
But last year Mayor David N. Dinkins appointed a committee on food peddling, divided equally between vendors and other business owners. After several meetings, that group recommended enforcing the law.
Such strict enforcement, said Alfred DelBello, lawyer for the vendors, "basically knocks out most, if not all, the economically viable streets in midtown."
Cliff Stanton, who operates 50 Frozade carts, said: "I may have to lay off half my staff. And some of these people have been on the street for 10 or 12 years."
Mr. Biederman of the Grand Central Partnership met with other business leaders in a hastily scheduled press conference yesterday. A flier from the vendors accused the partnership and other business improvement districts of conspiring to eliminate "inexpensive food choices" and trying to put them out of work.
But the business leaders said they had no quarrel with legal vendors, provided they worked in legal places. "The legal vendor operating legally is disadvantaged by the vendor operating illegally," said Brendan Sexton, vice president of the Rockefeller Group. "If I have a license to drive a car, it doesn't mean I have a license to drive a truck the wrong way up a highway."
The politics surrounding the issue are already as messy as a jumbo frank with sauerkraut and onions. Today, City Councilman Anthony D. Weiner intends to introduce a bill to declare a moratorium on enforcement of the vending restrictions for 120 days. Hearings would be held to draft new rules.
Mr. Weiner, who represents the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, said, "On a philosophical level, a lot of the midtown business groups want to have no vendors."
"The people who are lining up to get coffee and doughnuts in the morning aren't captains of industry," he added. He further suggested that it is unfair suddenly to begin enforcing a law after years of ignoring it.

HEADLINE: Many Americans Flunk Pop Science Quiz

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d 

 BODY:
A majority of American adults do not know that humans evolved from animal species or that the Sun and Earth are in the Milky Way galaxy. And one-third think that humans and dinosaurs existed at the same time, according to a new nationwide survey on scientific literacy among adults.
The survey, conducted by Louis Harris & Associates and the American Museum of Natural History and released yesterday, found that despite years of efforts to improve science education in public schools, American adults possess a low level of literacy in science. 
 "The message here is clear and simple," said Ellen V. Futter, the museum's president and a former president of Barnard College. "Americans do not know enough about science or the scientific process."
The survey portrayed an adult population with such a limited understanding of science that only 21 percent of the 1,225 adults questioned scored 60 percent or better on 20 questions that examined basic knowledge of subjects that included space, earth, the environment, animals and causes of diseases.
 
'Erratic' Grasp of Science
 In assessing the findings, Ms. Futter said American adults "seem to have an erratic, almost idiosyncratic" understanding of "bits of science information."
The respondents seemed to score best on questions with an immediacy in today's world. A vast majority, 78 percent, knew that AIDS is caused by a virus. And, questioned within weeks of the last California earthquake, most respondents knew that the continents move.
But more than half did not correctly answer a question on evolution that was asked in these two different ways:
*Human beings developed from earlier species of animals, true or false?
*Human beings evolved from earlier species of animals, true or false?
Forty-six percent said false to both. The survey did not address whether religious beliefs might have affected the result.
Sixty-five percent did not know how many planets are in the solar system, and only a fraction, 10 percent, could correctly name what scientists believe to be the nearest modern-day relative of Tyrannosaurus rex from a list of four: chicken, crocodile, elephant and lizard. (It is the chicken.)
The survey was conducted by telephone in February and March and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The findings are similar to other specialized surveys of what Americans know, like one on geography two years ago sponsored by the National Geographic Society and one last year on knowledge of economics.
And last September, a sweeping study by the United States Department of Education concluded that a large percentage of the American adult population has large gaps in basic knowledge, from an inability to read at all to an inability to read a utility bill.
 
Results to Help Museum
 Ms. Futter said the museum would use the survey's results to better tailor the museum's science education classes for adults and children alike. She said she hoped the findings would also be used by community colleges and science organizations to fine-tune existing science education curriculums or begin new efforts to address results that Ms. Futter and other museum officials called "surprising," given the flow of resources into science education into public schools since the 1957 launching of Sputnik by the former Soviet Union.
She and other museum officials said schools alone should not be blamed for the low level of science literacy. Although a four-year study released last October by the American Association for the Advancement of Science called for better curriculums and improved teaching, American students continue to lag behind European and Asian students in achievement tests, a trend that not surprisingly surfaces in the adult population.

HEADLINE: Nominee Seen for Fed Seat

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
President Clinton's senior economic advisers tentatively plan to recommend that he nominate a University of California economist, Janet L. Yellen, to the Federal Reserve Board, a senior Administration official said tonight.
Robert E. Rubin, the head of the National Economic Council, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, reached a consensus at a meeting late Tuesday, the official said. 
 Ms. Yellen is a former colleague of Ms. Tyson, who also taught economics at the University of California at Berkeley.
Ms. Yellen has a reputation as an eclectic writer, looking at themes ranging from influences on the trade balance to the behavior of street gangs. She has tended to take a fairly stringent anti-inflation position while also writing extensively on employment issues, showing a sensitivity to the problems faced by people who lose their jobs.
"The President has still not had a chance to meet with his economic team to discuss it, so it's not a done deal," the official said.
Ms. Yellen's prospective appointment was reported tonight in Thursday's issue of The Washington Post. It was confirmed tonight by the official.
The President is expected to nominate Alan Blinder, another member of the Council of Economic Advisers, to another open seat on the Fed later this week.

The Economy
Many consumers are shrugging off the higher interest rates that have sent the stock and bond markets into a tailspin, and some may even benefit from the increases. [Page D1.]
Home construction snapped back in March from midwinter doldrums as builders broke ground at a rate 12.1 percent faster than February's, the Commerce Department reported. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Guiding Bank of Mexico To Newly Won Respect

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 20

 BODY:
Through the first few rocky months of 1994, the Bank of Mexico loomed as Mexico's financial bulwark, stubbornly defending the peso against several runs in the face of a guerrilla uprising in Chiapas state, the kidnapping of a millionaire businessman and the assassination of a presidential candidate. In the process, the central bank impressed international investors with the way that Mexico's financial institutions have performed under pressure.
The Bank of Mexico has assumed a more independent identity since April 1, when it became constitutionally autonomous. For now, most economic analysts see the bank's new autonomy as positive. Separating the authority that prints money from the Government that spends it makes investors sleep soundly.
 
Debate Over Devaluation
 However, the bank's independence is likely to be tested by the pressure on the Mexican peso and the mounting debate over whether it should be devalued. Over the last month, investors pulled more than $3 billion in capital out of Mexico. 
 To stem the outflow of pesos, the Bank of Mexico raised interest rates on its treasury bonds today to 18 percent, leading to one of the year's largest drops on the stock exchange. The Bolsa index gave up 5.2 percent of its value, tumbling 107.44 points to close at 1,957.33. Of 103 issues traded, all but three declined.
Much of the prestige enjoyed by the Bank of Mexico derives from the quiet dignity of its director general, Miguel Mancera. A holder of a master's degree in economics from Yale, Mr. Mancera has worked at the bank for 36 years and headed it for the last 11. With his plain gray suits, hair combed straight back and heavy tortoise shell glasses, he is the image of the probity for which he strives in the bank itself.
Mr. Mancera, whose fiscal conservatism has prompted criticism that he is blind to Mexico's social needs, contends that tight monetary control is essential for a nation's security.
"In Mexico as in many other countries," Mr. Mancera said in a recent interview, "it has been clearly observed that the ultimate cause of inflation, mostly acute inflation, has been abuse of central bank credit, and this abuse usually is connected to the fact that the executive branch of government has at its disposal central bank credit in order to finance budget deficits."
As the engine of Mexico's monetary policy, the Bank of Mexico, like the Federal Reserve in the United States, continues to control credit and set interest rates.
Last year President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and his finance minister, Pedro Aspe, proposed that the central bank be granted independence, effectively shielding it from political interference. The move was taken as proof that Mexico was serious about controlling inflation and keeping its economy disciplined.
Previously, the bank was governed by a board composed mostly of government officials and a director who served at the President's pleasure.
The essential elements of the new system, under the Mexican constitution, are that no authority can order the bank to grant financing. The bank is now run by an independent five-person board made up of a governor and four sub-governors, who are appointed by the President and serve a six- or eight-year term from which they essentially cannot be dismissed. Their terms are staggered and overlap the six-year presidential term.
 
No Insulation From Politics
 The Mexican architects of the bank's new autonomy did not want the bank so independent that it would be isolated from politics. The governors' terms are structured so that by the fourth year of a six-year administration, the incumbent President will have been able to name at least three of the five members, giving him a majority, so presumably his policies will be enacted. In contrast, the American President can name only two of seven Federal Reserve members during a single four-year term.
"There should be independence, but that should not ignore the political evolution of the country," Mr. Mancera said at his office in the historic center of Mexico City.
Because Mr. Mancera and President Salinas share the desire to control inflation, almost never in the last five years has politics collided with monetary policy.
 
Past Pressure to Print Money
 In the past, however, free-spending Mexican officials put pressure on the central bank to lower interest rates and print more money. On one such occasion in 1982, Mr. Mancera quit rather than obey an order from President Jose Lopez Portillo to impose currency exchange controls. He rejoined the bank several months later after President Miguel de la Madrid took office.
The Salinas administration has succeeded in its economic priority of reducing inflation, bringing the rate down from 159 percent in 1987 to 8 percent last year. Mr. Mancera said there are now "more important goals" like social justice and sustained growth, which would have been even more difficult to attain "in an inflationary environment." Despite the current difficulties, he maintained, this year's Federal budget will be balanced.
But the biggest immediate economic concerns have to do with the peso, which has lost about 13 percent of its value since February. Morgan Stanley & Company, citing a report by Mexican foreign-exchange brokers, said that more than $3 billion left Mexico in the week following the assassination of the presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio, on March 23.
The continuing outflow puts new pressure on the bank to devalue the peso, but many analysts believe it will not do so before the Aug. 21 presidential election. Citicorp, for example, said that such a move would be "politically damaging for the credibility of the central bank and its recently acquired autonomous status."
 
Washington's Funds Untouched
 Mr. Mancera said the bank did not have to use any of the $6 billion in backup funds made available by Washington to support the peso in the turbulence that followed Mr. Colosio's assassination. The Bank of Mexico's own foreign capital reserves are reported to exceed $25 billion.
But political instabilities continue to bedevil the peso. A peace settlement in Chiapas remains elusive. The kidnapped businessman, Alfredo Harp Jelu, has not yet been found. And an investigation continues into an apparent conspiracy behind Mr. Colosio's murder.
Mr. Mancera expressed confidence that the peso, trading at roughly the top of an allowed band -- now at 3.37 pesos to the dollar -- will eventually come back down. Uncertainty about the peso continues, however. That is only natural, Mr. Mancera said, "in any country that has in the past suffered from devaluations.
"Fortunately," he continued, "that inclination is less strong now than it was years ago."

HEADLINE: Minority Business Chiefs Uneasy Over City-Contract Plan

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Minority and women business owners responded skeptically yesterday to a new city procurement system intended to aid their companies and other small businesses, saying it does not go far enough in filling the void left by the elimination of a more aggressive affirmative-action contracting program.
The new system, described by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at a news conference yesterday, is aimed at opening up the bidding process for thousands of small city contracts, enabling more businesses owned by women and minorities to participate. 
 While welcoming any attempts to broaden the system, the executives said that the Mayor's plan falls short in breaking down barriers confronting minorities and women in obtaining large government contracts.
"Minority firms have for years been fighting over the crumbs," said Serafin Mariel, president of the New York National Bank, a minority-owned bank in the South Bronx. The earlier affirmative-action program, cut by Mr. Giuliani in January, "recognized reality and tried to accomplish something meaningful," he said.
 
Higher Bids Were Okay
 That program, created under Mayor David N. Dinkins, enabled companies owned by women or minorities to obtain city contracts of any size even if they bid up to 10 percent higher than the competition.
"Now Mr. Giuliani's program seems to focus on the crumbs," Mr. Mariel added. "There may be a few more of them, but they are still crumbs."
The new procurement system, first outlined in general terms on Tuesday, will change the city's rules for filling small contracts and purchase orders. Until now, when buying less than $10,000 in goods or $15,000 in services, city purchasing agents called no more than five companies, offering them a chance to bid.
That system, Mr. Giuliani said, overlooked hundreds of qualified small companies that would have been anxious to bid. Under the new system, information on thousands of small companies will be fed into a computer that will match every city contract with every potential bidder. All qualified companies identified by the computer will be contacted and offered a chance to bid.
"It saves the city money by encouraging competition," the Mayor said. The changes, he added, are an "opportunity to obtain far more city business based on economic rather than race- or gender-based criteria."
 
Looking to Broaden
 The Mayor and Rudy Washington, the city's Commissioner of Business Services, said they would try to persuade other government agencies like the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, public utilities like Con Edison and the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, and even private corporations to use its computerized index of small companies as a source for minority bidders.
"It sounds great on paper," said Joel Silverman, president of HRH Construction, one of New York City's largest builders. He said his company has already decided to use the city's new computer file to look for women- and minority-owned companies to hire. But he added that the system, unless properly administered, may produce a deluge of poorly qualified companies bidding for work.
Many women and minority business owners are still smarting over the elimination of the 10-percent "price preference" provision in Mayor Dinkins's affirmative-action program. In effect for only a year before Mr. Giuliani eliminated it, the provision would not have survived even under the former Mayor, because it was ruled unconstitutional by a state Supreme Court in February.
Regarding Mr. Giuliani's plan, Roy A. Hastick, president of the Caribbean American Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Brooklyn, said "It's a step in the right direction," but added that "minorities will have to monitor" the new system to see if it really increases the amount of business flowing to them.
Harriet R. Michel, president of the National Minority Supplier Development Council, a Manhattan organization that helps corporations identify minority contractors, was less equivocal about whether the program would help minorities.
"This doesn't show me that Mayor Giuliani is committed at all," she said. "He is nickel-and-diming around the edges."

HEADLINE: Hectic Day Of Trading For Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Yesterday was a baffling day on Wall Street. For months, the stock market has followed the bond market, in lock step, up and down, but mostly down. Yet when bonds rallied yesterday, stocks plunged, as good signals from the bond market alternated with bad signals elsewhere. When stock traders become baffled, they tend to sell.
And they sold yesterday in unusually hectic trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.11 points, to 3,598.71. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also fell, but less precipitously -- 0.58 point, to 441.96. The Nasdaq composite index, heavy with battered technology stocks, continued its steep drop of the last week or so, falling 7.33 points, to 705.52. 
 Even companies reporting strong earnings, but which were below Wall Street estimates, saw their prices plunge. "We're just murdering stocks that don't deliver," Anthony T. Conroy, managing director of equities at Mabon Securities in New York, said.
 
 
A Case in Point
 Morton International, maker of salt and specialty chemical products, is a case in point. It reported a 48 percent increase in third-quarter profit to $1.42 a share, but Wall Street analysts had been expecting earnings of as much $1.50 a share. Traders sliced 10 percent off Morton's share price, leaving it at 82 3/4, down 10 1/8.
But what was especially confusing was the behavior of stock traders' counterparts in the bond market. Presumably assessing the same economic data, bond traders had one of the best sessions recently in a persistently sour market. Bond traders bid down long-term interest rates that are key to borrowing costs for everyone from General Motors to the consumer on the dealer's showroom floor.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond's yield fell 4 basis points, to 7.32 percent, and its price rose 18/32 of a point, to 876/32 . When the inflation outlook improves, bond prices rise and traders do not have to offer higher yields to entice buyers. [Page D18.]
 
 
Wall Street Reasoning
 But it seems that bond traders should not have been pleased. The day, at least in the peculiar reasoning of Wall Street, should not have started well. The Commerce Department reported a 12.1 percent increase in March housing starts, compared with Wall Street's expectations of a 7.9 percent jump.
The figure meant that despite higher interest rates, the housing market was red hot, probably indicative of future inflation.
"The housing starts figure was important for two reasons," Alfred E. Goldman, director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, said. "It meant that Alan Greenspan's view that the economy could be overheating had some validity. No. 2, it posed a test for the bond market and it passed." What should have prompted another drop in bond prices instead led to a lift in the market, he noted, meaning that bond prices may at last be bottoming out.
"It's too soon to say whether the bear market for bonds is over," Mr. Goldman said. "But we're close."
And if Mr. Goldman is right, that is the good news in yesterday's chaotic session: the bond market may at last be pulling out of its slump. If so, an improving bond market could lay the groundwork for an imminent rally in stocks, which thrive when borrowing costs stabilize, analysts say.
For yesterday, however, the trend was still down. The S.&. P 500's automobile, oil, bank, equipment manufacturing and chemical companies all declined in heavy trading. Among blue-chip stocks, Caterpillar, Boeing, United Technologies, International Paper and Union Carbide dropped. And in the smaller-company Nasdaq index, Lotus Development, U S Health Care and Oracle all fell.
The Dow industrials plunged so inexorably yesterday that the blue-chip average was only 0.63 point away from setting off so-called circuit-breaker rules designed to slow high-speed computer-guided trading when the Dow plummets more than 50 points. The day's trading volume of nearly 367 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange was one of the heaviest of the year.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.71 point, to 244.66. Declining stocks outnumbered advancing stocks by 1,417 to 835. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 3.50 points to 427.60.
Intel was again the most active stock yesterday as 7.8 million shares were traded. It had fallen for nearly a week on a poor competitive outlook, but yesterday it closed unchanged at 57 1/2.
While the housing starts increase may have been troublesome, the increase in housing permits, 5.1 percent in March, seemed weak, perhaps indicating that the economy will be growing at a slower pace in the months ahead. Permits are necessary to build future housing. Perhaps predictably in view of the markets' tendency to overreact, some traders started talking darkly of the Fed going too far with interest rate increases.

HEADLINE: A New Strategy for Welfare Overhaul

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
As President Clinton finalizes his proposal to overhaul the welfare system, his aides are pursuing a new financing strategy to avoid deep cuts in programs for the poor. The strategy would raise small amounts of money by cutting programs for veterans and affluent farmers and raising taxes for some investors.
The move is intended to answer critics, including some of the President's closest allies, who contend that deep cuts in programs for the needy would hurt the very people the welfare plan seeks to help. 
 But the attempt to calm one constituency risks provoking others. The measures that would affect farmers and investors are relatively minor, and the veterans' provisions simply preserve laws that are now scheduled to expire. But the proposals could still draw fire from representatives of each group, who have opposed similar measures in the past.
The options have not yet been reviewed by President Clinton, who could decide to reject them.
 
Scaling Back Proposal
 Frustrated by a lack of money, the Administration is leaning toward a smaller proposal than once contemplated, one that would spend between $10 billion and $13 billion over five years, rather than $15 billion. Officials are still considering a plan to raise about $4 billion by cutting programs that help indigent immigrants and families in temporary distress.
The new strategy is detailed in a list prepared by Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director, who has taken over the search for financing. The document is being closely held within the Government, to avoid disclosures to lobbyists likely to oppose the changes.
While Mr. Panetta declined to comment on the list today, people familiar with it agreed to describe some of the dozens of items it contains. They said they wanted to publicly present the rationale for some of the changes, to build public support for them.
President Clinton's promise to "end welfare as we know it" is one of his most popular calls and a potential key to his political future. But the search for viable financing has become the chief obstacle to drafting a bill, and officials have repeatedly returned to the drawing board.
 
Expanding Training
 Mr. Clinton has said his plan will expand training and child care programs for people on welfare, but then require those still unemployed after two years to enroll in a work program.
While the talk of ending welfare sounds like a cost-savings measure, it is not. That is because the Government plans to subsidize recipients' wages, and to provide them with child care while they work.
Budget experts will recognize many of the items on Mr. Panetta's list, since they are frequently advocated by people concerned about the deficit.
One proposal would limit the amount of agricultural subsidies paid to affluent farmers, perhaps those with non-farm incomes of more than $100,000 a year. The people familiar with Mr. Panetta's list would not say how much money would be saved, but the Congressional Budget Office this year estimated that such changes would save about $300 million over five years.
Robert D. Reischauer, the congressional budget director, said that supporters of the measure contend that Government subsidies should go to struggling family farmers, not rich investors. But opponents, he said, have argued that the step might be a prelude to deeper agricultural cuts.
 
Limits on Annuity Interest?
 A second item on Mr. Panetta's list would limit the amount of tax-deferred interest that could build up in annuities, a move likely to draw opposition from the insurance industry, which sells the plans.
Supporters of the proposal, Mr. Reischauer said, argue that the law lets wealthy people escape taxation by sheltering large amounts of income in such investments. But opponents, he said, insist that without such financial incentives the nation's low savings rate would further drop.
A third set of proposals would affect programs for veterans by extending temporary provisions already provided by law.
Veterans who live in Government-financed nursing homes, for instance, can now collect no more than $90 a month from veterans pensions. But that restriction is scheduled to expire in 1998.
Mr. Reischauer said the argument to preserve the cap holds that by providing pensions and nursing-home care, "we're double-paying in some instances." The argument against the move, he said, is that some veterans have short stays in nursing homes, and need larger pensions to continue paying rent or mortgages.
 
Limiting Free Treatment
 Mr. Panetta is also considering moves to collect more money from veterans or their insurance companies, when the Government treats them for conditions unrelated to their military service.
A veteran who goes to a Government hospital for a war-related injury, for instance, will sometimes get free treatment for unrelated problems, like asthma. Mr. Panetta is considering ways to bolster the enforcement of laws that say the Government should not bear these costs.
The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that capping pensions and recouping more health care costs could save about $545 million over five years.
Mr. Panetta's list still includes some of the measures opposed by advocates for the poor, like a plan to make it harder for immigrants to collect payments under the Supplemental Security Income program. The Administration argues that some immigrants are abusing the program by bringing elderly parents to the country, then signing them up for the payments.
 
Vigilant Lobbyists
 But the broadening of the options is a victory for advocacy groups, like the Children's Defense Fund, which have been concerned that the financing strategy will hurt poor people.
One lesson that has emerged from the months-long effort is that no Washington lobby wants its interests touched.
When it was disclosed several months ago that the Administration was considering a new tax on gambling profits, for instance, the gaming industry began a vigorous assault on the idea.
An official said today that if the Administration decides to go forward with the tax it would be able to afford the $13 billion program, rather than the $10 billion version. Much of the difference would be used to provide child care to poor families that work, to deter them from going on welfare.
