HEADLINE: Higher Rates Bring On a Shrug

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
It will cost an extra $200 a month, but Kipp and Andrea Good are going to buy a house anyway, even though the recent spike in interest rates has made their move to the Westchester suburbs of New York City more expensive.
There are a lot of Americans out there like the Goods, who have been caught as long-term interest rates have shot up more than a percentage point since February. But economists reckon that most consumers will, as the Goods have done, shrug off the higher rates that have sent the stock and bond markets into a tailspin. 
 Some Americans may even benefit a bit from rising rates, particularly the elderly and others who live off investment income. But for them the outlook is more complicated because interest rates on deposits rise a lot more slowly than rates on loans; furthermore, many of these people may have lost money in the recent downturn of the stock and bond markets.
 
Trouble for the Economy?
 Still, if higher rates do not dampen spending significantly, consumers will keep economic growth zipping along so fast that inflation might reignite. And the Federal Reserve, which has already raised interest rates three times this year, will feel compelled to nudge rates up again to slow the economy before inflation heats up even more.
Mr. Good, 28, who works in the marketing department at Prudential Securities, said he had figured how much a house would cost him, using different interest rates. In the three or four months the Goods have been looking seriously, mortgage rates have gone from roughly 7 percent to more than 8 percent.
"Sure, $200 a month is signficant, but I don't think it will change the way we're looking," he said, adding that he was also exploring the costs of an adjustable-rate mortgage. Over all, he noted, mortgage rates are still low; even now, if he refinanced the mortgage on his cooperative apartment in Hoboken, N.J., he would still save money.
Indeed, the recent surge, coming off the bargain-basement levels of last year, has still left interest rates nowhere near the double-digit levels of the late 1970's and early 1980's.
Higher auto loan rates are not deterring Jane and Ross Armstrong, a couple in their early 30's, from getting the new car they will need once they move from New Jersey to Connecticut.
"We started looking three weeks ago, but we just weren't ready to hop on it," she said. They will go ahead and get the new car, though it may cost an extra $10 a month now. "That's not going to make or break us, fortunately," she said.
Higher interest rates will be even less noticeable in the many parts of the country where real estate is not nearly so costly as in the New York metropolitan area. Jonathan Pond, a financial planner in Boston, says that on a $100,000 mortgage an 8.5 percent rate will cost a homeowner about $770 a month, or $70 a month more than a 7.5 percent mortgage. "That's not the end of the world," he said.
Furthermore, home buyers are increasingly turning to adjustable-rate mortgages, which now account for 30 percent of the loans made by Countrywide Credit Industries, one of the nation's largest mortgage lenders, said Jerry Baker, a managing director of the company. At 5 percent, a typical rate now on adjustable mortgages, a $100,000 loan would cost about $525 a month vs. $770 a month for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage at 8.5 percent, Mr. Baker said.
On the average car loan of $14,750, an increase of one percentage point from last year's roughly 8 percent rate would add $7 a month to a buyer's cost, said W. Van Bussmann, associate corporate economist for the Chrysler Corporation. "I think it will take much more than what we've seen -- I hope Alan Greenspan isn't listening -- to choke off the auto recovery," he said.
 
One Area Little Affected
 As for credit card rates, they are unlikely to jump, in part because most never fell. According to The Bank Rate Monitor's weekly survey of 100 large banks and savings institutions, the current average rate on a fixed-rate card is 17.6 percent, barely down from 18.1 percent in April 1989.
Are consumers likely to change their behavior in light of these increases? "No, I do not see that," said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, a coalition of consumer advocacy groups based in Washington.
Because consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the country's economic activity, how average Americans react to rising rates will have a big effect, however, on whether the Federal Reserve succeeds in walking its tightrope, slowing the economy and keeping inflation in check, without sending the country into recession.
"The economy can probably brush off rising interest rates, but the Fed would be forced to brake even harder, the bond market would be more nervous, and rates would spike," said Christopher Probyn, director of forecasting for the economics firm DRI/ McGraw Hill. "Eventually the economy would come to a dead stop and go into a tailspin -- probably in 1996."
 
'Perverse Effects
 On the other hand, "you can overstate the impact of rising interest rates," said David Kelly, an economist with Lehman Brothers, the investment banking firm. "They sometimes have perverse effects, so people will go out and buy that car while they can still get a good rate. When rates fell, we also got the very sad story of older Americans who weren't able to get much return on assets locked up in certificates of deposit with miserable rates of return. Rising rates help them out, help overall consumer income."
"Rates were something of a double-edged sword when they fell," he added, "and they will be a double-edged sword when they rise."
The Fed has raised short-term interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point since Feb. 4, and banks have followed, increasing their base lending rate -- the prime rate -- also by three-quarters of a point, to 6.75 percent.
The most interest-sensitve area of the economy is home buying, and rates on fixed-rate 30-year mortgages, which fell as low as 6.75 percent last fall and ended the year at 7.2 percent, have now climbed to 8.4 percent, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association's weekly survey of 25 of its largest members.
 
Varied Results
 The increase has caused a sharp drop in the number of people refinancing their loans, but only a modest decrease in the number of people applying for new loans. "Applications for refinancings have dropped a ton; those for new purchases are just starting to show a weakness just at the edges," said Lyle Gramley, the association's chief economist.
A big reason for that, he said, is that by traditional standards, mortage rates remain relatively low. The current rate of 8.4 percent is "the highest since the middle of 1992," he said, but then pointed out that "except for the past two years, it's the lowest since the first half of 1973."
None of this is to suggest that some would-be homeowners, particularly first-time and low-income buyers, will not be squeezed out of the mortgage market because of higher interest rates.
But even consumers who suffer more pain than gain from rising interest rates will benefit from them in the long run, most economists say. "From the standpoint of the average individual, if the Fed succeeds before inflation heats up, then rates will go up much less than they otherwise would," said Mr. Gramley of the Mortgage Banks Association. "If inflation begins to revive, the average person would get hit a lot harder."

HEADLINE: Yale Program to Strengthen New Haven Offers University's Employees Money to Buy Homes

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, April 20

 BODY:
In an effort to stabilize New Haven's impoverished neighborhoods, Yale University said today that it would give its employees $20,000 if they buy homes in the city before January 1996.
The employees would receive $2,000 a year for 10 years. The program is open to any Yale employee who works more than 20 hours a week, the university said. 
 The program is part of a broad effort by Yale to strengthen the city around it, whose crime and violence at times spill over onto the campus. Since the murder of a Yale student on the edge of the campus in 1991, the university has improved security and increased its efforts to improve the surrounding neighborhoods.
Despite the city's problems, 42 percent of faculty members live in New Haven, according to the university's latest figures.
Yale is not the first university to offer such incentives. The University of Chicago offers second mortgages to faculty members living near campus and has invested in cooperative apartments near the campus. The programs "have been a major stabilizing influence" on the surrounding neighborhood, said Jonathan Kleinbard, the university's vice president for community affairs. In the late 1970's, the University of Pennsylvania offered financial incentives for faculty members and employees living within 30 blocks of the Philadelphia campus.
Yale's program differs from some in that it does not offer incentives for renters.
For some employees, however, buying a house may be too costly, even with the university's help.
"For people who can afford homes, I think it's a very good idea," said Eva Heater, a cataloguing assistant at the music library who rents an apartment in New Haven. "But, even with this financial incentive, you would have to make a lot of money to buy a house."
Yale's president, Richard C. Levin, a 23-year resident of New Haven, said the program was a way to strengthen city neighborhoods.
"We are hopeful," he said, "that it will attract additional residents to the city who will be active contributors to their neighborhoods and who will, of course, contribute as taxpayers to the economic health of the city."
Cynthia Russett, a history professor, said that housing in New Haven is attractive because of lower prices than in the suburbs, and that the $20,000 from the university will make it even more attractive, "But," she said, "you also have to weigh that against the tax burden, the services that are delivered, and the school system."
Mr. Levin said the $20,000 incentive would have a greater effect on people buying lower-priced homes, like those on the edges of campus. A November 1993 Yale committee report on housing recommended that the university concentrate on rehabilitating the Park/Howe/Dwight neighborhood on the western edge of the campus. With a local property manager, the university bought an apartment building in that neighborhood in December and is upgrading the apartments.
Mr. Levin also announced the creation of a $5 million fund for investment in biomedical and biotech companies in the city. Yale will match dollar for dollar investments by selected venture capital firms in companies locating in New Haven's Science Park or any future center in the city.
The programs are part of a series of strategic Yale investments in the city. Yale is contributing $2 million toward a $6 million joint project with the city to revitalize a retail district near the center of campus. The university has invested $12.5 million in a $108 million project to rebuild and rehabilitate the downtown Ninth Square neighborhood. Yale also created the President's Public Service Fellowships to finance 20 students' community-service activities in New Haven during the summer.

HEADLINE: Home Building Shows a Brisk Recovery

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
Home construction snapped back smartly in March from midwinter weather doldrums as builders broke ground at a rate 12.1 percent faster than February's, the Commerce Department reported today.
Last month's annual pace of 1,473,000 new dwellings was somewhat brisker than expected and embraced all regions of the country, though half the advance was concentrated in the Midwest. 
 But higher interest rates were seen as already cutting into housing activity, and some specialists said today that the March pace might prove the strongest of 1994.
Warren Lasko, head of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, estimated that 250,000 potential buyers had been priced out of the market by the run-up that has lifted rates on conventional loans to 8 1/2 percent from a low of 6 3/4 percent in late October. Mr. Lasko predicted rates would be "creeping" above 9 percent in early 1995. Two percentage points on a typical $100,000 mortgage translates into $140 a month in higher payments.
A less pessimistic view was expressed by Robert R. Davis, chief economist for the Savings and Community Bankers of America, an association of savings institutions. He said the March pace could be sustained because affordability was not likely to be reduced enough to keep people from buying houses in a strong economy.
The Federal Reserve's drive to raise short-term interest rates, in fact, could allow mortgage rates to ease a bit during the second half of the year if markets are reassured about the prospects of keeping inflation in check, Mr. Davis added.
The March rebound in housing starts was attributed mainly to the return of normal weather from the especially harsh conditions that had earlier prevailed in the eastern part of the country. Starts also probably benefited from higher interest rates, goading some "fence sitters" into action before rates rose even further.
But the benefit of higher rates has now waned, said David F. Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. Any lingering effect "is going to be overwhelmed by the people filtered out" for not having enough income to qualify for higher-rate loans, mainly first-time buyers, he said.
Today's housing report was marked by an 11.3 percent advance in single-family starts, to a 1,247,000 annual pace, and a rare surge for apartment houses. Dwellings in buildings of five or more units jumped 20.5 percent, to a rate of 194,000, the most for any month in the last year except for December when builders rushed to take advantage of a restored tax credit for low-income housing.
Starts leaped 30.4 percent in the Midwest, to a 330,000 pace, but gains elsewhere were much smaller. Builders started 8.7 percent more homes in the West (a 375,000 pace), 8.4 percent more in the Northeast (142,000) and 7 percent more in the South (626,000).
The actual number of groundbreakings last month was 131,700, up 37.9 percent from the March 1993 total, the report also showed.
 
Permits Climb 5.1%
 Permits issued for home construction climbed 5.1 percent last month to a 1,314,000 annual pace, with the Northeast up 14.8 percent, the Midwest up 5.6 percent, the South up 5.3 percent and the West up 1.2 percent.
Although the number of permits is widely considered a gauge of future activity, Mr. Seiders of the home builders' group has found historic correlation to be poor. He points instead to the association's surveys of builders, which are now emitting storm warnings.
Only 38 percent of builders surveyed in April believe sales will be "good" over the coming six months, down from 48 percent in March and from 72 percent at the November 1993 peak.
Today's report also disclosed that producers of mobile homes shipped new units at a seasonally adjuted annual rate of 301,000 in February, 5 percent below January's 316,000.

HEADLINE: Banks' Securities Trading Makes Comptroller Fearful

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
In a sharp policy shift, the Clinton Administration's top bank regulator expressed alarm today that the nation's biggest commercial banks were taking too many risks in trading stocks, bonds, foreign currencies and other financial instruments. He said new regulatory limits might be needed.
The official, Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency, criticized two related but distinct approaches banks have taken to expand their securities trading as traditional corporate lending operations have withered. One approach involves increasingly speculative trading operations; the other involves derivatives, which are complicated contracts that allow traders to bet on the direction of future price changes in stocks, bonds, currencies and other financial instruments. 
 Banks have bought and sold bonds and currencies for years to limit their losses if interest rates or exchange rates suddenly move in an unexpected direction, or to help customers find scarce bonds and currencies. But in recent years they have used more complicated financial instruments like derivatives for these purposes and have increasingly sought profits from trades unrelated to reducing risks or serving customers.
Mr. Ludwig, who oversees more than 3,000 federally chartered banks -- three-fifths of the banking industry -- expressed his worries today in a speech to the Exchequer Club, a group of economic policy makers, financial lobbyists and wealthy investors.
Until now, Administration and Federal Reserve officials have tended to play down Congressional concerns about bank trading practices and derivatives. It was unclear whether Mr. Ludwig was simply responding to Congressional pressures or actually intended to take quick action on banks. He would not elaborate on his speech.
Douglas E. Harris, a senior policy adviser to Mr. Ludwig, said that the Comptroller's office had become more worried about banks' trading risks after reviewing information the agency gathered in preparation for a House Banking Committee hearing last week.
Edward L. Yingling, the chief lobbyist for the American Bankers Association, said the industry trade group would oppose any move by the Comptroller's office or by Congress that would impose tougher limits on commercial banks than on insurance companies, securities firms and other financial services businesses that engage in securities trading. Special limits on commercial banks would put them at a competitive disadvantage, he said.
Mr. Ludwig said he was concerned about federally insured institutions whose failure might cost taxpayers money.
Mr. Ludwig said in his speech that limits might be needed on the size of bank trading desks that operate independently of such traditional bank operations as buying and selling for customers and reducing risk. He compared these trading desks to hedge funds, which are investment partnerships, usually of fewer than 100 wealthy investors, that borrow heavily to take highly speculative positions in securities and commodities.
About 6 Banks
 Mr. Ludwig had mentioned last week that six nationally chartered banks had trading desks that he considered speculative, but he refused then and today to identify them. Many banks have trading desks.
He also warned today that banks might not belong in the derivatives market at all, adding that banks accounted for $12 trillion of the $14 trillion market for derivatives in the United States.
"Because of our increasing concern about the risks posed by exotic and complex derivative instruments, we are looking at whether they are appropriate for national banks -- and, if so, to what extent they are appropriate, and whether we need to take further regulatory action on these instruments," Mr. Ludwig said.
Mr. Ludwig's comments today coincide with growing enthusiasm in the House Banking Committee for legislation concerning bank trading of derivatives. The committee's Democratic and Republican leaders have introduced separate bills requiring extensive bank disclosure to regulators of derivatives holdings, and raising the threat of barring from the banking industry any bank executives who fail to supervise derivatives trading adequately.
Mr. Ludwig said today that while he perceived no immediate threat to the financial soundness of big banks, his agency would nonetheless send out 20 pages of policy guidance to senior bankers next week and would consider drafting new regulations.
The guidance would consist of answers to commonly asked questions about the agency's position on derivatives, he said. Mr. Harris said that the new guidance would expand and elaborate on existing policy, but would not represent a change in direction.
The office of the Comptroller first issued guidance on derivatives trading to banks in October. But Mr. Ludwig said today that after subsequent Federal examinations of large banks, "We are still not comfortable with the extent of senior management and board knowledge and oversight of bank derivative instruments."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues to Slump Along With Stock Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against the German mark yesterday for the third straight day as slumping stock prices eroded confidence in the American currency.
"The dollar has a bad aura about it because of the slump in stocks," said Steve Flanagan, a trader at Paine Webber. "Currency traders are quick to sell when they sense weakness like this." 
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6872 marks, down from 1.7001 marks on Tuesday. It was little changed at 103.05 Japanese yen, down from 103.20 yen.
Rising interest rates often buoy the dollar by making dollar-denominated assets more attractive. Instead, slumping stocks and bonds kept the dollar under wraps since February, when the Fed pushed up the Federal funds rate on overnight loans to banks. The Fed raised it to 3.75 percent from 3.5 percent on Monday. It was at 3 percent at the start of the year.
"The dollar is getting hurt because there's so much capital flowing out of the U.S.," said Frank Pusateri, a foreign-exchange adviser at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "People are scared out of their minds about what the Fed is going to do next."
 
German Rate Cut
 Even interest-rate cuts in Germany failed to lift the dollar from its torpor. The dollar languished after the Bundesbank cut its two-week securities repurchase rate to 5.58 percent from 5.70 percent. "Repos" are the most important means of refinancing for German banks, accounting for two-thirds of their short-term borrowing.
"People are wary of owning dollars," in part because the currency failed to rally with so many economic conditions on its side, said Dave Glowacki, senior trader at NBD Bank in Detroit.
Because German interest rates are still higher than American rates, it costs traders money to hold dollars against marks while they wait for the dollar currency to rally. Each day the dollar fails to rise, more traders sell off their dollar holdings.
Slumping European stock and bond prices also helped the mark gain against most major currencies today, traders said. Investors often buy the mark, a stable currency that offers high interest rates, when other markets falter.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Prices Off Sharply After Early Rally Collapses

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Lumber futures reversed an early rally yesterday and fell the daily trading limit, extending a recent decline to six-month lows despite signs of a reviving housing market.
Initially, lumber for May delivery jumped its $10 daily limit after the Commerce Department reported that housing starts rose 12.1 percent, to 1.47 million units, in March from 1.31 million units the month before. 
 "Once the emotion of the housing numbers was over, the reality of burdensome inventories took over the marketplace," said Mike Young of Pacific Futures Trading.
The May lumber contract ended the maximum $10 lower at $316.90 for a thousand board feet, the lowest since mid-October at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Much of the increase in construction last month was expected as builders caught up after harsh winter weather brought activity to a virtual halt in the Northeast and Midwest.
Housing construction is still lagging behind the fourth quarter of last year, in part because of recent rises in interest rates that make it more expensive to borrow and build.
"The effect of higher interest rates down the road will have a negative impact on housing starts as we get on down the year," Mr. Young said.
In the cash market, spruce two-by-fours were officially quoted at $318 for a thousand board feet, down $5 from late last week. But unofficially, prices were as low as $300 in some areas.
"Futures are still overvalued, unless we get some cash activity," said Bud Merrill, forest products analyst for Smith Barney Shearson.
On other commodity markets, early worries about weather conditions pushed up corn and soybean prices, and oil prices rose in light trading.
At the Chicago Board of Trade, May soybeans rose 5.25 cents, to $6.66 a bushel, and the November contract, which corresponds to next fall's harvest, gained 8.25 cents, to $6.2125. May corn firmed 0.75 cent, to $2.605, and the December contract added 3 cents, to $2.5175, a bushel.
May crude oil rose to a five-month high before expiring at $16.82 a barrel, up 33 cents, at the New York Mercantile Exchange. June crude rose 20 cents, to $16.32.
Traders said the market was affected by technical trading strategies and buying related to the May contract's expiration.
May heating oil gained 0.23 cent, to 46.25 cents a gallon, while May unleaded gasoline lost 0.02 cent, to 48.78 cents a gallon, with gasoline prices still affected by rumors of European imports heading for the United States.
In addition, prices for oil products were under pressure because the level at which refineries were operating, as reported by the American Petroleum Institute late Tuesday, climbed two percentage points, to nearly 91 percent of capacity last week.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Continue Improvement for 2d Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities gained for the second consecutive day yesterday as the market continued to improve after a selloff on Monday caused by the Federal Reserve Board's third interest rate increase of the year.
Gerald A. Guild, senior manager in charge of fixed-income securities at Advest Inc., said the market had suddenly realized that the economy was not as strong as expected, "as evidenced by the very large trade deficit numbers on Tuesday." He added, "The weakening of the economy would benefit the bond market because inflation would not be a consideration." 
 "However," he said, "I suspect the bond market may have hit a double bottom on Monday, and that long-term interest rates could decline from here as people start to realize that the Fed is serious about controlling inflation in the years ahead. It may have been a successful test of the peak in long-term interest rates at 7.41 percent, and technically interest rates could decline from this point as the market returns to fundamentals."
Analysts said investors' belief that the Fed would continue to raise rates had not allowed bonds to rally for weeks. That belief was reinforced by Wayne D. Angell, a former governor of the Fed and the chief economist for Bear, Stearns & Company, who said on CNBC yesterday that he expected the Fed to raise rates again in May.
 
Commodity Prices Drop
 A drop in commodity prices, working like a counterbalance to some of the market's negative tones, has been viewed by many market watchers as an indication of future inflation pressures. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of prices for 21 commodities, ranging from pork bellies to lumber, slipped below 220 yesterday for the first time since December, before finishing at 220.31.
"The drop in commodity prices suggest that prices paid for other goods will also decline, dampening chances of inflation," said James Hale, senior fixed-income strategist for MMS International in San Francisco.
By late in the day the 30-year bond was up 18/32 , to 876/32 , to yield 7.32 percent, down from 7.36 percent on Tuesday. Shorter-maturity bill rates were down slightly, as the short end of the market may be benefiting from the weakness in stocks.
Also yesterday, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said in testimony before a Senate committee that the recent rise in long-term interest rates could harm the economy if it was not reversed. "I am hoping we can cause them to settle down some," Mr. Bentsen said of the long-term rates. "Otherwise, they will have some dampening effect on growth."
Analysts said Mr. Bentsen's comments indicated that the economy had not been damaged by the three recent moves by the Fed to increase the Federal funds on overnight interbank loans.
 
Strong Housing Report
 Government securities also held their ground despite a relatively strong housing report for March, which some economists said might be a good indication that the market would consolidate at current levels.
The economists said the release on Tuesday of the higher-than-expected United States trade deficit had changed the market's sentiment about economic growth. Growth, which the consensus had expected to be 4 percent in the first quarter, has fallen to an estimate of about 3.50 percent or lower, economists said.
Traders were cautious in the early going, ahead of the announcement about the sizes of next week's two-year and five-year note auctions. The traders were waiting to see if another short-covering rally would give way to profit taking if the auctions got bigger, a signal that the Government's borrowing needs had grown. But the sizes of the auctions were unchanged.
In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.71 percent, and the five-year note was issued at a price to yield 6.63 percent.
 
Remarks by Economist
 Mr. Angell said on CNBC that the Fed's tightening was meant to insure that the economy did not grow strongly. He said the growth potential was greater than anticipated, and that the Fed had estimated gross domestic product growth potential at 3 percent, pointing out that the markets were pricing a Federal funds rate of 5.25 percent by December. The market believes the Fed's target is the current rate of 3.75 percent.

HEADLINE: Furniture Throws A Romantic Curve

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C., April 16

 BODY:
Teen-agers wearing cow and bull costumes were standing on street corners passing out leaflets on the glories of leather furniture. They were joined by a man wearing a fabric-covered sandwich board that looked like a mattress. But the 69,000 visitors to the Spring International Home Furnishings Market in High Point, a small city reveling in magnolias, dogwood and apple trees in full bloom, weren't there just to buy everyday furnishings.
At the nine-day market, which opened to the trade last Thursday, the 2,100 exhibitors were selling romance in the shape of furniture. Consumers will see the furniture in stores in six months. Unlike fashion shows, where the clothes shown on the runway are usually adapted for the stores (hemlines drop, for example), the furniture industry delivers to the stores what it shows at the market. 
 If the furniture industry has its way, Americans will be living like impoverished nobility next year. Sofas will be covered with a patchwork of brocade, chintz and canvas. Beds will have ornate headboards of woven metal, mosaics or rattan. (Footboards will be very low, for ease of television viewing.) Velvet pillows will be scattered everywhere.
Whether made of rattan, mahogany or metal, whether inspired by the 19th century or the mid-20th, furniture will be voluptuous and curvy, or it will have rich textures. Curves and lush texture signify romance. And romance spells money.
The "trashed palace" look -- as Ronnie Wells, the owner of Manderley, a furniture manufacturer in San Rafael, Calif., described what she saw at the market -- is a look of eclecticism and individuality.
"People are shopping for single items, buying the table one place, the chair someplace else," said Mark Hampton, the Manhattan interior decorator who designs for the Hickory (N.C.) Chair Company.
Customers aren't ordering matched sets. They aren't buying a style -- Chippendale or Danish modern. Instead, people are mixing different styles and coming up with their own style, call it "trashed palace" or "grandma's attic" -- and the more idiosyncratic the better.
"The tag is emotion," said Robert Currey, owner of Currey & Company, a furniture maker in Atlanta. Manufacturers want furniture buyers to feel like Rod Kreitzer, president of Baker Furniture in Grand Rapids, Mich., who said, laughing, "I've got stuff I'd give my wife up for."
For the industry, this is a period of rebuilding. As the economy soured, retail sales of furniture dropped from $36.9 billion in 1989 to $33.4 billion in 1991, according to the International Home Furnishings Marketing Association, sponsor of the market. The industry made up that loss only last year, said Jake Froehlich, a managing partner in Market Square, which owns 1.1 million square feet of showroom space, about a seventh of the market's total.
"Our customers, middle management, lost jobs," said William Merrill, the director of design at Hickory Chair. And when that happens, the first thing they stop buying is furniture and appliances, Mr. Hampton, the designer, said.
To try to lure customers back, Mr. Merrill said, "we go around adding moldings and palm trees and whirring fans -- moods." Under one of those fans in Hickory Chair's showroom was Mr. Hampton's voluptuous wicker lounge chair ($1,535) and matching ottoman ($725.)
Several blocks away, in the Market Square building, was Francisco Pinedo's sofa upholstered in brocade, cotton ticking and flowered chintz, designed for Cisco & Brothers in Los Angeles ($2,200). In the same building, Ms. Wells of Manderley, similarly inspired, showed an overstuffed armchair covered in a faded pink floral with a celery and ecru stripe and brown velvet piping ($1,600).
In the Commerce and Design building, Robert Williams's overstuffed sofa ($1,300) for Designline Ltd. in Taylorsville, N.C., was upholstered in brocade, chintz and linen.
"The best mix is when the fabrics blend monochromatically," said Peri Wolfman, an owner of Wolfman-Gold and Good Company, a store in SoHo. "It's easiest to live with in the long run."
To light the new eclectic rooms, Zev Vaughn, the president of Public Domain, a manufacturer in Manhattan, designed a crystal chandelier he called Twisted Venetian. Made from a spiral shaft of handblown glass with flexible metal arms and garlands of crystal teardrops, the chandelier looked like the creation of Mad King Ludwig of Bavaria let loose in a Venetian glass studio ($2,500).
Along with chandeliers gone askew, there was gilt gone frivolous. In the basement of the International Home Furnishings Center were thrones designed by Angele Parlange and William Sonner of New Orleans. In a booth covered in billowing lengths of shocking-pink silk, they offered a chair with a hand-carved, cross-shaped back of gilded poplar and a seat of red velvet ($1,800).
The most emphasized piece of furniture at the market was the most essential: the bed, overscaled and romantic, yet striking. Dakota Jackson, a Manhattan designer who was a study in monochromatic sartorial splendor in a gray suit just a shade darker than his silver-gray hair, offered a sleek and modern but richly textured bed of woven metal ($2,900) in his first collection for the Lane Company of Altavista, Va.
For customers who want to design their own furniture, Ercole, a Manhattan company specializing in mosaics, offered a lacy metal headboard with a mosaic medallion that can be custom-designed ($1,500 for the headboard, $2,400 for a complete frame).
In its first mass-market collection, Parish-Hadley, the Manhattan interior design firm, introduced a deep red lacquered four-poster with metal finials in the shape of plumes ($5,168) for Baker Furniture. An antique star quilt made the formal-looking bed cozy.
If palaces and attics were in the spotlight, so were the 1940's and 50's, especially the designs of Isamu Noguchi. The boomerang table, an icon of mid-century modern design inspired by Noguchi, was shown twice, in mahogany with spun-aluminum legs ($930 at Milling Road, a division of Baker Furniture), and in double-tiered glass ($325 by Bill Becker, the president of BDI in Chantilly, Va.).
For Marty and Nancy Tucker, the owners of Tucker Design in Wilder, Vt., the market transcends romance. They met at the fall market in 1989, married and have worked together ever since. Asked how long they have been together, Ms. Tucker responded, "For nine markets."

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Confessions of a Former Alarmist

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Here's a how-de-do! A network news special that makes light of the perils on which network news specials thrive. ABC's "Are We Scaring Ourselves to Death?" is a sharp expose of exposes about crime, pollution and other television favorites.
Leading the charge is a repentant sinner. In a mea culpa before an audience at Seton Hall University, John Stossel, who made his reputation as a consumer-affairs reporter, admits to having played up such transient worries as train accidents, lawn chemicals and coffee makers. But he has found the light and now maintains that in addition to raising blood pressures, the incessant scaremongering feeds public misapprehension and leads to the misallocation of public money. 
 His evidence is mainly statistical. Whatever impression you may get from television, for example, crime, including violent crime, is not rising. (The program includes a clip from a "20/20" segment, reported by one John Stossel, about "criminals dressed like cops, getting away with murder and robbery and rape.") Older Americans, who express the most nervousness about crime, maybe because they watch more news programs, actually have the least to worry about. (Although his targets have changed, Mr. Stossel cannot quite shake off news-magazine hyperbole. Now he is warning of the perils to the affluent elderly of living in "gated communities," which he describes as "fortresses like something out of the Middle Ages.")
The people who ought to be worried, and worried about, says Mr. Stossel, are black male teen-agers in the inner cities; their chances of being on the receiving end of violence are stunningly high.
Popular dangers that you need not lose sleep over abound. Mr. Stossel makes a case, for example, that the reaction to asbestos-flaking in New York City schools was overwrought but that no politician or official dared say so in the face of parental concern, stirred up by local television news. The expensive attempt to remove the asbestos, he says, not only may have spread the stuff into the air, but may also have subjected some children to more palpable dangers by leaving them on the streets while the schools were closed. (He does not go so far as to assert that the children may have been deprived of learning something in the classrooms.)
Also noted, as the debunking proceeds, is the lack of evidence of increased cancer at Love Canal, the object of much hand wringing by television reporters, and the unjustified agitation over the use of Alar on apples, stirred up by "60 Minutes." Mr. Stossel suggests, too, that the cost of tamper-proof packages is as excessive as the commotion about a few instances of contamination. (Not counting the damage to fingers and psyches in the efforts to open them.)
Particular attention is given to a lead-infested site in Aspen, Colo., that has made the Environmental Protection Agency's Superfund list. The agency wants to remove 150 houses, and dig up and dispose of tons of earth. In a striking reversal of the usual environmental scare story, this ambitious project has so far been blocked by residents who, besides not wanting to be bothered, argue that the lead, which has been in the ground for 100 years, has not been shown to have hurt anybody. (Just as pictures of stricken children are customarily used to arouse emotions about the risk of the hour, so pictures of healthy children are presented here as a testament to the harmless or beneficial nature of the lead.)
Despite the evidence, officials tell Mr. Stossel they are still determined to go ahead with their earth moving, possibly in accord with the principle that once an agency has been given the power and money to do something, facts must not be allowed to get in the way.
Mr. Stossel also engages in an amusing exchange with Ralph Nader, who has evidently never met a product he liked. Here he warns against hot dogs, carpets, chickens and coffee, including some sorts of decaffeinated coffee. He is also not wild about flying.
For viewers in need of serious things to worry about, Mr. Stossel offers automobile accidents, smoking, falling down stairs and, especially, poverty. He maintains, much like business spokesmen, that regulations to prevent minor or imagined risks are a brake on the economy and that the money would be better used to create jobs.
After the hourlong report, Mr. Stossel gives the regulators and health campaigners in the audience an opportunity to respond to his argument that "since your rules probably made America a little poorer, might you have killed people in the name of safety?" (Viewers may add a new worry of their own. What will Mr. Stossel do with himself now that he has abjured his calling?)
You don't have to agree with Mr. Stossel on all particulars to welcome tonight's program as a breath of good sense in the fear-and-trembling atmosphere of much television news. The evening's lesson: Don't panic about decaf, but try not to swallow too much Ralph Nader.
 
Are We Scaring Ourselves to Death?
ABC, tonight at 10
(Channel 7 in New York)
 
A special produced by Jeff Diamond for ABC News; anchor and reporter, John Stossel; Victor Neufeld, executive producer.

HEADLINE: Bosnia: A Promising Package

 BODY:
If the new military and diplomatic moves announced by President Clinton yesterday afternoon win endorsement from NATO and Russian leaders, they will constitute the most promising international initiative yet to bring the two-year-old Bosnian war to a workable diplomatic settlement.
The package includes proposals for extending the kind of NATO air threats that now protect Sarajevo to the other five U.N.-declared protected cities, tightening enforcement of international economic sanctions against Serbia and taking unspecified steps to better coordinate U.S., European and Russian diplomacy. Formal NATO endorsement of the package is considered likely and Russian approval is at least a strong possibility. 
 As the President made clear, the objective is not to defeat the Serbs, or even roll back all their forcible gains, but to make them "pay a higher price" until they agree to negotiate in good faith.
The "Sarajevo formula" of demanding the withdrawal of heavy weapons from the safe zones and backing that demand with the threat of air strikes worked in Sarajevo in February, and can work again, especially with Russian endorsement and support. That is where the plans for new diplomatic coordination come in.
Protecting all six U.N.-declared havens is urgent for more than just humanitarian regions. Holding those Muslim and mixed areas outside of Serbian military control is essential to the design of any workable territorial settlement.
Tighter enforcement of economic sanctions is a worthwhile though less immediately significant step. It is certainly a more appropriate response to Serbian duplicity than the earlier European proposal for a phased easing of the embargo in return for marginal Serb diplomatic concessions.
All along, the Clinton Administration's performance on Bosnia has been better than it looked. True, its public diplomacy has been maddeningly vague and its military tactics questionable. The Serbian penetration of Gorazde has been, like so much of the Bosnia war, a humanitarian disaster, this time with the added element of public humiliation of the U.N. and NATO.
Yet consider what the Clinton Administration has done right over the past 15 months. Almost alone, it resisted cynical European schemes for an enforced peace at the expense of the principal victims, until finally the Europeans became more evenhanded. It has advocated, though not energetically enough, an end to the U.N. arms embargo that prevents the Bosnian Government from adequately defending itself.
It has held out against an unwise commitment of U.S. ground troops to what would have been a mission impossible of enforcing a peace no Bosnian faction sincerely accepted. And it has understood all along that air strikes are not a magic formula capable of instantly reversing the fortunes of war.
As a result of the Clinton Administration's policies, the Serbs are now more isolated internationally and the U.S., Western Europe and Russia are closer to coordinating their policies than ever before in this war.
Even now, as NATO prepares to widen its air cover, a diplomatic rather than military solution must remain the goal. The object, put crudely, is to bomb the Serbs to the peace table and to preserve the integrity of all six U.N.-declared safe havens.
That will stir up bad memories from the Vietnam War, when the Johnson Administration's efforts to bomb its Vietnamese enemy to the peace table ended in disaster. Since that time, the Pentagon has argued that Washington's only military choices are massive intervention or no intervention at all. That is an unrealistic straitjacket for a global power; it is time to discard it.

HEADLINE: Singapore's Drug Policy Cuts Addiction

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I have just returned from a fact-finding trip to Singapore. The aim was to study first hand the drug policy of this city state. During my stay, I did not observe any of the features of a totalitarian regime, which were reported April 10, and which I experienced first hand as a youth in occupied France (1940-44) where imprisonment or deportation to death camps punished the mere expression of dissent. 
 In Singapore I read daily The International Herald Tribune and The Wall Street Journal, and noted that Time, Newsweek and The Economist were prominently displayed on newsstands. If The Straits Times of Singapore does not openly criticize government policies, it does not heap praise on government officials or the senior minister and it does not toe a propaganda line. It is a well-informed, cogent publication, with a comprehensive coverage of world news. I never felt the pervasive oppression prevailing in Nazi occupied countries or in those of the Soviet bloc, which I visited from 1947 to 1980.
If the drug policy of Singapore imposes the death penalty on traffickers, its main feature is a most comprehensive and costly compulsory rehabilitation program for former heroin addicts in specialized centers aimed at preparing the addict for a drug-free life. Such remedial training imposes on the trainees strict discipline and offers them a choice of highly structured workshops, including university courses, music, construction trades and computer technology. Competent civilian specialists teach the different courses and award state-recognized diplomas. The results of such a policy are positive. The number of drug addicts has decreased from 8,000 in 1980 to 4,000 at present in a population of 3 million.
In New York, with 10 million inhabitants, the number of addicts might be conservatively estimated at 150,000, and many of them 14 to 18 years old. Over 1,500 deaths by overdose are reported in a year.
There is no unemployment in Singapore, and continuous economic expansion; people enjoy social benefits which compare favorably to the United States.
 
GABRIEL G. NAHAS, M.D.
New York, April 14, 1994

HEADLINE: The Massacres in Rwanda: Hope Is Also a Victim

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 20

 BODY:
Tiny Rwanda has never been strategically significant in world politics. But for more than two decades this poor, overpopulated central African country has been a successful laboratory for foreign aid.
Its small size, cooperative government, relative lack of corruption and excellent roads, telephone systems and electric utilities attracted hundreds of millions of dollars to test development projects and made the country largely dependent on international generosity. 
 But after two weeks in which tens of thousands of people have been massacred and thousands of Europeans and Americans have fled, much of Rwanda's gains have been threatened or lost. Even if stability is restored quickly, the hope of reclaiming the agricultural or industrial achievements in less than five years appears bleak.
The killing and the anarchy have now spread beyond Kigali, the capital, destroying the West's efforts to promote democracy and respect for human rights, the quid pro quo for aid in Africa in recent years. For the moment, several hundred million dollars of aid has been suspended. Without foreign aid workers, many programs have stopped.
Faced first with the crisis caused by the hundreds of thousands of refugees, Rwanda must also replace an educated elite of Rwandans who have fled or have been killed.
 
Short Term Is Bleak
 Diplomats and aid officials are also unsure of Rwanda's ability to maintain a stable democracy. They fear Rwanda may become another Somalia, whose society has been so torn apart by civil war that it is barely able to survive.
"They will have to start again on Square 1," said Armon Hartmann, head of the Eastern and Southern African section of the Swiss Development Cooperation, a major donor. "They will have to prove to us that they can qualify for our technical assistance. To come back to the level we had just a few weeks ago could take four or five years."
But in Kigali the violence continues. Rwandan police officers executed 16 people today who were pulled from more than 5,000 refugees huddled in the national stadium, The Associated Press reported. On Tuesday, Rwandan Army troops shelled the stadium, killing 40.
Hundreds of United Nations peacekeepers also withdrew today, reducing the contingent of 2,500 by half, The A.P. said. Among those who left were more than 450 Belgians, 213 Bangladeshis and 144 Ghanaians. The Security Council, preoccupied with Bosnia, has taken no decisive action on Rwanda since the killing began two weeks ago.
 
The Warring Parties
 The fighting, provoked by a suspicious plane crash on April 6 that killed the Presidents of Rwanda and neighboring Burundi, both Hutu, has been fed by tribal hatred between the majority Hutu and the minority Tutsi.
But the killing, at least in its initial stages, was mostly politically motivated, set off by hard-line Hutu who disapproved of a new Government that integrated Hutu and Tutsi.
"There is a determination to dominate politically," said David Rawson, the United States Ambassador to Rwanda, who was evacuated home last week. "It is heart rending -- the beauty of the whole place, the responsiveness of the people, their desire for a better life, for democracy and development, set against this intense struggle to dominate, a struggle for political power.
"If you get into a stalemate and trench warfare in which the country totally exhausts itself and there is anarchy in the countryside, then we could have taken a step backward into Somalia."
 
Poverty Breeds Dependence
 With about 8 million inhabitants in 10,169 square miles, Rwanda is one of the world's poorest countries, the second most densely populated after Bangladesh. With an economy more than 90 percent agricultural, nearly every bit of land is under cultivation. In 1992, it had a gross national product of $1.6 billion and a debt of $873 million, and more than 50 percent of its budget was covered by foreign aid.
Belgium, a former colonial power and one of the biggest donors, provided about $30 million a year in the late 1980's and early 90's, followed by France, Germany and Switzerland. The United States provided $20 million a year in development aid until last year, when the figure fell to $14 million as Washington switched its funds to assistance for the hundreds of thousands of refugees created by the simmering civil wars in both Rwanda and Burundi.
Since the beginning of the civil war in 1990, foreign donors have been putting increasing pressure on the Government to make peace with the rebels of the Rwandan Patriotic Front, most of whom are Tutsi.
"This country was conscious of its situation and that it needed foreign help to survive," said a senior Belgian diplomat in Nairobi. "After such a disaster, it will take some time to re-establish relations."
 
Putting Aid to Good Use
 Rwanda has attracted donors for many reasons. Its needs are desperate, but the country is small enough that the impact of aid can be quickly seen. Communications were good, and rural development was a Government priority.
"It was a country with a very good record, proposing and implementing development activities," Ambassador Rawson said. "Obviously our democratization efforts aren't getting very far. If only we could somehow get a cease-fire, if you could find a number of qualified people still living or bring them back from abroad."
But to many of the relief workers evacuated last week and now waiting in Nairobi in the hope of eventually providing food, medical care and other assistance, the biggest hurdle is not winning back donors but recreating an atmosphere of confidence among the Rwandans.
"There will be a lack of trust among Rwandans," said Steve Wallace, field director in Rwanda for CARE International. "I don't think people will be wanting to work together and move the society ahead. There was a huge investment of time, effort and money. Many of the development projects will be casualties of this episode. It is pretty depressing."


CORRECTION-DATE: April 22, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday with an article about Rwanda misidentified the group responsible for shelling a stadium on Tuesday, killing 40 refugees. As the article pointed out, the shells were fired by the Rwandan Army, not by rebel forces.
 A front-page picture yesterday, showing wounded Rwandans, carried an erroneous credit in some editions. It was by The Associated Press.

HEADLINE: Athenian Games

BYLINE: By Robert D. Kaplan; Robert D. Kaplan is author of "Balkan Ghosts: A Journey Through History."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Rarely has a state visit threatened to do more damage to American interests than that of the Greek Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, which begins today. President Clinton should publicly reproach Greece for its economic embargo against the Republic of Macedonia and get a firm commitment that the Greek leader will stop coddling Serbia.
The Greeks are upset over Macedonia's name, which they consider the exclusive property of their northernmost region, over its constitution, which promises protection for Macedonians outside its borders, and over its flag, which contains the Hellenistic 16-pointed star. Mr. Papandreou's predecessor as Prime Minister, the conservative Constantine Mitsotakis, played on the dispute to retain his thin parliamentary majority. But Mr. Papandreou, with a healthy advantage in the parliament, doesn't have that excuse. 
 He takes on the airs of a modern socialist in the tradition of the late Swedish Prime Minister, Olaf Palme. But he is more like the late Argentineleader Juan Peron: a gutter populist. In the 1980's, he railed against U.S. airbases on Greek soil, calling them "American bases of death," and condemned Poland's Solidarity movement as "dangerously negative." He aided Muslim terrorists, refusing to extradite killers and allowing the Abu Nidal terrorist group to set up a logistical and financial base in downtown Athens.
With the cold war over, Mr. Papandreou has replaced his anti-Americanism with national chauvinism, stirring up support by destabilizing Macedonia, one of the few states in post-Communist Europe with a truly multiethnic Government.
Mr. Papandreou is a tried-and-true ally of the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, and the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic -- both all but convicted war criminals. He was the only NATO leader not to support the NATO ultimatum that ended the Serbs' siege of Sarajevo. And Greece has been a major sanctions-buster, exporting oil and other goods to Serbia in violation of the United Nations embargo.
Shortly after receiving his invitation to the White House earlier this year, Mr. Papandreou slapped the trade embargo on Macedonia, which is decimating the new country's economy. This is not to say that the Greeks' argument over Macedonia's name lacks merit. But to impose sanctions against a state that poses no military threat and is protected in part by hundreds of American soldiers is a hostile act toward the U.S.
Yet under pressure from prominent Greek-Americans, President Clinton has continually appeased Greece. He has not fulfilled his promise, made in February, to establish full diplomatic relations with Macedonia. In response to open criticism from the State Department, Administration officials have said Mr. Clinton will be tough in private negotiations with Mr. Papandreou. Yet the mere appearance of the two men, smiling together in the Rose Garden, will send the wrong signal to the Balkans -- a part of the Mideast where appearances are often everything.
Worse, the White House has scheduled Mr. Papandreou's visit on the anniversary of the 1967 military coup in Athens and near to Greek Orthodox Easter, both emotionally charged dates on the Greek calendar. This will further enhance Mr. Papandreou's prestige with his countrymen.
If Mr. Clinton hopes to retain any shred of credibility he may have left in the Balkans, he must get Mr. Papandreou to stop strangling Macedonia and aiding Serbia. Otherwise, if war erupts in the next few years in Macedonia and neighboring Kosovo, the Clinton-Papandreou meeting will appear in hindsight much like the 1990 meeting between Saddam Hussein and the U.S. Ambassador to Iraq, April Glaspie, that inadvertently gave Iraq a green light to invade Kuwait.
The last thing the Administration needs, while attempting a new military and diplomatic initiative in the Balkans, is to appear weak and conflicted. That is precisely what a visit from Mr. Papandreou, without significant Greek concessions, would do.

HEADLINE: Service Union And Buildings Reach Accord

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
Apartment house owners and the union representing doormen, porters and handymen reached a tentative agreement on a new three-year contract yesterday, averting a strike that would have left front desks, elevators and garbage in the hands of tenants or temporary workers.
Union leaders and officials from the owners' bargaining group, the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, said that wages and other economic issues were the main sticking point in the all-night bargaining session. 
 The talks ended shortly before 7 A.M. with an agreement on what the owners said was a 9.5 percent increase in wages and benefits over the life of the contract, a figure that real-estate specialists said was unlikely to jolt landlords' ledgers or the dollar-conscious budgets of co-ops and condominiums where union members work.
"What these numbers will do to the overall maintenance of individual apartments will be very small," said Clark P. Halstead, the managing partner of the Halstead Property Company, a Manhattan brokerage concern. "Everyone needs some modest raise, and this isn't even in accord with the cost of living. By those standards, this is modest."
 
Handymen and Superintendents
 The contract that expired at midnight yesterday, negotiated in 1991 after a 12-day strike, provided annual increases averaging about 4 percent. The new contract calls for wage increases averaging about 2 percent a year. The union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, said most workers would receive an extra $10 a week this year, another $10 next year and $12 in the final year of the contract. That will increase a doorman's salary to $528 a week this year, $538 in 1995 and $550 in 1996.
Handymen will receive a raise of $12 a week this year, another $12 a week next year and a $14-a-week increase in 1996. Superintendents' salaries will increase $13 a week this year, $12 a week in 1995 and $14 a week in 1996.
 
Anger Among Rank and File
 But some of the local's 30,000 rank-and-file members, who work at 2,800 rental, cooperative and condominium buildings in four of the five boroughs, grumbled that the deal was inadequate. Apartment-house employees in the Bronx are represented by a different local; workers in commercial buildings and housing projects run by the New York City Housing Authority are covered by different contracts.
"Ten bucks a week: I don't think it's fair," said Joe Pappas, a doorman at 327 Central Park West, at 93d Street. "With taxes taken out, you clear about $6 or $7. It costs more than that just to come to work. I'd have given up two sick days to get more money in my salary."
Ratification, though, by a 41-person committee instead of the rank and file appeared to be a virtual certainty. Dennis Sheehan, a spokesman for the union, said the committee fanned out through the city yesterday, visiting union members at the buildings where they work "to get a sense of how they feel" about the terms of the deal.
The negotiations reflected the evolution of the residential real-estate industry in the 1980's. When building service workers walked off their jobs in 1979, the strikers and most of the people who lived in the buildings where they worked shared the same foe: the landlord.
This time, as in 1991, apartment dwellers are often the owners. The 1980's co-op and condominium conversion boom shifted the balance of power on the owners' bargaining team.
 
Longer Probation Time
 Co-op and condominium owners have a personal investment in their buildings and day-to-day relationships with the members of Local 32B-32J, who keep track of residents' lives as well as their comings and goings, feeding their pets, watering their plants and bringing their dry cleaning to their doors. As a result, co-op and condominium owners might be more willing than rental landlords to let their desire for service override pocketbook issues.
Another aspect of the new contract is a longer probation period for new workers: 60 days instead of 30 under the old contract.
Owners maintained that they had raised other issues in the negotiations that could be brought up again in 1996, including a possible two-tier wage system under which new workers would be paid less than the experienced ones they replace.
While two-tier wages have not been uncommon in corporate labor settlements in the 1990's, another issue on some owners' minds was peculiar to the Local 32B-32J negotiations: summer employees.
Under the contract, replacements for vacationing workers are paid at full salary, even though the substitutes are often college students. Some owners say they should not be paid as much as full-time workers who have families. But others familiar with the negotiations say the issue is not so clear-cut: some building workers spend their vacations moonlighting as relief employees in other buildings. Their earnings would drop if replacements were paid less than regular doormen and porters.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Danny Galvin, a doorman at 700 Park Avenue near 70th Street, showed his pleasure after the union representing doormen, porters and handymen reached a tentative contract accord with apartment house owners. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
Charges that Joseph Jett executed an elaborate scheme to create $350 million in phantom profits, inflate his own bonus and conceal $100 million in losses while he was a top trader at Kidder, Peabody are a nasty twist in the plot of what was apparently a Horatio Alger tale for the 1990's. [Page D1.] 
 Stocks surged in extremely heavy trading after a three-day slump. The Dow rose 53.83 points, to 3,652.54. [D1.]
Short-selling activity climbed in the month that ended on April 8, the New York and American Stock exchanges reported. [D5.]
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen amid speculation that world economic leaders might curb the yen's rise. [D15.]
Oil prices posted solid gains amid expectations that the U.S. economy would increase its demand for petroleum products. [D15.]
Yields of Government securities fell for the third consecutive day, as inflation concerns eased in the bond market. [D17.]
 
Companies
Teledyne agreed to pay a $112.5 million fine to settle two lawsuits by former employees who accused the company of defrauding the Government. The settlement is one of the largest payments ever by a military contractor to settle whistle-blower lawsuits. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Ford Revamps With Eye on the Globe

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., April 21

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company today announced its most sweeping reorganization in more than 25 years, in a bid to compete better in the coming decades not only in its established European and North American markets, but in the potentially huge car and truck markets developing in Asia.
At the end of the year, Ford's North American Operations and Ford of Europe will vanish, merging into a single operating unit, Ford Automotive Operations, with global reach. Ford's Asian-Pacific and Latin American Operations will remain separate at least until the other, more extensive operations are merged, Ford officials said. 
 In creating the new structure, Alexander J. Trotman, Ford's British-born chairman and chief executive, is seeking to leverage the No. 2 auto maker's mammoth size -- Ford has plants in 30 countries and more than 322,000 employees worldwide -- to cut the costs of materials and other development expenses. As a result, he said today, Ford will more cheaply and quickly produce a wider variety of cars and trucks for diverse markets, from Michigan to Malaysia.
Mr. Trotman is addressing a chronic criticism of Ford: that its vehicle development process is unwieldy and wasteful. He is also realizing plans to streamline Ford's worldwide operations that he began dreaming up 25 years ago as a product planner in England. "It's a worldwide business," Mr. Trotman said.
But he is also placing a gigantic bet on the success of an ideal vehicle known as the "world car." Such a car can be sold in large numbers around the planet, with modifications for local tastes and regulations regarding styling, performance and emissions.
While many auto industry analysts praised Ford for tackling the waste in its development programs, some raised doubts about the feasibility of world cars. Indeed, many have called Ford's most recent effort at a world car -- the European Mondeo sedan and its American cousins, the Ford Contour and Mercury Mystique -- grossly inefficient.
In trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, Ford stock closed up $1.25 a share, to $55.625, in active trading. Other auto stocks also rose; General Motors shares increased 75 cents each, to $55.375, and shares of the Chrysler Corporation jumped $2, to $48.
Under its new organization plan, Ford plans to establish centers dedicated to developing specific types of vehicles that Ford will sell worldwide. Ford has run virtually distinct operations that create and sell different cars and trucks in different markets. By contrast, the new center in Europe -- divided between Dunton, England, and Merkenich, Germany -- will develop Ford's small, front-wheel-drive cars, like the Escort, for sale not just in Europe and America, but in Asia, too.
In addition to the new "Vehicle Program Center" in Europe, Ford will create centers in North America for large front-wheel-drive cars like the Taurus; for rear-wheel-drive cars like the Crown Victoria; for personal trucks like the Explorer sport utility vehicle, and for commercial trucks.
"We're going to combine the resources of a large and very successful company with the speed and responsiveness of a small company," Mr. Trotman said. "This, of course, will assure a better return for our stockholders and a more certain future for all the employees of the Ford Motor Company, and, we believe, much better product, and a wider array of product, for all of our customers around the world."
 The changes are intended to wring out duplication and other inefficiencies, such as designing similar engines from scratch for different markets, Mr. Trotman said. Because Ford's product line is set through 1998, little evidence of the changes will be seen outside the company until the end of the decade. By then, Mr. Trotman said, the savings to Ford should be at least $2 billion to $3 billion a year.
To manage the new organization, Ford elevated Edward E. Hagenlocker to the new position of president of Ford Automotive Operations. Mr. Hagenlocker, a soft-spoken Midwestern engineer with a passion for light trucks, is now the head of Ford's North American Operations. Wayne Booker, who is currently executive vice president for International Automotive Operations, will remain in charge of Asia-Pacific and Latin American operations, although Ford officials said the company would be considering merging those units with Mr. Hagenlocker's operations.
 
 
Gaining an Edge in Europe
 Ford's last reorganization of this magnitude was the creation of Ford of Europe in 1967, a move that helped to consolidate disparate operations on the Continent and in Britain. The move gave Ford a competitive advantage in Europe over its archrival, G.M., but Ford's edge has dulled in recent years.
One important effect of the reorganization announced today should be to hand more power to the people who run individual car and truck development programs, creating a system similar to the one that has worked well for Chrysler, said David E. Cole, director of the University of Michigan's Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation. In the past at Ford, Mr. Cole said, too much power was concentrated in functional groups, like engine development, that could keep program leaders from getting the people and help they needed.
 In putting his stamp on the company, Mr. Trotman is taking on several challenges. Not least is shaking up a huge organization -- Ford had $108.4 billion in sales and revenue last year -- during fat times. Mr. Trotman has said that the domestic auto makers' recent comeback has had more to do with the business cycle than with fundamental change within the companies.
Even more significant is the challenge of building world cars. "In this there is sort of a concept that the world is moving to a standard car," said Maryann Keller, auto industry analyst with Furman Selz, an investment banking firm in New York City. "It isn't."
Toyota, for example, is widely credited with selling similar cars worldwide. But Toyota controls only 9 percent of the United States car market, Ms. Keller noted. To gain more, it would need more products -- like a large rear-wheel-drive car similar to the Ford Crown Victoria -- that it could not sell in large volumes elsewhere, she said. Further, Toyota's most successful car here, the Camry, does not do nearly so well in other markets, Ms. Keller said.
"The question is not, 'Can you sell something around the world?' " she said. "The question is, 'Can you maximize your sales in each country that you choose to participate in?' "
 Ford hopes to sell a combined total of 800,000 of the Mondeo, Contour and Mystique sedans a year. But the Mondeo cost $6 billion to develop, an extraordinary amount. The development of Chrysler's new Neon subcompact, admittedly a smaller project, cost $1.3 billion.
Mr. Trotman emphasized today that very few Ford employees would be affected in the short term by the shake-up. He said growth in sales would absorb increases in productivity, making layoffs unlikely.
One notable employee whose career will change is William C. Ford Jr., a great-grandson of Henry Ford and one of two Ford descendants at the company. William Ford will head the new commercial use truck center, a position that should give him much greater visibility within the company.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edward E. Hagenlocker, the new president of Ford Automotive Operations, speaking yesterday at a news conference where Ford announced its most sweeping reorganization in more than 25 years. (Associated Press) (pg. D2)
 
Map/Diagram: "A Worldwide Reach"
 Ford Motor Company will create a single automotive operation worldwide with five vehicle development centers. Four centers in the United States will focus on larger cars, trucks and sport utility vehicles. The fifth center will be split between Ford's existing design centers in Dunton, England, and Merkenich, Germany. The idea is to develop specific types of cars that Ford will sell worldwide.
