HEADLINE: Dramatic Rise, and a Nasty Fall

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR with DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

 BODY:
To all appearances, Joseph Jett's life was a Horatio Alger tale for the 1990's. Studious, from a small town in the Midwest and armed only with brains and drive, he pulled himself to the top of Wall Street, commanding a trading desk and earning $9 million in a single year.
The fact that this dramatic rise was by an outsider in the clubby world of finance made his story even more of a classic tale of individual triumph. But this week the plot took a nasty twist. 
 Mr. Jett was publicly stripped of his job as a managing director and head of the Government trading desk at Kidder, Peabody & Company. The firm's executives accused the 36-year-old trader, honored in January as Kidder's employee of the year in 1993, of executing an elaborate scheme to create $350 million in phantom profits, inflate his own bonus and conceal $100 million in losses.
 
 
A Mystery Figure
 Despite his widely publicized fall from grace, Mr. Jett has remained a mystery figure. He has refused to comment and did not answer the doorbell at his loft in Manhattan's trendy TriBeCa district.
However, interviews in recent days with colleagues, classmates and former teachers portray him as a loner who had soared to stardom with little experience and less supervision.
"He's pretty isolated," a lawyer close to the case said.
Few of these people were willing to allow their names to be used and few were willing to step forward in his defense. Even his father said he was waiting to hear from his son before discussing the allegations.
"As soon as he tells us whatever he tells us, I'll have something to say," the elder Mr. Jett said in a telephone interview.
While officials at Kidder and its parent, the General Electric Company, have sought to place all the blame for the reported scheme on Mr. Jett, executives at competing houses harshly criticized management controls at Kidder. Several longtime traders said Kidder bore moral responsibility for granting so much power to someone with so little experience.
Since first disclosing the allegations earlier this week, Kidder officials have refused to answer detailed questions about the hiring and supervision of Mr. Jett. Those questions about Kidder's supervision took on a more compelling nature as former associates suggested that Mr. Jett had performed poorly in junior positions at two previous brokerage houses, Morgan Stanley & Company and CS First Boston Inc.
The portrait that emerges of Mr. Jett in recent years contrasts sharply with the image of the young man who left a small suburb of Cleveland nearly two decades ago.
 In Wickliffe, Ohio, where he grew up, Mr. Jett is still known by his first name, Orlando, and by his success. He is the local youth who made good, the one who got a scholarship to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and went on to the Harvard Business School and Wall Street.
"Orlando is a high achiever," Grace Alexander, a longtime neighbor of the Jett family, said. "Everybody is real proud of him."
The son of a local insurance business owner and a schoolteacher, Mr. Jett graduated near the top of his high school class and was a member of the school's academic team. Teachers and classmates remember him as soft-spoken and low-key, with an engaging manner. His teachers also remember him as someone who got along well with the other students at Wickliffe High School, where he was one of about 20 blacks in a graduating class of more than 400.
"For me, he was an extremely good student, straight A's in my math classes," Alex Bezjak, the chairman of the mathematics department at the high school, said.
At M.I.T., where he earned a bachelor's degree in 1980 and a master's degree in 1982, Mr. Jett left a similar impression. Deliberate and purposeful, he majored in chemical engineering and performed well enough to be accepted in the advanced master's degree program.
"He just seemed like a very well-motivated and directed guy," Jefferson W. Tester, a professor of chemical engineering, said.
It was at Harvard Business School, where he headed after three years at General Electric Plastics, that Mr. Jett's persona seemed to change. Although he dropped Orlando and began going by Joseph, his middle name, that was not the biggest change.
Classmates at Harvard say they encountered an angry young man. According to several, who declined to allow the use of their names, Mr. Jett complained loudly and abrasively that he had been held back at G.E., that his talents had been ignored.
"He seemed pretty impressive in the classroom," said Charles N. Hassen, another G.E. engineer who wound up in the same class at Harvard. "I remember him as quite intelligent and outspoken."
While at Harvard, Mr. Jett immersed himself in body building and martial arts. He struck some of his classmates as theatrical, as well as strident about his conservative politics. He said he had been harassed by police and often lectured fellow black students about the necessity of pulling oneself up by the bootstraps, without help from others.
 
 
Denied Degree
 Harvard said Mr. Jett fulfilled the requirements for an M.B.A. in 1987, but he was denied the degree. James Aysner, a Harvard spokesman, refused to say why Mr. Jett did not get his degree, but he did say the reason did not have anything to do with bad conduct.
Nonetheless, Mr. Jett was hired after graduation as a junior trader in mortgage-backed securities by Morgan Stanley, the blue-chip investment house. Former colleagues, who refused to allow their names to be used, said Mr. Jett did not perform well and that he did not have the sophisticated arbitrage experience he claimed in later job interviews.
A trader who sat near Mr. Jett at Morgan Stanley described him as "a smart guy" who spent a good part of the day reading Kung Fu comic books and Muscle magazine.
In 1989, he was let go along with a number of other employees in a cutback.
Mr. Jett was out of work for several months, but eventually landed a job at CS First Boston, another top-tier firm. A colleague there remembered him as someone who pushed himself hard, but insisted on operating on his own in a manner that sometimes disturbed his fellow employees.
 
 
Reaction to Anger
 By this time, colleagues said, Mr. Jett was spending two hours a night working out at a gym. Sometimes when angered, as when someone said he could not do something he wanted to do, they said, he would become very still, then arch his back and let out a fearsome roar.
According to former First Boston colleagues, who refused to allow their names to be used, other traders discovered that Mr. Jett sometimes concealed vital information from other traders, such as misstating the profitability of a deal. He lasted only 14 months at First Boston, leaving after having risen no higher than junior trader.
Young traders often try several jobs before they find the right fit. For Mr. Jett, the third time appeared to be a charm. Following another period of unemployment, Mr. Jett was hired in July 1991 as a trader on the Government bond desk at Kidder, Peabody.
After recovering from the insider-trading scandal of the 1980's, Kidder was the leader in mortgage-backed securities. In 1991, the firm was trying to diversify its profit stream by hiring aggressive young traders to help build its Government bond group and other operations.
 
 
Unusual Freedom
 Mr. Jett thrived, getting the opportunity for individual initiative he had so long sought. In less than two years -- and without prior experience trading Government bonds -- he rose to chief of the Government trading desk and a managing director, supervising 16 traders and apparently operating with unusual freedom.
Former colleagues at Morgan Stanley and First Boston, along with some of his Harvard classmates, said they were not surprised that Mr. Jett was hired at Kidder. But they said they were astonished that he was promoted so quickly to head of Government trading and managing director, responsibilities for which he seemed too inexperienced.
In the loosely structured environment on Kidder's trading floor, Mr. Jett had the freedom to expose the firm's capital to risks at levels normally reserved for the most seasoned and trusted traders at other firms.
To Kidder's managers, the returns seemed to justify their faith in Mr. Jett. His desk reported profits of hundreds of millions of dollars, earning Mr. Jett his $9 million bonus last year.
But last Sunday, after an internal investigation and a session in which senior managers questioned Mr. Jett, his meteoric rise was over. Kidder executives claimed that the profits never existed. Instead, executives said, the trades were merely computer entries, possibly designed to cover up losses of $90 million to $100 million.
Mr. Jett was immediately dismissed and six other employees, who have not been named, were suspended. On Wednesday, General Electric took a charge of $210 million, or 25 cents a share, to cover inflated profits at Kidder related to the fictitious trades.
The long-term damages are unknown. A Kidder spokeswoman said yesterday that officials would not respond to further questions. Many financial experts say General Electric clearly has the capital and the cash flow to survive the losses, even if they were to grow. They also speculated that the full extent of losses remained uncertain. But Wall Street sources said the episode could erode Kidder's relationship with lenders and institutional customers.
What seems clear, however, is that the actions blamed on a single young trader threaten to undermine Kidder's struggle to reinvigorate the firm and have raised new questions about its overall management.
"As a manager, you have to be willing to look when you go from making no money to making a lot of money," said Lesley Daniels, who heads global risk management at Chemical Bank and ran trading desks at two other banks. "You cannot just sit on your hands and hope that it's real."

HEADLINE: New View of Peril From A-Plant Emissions

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PASCO, Wash., April 21

 BODY:
A team of Government-sponsored scientists said today that deliberate releases of radiation four decades ago from the Hanford nuclear weapons plant in southeast Washington exposed thousands more people over a much larger region than previously thought.
Culminating seven years of research that cost the Government $26 million, the scientists recalculated the doses absorbed from the plant's huge radiation releases in the 1940's and 50's. The Government, which did not admit to the emissions until it responded to public pressure in 1986, first estimated those doses in 1990. 
 Based on computer modeling, the panel in essence said today that the risk from the emissions was higher than estimated in 1990 for people living 100 miles or farther from the reservation but lower for people living within 20 miles.
In perhaps the most surprising finding, the panel lowered the estimated contamination from a secret 1949 military test known as the Green Run. The exposure to children from the test, which involved a huge release of radioactive iodine into the air to help the military develop surveillance for Soviet atomic bomb plants, amounted to roughly 0.27 rad, a tiny amount of radiation that most scientists consider an insignificant risk to health.
 
Highest Exposure
 Nevertheless, the panel of 15 scientists and 3 members of the public affirmed and expanded the basic conclusion it made in July 1990. At that time, the panel announced that people in the Pacific Northwest, including thousands of children, were secretly exposed to the highest levels of radiation from the Government's bomb industry of any civilian population in the United States.
The latest conclusions come in an extraordinary period of reckoning for the United States and its atomic weapons industry. Last December, after learning that Government-financed doctors secretly conducted human radiation experiments in support of the industry, Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary apologized to those who were unwittingly exposed and promised to compensate them.
The White House in January took up the investigation of human experimentation, and the conclusions announced today could influence that project. As part of its charter, the White House advisory group that is coordinating the investigation will study the new findings on the Green Run and consider whether those exposed should be compensated.
Because the exposures from the Green Run are now estimated to be so small, several state officials and members of the scientific panel said the case probably did not warrant compensation. But the panel also estimated that other Hanford emissions exposed thousands to radiation levels thousands of times higher than in the Green Run, and State of Washington today asked the Clinton Administration to expand the list of those eligible for compensation to them. .
 
Limiting Compensation
 "They ought to look at all of the releases here and consider some sort of compensation plan," said Allen W. Conklin, the head of air emissions and defense waste for the state Department of Health.
But Dr. Tara O'Toole, the Assistant Secretary of Energy for Environment, Safety and Health, said it was unlikely the state would get its request. "The first thing we wanted to accomplish in this project was to have a manageable scope of work," she said. "We cannot expand the charge of the advisory committee."
The Hanford atomic reservation, spread across 560 square miles of sand and sage along the Columbia River just west of here, contained the nuclear reactors and processing plants that produced plutonium for the atomic bomb that devastated Nagasaki, Japan, and for thousands of atomic warheads in the American arsenal. The plant ended its production of nuclear materials in 1988 and is now the site of a multibillion-dollar environmental cleanup that has led to an economic boom here. Housing starts are at their highest levels since the 1970's.
But even as realtors and employers celebrate along the river of money flowing out of Washington, D.C., thousands of residents here remain concerned about health risks from the Hanford radiation releases.
The initial estimates of exposure made in 1990 focused on the 10 counties surrounding Hanford. This scientific panel, led by Dr. John E. Till, a health physicist from Neeces, S.C., examined a 75,000-square-mile region around the plant that included much of Eastern Washington and parts of Idaho and Oregon. More than 800,000 people lived in the region during the first decade of the cold war, when the radiation released from Hanford was enormous.
 
From Cows to Humans
 Virtually all of the radiation hazard from Hanford came from one element, radioactive iodine. The iodine, which settled on grass, was conveyed to humans when they drank milk from cows that had eaten contaminated feed. Since iodine collects in the thyroid, panel members said this was the organ that caused them most concern. Roughly half of the people in the region were exposed to at least 1 rad of radiation from Hanford, the panel said. About 10 percent were exposed to 10 rads or more.
A dose of one rad, which is a measure of radiation absorbed by human tissue, is not considered particularly large if given to the thyroid, but many medical specialists say that any radiation above that occurring in nature raises a person's risk of contracting diseases, especially cancer. In event of a nuclear reactor accident, Federal guidelines call for evacuation if the dose to the thyroid reaches 5-25 rads.
Dr. Richard Morrill, a geographer from the University of Washington who was on the panel, said some children in Eltopia, Wash., immediately east and downwind of Hanford, may have been exposed to 870 rads to their thyroid from 1944 to 1951, and adults there may have absorbed as much as 350 rads. The exposure for children is one-third the level the panel estimated in 1990.
But the panel also found it had underestimated the radiation absorbed by people living 100 miles and more downwind from Hanford. From 1944 to 1951, adults in Spokane, 130 miles northeast of here, may have absorbed 44 rads to their thyroid, 10 times higher than scientists estimated in 1990.
 
Caution on Health Effect
 The panel was very cautious in relating the findings to any particular risk of contracting disease. But when pressed, Dr. Till pointed to a study he had participated in that was published last year in The Journal of the American Medical Association. In that study, he said, researchers identified 3,500 people from southern Utah who as children lived down range of the Federal atomic testing ground in Nevada in the 1950's. Researchers found more cases of thyroid diseases, including cancer, than was expected in a group of unexposed adults, and the people the researchers studied were exposed to radiation levels half as high as those documented around Hanford, he said.
"We found a correlation between the dose and the incidence of disease," he said. "The higher the dose, the higher the numbers of nodules on thyroids and cancer."
In part, the panel's new findings about Hanford's releases reflect some basic horse sense about animal husbandry. The reasons the Green Run experiment produced such small exposures, said Dr. Till, was that the test occurred in the winter when cows were not grazing.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New Neiman Marcus Head Is Named

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
In a corporate shuffle that highlights the dearth of merchandising talent at the high end of retailing, the Neiman Marcus Group said yesterday that it had selected Burton Tansky, chairman and chief executive of Bergdorf Goodman, to head the Neiman Marcus department store group.
Steven C. Elkin, president and chief operating officer of Bergdorf, which operates two exclusive specialty stores in Manhattan, Bergdorf Goodman and Bergdorf Goodman Men's, will replace Mr. Tansky on May 1. And Dawn Mello, who left Bergdorf in 1989 to join the Italian retail and apparel company Guccio Gucci S.p.A., will return to her former post as Bergdorf president. 
 Mr. Tansky, who is 56, is one of the few merchants steeped in the rarefied world of high-end specialty store retailing, where high fashion and luxury are far more important elements of the sales pitch than the price. Before joining Bergdorf in 1990, Mr. Tansky spent 10 years as president of Saks Fifth Avenue, a competitor of Neiman Marcus, and he is a perennial presence in the front rows of fashion shows around the world.
"Neiman Marcus represents the very, very best of upscale retailing in America," Mr. Tanksy said yesterday in a phone interview from Dallas. "This is an unusual opportunity for me to become part of a team that has built the business and is driving the business, and with a store company that has a very bright future."
 
A Short List
 Executive recruiters said only a handful of merchants had the experience and stature to run a company like Neiman Marcus, and most of them were running its rivals. "Four or five would come to mind, and then you start stretching," said Sylvia Warren, a partner with Thorndike Deland & Associates who specializes in recruiting retail executives. "It's really a very incestuous industry."
Ms. Mello, who resuscitated the faltering Gucci brand by updating its style and fashion content to appeal to younger customers, will be Bergdorf's merchant. She left the company when Mr. Tansky succeeded Ira Neimark, the longtime chairman of Bergdorf, a position many in the industry thought she would win.
Robert J. Tarr Jr., president and chief executive of the Neiman Marcus Group, said yesterday that the quest for a merchant to replace Terry Lundgren, former chief executive of the Neiman Marcus stores, had been easy because there were so few choices. "It seemed pretty obvious that Burt was the right choice as I started considering other options," Mr. Tarr said of Mr. Tansky. "I'm very satisfied that this was the only choice right now."
Neiman Marcus was left without a strong merchant at the helm when Mr. Lundgren left in February to join Federated Department Stores Inc.
 Mr. Tansky said he would do little to change the course set by Mr. Lundgren, who developed relationships with new vendors and took the chain into new, lower-priced niches that helped it weather the recession without damaging its cachet as a high-quality merchandiser.

At a fashion show last week in Bryant Park, he sat with Neiman Marcus executives Butch Mullins, Joan Kaner and Janet Gurwitch. (Bill Cunningham/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Says a Smoking Ban Is Worth the Cost

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration estimated today that the benefits of banning smoking in all public places in the United States would outweigh the costs by at least $39 billion a year.
The report by the Environmental Protection Agency also estimated that more than one million smokers might quit immediately if such a ban, as proposed in a House bill now before the subcommittee on Health and the Environment, became law. 
 The report, released at a news conference, was written by economists at the E.P.A. and was approved by the White House Council of Economic Advisers and by the Office of Management and Budget.
The report estimated the benefits of such a prohibition at $39 billion to $72 billion annually. The bulk of this estimate, $35 billion to $65 billion, was based on the projection that 11,000 to 20,000 deaths of nonsmokers a year could be averted that otherwise would be caused by lung cancer and heart disease attributed to exposure to secondhand smoke.
 
Computing a Life's Worth
 The report set the value of a human life at $4.8 million, a figure commonly used by economists, said the principal author, Dr. David H. Mudarri. Economists base estimates of the value of a human life on how much extra a worker is paid for hazardous work compared with nonhazardous work in the same industry. In this way, they say, the market actually sets the value of risk to human life, which can then be transferred to other situations, like the risk to workers of pollution or secondhand smoke.
A ban would save another $4 billion to $8 billion, the report said, through reduced building-maintenance costs associated with smoking.
Another advantage would be that 3 percent to 6 percent of smokers would decide to quit when the ban took effect, the report's authors said, while 50,000 to 100,000 teen-agers would not take up the habit.
The report estimated the costs of such a ban at $2.5 billion to $3.5 billion, mostly for enforcing it and for expenses associated with constructing specially ventilated smoking rooms in the 10 to 20 percent of nonresidential buildings whose owners would want smoking areas. Buildings used by 10 or more people a week would be affected.
 
Tobacco Industry Disagrees
 Walker Merryman, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute in Washington, which represents the major tobacco companies, said the report was "useless" because it was based on a false conclusion, made by the E.P.A. earlier this year, that secondhand cigarette smoke caused disease.
Preliminary figures issued by the agency in February showed a much wider range of possible benefits -- "tens of billions to hundreds of billions" of dollars. But those estimates were calculated by a method different from that used in today's report and, officials said.
In today's estimate, the benefits of longer life spans were computed only for nonsmokers. The benefit to smokers was not included because smokers consider smoking itself a benefit, and a ban on smoking to be irritating. The E.P.A. officials were uncertain how to weigh these "benefits" against the health risks taken voluntarily by the smokers, and so, in order to be conservative, they did not offer estimates for the additional benefits for smokers' increased life spans.
 
Smokers Declining
 There are about 50 million smokers in the United States, with about 25 billion packs of cigarettes sold annually, accounting for about $43 billion in sales. Since 1983, the Tobacco Institute says, the number of smokers has dropped 2 to 3 percent a year.
Today's report did not count worker-productivity gains among the benefits of a ban on smoking. The report also asserted that declines in tax revenue and jobs in the tobacco industry would actually be gains for other sectors of the economy.
Dr. Mudarri said that the report used standard economic methods to arrive at its estimates and that in assessing the health consequences of a ban estimates were conservative. Thus, instead of using the American Heart Association and similar estimates of 32,000 to 40,000 deaths annually from heart disease blamed on secondhand smoke, the E.P.A., used a different formula to exclude exposure to secondhand outside the workplace, putting its estimate at 9,000 to 18,000 deaths.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Government Securities Drop in Yield for 3d Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Yields of government securities fell yesterday for the third straight day, as inflation concerns eased in the bond market amid signs that economic growth this year may not be as strong as some have forecast.
While some economists are expecting growth this year to be as much as 4 percent, up from 2.8 percent last year, other analysts note that evidence so far this year shows inflation is still subdued. Consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month and 2.5 percent for the 12 months that ended in March, below last year's increase of 2.7 percent. Producer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in the same period, and at a similar pace in 1993. 
 Economists like Greg Jones of MMS International, a Wall Street research and analysis firm, expect the Federal Reserve to stand pat until its May 17 Federal Open Market Committee meeting before approving another rise in short-term interest rates. "The only question to be answered then," he said, "will be whether the next rate hike will be another quarter-point, or a half-point."
Traders and investors dismissed yesterday's results of a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia that showed manufacturers were paying more for raw materials, because the same report also showed that manufacturing slowed and that prices will be falling six months from now.
Analysts found it interesting that the Philadelphia Fed price report, which two months ago led to a market rout, was only able to spur a brief selloff yesterday.
By late in the day the 30-year bond was up 16/32 , to 8812/32 , as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 7.21 percent, from 7.32 percent Wednesday. It was the biggest one-day drop in yields since April 5, when the yield on the 30-year bond fell from 7.41 percent to 7.24 percent.
"Looking at today's activity you have to be thinking that maybe the bear market is over," one trader said, "especially after showing its ability to rally after the Philly report."
Mr. Jones said the price action this week and the market's ability to bounce back after the Fed's tightening on Monday was a good sign for the long end of the market. "The last tightening by the Fed may have restored some of its credibility in the market, and dented the bearish psychology that has gripped it since the first Fed move on Feb. 4," he said.
But there are those in the market who are not convinced of a market turnaround. "As in all bear markets you have some rallies, but the rallies are only for a short period of time." said Peter Hirsch, a managing director and head of the government trading desk at Salomon Brothers.
Mr. Hirsch said that over the next two to three weeks the market will have to deal with a significant supply of new Treasury securities, which could put some downward pressure on prices.
Next week, the Treasury will auction $28 billion of two-year and five-year notes. In when-issued, or pre-auction, trading yesterday the yields were lower, with the two-year note at a yield of 5.61 percent, down from 5.70 percent the day before, and the five-year note at a yield of 6.50 percent, down from 6.62 percent.
Analysts said prices slipped after the first glance at yesterday's Philadelphia Fed survey as the price paid index for current conditions surged to 33.1 in April from 16 in March. But at a second look, they said, the report showed the price paid index falling to 38.8 from 50.4 in March and the price received index dropping to 13.7 from 30.7 in the manufacturers' outlook for six months from now.
The data gave investors just the type of news they were hoping they would find -- indications that the economy could be cooling off. With slower growth, inflationary pressures are reduced.
The unexpected rise in the latest weekly unemployment claims, after expectations of a decline to 341,000 from 348,000 the previous week, added to the market's firm tone.
Some economists said that the easing of inflation worries might support a belief among some analysts that the Fed will not raise short-term interest rates further before the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on May 17, thus removing the uncertainty about the timing of the next rate rise and allowing trading to take a more normal pattern.

HEADLINE: Colombian Drug Trafficker Implicates Haitian Police Chief

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
A former member of a Colombian drug cartel testified today at a Senate hearing that Haiti's powerful police commander, Lieut. Col. Joseph Michel Francois, collaborated in shipping tons of cocaine to the United States during the 1980's.
American drug enforcement officials and supporters of Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, have long asserted that members of the military regime that overthrew him in 1991 are involved in the cocaine trade. But the testimony today from Gabriel Taboada, a convicted cocaine smuggler, is believed to be the first sworn public statement by a drug trafficker that a senior member of the current regime has conspired to ship cocaine. 
 Speaking through an interpreter, Mr. Taboada said he had met with senior members of the Haitian military, including Colonel Francois, in the offices of the Medellin cocaine cartel in the Colombian town of the same name in 1984. He said the Haitian officers helped insure that roughly 70,000 pounds of cocaine were delivered from Colombia through Haiti to the United States in 1987.
"The cartel used Haiti as a bridge so as to later move the drugs toward the United States," Mr. Taboada said. "They took planes out of Colombia and landed in Haiti, protected by the Haitian military. Michel Francois protected the drugs in Haiti and then allowed the drugs to continue to the United States."
Mr. Taboada appeared before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee that held two days of hearings on the corruption of governments by criminal syndicates.
After the fall of the Duvalier family dictatorship in 1986, Haiti was ruled for five years by a series of military strongmen. Among them was Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, who governed from 1988 to 1990 and whom Mr. Taboada also identified today as a participant in the Colombian cocaine trade.
Father Aristide took office in February 1991 after winning the country's first democratic election. He was overthrown seven months later by a group of military officers including Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras and Colonel Francois, who are said by human rights groups to rule through terror and intimidation.
Mr. Taboada did not testify on what role the Haitian military is playing in the drug trade today, since he has been in Federal prison since 1989 serving a 12-year sentence for cocaine trafficking. He has testified for the Government in several cases, including the prosecution culminating in the 1992 conviction of the former Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Noriega, on drug trafficking charges.
Mr. Taboada also said he had bribed officials of the United States Embassy and other foreign diplomats in Colombia during the 1980's to use their diplomatic status to help him import luxury automobiles for members of the cartel. Senator John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, said he had raised the issue with the F.B.I. but had been told that there were "jurisdictional problems" in investigating the charge. A call to a State Department spokeswoman was not returned today.
The hearing was convened by Senator Kerry, who heads the Foreign Relations subcommitee on terrorism, narcotics and international operations. On Wednesday, the panel heard testimony from the Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey, that international criminal gangs had undermined the political and economic stabilility of Russia, bought the allegiances of Latin American leaders and saturated the United States with cocaine and heroin.
Combining public information with corroborative intelligence gathered recently by the C.I.A., the State Department and other Government agencies, Mr. Woolsey and Senator Kerry described organizations grown rich from the sale of drugs and weapons infiltrating governments, influencing legislation and investing in United States banks and legitimate businesses.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKET;
Oil Prices Surge on Hopes For Increased U.S. Demand

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Oil prices posted solid gains yesterday amid expectations that the expanding American economy would increase its demand for gasoline and other petroleum products in the next few months, which would restrain growth in crude oil inventories.
Crude oil prices have risen 17 percent since March 28, when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said it would leave its output unchanged at 24.52 million barrels a day for the rest of the year. Traders had thought OPEC production would send stockpiles soaring as demand fell off in the spring. Instead, crude stocks have risen by less than 1 percent since the meeting. 
 Reports that rioting in Nigeria forced the Royal Dutch/Shell Group to halt some production of the country's Forcados blend of crude oil also helped prices to rise, traders said.
"You had some news about Shell shutting in some Forcados production," said William Brown, president of W. H. Brown & Company, a consulting firm in New York. "It's basically the market reassessing its own view" of oil demand in the second quarter.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for June delivery, now the actively traded futures contract, gained 31 cents, to $16.63 a barrel. May unleaded gasoline rose 0.38 cent, to 49.16 cents a gallon, and May heating oil rose 0.47 cent, to 46.87 cents a gallon.
 With the minor gains in crude stocks, "there's a lot of room for OPEC to continue at its present ceiling," Mr. Brown said.
On other commodity markets, sugar prices rebounded from a recent selloff. Sugar for May delivery jumped 0.44 cent, to 11.21 cents a pound at the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.
Sugar prices have fallen nearly 13 percent in the last month after reaching an eight-month high of 12.34 cents a pound. The surge in prices served to dry up demand from importing countries like Egypt, Bulgaria and Pakistan, all of which are thought to be ready to buy sugar now, traders said.
Meanwhile, copper prices rose as stocks and bonds rallied. May copper gained 1.85 cent, to 88.70 cents a pound at the Commodity Exchange in New York, after falling as low as 86.05 cents a pound earlier in the day.
A rising stock market brightens the outlook for copper demand, which increases when construction and automobile manufacturing pick up.
Higher-than-expected housing starts in March also encouraged the copper market. Copper is used extensively in new construction for plumbing and electrical wiring.

HEADLINE: Lawyers Debate Rifkin's Sanity In Trial's Opening Arguments

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., April 21

 BODY:
The opposing parties in the murder trial of Joel Rifkin moved quickly today to lay out the challenge facing the jury: to decide whether Mr. Rifkin, who has admitted killing 17 women and methodically disposing of their bodies, was legally insane.
"The defendant is a very bright guy, with very high intelligence," the prosecutor, Fred Klein, said in his opening statement. "He was well aware of the consequences of his actions. 
 "Sure, maybe Joel Rifkin had an unhappy childhood, kids ridiculed him, and he didn't get along with women," Mr. Klein added. "But he knows what he did was wrong. He got caught red-handed, and now he's using and abusing the concept of mental illness."
Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, John Lawrence, argued just as aggressively that Mr. Rifkin was a troubled man who was unable to control his actions.
"The defense will show that Mr. Rifkin was not responsible for these unbelievable, random acts of violence because of a major serious mental disease," Mr. Lawrence said.
The jury will hear from psychiatrists and psychologists called by both the prosecution and the defense in what is expected to a battle of experts.
 
Held in Traffic Case
 Mr. Rifkin, a 34-year-old unemployed landscaper from East Meadow, L.I., was arrested on June 28 by the state police for a traffic violation. The police said they found the body of Tiffany Bresciani, 22, in the back of Mr. Rifkin's pickup truck.
During questioning by troopers, Mr. Rifkin confessed to killing Ms. Bresciani and 16 other women he says were prostitutes.
The trial in Nassau County Court before Judge Ira H. Wexner involves only the killing of Ms. Bresciani. Mr. Rikfin also faces prosecution in the other killings in Suffolk County, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.
Mr. Klein argued in his opening statement that Mr. Rifkin acted out of perverted sexual desire.
"The defendant acted with unparalleled evil and depravity," he said.
As Mr. Klein spoke, Mr. Rifkin sat slumped in his chair at the defense table, staring off into a corner, his face turned away from the jury.
Mr. Lawrence acknowledged that Mr. Rifkin had strangled Ms. Bresciani after he picked her up on a street in Manhattan. "I will not make light of what happened," he said. "The taking of Miss Bresciani's life was a senseless, horrifying act, as it was for his other victims."
But he said Mr. Rifkin was a paranoid schizophrenic and had suffered from the disease since early childhood. He said the illness had became uncontrollable after 1987, when Mr. Rifkin's father died.
"This caused him to act out in macabre ways," Mr. Lawrence said. "He has lived in a twilight zone unable to relate to reality, overcome by a compulsion of violent images toward women, a compulsion that took control of his life."
The first witness to be called by the prosecution was Cheryl Bresciani, the 46-year-old mother of Tiffany Bresciani, who she said was her only child.
 
'He Really Needs Help'
 She said her daughter had left their home in Metairie, a suburb of New Orleans, five years ago and lived three years in Los Angeles before going to New York City. She said she last saw her in October 1992, but had talked with her frequently on the telephone. The last time, she said, was two days before she was killed.
After leaving the courtroom, Ms. Bresciani said she had "only looked for a second" at the man who had killed her daughter.
"I think he really needs help," she said. "He did a horrible thing. Something's got to be wrong. He's certainly not led by God."
During the afternoon session, the prosecution called State Trooper Sean Ruane to the stand. He was one of the troopers who arrested Mr. Rifkin early June 28 after a 20-mile chase that lasted about 25 minutes and ended as Mr. Rifkin's truck slammed into a utility pole here on Old Country Road, about a block from the courthouse.
Trooper Ruane said the chase began when he and another officer tried to pull Mr. Rifkin to the side of the road because the license plate was missing from the back of his pickup. While inspecting the damaged truck, he was about to look into the glove compartment when, he said, he noticed a very strong odor.
"It smelled like decomposing flesh," he said. "I then went to the back of the truck and saw what looked like a human body wrapped in a blue tarp."
After Ms. Bresciani's body was found inside the tarp, Mr. Rifkin confessed that he had strangled her and had been trying to dispose of her body.
During Trooper Ruane's testimony, Mr. Rifkin slumped down in his chair, tilted his head back and fell sound asleep. He awoke when his lawyer rose from the defense table to cross-examine the trooper.
Mr. Lawrence later explained that Mr. Rifkin had not "gotten much sleep the last two nights." He also said that prison officials had given Mr. Rifkin a bologna sandwich during today's lunch break and that since Mr. Rifkin was allergic to the nitrates in bologna, it made him drowsy.
Although television and still cameras were permitted to view the courtroom action today, Judge Wexner assured the jurors that they would not be photographed or identified by name during the trial.

HEADLINE: City Wants Appraisal Made of Coliseum Site

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
New York City officials have given the Metropolitan Transportation Authority a deadline of Monday to decide whether to join it in having an appraisal made of the Coliseum site, whose fate is part of a complicated struggle involving the city, the M.T.A. and the developer, Mortimer B. Zuckerman.
In a letter, John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, informed the M.T.A., which owns the site, that if the agency does not go along with the appraisal, the city will proceed alone. 
 "Since we have repeatedly made this request," Mr. Dyson said, "we will initiate our own appraisal by an independent firm if we have not reached agreement by Monday morning."
John Cunningham, a spokesman for the M.T.A., said that the agency was still evaluating the request. The agency has resisted the appraisal, saying it was difficult to assess such a site in a rising real estate market.
Mr. Zuckerman, who owns The Daily News, has a contract to build a 2.1-million-square-foot mixed-use development on the Coliseum property. For more than a year Mr. Zuckerman has been trying renegotiate the agreement, seeking to build a smaller project at a price lower than the $338 million called for in the contract.
If Mr. Zuckerman does not close on the deal, he stands to forfeit a $33.8 million line of credit.
 
New Purchase Price
 The M.T.A. and Mr. Zuckerman have agreed to a new purchase price of $100 million for half the site; included in the price is a $20 million city subsidy from annual tax payments generated by the project. Still, the M.T.A. says there are other matters that have to be settled, including the amount of any new down payment and a required starting date for construction.
Last week Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called on the transit agency to help with an independent review of the site's value. He said that the appraisal would settle the question of whether Mr. Zuckerman is getting favorable treatment.
Mr. Dyson could not say what the appraisal would cost or who would pay for it.
"If we do it together," Mr. Dyson said, "we will both pay for it. If we do it alone, we will probably pay although they should pay for it. It's their site."
In his letter to the M.T.A., Mr. Dyson expanded on a plan that calls for a time period allowing other bidders to outbid Mr. Zuckerman's price for the property. Mr. Dyson proposes that if a bidder tops Mr. Zuckerman's price and becomes the developer, Mr. Zuckerman would have to pay a substantial cash penalty, based on the anount of the down payment, for being released from the deal.
Responding to City Hall's plan, Robert Selsam, a senior vice president of Boston Properties, Mr. Zuckerman's company, said he was not entirely happy with the plan but would go along with it.
"We are unhappy that we could lose the opportunity to develop the Coliseum site after years of work," Mr. Selsam said, "and pay a substantial penalty if someone comes along and bids even $1 more. But we will go along with with the city's request."

HEADLINE: Dell Computer Stock Slides Amid Rumors of Big Losses

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Dell Computer Corporation said yesterday that it might face losses from financial derivatives but that its exposure was nowhere near the $350 million that had been rumored on Wall Street.
The rumors sent the stock of the personal computer down by as much as $3.625 in Nasdaq trading. It closed down $2.875 a share, at $22, and was the most active Nasdaq issue, with more than 9.6 million shares traded. 
 A Dell vice president, Michelle Moore, said investor questions about a pending charge of about $350 million were "orders of magnitude out of the scope of reality."
Speculation was fueled by a report on CNBC, the business news television channel, which cited a source saying the swaps would have a major impact on Dell's earnings unless interest rates fell to February levels.
Dell, based in Austin, Tex., disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it held interest rate swaps -- a type of financial derivative to protect against interest rate fluctuations -- on a total of $350 million of debt.
It said that if interest rates did not return to the levels of mid-February, it would have to take a charge from its losses on the investments in early 1995. But Dell emphasized that the underlying value of the debt -- the notional amount of $350 million -- was far less than the actual risk that it faced on the contracts.
Dell said it swapped interest payments based upon fixed and floating interest rates, but said the underlying debt was not exchanged. "Consequently, the company's exposure to credit loss is significantly less than the stated notional amounts," Dell said in the filing.
In an interest rate swap, one company agrees to pay a variable-rate debt for another party in the belief interest rates would remain stable or drop further. In exchange, the other party agrees to pay a fixed-rate debt on the premise that rates would rise.
Many companies have been hit with charges from financial derivatives that have lost money. Among the losers have been Procter & Gamble, Cargill, Gibson Greetings Inc. and Mead.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Picking utility winners in the future may be more difficult.

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas 

 BODY:
A PLAN approved by the California Public Utilities Commission on Wednesday to open the state's utility companies to much greater competition will have an impact on utilities nationwide.
The decision is the first concrete move on a concept of open competition -- known as retail wheeling -- that has been worrying both utility executives and analysts acutely since last fall. But until Wednesday it was mostly an academic debate. 
 California regulators have often been the pace-setters and if they go ahead with what they propose -- allowing larger customers to contract for and buy power directly from other, lower cost sources -- they will end the grip that their local utilities have had on customers and put a lot of pressure on other states to follow.
Such open competition could drive down electricity rates and give California, which is still emerging from a severe recession, an advantage in keeping its own industries and attracting new ones -- an edge that other states could not long tolerate.
But if the California notion spreads, some analysts predict an upheaval in the industry, with the customers of many weaker utility companies raided by better-run companies that could offer lower rates. The competition could force some utilities into bankruptcy and leave some smaller customers facing higher rates.
The possibility of retail wheeling has already made many utility analysts and rating agencies revamp the way they look at utilities and find new ways to value them, especially on how well they could cope under the increased competition.
For investors, the change -- particularly if the concept spreads -- means it will become more difficult to analyze utility companies. Rates and rate increases will not be so secure. Customers will not be guaranteed and the quality of management will be far more important than it has been in the past. Analyzing utilities will now be similar to evaluating nonregulated companies.
"It has become much more complicated for the investor," said Alan Spen, a utility analyst with Fitch Investors Service Inc.
Mr. Spen said past yardsticks, including the measures of financial strength and the level of rates, were no longer as important.
"The world is changing," he said, adding that the most important criteria in looking at a utility now is how its management will react to the new world.
"Some will adapt very well, look for new businesses and become very aggressive," he said. "Other managers will do something very traditional and try to run their business as before."
At first look, he said, one would think that the three major investor-owned California utilities, Pacific Gas and Electric, Southern California Edison and San Diego Gas and Electric, would be considered high risks since they would face the brunt of the new competition.
But all three companies, he said, have been rated by Fitch as above average in their ability to deal with the new competitive era, in part because their management has been preparing and working with the regulators to adapt.
Most analysts agreed yesterday that the approval of the plan by the California commission has made retail wheeling a much more urgent issue.
"They are the trend-setter," Mr. Spen said. "The wind is blowing from west to east."
He said the initial reaction of investors had been negative. The news was interpreted as another blow to an industry that has already seen its stocks plunge as interest rates soared over the last three months.
Should investors then begin to bail out of utility stocks? Mr. Spen said such a conclusion was unwarranted, particularly because the new era has yet to begin.
Nevertheless, he added, investors should not be complacent because picking the winners in the future will be much more difficult.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances on the Yen As Economic Meeting Nears

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday amid speculation that world economic leaders may try to curb the yen's rise after a meeting on Sunday.
A rebound in American stock and bond prices also helped the dollar gain against the German mark and most other currencies. 
 Finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations are to meet in Washington on Sunday. Clinton Administration officials suggested yesterday the United States might may drop its tacit strong-yen policy.
 
 
'People Got Spooked'
 "People got spooked because they thought the G-7 might come up with a plan to defend the dollar," said Ezra Zask, president of Ezra Zask Associates, a Norfolk, Conn., hedge fund with $180 million under management. Mr. Zask said he bought dollars earlier in the week, anticipating the buying spree.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 103.70 yen, up from 103.05 yen on Wednesday. The dollar also rose to 1.6911 marks from 1.6875 marks.
The dollar gained after Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said the United States would not try to drive the dollar lower against the yen.
Mr. Bentsen and other members of the Clinton Administration sent the dollar into a tailspin last year when they said a strong yen would help reduce Japan's trade surplus with the United States. Such comments convinced many traders that Washington had a strong-yen policy.
"We're not going to try to devalue ourselves into their markets," Mr. Bentsen said. A strong yen makes Japanese exports more expensive and American products less costly in Japan.
 
 
'Vicious Selloff
 Mr. Zask said he would not hold his dollar position over the weekend because the results of the meeting are too unpredictable. "We could see a vicious selloff of the dollar if the G-7 leaders don't say anything about exchange rates," he said.
Many other traders don't expect the U.S. and Japan to make progress on trade or exchange rates until Japan replaces Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, who resigned April 8.
"The Japanese don't have a Government yet, so I don't expect much from the G-7 meeting," Earl Johnson, foreign exchange adviser at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said.
Meanwhile, the British pound was little changed at $1.4911. The dollar fell to 5.7951 French francs from 5.8011 francs. It was steady at 1.4351 Swiss francs and 1,616 Italian lire. The Canadian dollar rose to 72.57 United States cents from 72.46 cents.

HEADLINE: State Jobless Claims Rise

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
New applications for state unemployment benefits were a stronger-than-expected 364,000 last week, the Labor Department reported today, suggesting continued weakness in the jobs market.
The department revised upward its total from the previous week, to 350,000 from 348,000. 
 Wall Street economists had forecast a total of 341,000 new claims for state jobless benefits in the week that ended last Saturday. They said that the increase suggested layoffs had not tapered off considerably and that employment figures for all of April might not be strong.
"It tells us the pace of layoffs has not slowed much," said Carl Palash, senior economist at MCM Moneywatch. "There is no major slowdown in firing and no major pickup in hiring, which reduces the risk of a strong April payrolls figure."
But some economists said the long-term trend for jobless claims remained downward and that the uptick in the last two weeks could be caused by the teamsters' strike, which has hit the trucking industry.
"I'm not sure how many implications the figure has because it is not clear whether the teamsters' strike is having an influence on the numbers," said Robert McGee, chief economist at Tokai Bank.

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Museum Seeks Tenant
There's not exactly a "For Rent" sign outside the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum's SoHo branch, but it is looking for a tenant to increase its income. Ideally, Guggenheim officials say, the museum would like to sublet nearly 10,000 square feet of street-level space on Broadway that now houses the bookstore and part of the entrance. The tenant might also use part of the basement next to the museum's new tea boutique, called the T Room. The museum would move its bookstore to the Mercer Street side of the ground floor and retain all the existing exhibition space on both the ground floor and the level above.
"It would be an enormous gain for the museum without compromising exhibition space," said Catherine Vare, a museum spokeswoman, who added that the institution wasn't ruling out future expansion. 
 One company that has expressed interest in the space is the Gap. (That would put the clothing store across the street from A/X, Giorgio Armani's Italian version of the Gap.) But Ms. Vare said other companies had expressed interest, too. A spokesman for the Gap said it did not comment on new stores until a lease was signed.
"We're not having a store as part of the museum," Ms. Vare said. "The two would be separate entities with separate entrances." Since the museum opened two years ago, annual attendance has run between 175,000 and 220,000 visitors. Tomorrow, it will open "RolyWholyOver a Circus," a Conceptual exhibition designed by John Cage with randomly selected art and interactive elements. It opened at the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, where it was the most successful show in the museum's history.
 
Italians Modernize
 Italian cultural institutions have begun to realize that they have some catching up to do. Unlike such institutions as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which annually sells more than $85 million worth of merchandise and publications, Italian museums, libraries, archeological sites and historic houses have not tapped their marketing potential. The average museum store in Italy is little more than a place to buy postcards and guides.
Until now. A ruling by Alberto Ronchey, the Minister of Culture, allows these institutions to lease space to shops and cafes. In addition to rent, they are to receive 6 percent of the sales.
Daniel Berger, the manager of the mezzanine gallery and corporate sales at the Metropolitan, masterminded the plan for the Italians. For more than a year he traveled back and forth to Italy helping establish the program, which provides for Government-run quality control. "The Italian museums will become much more amenable places," Mr. Berger said.
Taking another cue from the United States, the Culture Ministry also decreed that Italian museums, which now close for the day at 1:45 P.M., should stay open until 7 P.M. unless they can prove they don't have the personnel to do so. "It will be nonstop museumgoing," Mr. Berger said. "And nonstop shopping."
 
2 Big Jumps
 Two more galleries are going bicoastal. Larry Gagosian, who owns two Manhattan galleries, is a native of Los Angeles and began his career there in the mid-1970's. He says he has just signed a lease on a 5,000-square-foot space on Camden Drive in Beverly Hills. Richard Meier, the architect who is designing the J. Paul Getty Center in Brentwood, will renovate the space. Mr. Gagosian said he hadn't hired a staff yet but planned to open in the fall. "I will be showing the artists we represent now," Mr. Gagosian said.
Given the recent earthquakes, not to mention the sluggish economic climate, why Los Angeles and why now? "A lot of galleries have closed, there's been a lot of pessimism, but these things run in cycles," the dealer said. "Los Angeles is a city of enormous wealth. Museums like Los Angeles County are expanding. The new Getty is coming soon. It just seems like the right time."
Mr. Gagosian also said that while this section of Beverly Hills had been overlooked by art galleries, he believed it was an exciting place to be. Mr. Meier is designing a Museum of Television and Broadcast History a block away and Planet Hollywood and Barneys are opening across the street from each other, also on Camden Drive.
The Ace Gallery of Los Angeles, meanwhile, opened a downtown Manhattan branch this week at 275 Hudson Street, just south of Spring Street. The space is large -- 25,000 square feet -- and unlike most galleries will be open only in the afternoon, Tuesdays through Saturdays from 1 to 6 P.M.
"I wanted to engage New York artists," said Douglas Christmas, the owner. On view are sculptures by Michael Heizer, who is also known for his earth works. The show runs through June.
 
Boteros for Chicago
 The voluptuous bronzes by the Colombian-born artist Fernando Botero do not travel light, but they get around. So far they've been on view in Florence and Monte Carlo, along the Champs-Elysees in Paris and on Park Avenue in Manhattan.
Now it's Chicago's turn. From April 29 through Aug. 14, seventeen Botero sculptures will stand along Michigan Avenue in Grant Park, across from the Chicago Cultural Center. "The Mayor is a Botero fan," Michael Lash, the curator of public arts for the Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs, said of Richard M. Daley. "On Park Avenue you had to dodge cars to see them; along the Champs-Elysees you had to walk to see them. In Chicago they'll be in a three-block area and will have quite a different feeling."
Mr. Lash, who organized the show with the Marlborough Gallery, the artist's representative, said the project would cost $300,000, which has been raised from private sources. That will pay not only for the outdoor sculpture exhibition but also a show of 100 Botero drawings from the artist's private collection at the Chicago Cultural Center and an educational program in English and Spanish about the artist and his works.
Some of the sculptures are for sale and others belong to Mr. Botero's own collection, said Jack Mognaz, the vice president of the Marlborough Gallery in New York.
"We're working on more sites in America but nothing is definite," Mr. Mognaz said. "A show of other Botero sculptures, however, is opening in Madrid next month."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Reclining Woman," 1 of 17 Fernando Botero sculptures that are on their way to Chicago. (Marlborough Gallery)

HEADLINE: Review/Architecture;
Urban Dreams, Urban Realities

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
Bernard Tschumi is a Morris Lapidus who thinks that he's a Walter Gropius. Like Lapidus, the legendary designer of Miami Beach hotels, Mr. Tschumi has an uncommon flair for glamorous architectural images. But he has managed to hobble this talent by styling himself as a cultural revolutionary. Like Gropius, founder of the Bauhaus, Mr. Tschumi seems to think that his designs can alter the reality as well as the look of urban life. Unfortunately, to judge from "Bernard Tschumi: Architecture and Event," a show of six projects now on view at the Museum of Modern Art, Mr. Tschumi has come to feel that the look of things has taken reality's place.
Unlike many architecture shows, where the main event -- the building -- is missing, this one, organized by Terence Riley and Anne Dixon, puts Mr. Tschumi's best face forward. The Swiss-born architect, dean of the architecture school at Columbia University since 1988, has built only one major project to date, the 165-acre Parc de la Villette in Paris, shown at the museum in a model, drawings and photographs. Otherwise, his work (surveyed in a hefty 634-page book, published by MIT Press to coincide with the exhibition) has been largely confined to paper. 
And on paper, it looks great. Clearly, Mr. Tschumi has a genuine love for the urban spectacle and an array of arresting graphic techniques to convey it. His drawings, models and montages exhibit infectious delight in the city's crowds, moods and visual complexity, its constant sense of possibility and surprise. He wants to create buildings that intensify these sensations.
Yet he grasps that these moments are fleeting. It's hard to pin them down. And architecture, alas, is an art of pinning things down. That dilemma may explain Mr. Tschumi's fascination with movies, documented in the show by "The Manhattan Transcripts," a series of film strip-like drawings first published in 1981. Movies do sometimes give the moody metropolitan atmosphere a fixed, enduring form. Why can't buildings?
Mr. Tschumi's design for the show captures an alluring cinematic ambiance. With dark gray walls and pin-spot lighting, it evokes what Pauline Kael calls the magic moment "when the lights go down," before the show begins. No starlet's lips ever looked more luscious than the Max Factorish red that inflames a row of spot-lighted drawings that you see on entering the gallery. Scale models, suspended from metal cables at quirky, Orson Wellesian angles, look more than ready for their close-up.
But they're not. For when you look beyond the glamorous presentation, it becomes evident that these designs don't live up to their radical billing. There's nothing revolutionary about the urban concept Mr. Tschumi offers in works like "Bridge City," a quartet of enclosed spans designed in 1988 for the Swiss city of Lausanne. It is what developers call "packing with program." What that means, basically, is creating a mall: a mix of uses sufficiently diverse to attract a broad public. No longer just places for retail shopping and multiplex movie theaters, malls now include health clubs, even health clinics, schools, post offices, police stations and other traditional downtown services. Mall designers are already skilled at deploying atriums, escalators, glass walls, video monitors and other devices to create the fluid, theatrical spectacle Mr. Tschumi has made it his mission to invent.
Increasingly, morever, the mall formula has been adopted by downtown buildings and structures that were once restricted to a single use. The kind of program-filled airport Mr. Tschumi proposed for Osaka, Japan, is already a reality in Pittsburgh and Denver. Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan, initially designed as a multi-use complex, is becoming so packed with program it may soon be hard to find the trains. What's radical about a development that the market already supports? Surely the truly radical gesture would be to resist these market pressures, as Sir Norman Foster did, for example, when he sought to prevent commercial intrusions from overtaking his design for Stansted Airport in England.
Mr. Tschumi's conventional notions of programming would be less disappointing if he had invented some startling fresh forms to express them. Beautiful as they often are, however, his formal ideas do not crackle with originality, either. Some of them, like the lunging beams of Bridge City, recall ideas that have been more substantially developed by Mr. Tschumi's contemporaries, like Rem Koolhaas, Daniel Libeskind and Wolfgang Prix. Others, like the hovercraft-shaped "Edge City," an office and recreational complex for Chartres, France, hark back to the kinetic structures proposed by Peter Cook and others in the 1960's.
Often, Mr. Tschumi's ideas appear to have floated in from the art world. An elegant computer-generated "night simulation plan" for a multi-media art school in Tourcoing, France, will appear less riveting to those familiar with Ross Bleckner's black paintings and the Izhar Patkin light boxes that preceded them.
But the most provocative precedent for Mr. Tschumi's designs lies well outside the avant-garde. It is one of the most popular styles in 20th-century American architecture. Remove the rhetorical veneer from these designs, and what is left bears an uncanny resemblance to "Googie," the classic style of 1950's California roadside coffee shops like Googie's, Biff's, Ships, Pann's and Bob's Big Boy. Occasionally designed by well-known architects like John Lautner, buildings in the Googie style represented the postwar Americanization of European modernism. In place of severe boxes, Googie architects created flamboyant public places where Americans could act out the mass spectacle of Eisenhower-era prosperity.
Mr. Tschumi reverses the process: he gives us a high-brow, Europeanized Googie. Undulating canopies, tilted glass walls, winglike roofs of thrusting, cantilevered metal trusses, cloud and amoeba-shaped cut-outs, ceiling grids of twinkling lights, neon-clad exteriors that blaze into life at night: these and other classic 50's forms turn up repeatedly in Mr. Tschumi's vocabulary. The undulating wave of his Osaka airport design is even colored turquoise, that cool 50's tone. Intentionally or not, the overscaled staircase on the outside of the art school Mr. Tschumi has designed for Tourcoing resembles the famous "stairway to nowhere" with which Morris Lapidus aggrandized the lobby of the Fountainbleau and other hotels. And how better to describe the illuminated scale model for Bridge City than with a refrain of the advertising slogan for that populuxe icon, the Princess telephone? It's little, it's lovely, it lights.
Mr. Tschumi, however, views these projects in darker terms. Drawing on themes from the philosophers Georges Bataille and Paul Virilio, the show's brochure describes the designs as if they were guerrilla weapons; they attack, explode, undermine, subvert and disrupt traditional practice. Of course, one could interpret Googie coffee shops in similar terms, and there's even justification for it: these roadside places were part of the wrenching urban disruption brought about by the car. And they were integral to the highway urbanism that emerged from that disruption. Unfortunately, Mr. Tschumi uses terrorist language not to enlighten, but to confuse. Like a sheep in wolves' clothing, he seeks to conceal how tame his ideas actually are. It's earth-shattering, it's dangerous, it explodes: this is the advertising lingo of today's avant-garde.
It may well be that our ludic, hedonistic times require a Morris Lapidus to occupy the place of Walter Gropius. If I were Donald Trump, I might well ask Mr. Tschumi to make me a casino. But why should the Museum of Modern Art capitulate to a beach-resort conception of urbanism? What the museum ought to be promoting, surely, is a comprehensive approach to the urban condition that does not pressure architects like Mr. Tschumi to promise more than they can deliver.
If the museum wants to champion progressive urban visions, it should first devise a progressive context in which to present them. Instead of propping up the exhausted concept of the solitary urban visionary, the museum ought to lay out a graphic map of the different forces that generate urban diversity. Ecological and economic systems; historical patterns of growth; technological innovations that have transformed urban space: these could all be graphically represented in a manner suitable for museum display. And they would expand the viewer's awareness of the city as an inclusive, collective endeavor.
Mr. Tschumi's ideas deserve a place on such a map. Cities do need vibrant architectural images, and Mr. Tschumi's gift for them is estimable. The problem is that for too long we've indulged the premise that cities can be supported by images alone. They can't, any more than art direction, by itself, can sustain a feature film. If the museum wants to do something authentically subversive -- and constructive at the same time -- it ought to challenge that premise. Instead of striking radical poses while things continue to fall apart, it could assume responsibility for putting a few of the pieces together.
"Bernard Tschumi: Architecture and Event" remains at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, through July 5.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bernard Tschumi's design of an underside of a roof, for an art school in Tourcoing, France. (Museum of Modern Art)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Clubs' Economic Data Are Turned Over to Union

 BODY:
Labor representatives of major league baseball's club owners took a significant step yesterday in the plodding negotiations with the Players Association for a new collective bargaining agreement.
Lawyers turned over to the union the first set of the clubs' economic information that was promised when the two sides began their negotiations more than six weeks ago. 
 "We have received some of the information we sought, not all of it," Lauren Rich, a union lawyer, said after meeting with lawyers for the player relations committee. "We expect this will be a continuing process."
At the negotiating session March 7 in Tampa, Fla., Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, told union officials and a group of more than 70 players that the clubs would give the union the financial data they used in their successful effort to formulate a new plan for sharing of local revenue among the clubs.
"We want to replicate what the owners went through to get to their revenue sharing plan," Donald Fehr, the union chief, said at the time. "We'll see if we share the same conclusions of their economic analysis."
Only two bargaining sessions have been held in what promises to be a long, arduous task to arrive at a new agreement. Chances are good that a work stoppage will occur before an agreement is reached.
The players have discussed the possibility of a strike sometime between the All-Star Game and Labor Day as a way of pre-empting what they expect will be the owners' strategy of implementing a salary cap for next season after declaring an impasse in negotiations.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Clinton On South Africa

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"It's amazing," President Clinton said. "Think of it contrast what we see in Gorazde with what we see about to happen in South Africa.
"I believe that if the [South African] election comes off well, it will send a message around the world that there is another way to deal with these problems. If it can be done in South Africa, how can you justify the old-fashioned killing and fighting and dying over a piece of land . . . in other places?" 
 The President was speaking with four journalists Wednesday evening about South Africa. He had agreed to an interview by Richard Steyn, editor of The Johannesburg Star, and Aggrey Klaaste, editor of The Sowetan. Clarence Page of The Chicago Tribune and I were asked to join them.
In Bosnia and other places with "ancient racial, ethnic and religious divisions," Mr. Clinton said, people "don't understand yet, for whatever reason, that in the end they'll be better off if they work together, and that controlling territory has nowhere near the significance . . . that it had 100 years ago.
"I think it has worked in South Africa partly because people with enormous influence decided to be statesmen instead of wreckers [and decided] that somehow they were going up or down together. And then they translated those understandings into concrete commitments -- not just an election. An election is only part of it, although a big part.
"The decision to go for a government of national unity for five years is absolutely critical to this -- and making the decision before you know the outcome of the election. The decision to have a bill of rights, the decision to have a constitutional court -- I think all these things have made a huge difference."
Mr. Clinton was extraordinarily well informed about South Africa, and he seemed happy to be talking about an upbeat subject. He remarked that "for the last 10 days, except for my forays on health care, I've done almost nothing but work on Bosnia and Haiti and one or two other foreign policy issues," all no doubt painful.
He said Americans had a particular interest in South Africa because of our own history of racial division.
"If you ask me one thing I have learned in my own life," he said, "growing up as a young boy in the segregated South, it is that this is something that you never solve; you just have to keep improving, you have to keep working with it. My own interest in politics in America was inflamed overwhelmingly by my opposition to racial segregation. . . .
"Unfortunately, human nature being what it is, identifiable differences will always be used by narrow-minded people or frustrated people or ignorant people, or sometimes bad people, as a lever, a wedge, a means of acquiring power or influence or dominance or just inflicting harm."
There is still "too much" discrimination in this country, Mr. Clinton said. As an example he cited the fact that 36 percent of American children under the age of 2 had not had all the necessary immunizations -- and one reason was that they "are more likely to be children of color and more likely to be poor than adults who tend to make the decisions."
A multiracial society can be "an enormous asset in a global economy," he said, but only if we and South Africa take advantage of it by providing adequate education and health care and teaching people "to live together."
In a striking comment, Mr. Clinton said he thought two kinds of societies would do well in today's world: one homogeneous and disciplined, the other multi-ethnic and open. Yet both now had problems. In Japan, reformers were trying to make the society more open, more accepting of diversity. In America we want more discipline, less crime.
Something about the subject had the President speaking philosophically and with unusual eloquence, or so I thought. He plainly cared about South Africa and the hope it represented, and he said he had plans to help the new government.
Together, he said, Nelson Mandela and President F. W. de Klerk "are a stern rebuke to the cynics of the world." Mr. de Klerk had overcome so much of his own Afrikaner people's history, and Mr. Mandela was "able to free himself of the bitterness that would surely have destroyed most people who had to live 27 years behind bars."

HEADLINE: Uncovered Short Sales Hit Highs at 2 Exchanges

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Short-selling activity, usually done as a bet that stock prices will fall, continued to climb in the month that ended April 8, the New York and American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday.
The Big Board reported that the total short position in its stocks -- the number of shares borrowed and sold short, but not yet covered by repurchasing the shares -- rose 3.5 percent, to a record 1.37 billion shares. At the Amex, the short position rose 4.4 percent, to a record 112.7 million. 
 The increases came as the stock market showed considerable weakness, with most leading market indexes falling as investors reacted to higher interest rates. The figures cover trades settled by April 15, which means those that were transacted a week earlier.
 
Big Move in Hanson
 Although short interest figures are often analyzed as an indication of overall bearishness, there are other reasons for changes in the figures. For example, the largest decrease in position came in Hanson P.L.C., the British conglomerate, where the short position fell 15.8 million shares, to 3.3 million. A big part of that short position had evidently been accumulated as a hedge in connection with a convertible financing, and the completion of the financing evidently let the short positions be liquidated.
 
Useful to Avoid Taxes
 Another factor that has caused the short interest position to increase is tax avoidance. A tax loophole being used by more investors holds that when a single taxholder holds offsetting short and long positions, there is no taxation until one or both positions are closed.
For example, the short interest in Salomon Inc. rose 4.4 million shares, to 8.8 million, and has risen 8.3 million in the last two months. The second-largest holder of Salomon stock, the Dart family, sold 7.6 million shares during that period, exactly offsetting their long position. But they will not owe capital gains taxes on the transaction, even though they no longer have a net economic stake in the company.
The largest increase in short position came in the stock that already had the largest position, RJR Nabisco. It rose 6.4 million shares, to 36.6 million shares, as the company scrambled to arrange new financing that is still pending.

Short Sales Tables Explained

 Cover ratio represents the number of days, at average volume level, that it would take to purchase the number of shares sold short.
