HEADLINE: THE WHITEWATER AFFAIR: NEWS ANALYSIS;
'Sorry' as a Political Weapon in the TV Age

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton said she was influenced to hold her first formal news conference as First Lady when she read that Eleanor Roosevelt had held more than 340 news conferences during her White House years.
"Now, Mrs. Roosevelt only invited women reporters," Mrs. Clinton said today, smiling. "I don't think I could get away with that." 
 The comparison was telling. Mrs. Roosevelt liked to remind reporters, as she gave them scoops on how often she got her hair done and when the White House would resume serving wine after Prohibition, "You don't elect the woman nor the family when you elect a man President."
Half a century later, sitting in a soft pink sweater before bouquets of matching spring flowers, Mrs. Clinton disproved that notion once and for all as she agreed to talk at length about her central role in the complicated web of her family's personal finances. With her image teetering in recent weeks between Saint Hillary and go-go profiteer, Mrs. Clinton tried to take back control of her reputation, so that she could move ahead on health care this summer without being dogged by her Arkansas past.
In an exceptionally polished and calibrated performance, in a town where politicians never like to say they're sorry, she showed the value of contrition as a political weapon in the television age.
She tried to banish the public doubts caused by White House actions that have seemed suspicious, inconsistent and protective by pleading that any mistakes that had occurred were caused by ineptitude and inexperience.
She said she had "rezoned" herself to get used to less privacy and to abide by the capital's tribal ways.
"This is really a result of our inexperience in Washington," she said. "I really did not fully understand everything that I wish now I had known."
With a calm, unwavering gaze, she apologized over and over for whatever customs of the city she and her husband might have violated; but she did not admit any mistakes in her financial and ethical behavior in Arkansas nor confess to any doubts about the propriety of her actions or those of her husband.
 
'Zone of Privacy'
 The First Lady had fought this moment for months, angry about what she felt were encroachments on her "zone of privacy," backed by former advisers like Bernard W. Nussbaum, a scorched-earth Manhattan litigator who had agreed that the less she revealed, the better. She resisted the appointment of a special prosecutor, and she spurned calls to hold a full-scale news conference to answer lingering Whitewater questions.
But with a new White House counsel, Lloyd N. Cutler, in place, and with the Whitewater story ebbing in the scary shadow of Bosnia and the lazy shade of spring, Mrs. Clinton suddenly succumbed, surprising even some White House officials with her timing.
As several of Bill Clinton's advisers stood in the back of the room watching Mrs. Clinton, it was clear that a lot of thought had gone into how today's performance would be staged.
Hard right angles were avoided. Even her chair was set at an oblique angle, cater-corner to the angle of the chair in which Lincoln, in the darkly gleaming oil portrait above her, sat contemplatively.
Everything was soft and warm, the sweater with the long, black knit skirt and the black high heels; the beige-and-gold decor of the State Dining Room, which is often used for private dinners; the profusion of ferns in the fireplace behind the First Lady, and the brass vases full of pink and white flowers.
Fearing any impression that she was the co-President, Mrs. Clinton avoided the heavy Presidential lectern and seal and chose instead to sit in a straight-backed chair on a small platform, her legs crossed at the knee and her hands clasped in her lap. Unlike her husband, who has a tendency to bristle when challenged on Whitewater, she was so cool that she never even needed to take a sip of the water placed on a small table at her side.
There were, inevitably, comparisons to the news conference in 1984 in which Geraldine A. Ferraro, then the Democratic candidate for Vice President, defended her family finances at length. But in Ms. Ferraro's case, she was forced to justify and explain her husband's financial dealings to protect her own candidacy; today, Mrs. Clinton had to justify her own financial dealings to protect her husband's Presidency.
She appeared comfortable, as if she were sitting at her kitchen table chatting over tea and cookies, an impression heightened as she often nodded empathetically and called the reporters by their first names, an effective technique except for the moment when she called Newsday's Susan Page "Ann."
The sense of uncertain protocol was illustrated when no one seemed to know how to begin the session. Mrs. Clinton waited for Helen Thomas, the longtime reporter for United Press International who traditionally starts Presidential news conferences, to ask her the first question. But Ms. Thomas seemed dubious about whether the same custom would apply in a terra that was incognita for everyone in the room.
 
Waiting for the First Question
 "Are we ready?" Mrs. Clinton asked twice, first looking expectantly toward Ms. Thomas, finally prompting her. Ms. Thomas asked Mrs. Clinton about reports that money from the Whitewater Development Company might have gone to her husband's campaign for Governor.
Mrs. Clinton's news conference had been under discussion at the White House for the last couple of weeks, because advisers said that they knew, as one put it, that "only by doing this can you move on and get away from the questions that are dogging you."
She did not feel ready to do it until today, one White House adviser said, because she wanted to be on top of the material when she met the press.
As an ebullient Mr. Cutler said after the news conference: "Of course she prepared. She's a lawyer. She knows her brief."
But the performance today was more than just an accommodation to "a press corps in full throat," as one Presidential aide characterized it. It was also clearly a dress rehearsal -- and a pre-emptive public relations strike -- should she have to appear before a Congressional committee on Whitewater and for her inevitable encounter with Robert B. Fiske Jr.'s investigators. Mr. Fiske, the independent counsel, has vowed to take the Clintons' testimony under oath about Whitewater.
White House advisers also expect that hearings will be held this summer, but it is difficult at this point to imagine senators or members of Congress, who greeted her first testimony on Capitol Hill on health care with gushing praise, questioning Mrs. Clinton any more aggressively than she was today.
At one point, as she tried to decide which of the scores of reporters to call on, Mrs. Clinton laughed and proclaimed, 'How does my husband ever make these choices? These are hard choices." Yet, it was also clear that Mrs. Clinton was wearing down the press when, after less than an hour, some reporters changed the subject to the more benign topic of health care.
Despite a demeanor that suggested infinite patience and openness, she never fully resolved the central question of Whitewater and the commodities trades: Whether powerful friends had given the Clintons favorable treatment and had opened financial doors not accessible to ordinary Arkansans.
"I wasn't a cattle expert," she said at one point. "I trusted Jim Blair and it worked out for me."
At other times, she insisted that neither Mr. Blair, her financial adviser and close friend who works for Tyson Foods, nor James B. McDougal, her Whitewater partner, had done anything improper for her and her husband. Mrs. Clinton said she saw no problem ethically with, in essence, being so financially dependent on friends who also did business with the state government that her husband ran.
 
No Red Flags
 Mrs. Clinton said, in particular, that her business relationship with Mr. Blair had raised no flags. "And the reason it didn't is that he and his wife are among our very best friends," she said. "My husband performed their marriage ceremony. I was the best person at the wedding. We are very close friends."
Nor did she ever really answer the question of why the Clintons' partners, the McDougals, wound up bearing so much more of the burden of the losses in Whitewater than the Clintons did.
And she was never able to satisfactorily explain why the White House has had so many conflicting stories on so many important issues, and why their explanations have changed so many times in the past few weeks.
Although Mrs. Clinton seemed to take care not to contradict the public record of White House statements on Whitewater, there were a few small inconsistencies in her comments today.
For example, she said that the White House had not revealed that she only invested $1,000 in the commodities account because they had been searching for old check stubs. But the White House had those records more than a week before the figure was released; an official had showed them to a reporter but had refused to allow him to copy them or take notes.
Trying to explain why the White House first tried to distance itself from Mr. Blair's involvement and then, days later, conceded that he had placed most of the trades for Mrs. Clinton, she said: "You know, I've been traveling and I'm more committed to health care than anything else I do. I probably did not spend enough time, get as precise. Different people heard different things that I said, or by the time it got passed to the third or fourth person, or one member of the press would call somebody in the White House but somebody else would call another person, so I think that the confusion is our responsibility. We did not give you a focused place to come, and we did not spend the time necessary. There's not really a contradiction in what you said and what I said, but I can understand how somebody could assume that."
Mrs. Clinton was also not successful in integrating her competing images. She sounded more like the Goldwater Girl she once was than the crusading '60s Democrat she became when she made this observation:
"I was raised by a father who had me reading the stock tables when I was a little girl, and I started doing that with my daughter when she was a little girl," she said. "I mean, I don't think you'll ever find anything that my husband or I said that in any way condemns the importance of making good investments and saving, or that in any way undermines what is the heart and soul of the American economy, which is risk taking and investing in the future."
Last May, Mrs. Clinton had a tune that sounded different as she complained about the greedy '80s: "The 1980's were about acquiring -- acquiring wealth, power, privilege." And her husband said this in his speech announcing his intention to run for President: "The 1980's ushered in a Gilded Age of greed and selfishness, of irresponsibility and excess and of neglect."
And, of course, commodities trading is not the safest or most common way to save and invest for your family. More traditional avenues of investing in the future would have been bonds, treasury securities and certificates of deposit, or even blue chip stocks. Commodities trading is a very high-risk speculation in which large sums are lost as often as large sums are made.
Mrs. Clinton, for instance, made more than $5,300 the very first day she was in the commodities market on her $1,000 stake, and she could just have easily as lost $5,300.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
President Clinton nominated two economists to the Federal Reserve Board whose philosophies suggest that they may seek to temper the pace at which the central bank raises interest rates to fight inflation. The nominations allow the President to put his stamp on an institution run entirely by Republican appointees. [Page 39.] 
The Administration is taking the first steps to restrict imports of Canadian wheat and barley into the United States, a move that intensified a dispute over wheat. [39.]
 
Markets
Kidder, Peabody discharged another trader for concealing losses, in a sign that broader problems were emerging on the securities firm's trading desks. [39.]
Stocks closed essentially unchanged, as the bond and stock markets tracked each other within a narrow range after the nominations of two economists to the Fed. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.86 points, to 3,648.68. [40.]
Prices of Treasury securities slipped after a three-day rally. The 30-year bond was down 4/32 , to 888/32 , to yield 7.22 percent, up slightly from Thursday, but down 6 basis points for the week. [48.]
Crude oil prices jumped to a five-month high as traders said an expected rebound in the world economy could draw down supplies while production stagnates. [47.]
The dollar was steady against leading currencies as traders waited to see whether world economic leaders meeting on Sunday would try to curb the recent rise of the Japanese yen. [47.]
 
International
Brazil's auto industry is undergoing a $12 billion modernization intended to put Brazilian-made cars on streets around the world by the end of the decade. Last year, Brazil produced a record 1.4 million cars, leapfrogging over Italy and Mexico to become the world's 10th-largest car maker. [39.]
 
Companies
About 300 airlines may get their flight schedules bumped from Apollo, the airline industry's computer reservations system, if they do not become full participants in the network. [38.]
Exxon and Mobil reported stable earnings for the first quarter in the face of falling crude oil prices. Increased profits for refined products made up for much of the falloff in income from exploration and production. [41.]
Liz Claiborne hired Paul R. Charron, executive vice president of the VF Corporation, to be its chief operating officer and vice chairman, potentially resolving the issue of corporate succession that has bedeviled the apparel company. [41.]
Shares of Unisys plunged after the computer company said its first-quarter revenues had dropped nearly 12 percent, well below analysts' expectations. [41.]
Duracell and Intel announced standards for a battery with a chip that tells portable computers, cellular phones, camcorders and similar devices exactly how much charge they have left. [41.]
Prudential Securities settled charges of securities law violations with California, which had been the lone holdout to the firm's broad settlement of fraud charges with regulators. [51.]

Your Money
Japanese stock prices have gained despite the country's political instability, a sour economy and an overvalued currency. [37.]
Investors in some favorite mutual funds have learned a hard lesson: There are not always ready buyers for the funds' holdings, especially when times get tough. [37.]
Mortgage life insurance policies may not be the bargains they appear to be. Other types of insurance can usually achieve the same result at far less cost, consumer groups say. [37.].
Easy-to-use software offers expert help to get a handle on the vast number of variables that affect retirement plans. [38.]

HEADLINE: Dow Edges Down 3.86; Nasdaq Index Rises 3.82

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed essentially unchanged in normal trading yesterday, as both the bond and stock markets tracked each other within a narrow range following President Clinton's nominations of two economists for the Federal Reserve Board.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.86 points, to 3,648.68, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 stock index fell 1.10 points, to 447.63. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index continued its recent rise, gaining 3.82 points, to 722.56. 
 For the week, the Dow fell nearly 13 points.
A variety of large stocks were hurt slightly. Among them were local-telephone stocks like GTE and Southwestern Bell, electric utilities like Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison, retail chains like Wal-Mart and Sears, Roebuck, as well as money-center banks like BankAmerica and J. P. Morgan.
 
Technology Issues Gain
 But many technology stocks gained, including Novell and Lotus Development. The Nasdaq was led by Amgen, a biopharmaceuticals stock that rose 4 3/4, to 42, after its first-quarter earnings, announced Thursday, exceeded analysts' estimates.
When President Clinton nominated Alan S. Blinder and Janet L. Yellen to the Fed yesterday, the news was out shortly before 11 A.M. Bond traders bid up the 30-year Treasury bonds, and stock traders bid up the Dow and the S.& P. 500 shortly afterward.
But the quick retreat from the small gains on the stock and bond markets was a measure of how little traders know about Mr. Blinder, an economist from Princeton University who is on the President's Council of Economic Advisers, and Ms. Yellen, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley.
"There were some technical reasons for the fall of bonds," said Frederic T. Leiner, fixed-income market strategist for Continental Bank in Chicago, "but mainly people were talking about Blinder and Yellen and whether they would be hawkish on inflation." Rising inflation hurts the value of stocks and bonds.
 
Nominees' Views Unknown
 There seemed to be little in the public records of the nominees about their stances on, for example, the Fed's three interest-rate increases in less than three months. And a rumor that Mr. Blinder favored eliminating the 30-year Treasury bond -- something on which he would have no say at the Fed -- swept the bond markets and was interpreted somehow as showing he was dovish on inflation.
Dennis Jarrett, chief market analyst for Kidder, Peabody, compared the markets' uncertainty to the legal community's uncertainty about a Supreme Court nominee. Like a Justice, "it almost doesn't matter what Fed nominees have said because once they are behind closed doors, they could turn around 180 degrees," he said. "It's why stock traders went back to sitting on their hands today, waiting for Monday."
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday totaled nearly 296 million shares, a bit below the year's average of 304 million shares, and far below the previous three sessions.
 
Gainers Outnumber Losers
 The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.23 point, to 247.95. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining issues by 1,282 to 930. The American exchange's market value index rose 2.18 points, to 433.31.
Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 14 fell, led by Sears, which dropped 1 3/4, to 46 1/2, and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which fell 1 1/8, to 47 3/8, on no discernible news.
Of the 500 stocks in the S.& P. index, 235 stocks fell. GTE fell 1 1/8, to 31 7/8, after its share price rose earlier in the week when it reported higher-than-expected first-quarter earnings. Wal-Mart fell 1/4, to 25 3/8, on no discernible news.
The most active stock yesterday was Informix, a data base software company, with 9.8 million shares traded. Its share price dropped 29/16 , to 169/16 , after the company reported on Thursday that its first-quarter profits were lower than expected.
The second-most-active stock, with 6.8 million shares traded, was Intel, whose shares had recovered somewhat after falling sharply during April on a poor competitive outlook. Intel rose 1/8, to 60 3/8.
In Tokyo, stocks were higher yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 165.03 points, or about eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 19,964.39. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 82.82 points.

HEADLINE: 2 Economists Nominated to Fed

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
President Clinton nominated two economists to the Federal Reserve Board today whose philosophies suggest that they may seek to temper the pace at which the nation's central bank raises interest rates to fight inflation.
The nominations of Alan S. Blinder, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers on leave from Princeton University, and Janet L. Yellen, an economics professor at the University of California at Berkeley, allow the President to start putting his stamp on an institution now run entirely by Republican appointees. Mr. Blinder and Ms. Yellen have reputations as mainstream economists who may put a bit more emphasis than their predecessors on increasing short-term economic growth rather than fighting inflation. 
 If confirmed by the Senate, as appears likely, Mr. Blinder, who is 48, would become vice chairman of the seven-member Federal Reserve Board. Ms. Yellen, 47, would become a governor.
Mr. Blinder would replace David W. Mullins Jr., who recently resigned to work at a money management firm and had a reputation as a moderate on inflation.
Ms. Yellen would replace Wayne D. Angell, who retired from the board in February and was the Fed's most outspoken advocate in recent months of higher interest rates; he has since joined Bear, Stearns & Company.
Mr. Blinder has played down concerns that strong economic growth now might cause inflation to rise significantly from its current rate of about 3 percent. "It is not something that is going to get anyone excited if, in the next several years, it edges up to 3.5 percent," he said last month.
By contrast, other Fed officials have been talking in terms of holding inflation steady or even trying to eliminate it entirely. Edward W. Kelley Jr., a Fed governor, said in an interview on April 4 that zero inflation "is our long-term goal."
Ms. Yellen has written mainly about employment issues, and not much is known of her views on the trade-offs between inflation and short-term economic growth. Jagdish Bhagwati, a Columbia University economics professor and an acquaintance of both nominees, predicted that "they'll provide more of a pro-inflation bias."
But Lyle E. Gramley, a former Fed governor who was appointed by President Jimmy Carter, said such evaluations might be overstated. "I would classify both of them as traditional mainstream Democratic economists," said Mr. Gramley, who knows both nominees. "That scares some people because they think that all traditional mainstream Democratic economists are inflationists, but I don't believe that."
Mr. Gramley said that most economists, probably including Mr. Blinder and Ms. Yellen, now agree that while rising inflation might very briefly help economic growth and reduce unemployment, inflation harms growth and employment in the long run and should be kept under tight control.
Frederick H. Schultz, a former vice chairman of the Fed appointed by President Carter, said the Fed resembled the Supreme Court in that predicting the votes of either body's members based on their previous writings was extremely difficult.
The initial influence of Mr. Blinder and Ms. Yellen on interest rates, if they choose to try to slow or reverse the recent rapid pace of increases, may be limited because they will almost certainly be outnumbered. Although they will hold two of the seven seats on the Fed board of governors, Fed policy is determined by the Federal Open Market Committee, which consists of the governors, the president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank and, on a rotating basis, the presidents of four of the 11 other regional Fed banks.
Top Fed officials say there has been considerable backing within the central bank for the steps it has taken since early February to raise short-term interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point. Broad support also exists for one or more additional increases this year.
Mr. Blinder graduated from Princeton University in 1967 and earned a Ph.D. in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1971. He taught at Princeton from 1971 until becoming a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers last year. Mr. Blinder, who is married and has two sons, is the author or co-author of 10 books and wrote monthly columns for Business Week magazine from 1985 to 1992.
Mr. Blinder is scheduled to serve the balance of Mr. Mullins's term, which expires on Jan. 31, 1996. In theory, he would then be in a position to replace Alan Greenspan as the chairman of the Fed, because Mr. Greenspan's second four-year term as chairman will expire a month later. But in practice, no vice chairman of the Fed has ever gone on to become chairman.
Mr. Blinder chose to be nominated for a term expiring in early 1996 instead of taking the 14-year appointment that went to Ms. Yellen. Mr. Blinder said in an interview this evening that he chose the short term because his leave from Princeton will expire at the end of January 1996 and because it would have been hard for the President to find a talented economist to serve as a governor without the vice chairman title for such a short period. Mr. Blinder also said at a White House news conference today that no one had spoken to him about whether he might succeed to the chairmanship.
 
Service at Universities
 Ms. Yellen graduated with a degree in economics from Brown University in 1967, and earned a Ph.D. in economics from Yale University in 1971. She was an assistant professor of economics at Harvard University for five years, before serving briefly as a lecturer at the London School of Economics and an economist with the Federal Reserve Board. She has taught at the University of California at Berkeley since 1980, and is married to George Akerlof, also an economist there; they have one son.
Mr. Blinder and Ms. Yellen are both friends of Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers and another former economics professor at Berkeley. Ms. Tyson, Robert E. Rubin, the chairman of the National Economic Council, and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen were the members of a special panel that chose both candidates.
Mr. Blinder won the support of all three of them weeks ago. Ms. Yellen assured her nomination when she met Mr. Bentsen for the first time last Saturday and convinced him that she was well qualified, said a senior Administration official who insisted on anonymity.
President Clinton technically announced today his intention to nominate Ms. Yellen, because the actual nominating papers will not be completed until the Federal Bureau of Investigation has completed a routine check on her background. But Mr. Rubin said that Ms. Yellen had already been asked many questions by Administration officials and did not appear to pose any problems.
The Administration took pains today to say that it was not trying to fill the Fed with friendly economists who would hold down interest rates when President Clinton is up for re-election in 1996. Mr. Bentsen said at the news conference today that neither candidate had been asked whether they approved of the recent interest rate increases or would seek further increases.
Yet some White House officials privately express irritation and concerns about possible damage to the economy if interest rates increase further, particularly if the Fed raises short-term rates above 4 percent. Ms. Tyson wrote a strongly worded article for the Op-Ed page of The New York Times a week ago in which she argued that inflation was not an immediate risk.
Senior Fed officials agree that they see no imminent signs of inflation, but worry that the economy is approaching its maximum level of output too quickly. Once that maximum level is reached, which is hard to measure, growth will tend to slow to the rate of expansion of the nation's total capacity to produce goods and services.
Mr. Blinder said this evening that the nation's underlying capacity to produce goods appeared to be growing about 2.5 percent a year. He also estimated that the economy could not grow more than another 0.75 to 1.5 percentage points above this capacity rate before reaching maximum capacity.
As a result, Mr. Blinder estimated that the economy would grow by no more than nine percentage points altogether in 1994, 1995 and 1996.

HEADLINE: THE 37th PRESIDENT: REACTION;
In Death as in Life, Nixon Provokes Strong Passions

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
In life, Richard Nixon was loved or hated with a special ardor by those who knew him best and dealt directly with him on political matters and matters of state.
His death did not cool that ardor. 
 His admirers and defenders stood steadfastly by him in death, as in life, glossing over Watergate, the most prominent entry on his career ledger. They focused, instead, on the second most prominent entry, his handling of foreign affairs, especially the diplomatic opening to China.
Mr. Nixon's critics and detractors remained steadfast, too. Their language was respectful in the hour of trial for the Nixon family, but their message was as disapprovingly blunt and as censorious as ever.
Typically, for one Nixon defender, former Secretary of State William P. Rogers, Mr. Nixon departed as "a great world leader."
"His accomplishments," said Mr. Rogers, now a New York lawyer, "were overshadowed by another event that was deemed more newsworthy at the time."
 
'He Never Gave In'
 But he continued: "I think history will overcome that. In fact, I don't know of any other mortal who went through what Richard Nixon went through and by the end of his life had recovered as much as he had. He never gave in."
No such recovery occurred in the view of Alger Hiss, the former State Department official who was a target of one of Mr. Nixon's intense searches for Communist subversives hidden in American Government.
"He left many deeds uncorrected and unatoned for," Mr. Hiss, now retired, said in a brief statement issued from his home in New York.
"I naturally feel sympathy for the members of Mr. Nixon's family," Mr. Hiss added.
President Clinton, who after taking office periodically conferred with Mr. Nixon on matters of state, said tonight in reporting his death to the American people that "he experienced his fair share of adversity and controversy." But that point made, Mr. Clinton delivered a warm appraisal of Mr. Nixon's handling of foreign affairs.
"I was deeply grateful for his wise counsel on so many occasions on many issues over the last year," the President said, adding "his country owes him a debt of gratitude," voicing something that would have been heresy for a Democratic leader in earlier years. "He was a statesman who sought to build a lasting structure of peace."
Mr. Clinton added: "His resilience and his diligent desire to give something back to this country and to the world provide a lesson for all of us about maintaining our faith in the future." The President said that as recently as a month ago, "he was still in touch with me about the great issues of the day."
Former President Ronald Reagan praised Mr. Nixon without qualification, calling him "a great champion of democratic ideals who dedicated his life to the cause of world peace, for millions truly one of the finest statesmen this world has ever seen."
Although down through the years the simple mention of Mr. Nixon's name was usually enough to elicit a pointed comment and judgment from those who knew him best, a few prominent figures from the Nixon years chose to remain silent upon the occasion of his death. And a few others acknowledged his passing with notable curtness.
One was Spiro T. Agnew, never at a loss for words while serving as Mr. Nixon's Vice President and oratorical point man, until he was driven from office by an influence-peddling scandal that preceded the Watergate scandals.
"I have no comment," Mr. Agnew said, speaking by telephone from his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He would not elaborate, but a White House official in the Nixon-Agnew days said that Mr. Agnew was bitter because he felt that the Justice Department in the Nixon Administration had been unduly severe with him and that he had been treated too harshly.
Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor in the Watergate case whom Mr. Nixon had dismissed, was only slightly more forthcoming.
"I don't think the occasion of his death merits getting back into any of that," he said from his office at Harvard University, where he is now a professor of law.
Former Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona, one of the most revered elders of the Republican Party, was equally succinct, calling for prayers for Mr. Nixon in a two-sentence statement and then adding, "He is, without a doubt, the most knowledgeable President we've had in foreign policy."
Likewise, former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, a Nixon appointee who played a major role in swinging the Court to the right, opined in a two-sentence statement that Mr. Nixon should be remembered for achievements in foreign policy and for "leading the opposition to Communism when Communism had achieved some popularity in this country."
Elliot L. Richardson, the Attorney General who resigned rather than dismiss Mr. Cox at Mr. Nixon's behest, reflected at length on his old boss, finding both good and bad but leaving no doubt that Watergate still rankled.
Mr. Richardson saw Mr. Nixon as "a figure not unlike the flawed hero of a Greek tragedy," a man who "had it within his grasp to be a great President" and who, in fact, achieved great domestic and foreign victories. Then, Mr. Richardson added, the "flaw" came into play and Watergate resulted.
"Richard Nixon's great weakness," Mr. Richardson said, "was the approach to life that came out of his battle to achieve station, influence, power -- all the things he felt he had not been accorded as a youth. He had an insecurity -- an insecurity that eventually propelled him to the Presidency via his aggression, suspicion, vindictiveness, retaliation and so forth. He viewed every opponent as an enemy and he never understood when he had won."
Mr. Richardson said that Mr. Nixon's "considerable accomplishments" in foreign and domestic affairs should never be denigrated.
"I certainly never do," he added. "But I have never been able to feel the same way about him since I resigned. For a time I actually had bad dreams about ever seeing him again. I never did, except once, years later at some offical function or the like. We exchanged pleasantries for a moment and then I tried to tell him that for all our differences I had never said bad things about his genuine accomplishments. He said he didn't care what I ever said about him."
George McGovern, the South Dakota Senator soundly defeated by Mr. Nixon in the 1972 Presidential election, also saw Mr. Nixon as a man with a fatal flaw.
Mr. McGovern, now president of the Middle East Policy Council, a study group, gave the former President high marks for his handling of Soviet and Chinese issues and spoke of finding common ideological ground with him on some domestic issues, such as agriculture and nutritional aid.
"The truth is that when I was in the Senate I often looked upon him as an ally on some of these issues," Mr. McGovern said. "But then there was always that one dark street in him, that McCarthyesque thing. That was his worst character flaw and it manifested itself -- the conspiritorial stuff -- all the way to Watergate. That office break-in? Heck, looking back on it, we Democrats didn't have anything going at that point that was worth keeping secret."
To Alexander M. Haig Jr., who was chief of the White House staff when Mr. Nixon resigned, Mr. Nixon was "the most competent and capable President in foreign policy in the post-World War II era and a President who was well ahead of his legislature on such important domestic matters as health care, the environment and the economy."
And what of Watergate?
"He violated the law," replied Mr. Haig, now a Washington consultant. "But he made his peace with that the day he resigned and left the White House. And then he came back from setbacks that were unprecedented. His influence in foreign affairs at the time of his death was still such that every President and world leader sought him out. He wrote more extensively than any other former President. He was a great man and he will be a role model for generations to come in the way he bounced back from adversity. Time will tell about Richard Nixon."

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Decline On Technical Factors

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities slipped yesterday, following a three-day rally. Traders said that with the absence of new economic news to respond to, bond trading was, for the most part, technically driven.
The naming of Alan S. Blinder and Janet L. Yellen as President Clinton's first two appointments to the Federal Reserve Board had no immediate impact on bond prices since news had been leaked in advance. 
 If market participants are worried about whether the two appointees will be as tough on inflation as their predecessors, David W. Mullins Jr. and Wayne D. Angell, they are guarded about it.
 
 
'Risk in Slowing Down'
 Some fear that Mr. Blinder and Ms. Yellen are doves and are concerned that they may slow down the Fed's current effort to fight inflation. "The risk in slowing down the process of tightening credit is that it creates a dangerous atmosphere of anticipation which prompts people into spending more in order to get a jump on rising interest rates," Peter J. Canelo, chief investment strategist at NatWest Securities, said.
Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Securities, believes that the Fed would not change policy at this stage of the interest rate cycle. With reference to Mr. Blinder, Mr. Fine said: "His credentials as an economist are impeccable. I'm sure his intelligence would lead to the correct conclusions which would not be any different than those of the current memebers."
Mr. Fine said the difference in policy between hawks and doves would probably be visible if the economy was in a contraction phase, rather than an expansion.
Then there are those in the market who are not worried about the two nominees, and find it puzzling why anyone would be. "We don't know much about either of their views on monetary policy," Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist for First Albany Corporation, said. "If it's true they take a balanced approach to policy, its nothing new. I think they're not likely to have any influence on policy in the near future."
 
 
Volatile Session
 Trading yesterday was volatile in a session that saw the expiration of bond options as traders and dealers began looking ahead to next week's schedule of new Treasury bills and notes.
By late in the day, the 30-year bond was down 4/32 of a point, to 888/32 , as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, inched up to 7.22 percent from 7.21 percent Thursday. However the yield was down 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, for the week.
The Government said yesterday that it would sell $16.5 billion of new one-year bills on Thursday. The size of the sale was unchanged from the previous auction.
Next week the market will also be busy with the regular weekly bill auction on Monday, two- and five-year note auctions Tuesday and Wednesday and the first report on how strong the economy was in the first quarter on Thursday.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's auction, the new two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.66 percent and the five-year issue at 6.55 percent. The current one-year bill rate is 4.64 percent.

 
 
Move by Trump
 Elsewhere in the corporate debt market, the Trump Taj Mahal Finance Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to raise $125 million through the sale of discount notes and warrants to purchase such securities.
A newly created finance unit, the Trump Taj Finance Company, plans to package the notes into units. Each unit would consist of $5,000 principal amount of senior secured discount notes and a warrant to purchase $1,000 principal amount of the discount notes.
Donald J. Trump plans to use the proceeds from the unit sales in part to acquire a 100 percent equity interest in a holding company for the partnership that owns and operates the Trump Taj Mahal Casino, the largest casino and hotel in Atlantic City.

HEADLINE: Ukraine Olympians Dedicate Rink Site

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SIMSBURY, Conn., April 22

 BODY:
Oksana Baiul and Viktor Petrenko, the Olympic skating champions from Ukraine, seemed surprised by the size of the crowd gathered for the groundbreaking of this town's Olympic-size skating center. More than 1,200 people gathered at the rink site for a glimpse of the skating stars, who are scheduled to move here this fall and train at the new rink.
The $5 million skating center is being built 4 miles north of the Simsbury town center off Route 10, 12 miles northwest of Hartford, in a clearing behind two weathered tobacco barns. 
 Proposals for an Olympic rink have been around for years, first centered on nearby Farmington and most recently on Hartford. It settled in Simsbury when Stephen Fish, a Simsbury developer, formed World Skate Inc. and the Culbro Corporation, a local company, donated the land. Fleet Bank is financing the venture, with a state loan guarantee.
 
Throngs of Fans
 Making her way through throngs of fans, Ms. Baiul, the 1994 Olympic gold medalist in figure skating, was all smiles, looking more poised than her 16 years. Mr. Petrenko, the 1992 gold medalist, was stern faced and nervous, clasping the hand of his wife, Nina.
They were greeted by members of the Zoria, a Ukrainian dance group from Hartford, dressed in traditional costume. A large round loaf of bread called kolach was passed first to Ms. Baiul, then to Mr. Petrenko and his wife, and to officials of Fish Enterprises/World Skate Inc., which is building the rink.
A wind wreaked havoc with hair-dos and microphones, but the ceremony came off as smoothly as one of Ms. Baiul's and Mr. Petrenko's routines. A native of Ukraine now living in Hartford provided some home country soil for the groundbreaking, and the choir from the Children's Ukrainian School in Hartford sang Ukraine's national anthem as well as "The Star Spangled Banner."
"I think it's just terrific," said Kim Hayden of nearby Avon. Mrs. Hayden took a long lunch from work with her daughter, Kelly Anne, 13, an avid figure skater, thrilled to find a front-row seat.
"I think it will be wonderful to have a big sporting facility under one roof," said Sandra Sundwall of the Tariffville section of Simsbury. The center will have two rinks, one for the public, the other for competitors in training.
Others looked at the economic impact. "I think it will put Simsbury in the forefront," said Sal Gilberto, who works at Wagner Ford, just in front of the rink site. "And it'll be good for the car business."
Mr. Petrenko said he was "very excited" about the prospect of living and training in Connecticut, although he will still call Odessa his "base home." World Skate Inc., formed by Mr. Fish, is providing town houses to Ms. Baiul, the Petrenkos and their coach, Galina Zmiesvskaya.
Why Simsbury when they could train anywhere? Mr. Petrenko said he wants to be near his coach, Ms. Zmiesvskaya -- who is also his mother-in-law. He said the center would be world class, with an Olympic figure skating coach, Bob Young, a West Hartford native, as executive director. Mr. Young will also be the pair's skating coach.
Ms. Zmiesvskaya said she is committed to stay in Simsbury through the 1998 Olympics. Her daughter, Nina Petrenko, a professional dancer, will be the center's director of choreography.
