HEADLINE: Managed Care Is Supermarket Medicine

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Having been told by my colleagues of the near certainty that the insurance companies have targeted New York City for conversion to managed care, I made inquiry as to the payment to the primary care doctor -- the so-called gatekeeper whose presence is essential to the plan.
The fee to this doctor is $5 to $10 a month per patient, that is, between $50 and $120 a year. His responsibility is the health of that individual, which to me means an annual evaluation and examination, 24-hour call, all hospital care and the coordination of the individual's health care. 
 I spoke to a doctor friend in the plan, a good internist, and asked how he could provide quality care for that remarkably discounted price. His answer was "I can't; they get what they pay for."
The insurance companies are generally paid an average of $3,500 by the employer who purchases the insurance. The insurance company keeps around 20 to 25 percent of the fee for profit and calls the payment for medical care its "medical loss ratio."
We as a society and the insurance company in particular don't really value our health. By comparison, a good divorce lawyer gets more than $350 an hour (just to protect our assets). An accountant gets $2,000 and up, to protect the doctor from excess taxation. The price for magnetic resonance imaging is $1,000 (at my hospital). The fee for reading it, a five-minute job, is $260.
The diagnosis of a need for reform is correct. It is a crime for 40 million people to be uninsured. The prices of prescription drugs are ridiculous. Sick people are dropped from insurance rolls because of the expense of their illness.
Good medical care cannot be rushed. Ninety percent of the diagnosis is from the history and physical examination. What good is a correct diagnosis if time is not taken to explain the need to take medication or, more important, to encourage the patient to discontinue self-destructive habits?
The insurance companies are anxious for that 8 percent of the gross national product that goes into health care.
Supermarket medicine, that is, managed care, is not the answer. The status quo cannot continue either. I suggest universal health coverage, preferably single payer (eliminate the insurance company and the bureaucracy) and preferably without an employer mandate (like most of Western Europe). If we acquiesce to managed care, we will have corporate takeover of an honorable profession. Care of the individual will suffer.
 
RICHARD B. CHERNAIK, M.D.
Bronx, April 17, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section 7; Page 28; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 951 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:
THE FATE OF THE ELEPHANT
By Douglas H. Chadwick. Sierra Club, $14.
Selected one of the best books of 1993 by the editors of The Times Book Review, this study examines the natural history and habitats of elephants in the regions where they dwell, from Africa and Asia to American zoos. Ultimately considering whether these animals will survive, the book is "fun to read and a splendid and much-needed introduction," Vicki Hearne said here.
PIGS IN HEAVEN
By Barbara Kingsolver. Harper Perennial, $13.
In this sequel to the author's novel "The Bean Trees," Taylor Greer, a young single mother, is confronted with the possible loss of her 6-year-old daughter, Turtle. The child, a Cherokee Indian, was taken in by Taylor after she was left, abused and neglected, on the front seat of Taylor's car; although Turtle was officially adopted, such proceedings are illegal according to the Indian Child Welfare Act if they take place without the tribe's consent. Last year our reviewer, Karen Karbo, said: "Possessed of an extravagantly gifted narrative voice," Ms. Kingsolver "blends a fierce and abiding moral vision with benevolent, concise humor. Her medicine is meant for the head, the heart and the soul -- and it goes down dangerously, blissfully, easily." 

LATINOS: A Biography of the People
By Earl Shorris. Avon, $12.50.
The author argues that Latinos are not one culture but many, and that their contributions are enriching American society despite the prejudices (both Anglo and Hispanic) that have often impeded their efforts to succeed. This history "is likely to remain unequaled in its sweep and profundity for some time," J. Jorge Klor de Alva said here in 1992. One of the darker aspects of the Latino experience -- the lure of gangs for impoverished youth -- is explored in ALWAYS RUNNING. La Vida Loca: Gang Days in L.A., by Luis J. Rodriguez (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $10). The author, a poet, traces his own descent into violence as a young Mexican immigrant in the 1960's. Last year our reviewer, Gary Soto, called his account "vivid, raw . . . even tender." Personal and ethnic history -- both Latino and Mexican -- are at the heart of TRANSLATED WOMAN: Crossing the Border With Esperanza's Story, by Ruth Behar (Beacon, $15). The author, a Cuban-American anthropologist, having intended to do a historical portrait of Mexican women, instead focuses on a contemporary Indian, a fierce peddler and reputed witch. "One is mesmerized," Nancy Scheper-Hughes said here last year.
FOR LOVE
By Sue Miller. Harper, $6.50.
Lottie Gardner, a middle-aged freelance writer, goes back to her childhood home in Cambridge, Mass., where she becomes involved in the aftermath of a tragedy that illustrates all the terrible possibilities single-minded passion can bring. Last year our reviewer, Ron Carlson, said this novel "may be the most honest 20th-century love story we've had in a while."
THE PASSION OF MICHEL FOUCAULT
By James Miller. Anchor/Doubleday, $14.95.
In a book that is neither pure biography nor criticism, the author investigates the parallels between Foucault's life and his work. He interprets the philosopher's interest in sadomasochism and self-destruction as emblematic of his intellectual preoccupations with power and transgression. "Mr. Miller succeeds in re-creating the passionate progress of an exceptional man," Isabelle de Courtivron said here last year. Also available in a new edition is Foucault's THE ORDER OF THINGS: An Archaeology of the Human Sciences (Vintage, $12), an intellectual history in which he looks at the evolving world views propounded by biology, economics and linguistics from the Renaissance to the end of the 19th century. In 1971 our reviewer, George Steiner, said, "One is left with a sense of real and original force."
THE MAN WHO WAS LATE
By Louis Begley. Fawcett Columbine, $10.
This novel by the author of "Wartime Lies" explores the alienation of a Holocaust survivor, a businessman whose immersion in a world of wealth and casual affairs threatens to destroy him. "Mr. Begley has taken a courageous risk," Eva Hoffman said here last year.
THE MOTION OF LIGHT IN WATER
Sex and Science Fiction Writing in the East Village:
1960-1965
By Samuel R. Delany. Richard Kasak/Masquerade Books, $12.95.
This memoir chronicles the author's literary and sexual awakening, describing his early marriage to the poet Marilyn Hacker and his recognition of himself as a writer and as a gay man. The book "will be of interest primarily to those who already know the many pleasures that Mr. Delany's fiction can afford," Gerald Jonas said here in 1988. Much of that fiction has also been brought back into print; Wesleyan University/University Press of New England has reissued Mr. Delany's "Return to Neveryon" series, a fictional archeology of an ancient civilization led by a former slave. In 1979 our reviewer, Mr. Jonas, characterized the first volume, TALES OF NEVERYON ($12.95), as "superb science fiction." In the second book, NEVERYONA: Or, the Tale of Signs and Cities ($14.95), Mr. Delany "continues to surprise and delight," Mr. Jonas said here in 1983. FLIGHT FROM NEVERYON ($14.95) "may be the most successfully experimental work yet from an author for whom language and story are inseparable," one reviewer said in 1985. The conclusion of the series, RETURN TO NEVERYON ($14.95), originally published as "The Bridge of Lost Desire," carries on the story of a place in which hieroglyphics are being replaced by an alphabet and dragons are an endangered species. In 1988 our reviewer, Mr. Jonas, said, "As always, Mr. Delany writes with equal ease about ideas, processes and feelings."
 LAUREL GRAEBER

HEADLINE: Mangia!

BYLINE: By R. W. Apple Jr.; R. W. Apple Jr., the Washington bureau chief of The New York Times, is a director of the American Institute of Wine and Food and the author of "Apple's Europe."

 BODY:

TREASURES OF THE ITALIAN TABLE
Italy's Celebrated Foods
and the Artisans Who Make Them.
By Burton Anderson.
318 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $20. 
MUCH has been made in recent years of the healthiness of the Mediterranean diet, with its emphasis on fruit, vegetables, fish and olive oil. Even the habitual daily glasses of wine are said (hurrah!) to confer health benefits.
Italian cooking, the most accomplished in the region, has long been the most popular "foreign" cuisine in the United States -- not because it is healthy, but because it tastes so good. There can be few people in this country who have never eaten spaghetti; pizza rivals hamburgers as the fast food of choice, and the New American Cuisine, pioneered in California, with its pastas, salads and grilled fish and meat, has its roots firmly planted in Italian soil.
Yet in the motherland, danger stalks the rich traditions of the table, including the wonderful array of local specialties that remind us that Italy was a patchwork of duchies, monarchies and city-states until our own century. The standardizing Eurocrats in Brussels, the lure of fast food and a faster style of life, the economies of scale and the convenience of the microwave oven and the food processor are changing what Italians eat. Family farms are vanishing, to be replaced by vast spreads using chemical fertilizers, pesticides and herbicides. Traditional processes -- and hence flavors -- have in some cases been banned in a mindless pursuit of sanitation and alimentary purity.
Now comes Burton Anderson to tell the world what it is in danger of losing. In Italy, as in France and other European nations, growers and skilled artisans remain locally (and in some cases nationally) celebrated for their produce. One of my greatest pleasures in 35 years of traveling in Europe has been the discovery of some of these -- the last artisanal maker of Cheddar in the Mendip Hills of England, a distiller of prize-winning Calvados in a picture-perfect half-timbered Norman farmhouse -- usually with the help of a friendly hotelier or restaurateur proud of local achievement.
Mr. Anderson has captured all the joy of such chases in "Treasures of the Italian Table." A journalist from Minnesota, he moved to Tuscany in 1969 and has spent the last 25 years making himself into the leading authority on Italian wines writing in English. Poking into every corner of the country, he has discovered undervalued wines in the Abruzzi and the secrets of prosciutto curing in and around Parma. His book "Vino: The Wines and Winemakers of Italy" is now the standard reference, in Italian as well as English. His new book makes no pretense to comprehensiveness, but it is packed with the lore of products like white truffles and balsamic vinegar and dishes like risotto, Florentine beefsteak and pizza.
Do not turn to Mr. Anderson to discover how to make a perfect pasta primavera; this is no cookbook a la Marcella Hazan. Do not look here for travel itineraries; Mr. Anderson says he does not want to overwhelm the artisans he describes with busloads of gastronomic tourists, although he names restaurants where regional specialities can be tasted at their very best.
Some will say that this is a specialist's book, interesting only to those bewitched by food. But that is not so, because in describing the way rice is cultivated or bread is baked, Mr. Anderson tells much about traditional Italy and how it is changing. And he paints vivid portraits of stubborn men and women for whom extracting the best products from fields and forests constitutes the "highest form of self-fulfillment: art, passion, a way of life." Few who read about them will quickly forget the cast of characters, which is worthy of Boccaccio: consider, for example, Teresio Vaschetto, the master truffle hunter, who looks like James Mason; and Giuseppe Mazza, the impish, roly-poly king of the pizza oven, and Carlo Latini, the red-haired, blue-eyed pasta maker.
Mr. Anderson brings a reporter's tenacity and a novelist's touch to his work. A researcher in grain genetics might be described routinely by many. But not here: "Cesare, with his ambling gait and serene smile, had a spiritual air about him, like a Franciscan monk who for the occasion had exchanged his frock for a short-sleeved blue Oxford shirt and neatly pressed beige cotton slacks."
The book is crammed with history. I had not known before that pizza was sold in New York as early as 1895 or that pasta came to Italy long before Marco Polo visited China. There is food lore of delicious obscurity: how balsamic vinegar is moved from one barrel to another during conditioning, from oak to chestnut and often to cherry, ash, locust, mulberry and juniper in turn; how hams are inspected with a gugia, a long needle made of horse bone; how olive trees are pruned into the shape of chalices so the sun's rays will reach into the center.
Know what calzone means? "Trouser leg," according to Mr. Anderson. Focaccia comes from the Latin focus, meaning "hearth." Extra-virgin olive oil -- the only product to "transcend a state which in mortals is considered absolute" -- must by law be cold-extracted by rollers (no chemicals) and contain less than 1 percent oleic acid. Mr. Anderson will tell you all about espresso, too, from a list of the countries where the best coffee beans grow to the story of Achille Gaggia, the Milanese who perfected the espresso machine.
He may irritate you with his too frequent use of untranslated, unfamiliar Italian words, such as intenditori ("connoisseurs") and merenda ("light meal" or "snack"). But I'll wager that he'll win you with his fond, uncondescending descriptions of his friends among the contadini, the often secretive countrymen who struggle against mass production, and with his lyrical accounts of the good things they make as others pursue the "dreary dream" of a Europe of "homogenized tastes."

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: My Search for Donna Delbert

BYLINE: By Teller; Teller is the smaller, quieter half of Penn and Teller, the noir comedy magic duo. This is an excerpt from a work in progress, "No Bunnies: The Dark Side of Magic."

 BODY:
"HAVE I GOT A woman for you!" Bob Lund announced with a procurer's wink, and heaved an apple box labeled "Donna Delbert" onto his kitchen table. His wife, Elaine, set out a pot of decaffeinated tea with some slices of poppy seed cake and said apologetically that she and Bob had to go "over to the museum to wait for the man to read the gas meter." Now, Bob and Elaine really do own a museum -- the American Museum of Magic, in Marshall, Mich. -- specializing in all the magicians who were not Houdini, but I bet Elaine was lying about the gas man; Marshall is the kind of blueberry pie town where the gas company trusts you to read your own. No, they were leaving me alone with Donna Delbert's apple box because they knew I would fall for her, and l'amour is a private thing.
When they were gone, I opened the box. I like touching personal things that belonged to the dead, things I have no right to touch. As the snow began to fall outside the Lunds' kitchen, I read Donna's letters, stroked her dainty gloves and sniffed the torches she ate fire from. Then, in an advertising photo, I saw her for the first time, peering from her own plump shadow, her vampire lips in a coy half-smirk under plucked, painted eyebrows. She was my kind of woman, a creature of the night. 
 She had been notorious. Her sultry mug had graced the pages of glossy rags from Sir! to Time. Rumored to be the American widow of a British tank gunner killed in the Normandy invasion, she appeared suddenly on the English music hall circuit shortly after World War II, calling herself "America's Outstanding Lady Magician and the Only Lady Fire-Eater in the World." Agents booked her at once. A Yankee dame to the tips of her long red fingernails, she conjured, sucked the flames from torches and snuffed candles with a crack of her whip. She was the perfect postwar woman, the Rosie the Riveter of magic.
Then, as I learned from her clippings, one spring midnight in 1949 she was having a late supper at her boardinghouse in Newcastle-upon-Tyne when a detective inspector appeared, saying he believed she was a fugitive in disguise. Donna went silent and shook her head no. The inspector searched her purse and found a pass card and Army Registration Certificate for a soldier missing from the United States Army Air Force. Hours later at the police station, in a voice an octave below her usual contralto, she confessed: she was that missing soldier, Delbert Hill, a male Pfc. gone AWOL from the U.S.A.F. He had been living as a lady fire-eater for four years and had fooled everybody except the two women who were his lovers. Unfortunately, jealous Betty got wind of rival Edna and blew the whistle on their cheating heartthrob.
The Air Force took away Delbert's falsies, cut his brunet curls and sentenced him to two years' hard labor. Sleazy reporters showed up to sneer, but he basked in the attention. He bragged to them how he had shocked the judges by swallowing lighted cigarettes. When they asked what he would miss most in prison, he replied without skipping a beat: "My corset. I can do without my high-heeled shoes, but when you wear a corset for almost four years, you get kind of used to it. That's why I'm looking fat today." He was shameless and they loved him for it. "It won't be so bad in the clink," he said with a shrug. "I'm going to write a book on my years as a woman. That will show them." In his diary, Delbert summarized his trial: "Like Hollywood premiere. Plenty cameras and reporters." Warhol would have worshiped him.
Transvestism is boringly popular in the 1990's: "Mrs. Doubtfire" pulls in $27.6 million its first weekend; Divine receives a reverent obit in The Times; Johnny Depp snaps up the movie role of sweater girl Ed Wood. But Delbert was more than a crossover cross-dresser -- he was a nut who pulled off a "Mission Impossible" high-stakes ultradrag, a magic trick on a hostile Government.
He had been sent to Britain in 1942 as an entertainer in the Air Force Special Service. In those days he did his act in a soldier's uniform, but that didn't stop him from making headlines. He was in the middle of his act in a London theater when an air-raid siren screamed. According to a July 1944 Philadelphia Evening Bulletin article:
"While bombs fell outside and shook the building, Hill went right on thrusting a fiery torch down his throat to keep the attention of an audience on the verge of panic. A fellow soldier emerged from the wings with a G.I. helmet and clomped it down on Hill's head. It was too large and covered Hill's eyes, but he went on with the routine. Flames gushed from his lips and smoke crept all around the helmet. The children screamed with delight at the ludicrous sight and their mirth spread to the adults."
There are those who would be abashed to have their heads on fire in public. Not Delbert. He was a star and wasn't about to let anybody, least of all Hitler, disrupt his act. Queen Mary the Queen Mother chose him for a command performance on the fourth of July to honor his coolness under fire.
After the war ended in Europe, he learned that the bureaucracy had classified him out of Special Service and reassigned him as latrine orderly. Stars do not scrub toilets. So he collected his paycheck, got stinking drunk and ran away to adventure.
Running away is a good thing. I recommend it. Twenty years ago I was a respectable high-school Latin teacher, apt to suffer the fantods as I noticed September approaching. I ran away, and now I earn my living producing roaches from top hats and trading wounds with a large man in red shoes. It's insecure and disreputable, but each fall when I hear the cheerful chant "Back to School!" and think of getting up at 5 A.M. to grade papers, something inside me does a little dance. So I root for Delbert.
He was now a hunted man with a near compulsion to stand in the spotlight and make a spectacle of himself. But the same lack of shame that let him flambe his head and become a hero came to his rescue. In his Air Force shows, he had appeared in comedy sketches in a grass skirt and halter top as "Dirty Gerti From Bizerti." With his plump little shape, he had considerable 1940's sex appeal. Female magicians are rare -- few women want to join a fraternity that uses them as decorative props to be sawed into bits -- so as Donna Delbert, ex-Private Hill was prepared to corner the market.
Doing the act was easy, but life offstage was trickier. By calling himself the wife of a tank gunner killed at Normandy, he sidestepped dating; no decent man would hit on a patriotic widow. One season he was unemployed (which he grandly termed "resting") and took a job packing tobacco at the Lambert and Butler factory, as, of course, Donna, in nylons and stuffed bra. Some thought him a bit unladylike -- apt to dispatch a pint and demolish a cheese sandwich with manly relish -- and some suspected he was a lesbian. But that was a good cover when, after two years of celibacy as Donna, he fell for pretty Betty in an Islington theater bar.
They had been girlfriends for a month when, according to Betty: "Donna asked me if I would like to share digs. I agreed. I watched her unpack. Donna had exquisite transparent cami-knickers, little lace panties, corsets, lots of nylons. We talked for a time, then Donna gave me my first shock. She asked, 'Would you mind if I smoked a pipe?' Later that evening I learned the truth. From that moment we led a strange life. Always in public he wore his long, black hair in smart feminine styles, but when we were on our own, he would fasten back his locks with an elastic band and sometimes even pencil in a moustache. It was only when we had a lovers' quarrel that he used his normal, deep man's voice. Other girls never guessed." She was right. Even Irene, who assisted Donna for 15 months and often shared the same bed, didn't have a clue.
BY THE TIME BOB AND Elaine Lund got back from their rendezvous with the mythical meter man, I had Donna spread all over the kitchen table and had missed my flight home to New York. "We'll get you a room down at the motel," said Bob. "Don't worry. I know. Donna gets under your skin. Donna will drive you nuts."
The next day Elaine had fresh muffins and an assortment of fruity teas for me, and I had just opened an envelope full of papers from after Delbert's arrest when I noticed Bob looking over my shoulder. "You know," he said, "the Donna Delberts are what my museum" -- Bob always accents the first syllable -- "is really about. They wear capes or tights or clerical collars and dub themselves Doc or Princess. They're innocents; the last of the innocents of the world. Deep down they suspect that if they pitch the sugar water with the right spiel, they just might end up curing cancer. They think there's real magic."
A mimeographed prison newsletter showed that even in jail the magic of shamelessness still worked: Delbert had used his fame as Donna (and, of course, his celebrated performance before the Queen Mother) to book himself a star slot on the inmate talent show, "A Musical Roundup." His reviews were socko. Hungry for the latest show-biz gossip, he wrote to the Performer, the British equivalent of Variety, told the whole truth about his years as Donna Delbert and invited his music hall cronies to get in touch. Would these people resent being lied to for four years? Would they despise him for being a deviate and a deserter?
An inch-high stack of letters was the answer. His theatrical pals praised him for fooling them, and tried to cheer him up: "If you are finished with your breast pads & nylons, my mum says don't forget her. Ha, ha, ha." They extended invitations: "You will be sure of a warm welcome whether you come as Donna Delbert or Private Hill." Agents congratulated him on his great publicity stunt. All the letters were upbeat, except the telegram from Edna, Betty's rival from Newcastle. She wrote, "BROKENHEARTED WILL WAIT 20 YEARS I LOVE YOU SO."
Near the bottom of the apple box there was a datebook for 1952, showing that after jail, Delbert went home to Philadelphia and was back doing his act for all the wildlife in the show-biz jungle: Lions, Elks, Moose, legionnaires and Boy Scouts. He evaluated the reception of each performance -- a New Jersey mental home, for example, was "better than some so-called normal audiences. The lads loved the show and I loved to do it." He was still a star.
At some shows he was Col. Don Q, a Buffalo Bill-esque Old West magician with a crepe-hair goatee, but a tear sheet from the Magicians listings in the Philadelphia Yellow Pages showed that his years in Britain had not been wasted. It advertised:
 
DELBERT, DONNA
The Celebrated English
Magician & Fire-Eater
Strangely, one thing was missing from the apple box: evidence of Delbert's death. I began to wonder -- could Delbert Hill still be alive? Bob didn't know. "I think he must be dead. Nobody in show business gives away stuff like this," he said, pointing to the box. "But if you ever find out, let me know. . . ."
In his dry, understated way, Bob is almost as shameless as Delbert Hill.
"OH-HO-HO! SURE, I KNEW DELBERT. YOU never knew whether you were going to meet him as a man or a woman."
I was on the phone to Harry, the Philadelphia magician who taught me how to squeeze a navy bean through my sinuses and out my eye.
"I loved him, but then, I love oddballs. I remember he had all sorts of jobs -- one summer he went around selling ice cream from a backpack." What was Donna like? "A classy middle-aged woman, with excellent taste in clothes. Had dinner at our house and completely fooled my dear wife. But when he was a man, boy, did he have a mouth on him. Try calling Ed at the Magic Fun Shop."
"Hmmph," said Ed, who long ago sold my parents a crucial magic kit. "Oh, I knew Delbert. Worked for me for a while until I found him becoming a partner, if you know what I mean. Last I heard of him he had some kind of restaurant on South Street."
"You mean the one next door to the tailor shop? Awful food? Only lasted a few months?" recalled Paul at Factotum Books on South Street. "I think it was called Del's Diner."
The tailor was sitting at an ancient sewing machine in his shop. He snipped a thread and raised his cropped white head. "Delbert Hill," he pronounced in a tone of biblical finality, "is dead."
So I called my pal Frank, the lawyer-novelist who is either related to or knows intimately every 10th human being in Philadelphia, who called his brother-in-law Steve the magic fan/undertaker, who called the Pennsylvania Division of Vital Statistics, which led me to two hospital workers, Vickie and Paula.
"Mr. Hill charmed everyone at the hospital," said Paula, a social worker who met Delbert during his last bout with cancer. "He got through his illness on his wit. I offered to help, but he was extremely independent and said, 'When puppies get sick, they just go off by themselves; then they either get better or they die.' And whenever I'd say something sympathetic, he would just laugh and say, 'Don't worry about me. I'm a soldier.' "
Vickie remembered that Delbert used to come over to Graduate Hospital on South Street, eat in the cafeteria and tell stories of life on the stage. "He had a clear, rosy complexion and a casual way about him. His apartment was full of magic and circus stuff -- to be honest, he really didn't keep the place up -- and he had a story for every poster. There were lots of women's clothes in his closets; he said they belonged to his girlfriend."
On Jan. 10, 1991, Vickie found him, 77 years old, dehydrated and dying in a chair surrounded by the memorabilia of his triumphs. He had refused to plan his burial or reveal anything about his next of kin. So he made his final exit through an unmarked grave. "You know," said Vickie, "Mr. Hill told us he once performed for the Queen of England. Do you suppose that was true?"
I told Bob and Elaine what I had unearthed in eight months of amateur sleuthing and handed Bob the last item for his Donna Delbert file: a handsome gray death certificate. Bob thanked me.
"You're one of them, too, you know," he said, pointing at the dining table laden with envelopes full of his "innocents." "I've already got a file started on you."
That means someday I'll be in an apple box, side by side with a transvestite fire-eater. I'm guessing I'll feel right at home.

HEADLINE: The Havana Hat Trick

BYLINE: By Daisann McLane; Daisann McLane writes about Caribbean culture.

 BODY:
SOMBREROS DE FIESTA," REPLIED ONE OF THE HAT LADIES WITH A smile and a wink when I asked her to explain why she'd fastened 18 pairs of dime store earrings, several faux sunflowers and eight plastic beaded hair clips to her straw boater. Since this was my first Miami-Havana voyage, I figured that the party hats were a Cuban style statement, a badge of the cosmopolitan similar to the American college insignia T-shirts worn in pre-glasnost Eastern Europe. But in Cuba, I didn't see a single person wearing a sombrero de fiesta. After customs, these collisions of Cuban baroque and Woolworth's bricolage evaporate instantly, like Cinderella's finery.
My second trip down, a lady in a sequinned bonnet let me in on the hat trick: Charter companies flying the jam-packed Miami-Havana run impose a baggage limit of 44 pounds per person. But they cannot set a limit on how much the passenger weighs. So Cubans and Cuban-Americans load themselves with whatever won't fit into the regulation duffel bag: socks, jeans, underwear, shirts worn in layers. Packages of rice, coffee, flour stuffed into the linings of crinolines; rolls of United States dollars pinned into pockets. And, to top it off, the hats, lovingly bedecked with little gifts for family and friends. 
 Incredible stories abound: There was the women whose hat was confiscated only to reveal her hair rolled up in sausages; the woman who marched up, ticket in hand, wearing a helmet made from a pressure cooker. I first dismissed these as Caribbean tall tales, but then I saw a woman with a colander dangling from the brim of her Miami Dolphins cap.
"This is not fashion; this is necessity," a Cuban-American woman said as she sent her mother back home to a Havana that is shrinking daily on a ration of five pounds of rice a month and little else. Cuba's economy, buffetted by the end of the Soviet Union's subsidies and the United States embargo, is at crisis point. These flights represent a trickle of relief for Cubans lucky enough to have family abroad. Even so, the flights are controversial in the politicized Cuban-American community. But while husbands and fathers debate whether bringing goods to needy relatives represents "traitorous" support of Castro, their wives, sisters and daughters pack their bags, and themselves, and put on their hats. Like modern galleons, bursting with small treasures from Taiwan and Hong Kong, they sail majestically across a gulf of politics, machismo and pride.

Bottom left: Returning home to Matanzas, Cuba from a visit with her family, Elida U. laughs and punches her "breasts": "They're not mine!" Bottom right: The trip is an occasion, and the hats commemorate a moment as memorable as a birthday or baptism. Estrellita's 33-day visit was her first reunion with her sister in 30 years. (Photographs by Karen Kuehn)

HEADLINE: ABOUT MEN;
My Conversation

BYLINE: By STEVEN BARBOZA; Steven Barboza, who lives in Manhattan, is the author of "American Jihad: Islam After Malcolm X."

 BODY:
My abandonment of Roman Catholicism was spawned by a premature death, my mother's at age 49, on the day before my 22d birthday. I prayed like crazy for God to spare her, and when He did not, I established a new line of communication. I called God Allah and prayed with my palms cupped (to catch blessings) and my eyes wide open (to keep Allah's creations in sight).
Given the irony and absurdity of events in racially torn Boston, where I lived, Islam was a godsend. A few months after my mother's death, whites assaulted a black man in front of Boston City Hall, using as one weapon a flagpole with an American flag attached. With that attack and my mother's death, a lifetime of frustrations reached the breaking point. 
 My odyssey 20 years ago was not unlike that of hundreds of thousands of blacks in the United States. The journey became my jihad -- literally "struggle" -- waged not for political power or economic enfranchisement, but for control over my own soul.
Then as now, in the Roxburys and Harlems across America, only liquor stores outnumbered churches in vying for blacks' attention, and in my opinion, both stupefied millions of black Americans.
Islam, as I was familiar with it, seemed the perfect way to fight back. As a religion, it offered clear-cut guidelines for living; as a social movement, it stood for a pride born of culture and discipline.
Before my mom died, I had dipped into Malcolm X's autobiography. After she passed, I plunged into it. Malcolm had undergone a metamorphosis: from hoodlum to cleaned-up spokesman for the Nation of Islam and finally a convert to orthodox Islam, and through his own transformation he had shown that change, even from the most miserable beginnings, was possible.
Of course, Malcolm's life and mine were very different. He had discovered Islam in prison. I discovered it in college. He was the spokesman for a black theocratic visionary. I held down a midlevel white-collar job in a Fortune 500 company. Still, I felt a kinship with Malcolm and the Black Muslims. The color of our skin made us all cargo in a sinking ship, and Islam beckoned like a life preserver.
Two decades ago in Boston and New York, however, there were few orthodox mosques. In black neighborhoods, one institution, the Nation of Islam, dominated in the teaching of Islam, or, rather, a homegrown version of it. Many blacks who converted took to the Nation's teachings -- its admonitions to self-love and racial solidarity; its belief in productivity and entrepreneurship. And with equal ardor, they also took to the Nation's other teachings -- its racial chauvinism, and belief that white people were genetically inferior, intrinsically evil "blue-eyed devils" who had been created to practice "tricknology" against blacks.
Using the twin motivators of myth and pride, Elijah Muhammad built the Nation into one of the largest black economic and religious organizations America had seen. It claimed a heavyweight boxing champion the whole world adored, Muhammad Ali. Its women looked like angels in their veils, crisp jackets and ankle-length skirts; its men cut no-nonsense yet gallant figures in their smart dark suits and trademark bow ties.
But sitting in the Nation's Roxbury temple was like being on a jury listening to a closing argument. The defendants (in absentia): white folks. The prosecutor: a dapper minister who practically spat, saying whites were so utterly devilish that their religion was grotesquely symbolized by a "symbol of death and destruction" -- the crucifix. The charge: perpetrating dastardly deeds on blacks "in the name of Christianity." The verdict: guilty.
I barely lasted my one visit. To me, demonizing the "enemy" as the Nation did hardly seemed the best way to learn to "love thyself." Anyway, I abhorred the idea of colorizing God, or limiting godly attributes to one race. And though Elijah deserved credit for redeeming legions of blacks from dope and crime when all else, including Christianity, had failed them, I didn't believe that earned him the title of Allah's "messenger."
So I moved to New York and became an orthodox Muslim in the manner all converts do: I declared before Muslim witnesses my belief in Allah and my faith that the Prophet Muhammad of Arabia was His very last messenger. I entered a Sunni mosque and prostrated myself on rugs beside people of all ethnicities.
Here was what I deemed a truer Islam -- the orthodoxy to which Malcolm had switched, the one most of Elijah's followers opted for when the Nation of Islam waned after his death, the Islam to which most of America's 135,000 annual converts, 80 to 90 percent of them black, belong.
Questions, however, persisted. For example: Why didn't we blame Arabs for their ancestors' role in slave trading the way we blamed white Americans and Europeans? One answer is that mistreatment of slaves is specifically prohibited by Islamic law, and the vast majority of Muslims living during the slave trade era observed that law. The children of female slaves and free men would assume the social status of the father, unlike the children of American slave owners. And while the children of two slaves remained slaves, Islamic law encouraged manumission.
And why did so many black Americans revere the Middle East as if it were their homeland? On a plane to Senegal, sitting next to a black American wearing a traditional Arab robe, I got an inkling of the answer. The man was headed to meet an imam, his spiritual leader, a black African Muslim. I later met other black Americans who had spent years in Africa studying Islam. Through research, I found that up to 35 percent of enslaved blacks brought to the New World were Muslim. In converting, many black Americans may have been simply returning to the religion of their forefathers.
Over the years, I have come to understand what should have been obvious long ago -- that Jesus had not forsaken my mother. She died because God had willed it, regardless of what form my prayers took.
And I hadn't rejected Christianity so much as embraced Islam. Malcolm X's struggle -- and Mom's death -- had been Allah's instruments for my conversion. After all, Allah, it is said, makes Muslims by whatever means He sees fit.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Florida Reviving Efforts To Legalize Gambling

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
LESS than a decade after Florida voters resoundingly defeated a proposal to bring casino gambling to the state, a coalition of hoteliers, cruise ship operators and race track owners is trying again. Seizing on fears that a recent widely publicized series of killings of tourists here, combined with the advance of gaming in other states, might encourage visitors to go elsewhere, they have begun a well-organized and lavishly financed effort to have the issue placed on the ballot in November.
The most sweeping of the four proposals being floated is endorsed by the Florida Hotel and Motel Association and would grant each of the state's 67 counties the right to choose among any combination of freestanding casinos and casinos in hotels, riverboats and parimutuel facilities. The campaign to pass a constitutional amendment authorizing gaming picked up momentum after the Florida Legislature defeated similar legislation during its annual 60-day session, which ended earlier this month. But supporters are heartened by a recent statewide poll that found that a majority of Florida residents currently favor some form of gaming. 
 In the eight years since voters rejected legalized gambling by a 2-to-1 margin, numerous states, including nearby Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana, have authorized the operation of casinos on riverboats or Indian reservations or in designated gaming zones. In addition, casino operators in Las Vegas, hoping to change their image and widen their tourist base, have opened several huge hotel complexes that include the sort of family-oriented attractions that are traditionally the backbone of Florida's $31-billion-a-year tourism industry.
"Just look at what Las Vegas is doing, building casinos around theme parks," said Michael Levine, spokesman for the hotel-backed proposal. "We have the weather and the beaches, but we are losing out because we don't have gaming." Other backers of casino gambling say they worry about competition from a post-Castro Cuba and about Florida's image as one of the nation's most crime-ridden states.
"Our reputation in reference to crime is not what we would like it to be," said Alberto Gutman, a State Senator from Miami who sponsored two gaming bills that failed this year. "Florida has all the ingredients to make it the top tourist attraction, but in order to keep that position firm and strong, we need to use every tool available, and that includes casino gambling."
The gaming drive is opposed, however, by Lawton Chiles, the Governor of Florida, and various local officials and religious groups. Mr. Chiles, who is running for a second term this year, "believes that Florida's future is about more than a roll of the dice or the spin of a roulette wheel," his spokesman, Ron Sachs, said in February. "He is committed to the kind of wholesome economic development that generates skilled, high-paying jobs."
Several of the proposed amendments envision some sort of freestanding "megacasino" in the tourist mecca of Miami Beach, but that city's Mayor, Seymour Gelber, said he is not interested. "The thought of 500 buses a day coming down from Disney World to get to the slot machines is frightening," said Mr. Gelber. "It would destroy everything that we have ever built here.
"Nobody is looking on us as a place where people live and work and enjoy the ordinary things of life," Mr. Gelber said. "We're not a gambling factory like Las Vegas, and we're not Atlantic City or some town on the Mississippi. We are a thriving city and tourist destination, and we want to attract assets that conform to our style of life here."
It is too early to tell how many of the proposed constitutional amendments will qualify for the ballot. Backers of the various proposals have already begun circulating petitions; they have until Aug. 9 to get the signatures of 430,000 registered voters. Gambling opponents, on the other hand, are much less organized, and two of the main leaders of the 1986 anti-gambling effort have said they plan to sit out this year's dispute.

HEADLINE: Got a Minute?

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER 

 BODY:
Call it idle time, relaxation, daydreaming, procrastination, lollygagging or just goofing off -- the hallowed tradition of dodging work for no particular reason other than "to be" may be an endangered pastime.
True idleness, as opposed to goal-directed recreation like skiing or tennis, might be defined as those little windows of solitude in busy days that allow minds to wander the highways of imagination with no specific destination in mind. Psychologists and sociologists who study the use of leisure time say that these unstructured moments, like taking a walk, gazing out the window or sitting on a park bench, are emotionally vital because they help people sort out life's complications, generate creative ideas or simply regenerate. 
 "People have been agonizing about the question of leisure since ancient times," said Prof. Witold Rybczynski, an architect, social historian at the University of Pennsylvania and the author of "Waiting for the Weekend" (Viking, 1991). "The difference today is that there are so many more distractions; we have to decide when not to use them to keep in balance."
The chirp of a cellular phone, breaking one's concentration, like a car alarm in the middle of the night, is as familiar these days as a laptop computer's converting an airplane seat into an office. But more and more, the symbols of this electronic age are turning up in unexpected places, simultaneously thrashing tranquillity and shattering solitude.
"I was just skiing in Vail and they were offering cellular phones and pagers to use on the ski lift," said David Michonski, who manages estate offices in Greenwich, Conn. Many rental cars now come with cellular phones; hand-held radio transmitters allow access to computer E-mail from anywhere, and the Internet, the vast web of computer networks, links users with volumes of information that were previously accessible only from an office.
Of course, popular culture has embraced these props of contemporary life. Stylized cellular phone cases are now common. The bouncy, repetitive dance music called techno plays off the new technology. And the audience at the Betsey Johnson collection at the recent fashion shows in New York was treated to the sight of models holding cellular phones and wearing beepers and headbands with antennae. The portion of the audience that was watching, that is. Many were busy at the time, themselves talking on cellular phones.
But even as society accepts the new technology, many people are developing strategies for unplugging themselves, hoping to restore a measure of control over their time, even a fleeting sense of isolation.
The explosion in communications technology has made it possible, indeed compelling, to work just about anywhere.
Social scientists suggest that devices like the pocket-size portable phone not only rob people of the security of isolated moments but also can make them unwitting prisoners of their homes-turned-offices.
David Farber, Moore Professor of Telecommunications at the University of Pennsylvania, laments the loss of one childhood joy known to anyone who grew up in cold-weather regions: the snow day. "We had a blizzard this year out in the countryside where I live, and nobody could get out," he said. "A lot of other faculty stayed home and relaxed, reading or whatever, but I was connected to the office with the computer and worked all day."
Professor Farber added that after the San Francisco earthquake in 1989 many people who were cut off from their offices wound up working from home via computers even before they had a chance to sweep up all the broken glass.
So what's wrong with ultra-efficiency? Nothing, experts say, if the time saved is used for restorative relaxation.
"Proper relaxation is a must for keeping the level of stress in our lives down," said Peter G. Hanson in his book, "Stress for Success" (Doubleday, 1989). He added that the key to a balanced life is compartmentalizing work and leisure. "If you don't close the door to your work compartment," he said, "it spills over into other areas of your life, making it hard to give anything your full attention -- particularly leisure."
Individuals interviewed agree that the potential solution to intrusive technology is our ability to choose not to use it sometimes. That's easy enough to say, but as researchers have found over the years, good technology has an irresistible seduction.
"I love to use my little pocket computer; I have fun programming my cellular phone," said Jerry Kravat, a music agent in Manhattan who is rarely farther than arm's length from some form of electronic communication.
A backlash to this overstimulation is surfacing in some unlikely places.
"I recently read about a large Japanese company that has instituted a 'no communications' hour between 9 A.M. and 10 A.M.," said Juliet Schor, a senior lecturer on economics at Harvard University, who specializes in women in the workplace. "That means no phone calls, no faxes, even from the president of the company. And they are finding that this is the most productive time of the day for employees."
The unexpected popularity of MTV's "Unplugged," in which rock stars perform without electrified instruments or special effects, also hints at a back-to-basics attitude among many fans of popular music.
"This flies in the face of all the high technology that made MTV possible in the first place," said John Cannelli, the network's senior vice president for music and talent. "We wanted to give viewers a little release and escape from the fast pace."
Individuals have their own strategies, too.
"This new technology is riding us; we are not riding it," said Peggy Noonan, an author and a former speechwriter for President Ronald Reagan. "Because we can be in touch instantly, we feel that we must be in touch instantly. I know people who think they must fax me directions to a meeting that is three weeks away!" This behavior is the 1990's extension of what E. B. White 40 years ago called "the intrusive urgency of the telephone."
Ms. Noonan, a single mother, said that she deliberately plans "ambling, pointless weekends" without computers and faxes so that she and her son can talk and be close. "Sometimes I feel guilty that he is not ice-skating and going to the symphony every weekend," she said. "But this makes us happy. Some people have minds that require loose, pointless daydream time."
Mr. Michonski in Connecticut said he saw the dangers of instant communication several years ago and planned his family life to circumvent them. Although he has three incoming phone lines at home, one exclusively for work, the tape machine answers in the evening. Mr. Michonski also schedules "downtime" in his daily appointment book along with business meetings to remind him to take time for himself and his family.
"It might lack spontaneity, but I had to do it," he said.
Mr. Michonski fondly recalled time that his father always put aside for his family: "Every Sunday when I was a kid in Massachusetts, my parents would pile me and my sister into the car and my father would drive. We never knew where we were going; it was downtime for the family -- time to sit in the back and fight with my sister, time to talk with our parents. That was great, and I don't want my children to miss experiences like that because I'm working at home."
Bruce Stark, a computer consultant in Manhattan, is also adamant about preventing gadgets from consuming his life. "I answer the phone and fax until 9 P.M.," he said. "Then, it's private time. On weekends I cannot be beeped -- but I check messages from time to time."
Mr. Stark estimates that of the hundreds of clients he works with annually, 40 percent to 50 percent are "consumed by the technology," unable to separate it from their personal lives.
"I need time for my soul," he added. "Some people haven't learned yet."
This sort of high-tech living, experts say, is still largely an urban, white-collar phenomenon. But as computers, cellular phones and the like descend in price and a computer-savvy generation emerges, these devices are expected to become commonplace. For a glimpse of the future, computer scientists say, walk down a street in Hong Kong today. Everyone, it seems, from bank officers to waiters, is barking into a portable phone. If only researchers could find out what they are saying with such urgency.
To be sure, communications wizardry has many positive effects: increased mobility, freedom from confinement in offices, the ability to screen phone calls rather than jump up and answer every one. And for all its ability to depersonalize communication, it can also bring people closer.
"I have a 23-year-old son living in Europe," said Professor Farber of the University of Pennsylvania. "Every time he sneezes, I get E-mail from him. Actually it's nice."
Professor Farber summarized the belief of many who study the phenomenon of work versus leisure: "These devices provide an opportunity for overworking, not a mandate. Workaholics have existed forever, with or without machines."

HEADLINE: Taking City Planning in a New Direction

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
UNMISTAKABLY sharp-edged on issues like crime and education, the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani cannot be so easily defined when it comes to land use. There are some civic leaders, indeed, who say they have yet to see any planning policy at all coming from City Hall.
In part, that is because the administration is still young and has been preoccupied with a number of issues it inherited, like the fate of the New York Coliseum site on Columbus Circle or the future of the Melrose Commons urban renewal area in the South Bronx. 
 However, it may also foretell the Giuliani administration's preference for laissez faire, for getting government out of the way and allowing the private market to determine what gets built -- and when and where -- rather than drafting ever more guidelines, regulations and criteria.
Joseph B. Rose, the 34-year-old chairman of the City Planning Commission and director of the City Planning Department, said his goal "is to reinvent City Planning as a user-friendly agency, a customer-oriented service agency, as opposed to an oversight body."
Mr. Rose said he hoped housing production would at least double during the Giuliani administration, something city planners could abet by rezoning manufacturing districts for residential development and by pruning rules that tightly govern the layout of certain apartment buildings.
"No one is looking to unravel necessary and appropriate community protections," Mr. Rose said, "but there is no question that this is an administration that is sympathetic to the role of development in the economy."
Meanwhile, the Mayor is still assembling his land-use team. (This is not unprecedented; it took Mayor David N. Dinkins three months to appoint his planning chairman, Richard L. Schaffer.) For example, Mr. Giuliani has yet to either replace or reappoint Laurie Beckelman as chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
The Mayor currently controls only one vote -- the chairman's -- on the 13-member City Planning Commission. Because of the way terms are staggered, Mr. Giuliani will not be able to appoint a majority of commission members until the summer of 1997.
And it was not until mid-March that the Mayor named Clay Lifflander as president of the Economic Development Corporation. On the same day, he named Richard D. Parsons, chairman and chief executive of Dime Savings Bank of New York, as chairman of the corporation.
Before joining government, Mr. Lifflander, 31, specialized in mergers and acquisitions as managing director of Smith Barney Shearson's corporate finance division.
"THE fact that I come from the corporate side means that I bring a new dimension vis-a-vis the business community and corporate recruitment potential," Mr. Lifflander said.
"I'm hellbent for leather to get proactive with corporate retention and attraction," he said. "I'm already pitching one company in the food business which is considering locating a manufacturing plant. We'll bury our egos and not take a headquarters. We'll take a manufacturing plant any day of the week, with its jobs."
Mr. Lifflander's background also prepares him for another important facet of his new job, he said, and that is "getting the city out of the asset-management business."
As a "perfect example," he cited the recent sale for $1 of eight city-owned industrial buildings in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn to the Greenpoint Manufacturing and Design Center for use by furniture makers, artisans and other small businesses. Some tenants have been there since 1972, when the property was seized for nonpayment of taxes.
"These guys are up and running," Mr. Lifflander said. "They've already done a lot themselves. They can be more successful without us." But he added: "It's not total altruism. If you sell them a building, it goes back on the tax rolls."
"This whole privatization concept has taken on scary dimensions and misunderstandings," Mr. Lifflander said. "I consider it optimizing. It's trying to have the city not own the things it doesn't need to own, having competition, not granting monopolies unless you have to." This is a theme that has also been sounded by William J. Diamond, the new General Services Commissioner.
Mr. Rose, who was executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a nonprofit group concerned with housing and planning issues, has his own goals.
"We should, at the least, double private-market housing production in the Giuliani administration," he said. "And I'd like to see it triple. That would be a very grandiose statement if the actual number of units being produced in the City of New York weren't so ridiculously low." He estimated last year's production at 5,000 units.
One way to increase it, Mr. Rose said, is by "creating opportunities for residential development" in areas now zoned exclusively for manufacturing -- many of them on the waterfront -- where there is "simply no market, no demand and no prospect whatsoever" that the land will be used for industrial purposes.
Another way, he said, is to prune regulations in the Quality Housing zoning program that dictate building interiors in great detail -- specifying the location of laundry rooms, the size of windows in laundry-room doors, the number of apartments on a corridor, the amount of play equipment in a recreational space. "I call it getting zoning out of the bedroom," Mr. Rose said.
There are other items on Mr. Rose's list of "anti-obstructionist" measures:
* Study the "fair share" criteria under which city facilities are supposed to be apportioned among communities.
* Raise the threshold under which projects are subject to environmental review.
* Substitute automatic, "as-of-right" regulations for those that now require special permits and authorizations.
* Hasten the approval process through "self-certification," in which a developer's architect or engineer -- rather than city planners -- would certify that an application was complete and ready for review.
"Yes, it's a pro-development agenda, as New York City needs," Mr. Rose said, emphasizing that he favored "appropriate" development only. "Inappropriate development that destabilizes neighborhoods and makes them less attractive places to live is not in the city's long- and mid-term economic interest," he said.
However, he also stressed that the city's environmental quality review procedure had "become an obstacle," rather than an aid.
"Reams of analyis that no one ever reads or pays attention to are generated in a way that the city has lost its ability to be competitive and be an acceptable place to do business," Mr. Rose said. "The people who come before and have dealings with City Planning should be treated as clients and customers, as opposed to supplicants."
That kind of talk cheers the real-estate and building industries.
"Hurray for him," said Richard T. Anderson, the new president of the New York Building Congress. "The building industry has echoed that sentiment for a long time and it's terribly reassuring to us to hear someone in that position so clearly state the need for improved procedures."
BOROUGH PRESIDENT Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island said, "We're hearing from more and more people in the business community that they have hope, whereas they'd abandoned hope in the past."
Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, also likes what he has seen since Mr. Giuliani took office. "At the moment, I've got to be positive from the industry's point of view," he said. "Every appointment has expressed the same, positive 'We want to be helpful' attitude."
Mr. Spinola characterized City Hall's approach to land use as: "We want to provide the right climate for growth in the business community and the real-estate community."
But enthusiasm is not universal.
When asked about the Giuliani administration's land-use policy, Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx replied:
"Do they have one?"
"My sense is that they're not much into planning and more into mechanics," he said. "I'm not aware that they have a planning policy and that's a little frightening."
In his first imbroglio as planning chairman, Mr. Rose raised questions about the Melrose Commons urban-renewal plan, which was devised with considerable neighborhood participation for a 45-acre area of the Bronx bounded roughly by East 156th and 163d Streets, Park and Brook Avenues.
What concerned Mr. Rose were design guidelines requiring six- to eight-story apartment buildings on some sites.
"Right now, there are no programs or mechanisms or market for the built form that the plan calls for," Mr. Rose said. He said he wanted more "flexibility" in the design controls, so that they could be modified to accommodate smaller buildings, without having to go through a formal urban-renewal amendment, which can take years.
"Inflexibility can be just as harmful as a lack of resources," Mr. Rose said.
But those responsible for the plan were angered by any suggestion that density be reduced, particularly since that suggestion seemed to be coming at the 11th hour, after the community had labored on the plan.
"That's not what this urban infrastructure was built for," Mr. Ferrer said. "A mix of densities is what builds a community."
"Nobody is pretending that there are programs on the table this morning for six- to eight-story buildings," said Richard Kahan, president of the Urban Assembly, which is coordinating the overall Bronx Center planning effort. "What the community has said is that if they have to wait five or 10 years for someone to be innovative enough to create such a program, they're prepared to wait, so that when this project is built, they'll have a neighborhood that will last."
A vote on Melrose Commons is scheduled for tomorrow at the City Planning Commission and the design guidelines were still under negotiation late last week.
Another unresolved land-use battle concerns the Coliseum site, which Mortimer B. Zuckerman is under contract to redevelop. The Giuliani administration has allied itself with Mr. Zuckerman in his efforts to restructure the longstanding deal instead of compelling him either to build as planned or forfeit a $33.8 million letter of credit.
"It doesn't indicate that there's any land-use policy," said Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge of the Upper West Side.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan said it was "distressing both that the focus was so much on, 'Let's make a deal -- any deal,' and that it wasn't clear who was setting administration policy."
MS. MESSINGER also expressed concern about City Hall's approach to revising the "fair share" program by which, in theory, every neighborhood bears equitably the impact of city facilities. Earlier this month, Mayor Giuliani was quoted in The New York Post as saying about the program that "it deteriorates every neighborhood to bring it down to the lowest common denominator."
As Ms. Messinger read it, this meant that "they're talking about seeking permission to dump facilities in already saturated neighborhoods."
And Mr. Kahan said "that may well be the most significant land-use policy pronouncement so far and would, over the years, influence the placement of many facilities."
In the wake of the storm kicked up by the article, Mr. Rose emphasized that in his review "nothing will involve fewer protections for communities than are now entailed in fair-share criteria."
For a number of key players, it is too early to take the measure of the Giuliani administration's approach to planning. "I think they're still developing their persona," said Councilwoman June M. Eisland of the Bronx, who heads the land use committee.
"The jury is still out," said Greg Brooks, executive assistant to Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn.
"I haven't really noticed any difference," said Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens. "The items we had are moving along the way they were before Giuliani took office."This month, she appointed Irwin Cantor, a structural engineer, to succeed Joel A. Miele Sr., who was named Buildings Commissioner in February.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 13; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Trump Tower;
New Tenant Mix, New Image and New Revenues

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
SOME buildings are just structures. Others are icons. And icons are just not expected to change.
So it is with more than a small degree of wonder that New Yorkers have watched Trump Tower, once home to stores that attracted the biggest of big spenders, metamorphose into a vertical mall that, while still higher toned than anything in, say, A & S Plaza, is a far cry from the posh emporium created at 57th Street and Fifth Avenue 11 years ago. 
 Gone are Martha, Lina Lee, Charles Jourdan, Buccellati and other stores with astronomical prices. They've been replaced by the likes of Coach, Footloose, Dooney & Bourke, and other highly respected but decidedly upper middle-class retailers.
Ferragamo, also an upper-middle-class shop, is opening a street-level shoe store and a third-floor accessories shop in June. Rumors are rife that Nike, an egalitarian footwear store if ever there was one, will open where Galeries Lafayette, the struggling French department store, now is.
And while The Trump Organization and Galeries Lafayette's president George J. Graf, deny that the French store's 80,000 square feet will soon change hands, there's another shocker of a tenant that no one is trying to deny. Tower Records, that purveyor of sound to the masses, will open an 8,000-square-foot store in Trump Tower in May.
"The whole idea of the new tenant mix is that everyone who comes through here, tourist or New Yorker, can leave with a shopping bag," said David J. Malitzky, vice president of real estate for The Trump Organizaiton.
The Trump Organization is bowing to demographic realities. When the building opened in 1983 it made no bones about catering to the rich. Its residential condominiums were among the country's most expensive, and the retailers it sought -- and got -- were the type that thrived in rarefied atmospheres.
Apparently, Trump was too successful in creating that image of exclusivity. Trump Tower rapidly became a tourist attraction, a place where thousands of people came to gawk at the marble walls and the ultra-expensive baubles and clothes but who left having bought, perhaps, a cup of coffee in one of the cafes. The bustle and crowds, meanwhile, drove many truly rich New Yorkers to do their shopping elsewhere.
"Trump is being realistic," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty, a retail brokerage. "These days many of the real high-end retailers and their New York customers want Madison Avenue."
Conversely, mass-market retailers have sought to capitalize on 57th Street's tourist flow. Warner Brothers has a store across the street from Trump Tower and the store selling merchandise with the Coca-Cola logo is just a block to the south.
"They wouldn't have been as interested if Warner's hadn't come in," said Richard T. Halpern, the broker who represented Tower Records. "They like that Fifth and 57th is no longer so chi-chi, but is a place where millions of people not only look, but can buy."
Existing Trump tenants seem to grudgingly accept the mass-market influx.
"Our customers come to us from all over the world, it doesn't matter who else is here," said Daniel Yerushami, whose ultra-expensive Napoleon men's wear store was one of Trump Tower's original tenants and who just opened a Lady Napoleon store there.
Other tenants, while less ebullient, still seem to feel the pros of their Tower location outweigh the cons. Stephen Russell, which sells fine jewelry, recently renewed its lease -- for a more favorable rent -- for its 200-square-foot third-floor store.
"The location is good, the security is good, and at least Tower Records isn't right next to me," said Russell Zelenetz, the store's owner.
Similarly, Karen Franceskin, manager of the Coach leatherware store across from Stephen Russell, said she had "mixed feelings" about Tower Records, but added "I'd rather see them there than an empty space."
CLEARLY, The Trump Organization was willing to risk disgruntling a few tenants to fill up the building. For the Tower's new tenant mix did not result from natural evolution; it is something the Trump Organization methodically pursued.
It had no choice. For the last four years the Tower has hemmorhaged tenants. Martha International and Lina Lee both closed their Trump Tower outlets, as much because of financial problems pervading their companies as for any lack of success on 57th Street. Bonwit Teller had left in 1989, and even though Galeries Lafayette quickly signed on for most of Bonwit's space, there was a year of costly buildout work before the new tenant started paying rent.
Meanwhile, an antiques store, a furrier and a restaurant succumbed to the New York recession. Other tenants were merely scraping by, and could not pay the mininum $200 a foot that Trump had been charging for mediocre space, let alone the $500 a foot that Jourdan shoes and other Fifth Avenue-frontage stores were paying.
With the retailers struggling, the revenue stream that came from a percentage of their sales dried up too, although that had never been very high to begin with.
"We had always preferred charging high rents to depending on sharing in revenues," Mr. Malitzky explained.
Suddenly, the path to those high rents was blocked. For the first time, the Trump Organization had to actively market for tenants. It hired Garrick-Aug Store Leasing, a brokerage that had found space for many mid-scale retail chains, to do the job.
The Garrick-Aug brokers quickly recognized that Trump's preferred split of high rent/low percentage of retail sales had to be turned on its ear.
"We couldn't scare tenants away with $500 rents," said Robert Futterman, a Garrick-Aug managing director. "We had to convince them they could afford Fifth Avenue."
In fact, Trump Tower had problems attracting new tenants. Donald Trump, who still insists on signing off on every deal, spoke to Warner Brothers and to Disney about perhaps opening in the Tower, but those deals never came through. Several retailers, including the Bostonian and 9 West shoe chains, were interested only if they could get the choice spots at the building's entrance, for a relatively low rent.
Meanwhile, Fifth Avenue storefronts were becoming available for as low as $300 a square foot for avenue frontage equal to the type of space for which Trump Tower still wanted top dollar. Several retailers spoke to Mr. Trump about space, couldn't agree on rents, and moved a few blocks south.
IN one sense, Trump Tower may be benefiting from the renewed competition. Many new Fifth Avenue stores, including Bruno Magli shoes on 52d Street and Golden Books Showcase children's books on 51st, are doing very well, which has not gone unnoticed by other retailers looking to expand.
"There are leases being written for $400 a foot again," noted Faith H. Consolo, another Garrick-Aug managing director. Those kinds of numbers may help Trump inch its asking rents back up, too.
For now, though, much of Trump Tower's retail negotiations are behind it. Galeries Lafayette, by far its largest tenant, has "repositioned" itself, as Mr. Graf put it. It has sifted through its merchandise lines, brought prices down, held some well-advertised sales. Mr. Graf concedes that the store is not making money. Nonetheless, he insists he has no intention of reneging on his lease, which runs until 2006, or of subletting space to Nike.
"That is not our game plan," he said.
Today, Trump Tower's 140,000 square feet of retail space is nearly full. A few new tenants, particularly those taking tiny spaces, are paying the old rich rents -- Sunglass Hut is paying close to $800 a square foot for a 125-square-foot store that used to house Trump Tower's own residential sales office. But most of the new tenants signed on at far lower rents than Trump Tower had traditionally been charging, but at a higher percentage of sales.
The numbers seem to bode well for the Tower. Mr. Malitzky notes that revenues from retail space came in at about $12.7 million in 1992. They were up to $13.6 million last year. And the forecasts are for steady increases each year, bringing the revenue stream to nearly $16.9 million in 1998.
And, best of all from the Trump Organization's view, "Since we started making them, our projections have proven to be conservative," Mr. Malitzky said.
