SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1512 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Roxbury;
Low Taxes, Low Profile and Rural

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
STRICT zoning dating to 1932, a profusion of ledge rock and wetlands that are natural deterrents to development, a location that is off the main routes and a population that prizes peace, privacy and low taxes have combined to let Roxbury retain a rural character that elevates the term low-key to new heights.
Because of the zoning there are no restaurants, movie theaters, liquor stores, dry cleaners, sidewalks, clothiers, condominiums or co-ops. The nearest hospital and supermarket are nine miles away, in New Milford, and the nearest major shopping is at the Danbury Mall, 20 miles away. 
 There are no traffic lights, and crime is so negligible that a resident state trooper and four constables suffice. The fire department, housed in a pristine white colonial building, is entirely volunteer, and the Town Hall next door, equally white and well-tended, is manned by part-timers and volunteers.
"This is a heavily Republican community," said Edward T. Went, the First Selectman -- a Democrat in his fifth term -- "but for the past 30 years the Republicans have been in for only six years. People in small towns don't bother with party labels."
There is no public water supply or sewage lines, and houses -- on lots that must be at least three acres -- have individual wells and septic tanks. Although some contemporary architecture is acceptable, colonial is preferred. That is in keeping with the almost 100 homes, barns and other structures, many built in the 1700's, in the Historic District along Church Street, Route 67, South Street, Southbury Road and Weller's Bridge Road that was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1983.
Taxes are kept low by the generosity of residents. Recently they supplemented state and Federal grants by substantial contributions to the new $1.5 million library scheduled to open in mid-May without a penny of local taxes.
"Now we will have a community room," said Timothy Beard, the town librarian, "where we will run film series, have parties, club meetings and tap into our pool of resident authors and artists for lectures, readings and performances."
He will have quite a choice. A short list of celebrities with homes in Roxbury would include the actors Dustin Hoffman, Richard Widmark and Walter Matthau; the novelist William Styron; the playwrights Arthur Miller, A. R. Gurney and Robert Anderson; the composer-lyricist Stephen Sondheim and Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in Lyndon B. Johnson's Administration.
MARION SKEDGALL, a former editor at E. P. Dutton, the New York publishers, and her husband moved to Roxbury in 1975 from Rye, N.Y. "We've never been sorry," she said. "What we saved on Westchester taxes bought us an apartment in Manhattan."
They live near Painter Ridge, where on a clear day, the Catskills -- 60 miles away, beyond a succession of ridges and valleys formed by glaciers several milleniums ago -- can be seen.
Mrs. Skedgall is the volunteer chairman of the Roxbury Planning Commission. "Things were very slow last year," she said. "Only three lots came up for subdivision approval. This year we had more than that in the first three months. Land prices are pretty good. In 1989 a 3-acre unimproved lot on a dirt road went for $150,000; now you can find some at $50,000."
About 30 preapproved lots, unsold through the recession, are available. Among them are six 10-acre wooded residential lots at Forest Farms on Davenport Road and North Street, for sale at $174,000 to $250,000 by Joan Galligan, a local developer. Under 10-acre zoning rules, the houses must have at least 4,000 square feet of space.
Roxbury began as a part of the Town of Woodbury in the early 1700's. In 1796 it incorporated, becoming a farming, manufacturing and mining town. In addition to silver, gold, copper and mica, iron ore was mined, and in the mid-1800's a smelting furnace was built with granite Gothic arched entryways, giving it the appearance of a small castle.
Outmoded and inadequate, it ceased operations in 1875. Columbia University's School of Mines used it briefly as a demonstration site and today it is owned and maintained by the Roxbury Land Trust as an educational curiosity. The trust also owns 1,400 acres of open space for hiking and birding, and in the summer town residents can use the trust's natural spring pond on River Road for swimming.
Through the 19th century Roxbury's economy flourished with sawmills, granaries and hat and button factories along the Shepaug River, but they began disappearing at the turn of the 20th century, unable to compete with huge plants in the Naugatuck and Housatonic River Valleys. Dairy farms continue to operate, but pieces of them have been sold off steadily since the 1940's, mostly to New Yorkers seeking vacation homes.
Edward Tierney, head of Tierney Real Estate, moved his family to Roxbury from Long Island in 1956 "to raise our children in the country," he said. He noted that Roxbury, despite its reputation for affluence, had "a mix of people, with lots of native families who don't have a lot of money."
His office is on Route 67, opposite the Town Hall in The Marketplace, a building that also houses a general store, the post office and the only bank, an office of First National Bank of Litchfield.
THE 9,000-square-foot structure, operating as a nonconforming building in the Historic District, was recently bought for $675,000 by Roderick Thorne and David Cleaves, local developers who are upgrading it and adding second-story offices. The store will have a meat market, fresh produce and groceries, and "we have hired a chef to prepare take-out as good as Balducci's but a lot cheaper," said Mr. Thorne.
The only other commercial site, zoned 30 years ago to permit a few stores, is in such a poor location on Route 67 that "the commission thought nobody would be crazy enough to build on it," said Mrs. Skedgall. Somebody did recently, but the four-unit, half-vacant retail building has not prospered and is for sale at $625,000.
Another thing that Roxbury lacks is private schools, but many consider the public system, with its low enrollments, educated families and generous budget, the equal of a private education.
Children from kindergarten through Grade 5 -- there are now 136 of them -- attend the Booth Free School on South Street. From grades 6 through 12 they go to the Shepaug Valley Regional Middle-High School in neighboring Washington, along with students from Washington and Bridgewater.
"The region was formed in the 60's to save money and avoid duplication," said the Superintendent, Robert Nicoletti. Today, he said of the regional school, "we have 491 students in a building designed for 1,000."
Roxbury's population has declined from a high of 3,500 in the mid-1800's to 2,100 in the 1980's to 1,850 today, a result of a lower birthrate and the exodus of young adults who can't afford to live there.
"We would welcome some minority students," said Mr. Nicoletti, "to comply with a state mandate for greater diversity, and because we have the room and the money to absorb them." He estimated that fewer than 20 of the Shepaug Regional School's pupils were nonwhite.
The regional school was cited for three years running by the State Department of Education for its innovative senior pilot project, which requires a year's work on a student's chosen topic. That project will become mandatory next year. Under the pilot program, individual students have produced a full-scale musical comedy, a hovercraft, a 45-minute documentary on the similarities of the five major religions and a design for a golf course and have raised, slaughtered and sold four breeder hogs and done a business analysis of the process.
About 85 percent of high school seniors go on to two- or four-year colleges. SAT scores in 1992 were 488 in math and 487 verbal, well above state averages.
UNDER the supervision of a volunteer commissioner, Jay Kronfeld, the town's recreation department offers free ice skating, a children's playground, baseball, shuffleboard and outdoor basketball at the Everett B. Hurlbut Community Park. There also are three blacktop tennis courts at other locations.
"We live a Spartan life here," said Mr. Kronfeld. There's no one to roll clay courts."
The Shepaug River can produce rigorous whitewater conditions for canoes and kayaks, and horse owners with riding-to-hounds experience may apply for membership in the Fairfield County Hounds, which originated in Westport in 1926 and gradually moved upcountry. The red-coated group meets on Tuesdays and Saturdays to gallop after the foxhounds that chase the foxes "but never catch one," said William Stewart, master of the hunt.
"We do not kill foxes," he said.
On May 20 there will be a Maypole celebration, and Old Roxbury Day will take place on July 23, when the Historical Society shows off its collection of antique farm machinery.
"We'll run the old threshing machine," said Robert Hodges, the event coordinator, "provided we can grow a crop of rye in time to feed it."

LENGTH: 1479 words

HEADLINE: New Jersey Q & A: Charles Osgood;
A New Face at CBS 'Sunday Morning'

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI 

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD

 BODY:
HIS television tag line is already known to millions: "See you on the radio." Charles Osgood will be saying a lot more than that in his new, high-visibility television assignment, one he says fills him with pride, joy, and a bit of anxiety about long hours at work and responsibilities at home in Englewood.
On April 1 -- April Fools' Day, he notes -- Mr. Osgood was named as the replacement for Charles Kuralt as host of the CBS News program "Sunday Morning." Mr. Kuralt, best known for his "On the Road" reports, was the program's host for 15 years. 
 Mr. Kuralt's retirement came as a surprise to many, including Mr. Osgood. But the choice of his replacement has been hailed by many people, including Mr. Kuralt.
Mr. Osgood, 61, brings to the Sunday program years of experience and a strong reputation for his witty radio and television reports, "The Osgood Files," which have spawned four books. His reports often include the whimsical poetry that is as much his trademark as is his bow tie.
Explaining his fashion choice, he said a study in Success magazine once found that men who wear bow ties are "distrusted by almost everyone." The magazine writer recommended that a bow tie be left at home, unless one is willing to wear with it the proper accessories, like "a red nose and a beanie cap with a propeller."
Mr. Osgood took issue with this, he said, "since credibility and being trusted are important in my line of work." Saying that people should never take themselves too seriously, he wrote:
For those who have lusted to be honored and trusted,
A bow tie, I say, doesn't hurt.
It isn't your tie that most people will eye --
It's the big soup stain there on your shirt.
Mr. Osgood lives in a home built in the 1850's by one of Englewood's founders, J. Wyman Jones. "When you've got five kids, you have to think of things on a grand scale," he said. In recent weeks, technicians have installed electronic equipment, so he can write and record his radio broadcasts from home.
With a demanding schedule that has him up at 2 A.M. and in Manhattan by 4, he said, getting some work done within view of his family will improve his recognition factor at home and prevent a call to the police reporting a burglar.
Q. What's a typical day like?
A. I get up at 2, 2:30 in the morning, shower and shave, get into the office by about 3:30, and by 4 o'clock I'm hovering over the Associated Press and Reuters wire and scanning the papers for story ideas. I do four separate stories, on the hour. And what's nice about being in a broadcast center is that with CBS "This Morning" being on for two hours, there's always a parade of people going in and out on any number of subjects, and I've been known to shanghai them on occasion.
With less than an hour between shows, you've got to write fast. And as the morning goes on, there's always less and less time. The trick is to stay ahead.
Q. How do you handle that kind of pressure?
A. Beats me. I do one story; then I have to erase my mind and move on to the next. It's the only way I can work. That's why, when people say to me, 'Hey, that was a really nice story you did this morning,' I have to say, 'Why, thank you. Which one?' "
Q. Your style has been termed unique. What do you look for in terms of stories?
A. Something that I can sink my teeth into. Nothing bizarre. Sometimes if you take a conventional story, add a rhyme to it, you can turn it into something special and spin it out over two and a half minutes. Of course, the story should be funny. Or poignant. Sometimes you're lucky, and it turns out to be both.
Q. You have a Steinway grand piano. I'm told that there's a story behind it.
A. This piano I bought from what used to be Columbia Records, back when it was CBS Records. This was in their recording studio on 30th Street, and this was their recording piano. It was used by Rudolf Serkin and Glenn Gould. In fact, this piano was used for the "Sing Along With Mitch" records, many of the Frank Sinatra recordings, and since 1939 and its lifetime there, it was kept under perfectly controlled humidity and tuned every day. It's lived a much harder life here, I must say.
Q. For many, watching "Sunday Morning" is an integral part of the weekend. As its new host, and in replacing Mr. Kuralt, do you feel you have some pretty big shoes to fill?
A. I have learned a lot about this show in just the last couple of weeks, and I think that it's really amazing how over the years it has become a ritual for a lot of people.
I've heard some say that they plan going to church around it, either before or after the broadcast. On weekends, on Sundays, people like to relax, to do the same things, and they find comfort in that, like reading the Sunday paper.
To say that the "Sunday Morning" show is part of that routine is really saying a lot. Hosting it is being part of that whole experience, because people are allowing you into their homes at a cherished time of the week.
Q. On your first "Sunday Morning" as host, you mentioned that Mr. Kuralt was going to sit back and watch the program in his bathrobe. Did he?
A. I don't know. He said he was going to. After 15 years of this, I hope he took the opportunity to sleep in.
Q. Do you plan on changing the format of the program?
A. The show has not changed over the last 15 years, but it has evolved. It's like the Sunday paper and sitting back and letting it all sink in. We have an arts section, the essay, the news and a time to reflect. Some lovely scenery shots with no talk over, no background noise. I think that, personally, that is my favorite part.
A lot of TV today, no matter where you turn, no matter where you tune in, it's just wall-to-wall yammer. Except on "Sunday Morning," and a lot of people on the broadcast are proud of that. I know I am.
Q. In college, you were an economics major. You have no formal training in print or broadcast journalism. How did you get into radio?
A. At Fordham University, there was a college radio station there, and I was drawn to it. My colleagues included Alan Alda and Jack Haley Jr. They were infectious, and we had lots of fun. There were times, of course, when we spent more time at the station than in classes, but we managed to graduate anyhow.
 Q. Didn't a stint in the Army also prepare you for your later career?
A. It did. When I got out school, I met a friend at a local radio station and ran into a fellow in this grand white suit with a ton of gold braid. Very impressive. It turns out that he was the announcer for the U.S. Army Band and was about to finish his hitch. I took note of that, talked to his commanding offficer and signed up. For three years, between 1955 and 1958, I toured as the band's emcee although we were based at Fort Meyer.
While in Washington, I moonlighted as an announcer at WGMS, which stood for Washington Good Music Station, by the way. At one point, when President Eisenhower had suffered a heart attack and was hospitalized, it was my job to put together a radio show that was piped exclusively into his room. I kept it light, because it's not every day that you have a captive Presidential audience.
Q. Do you regret not having a formal education in journalism?
A. Not in the least. I joined CBS in 1967, and when you work with the likes of Charles Kuralt, Douglas Edwards, Dallas Townsend and Walter Cronkite, it's kind of tough not to learn from the example they set. Most of all Kuralt.
At CBS, there was no one mold that everyone needed to fit in. That's why there was such a colorful repertoire of talent, such as Bill Moyers, Andy Rooney and Hughes Rudd. Early at CBS, I remember subbing for Lowell Thomas on a newscast. I was in such awe, because here I was filling in for someone that I'd been listening to since I was a kid. What a cast of characters, and here I was, right in the middle of them!
Q. How did your style evolve?
A. One day in a particular story I incorporated a little rhyme just as a way of doing something different. The report aired, and I immediately heard from a management type in the news division: "Very nice, Charlie, very clever. Don't do it again."
Needless to say, I did, although I did allow some time to elapse, and we got positive feedbacks from listeners. It just goes to show that no matter how crazy things can become around you, there is poetic justice after all.
 
Profile
 Born: Jan. 8, 1933, in the Bronx.
Education: St. Cecelia High School, Englewood. B.S. in economics, Fordham University, 1954.
Career: Former morning anchor and reporter for WCBS News Radio, 1967 to 1971; general assignment reporter for ABC News, 1963 to 1967; recipient of the George Foster Peabody Award in 1985 and 1986.
Family: Married to Jean Crafton; five children: Kathleen, 19; Winston, 17; Anne Elizabeth, 16; Emily Jean, 14, and Jamie, 10.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1518 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: April 17-22

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Could That Be I.B.M. Emerging From the Tar Pits?
It made good copy: the tale of a dinosaur that failed to keep up with the times and was clearly headed for the high-tech tar pits. But I.B.M., it seems, decided that it wasn't too pleased with that script. And last week -- a year after Louis Gerstner took charge -- it came out with a surprisingly strong quarterly report that says, at least tentatively, that I.B.M. is alive and kicking. These numbers don't say "extinct": profits, $392 million, on revenues of $13.4 billion. And, miracle of miracles, sales of mainframes -- the very word conjures images of dusty bones in this world of miniaturization -- aren't doing as badly as they were. The stock market, often cool to good profit news these days, was gleeful, as I.B.M. shares jumped 12 percent in a day, and crept up even more the next, to close the week at $58.75. O.K., that's not $170 (August 1987) but it's not $41 (August 1993) either. 

Ford Has a Global Idea
Ford, watching the world shrink, wants to set up shop on that new global street corner. Last week it redefined itself, announcing the broadest changes in a generation -- all aimed at hacking away at duplication in its vast worldwide operations and streamlining its sprawling organization. As a start, it will merge its North American and European operations -- but that's part of a broader vision of better coordinating its plants in 30 countries. A big part of that vision is a "world car" -- one that sells well everywhere. But is this a pipe dream? Ford's Mondeo, its latest try at a world car, has been criticized as inefficient, and other auto makers, like Toyota, have found that the world is still a big and varied place when it comes to tastes in cars.
 
Less Recourse on Stock Fraud
Suppose you buy a stock, the company goes bust, and it later turns out the company lied about its vital signs. What's your recourse? It used to be that you could look around for others to blame -- the accountant who checked the books, perhaps, or a lawyer who advised on a stock offering -- and sue them for "aiding and abetting" a securities fraud. No more. Last week the Supreme Court ruled that such suits are not allowed under the 1934 Securities Exchange Act. It was a victory for the securities industry and, of course, for accountants, who insist that securities laws have reached too far into their turf. But others say it will make securities laws harder to enforce and they see great dangers in taking the pressure off accountants.
 
Teledyne Whistle-Blower Deal
The Government's idea of getting whistle-blowers to help in recovering money lost to procurement fraud is clearly paying off. This year, in fact, the amount recovered could surpass $1 billion. A big chunk of that came last week, when Teledyne agreed to pay $112.5 million to settle two lawsuits by former employees -- one of the largest such payments ever by a military contractor. And the employees who came forward will get 15 to 25 percent of that. On the news, Teledyne's stock jumped $2.50, to $16.875.
 
Opening Up an A.T.M. Network
With automated teller machines increasingly becoming the way people do their banking, the Government is taking a closer look at the way the A.T.M. networks are run. The Justice Department zeroed in on the MAC network, the nation's biggest regional network, saying it had tried to create an illegal monopoly and had charged banks an extra dime per transaction, adding up to $100 million a year. Last week MAC settled with the Justice Department, agreeing to open the network to new rivals.
 
Earnings Up? Sell!
Many companies told the world how they were doing last week, and you'd think investors would act rationally, buying stock in those doing well. Get real, as the 10-somethings would say. Chrysler reported record profits of $938 million; its stock fell 4.7 percent in a day. Lotus's profit rose 74 percent; its stock plunged 12 percent. Morton's income soared 48 percent; its stock dropped 11 percent. What's up? Investors, it seems, want nothing but miracles. "No failure to generate a positive earnings surprise goes unpunished," said one analyst (ignoring I.B.M.). Meanwhile, AMR lost $7 million, and its stock rose.
 
A Success Story Explodes
Kidder, Peabody dismissed a bond trader named Joseph Jett last week, saying he'd wildly inflated profits to lift his bonus. Not that Mr. Jett's bonus was meager: $9 million last year. Would car payments and dental bills have been a burden at, say, half that? Kidder says Mr. Jett created a phantom $350 million profit working with today's high-tech investments, weaving pieces of bonds into webs so elaborate a spider would get lost. But here's the puzzler: didn't Kidder find it odd that a $350 million profit appeared out of thin air? If you plant a radish and get two radishes, you're pleased; if you get 350 million radishes, alarms should go off.
 
4-Megabyte Eggs and Ham
Yes, yes, the world is going high-tech. But aren't some cultural icons exempt? Last week the multimedia rights to the Dr. Seuss books were sold to Living Books, and the classic stories are headed for CD-ROM. So this is what's coming: After a two-income, zero-serenity day, you grab a little "quality time," snuggling up for the miraculously soothing cadences of "Green Eggs and Ham" -- just you, your 4-year-old and the computer. Do you like it, Sam-I-Am?
 
THE ECONOMY
 
The Fed Runs Its Own Race
The Federal Reserve and the Administration are like runners in a very odd race -- the two have different finish lines. The Fed, in a marathon, keeps its eye in the distance; when it raised short-term rates last week -- the third time this year -- it was reacting not to any inflation erupting with the daffodils, but to the far-off threat that if things are too good, inflation will follow. But politicians run sprint after sprint -- dashing to an election, easing up, dashing to the next. And they know voters are even more shortsighted, voting that week's pocketbook. So the White House is watching nervously as the Fed measures its pace, worried that short-term ripples from central bank moves could upset this fall's elections.
 
Stocks on a Seesaw
At first last week, the stock market had its usual knee-jerk reaction, with the Dow industrials plunging 41 points on Monday, the day the Fed rate rise was announced, and 21 more on Wednesday. But on Thursday investors had a change of heart and stampeded back in, sending the Dow soaring 53 and pushing bond rates down. It didn't hurt, of course, that that was the day I.B.M. had its rosy news.
 
The Greening of the G.D.P.
The gross domestic product supposedly tells us how we're doing -- in an economic sense, at any rate. But critics have long seen a flaw in the figures. Look at it this way: If a farmer plants unwisely, depleting the soil's riches, the farm's output may be high for a while, but long-term damage is ignored. Similarly, G.D.P. data measure only the nation's output, not factoring in whether we're damaging the "farm" at the heart of that output -- the environment. So for some time the Commerce Department has planned to come up with an alternate G.D.P. number -- not a replacement for the usual number -- that includes the impact of things like air pollution and lost trees. Last week it said it would soon release its first such "green" accounting.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
A World Out of Balance
The industrialized world is badly out of balance, and Washington can't seem to do anything about it. While the American economy speeds ahead, Western Europe and Japan can't, or won't, do what it takes to shake off recession, even though the White House is exerting what pressure it can for cuts in taxes or interest rates. So with rich America gleefully buying the world's goods, and with its trading partners unable to return the favor, the trade deficit is taking off. In February, it hit $9.7 billion, its worst level in six years, the Commerce Department said last week.
 
A Middle Ground on China
Our relations with China have been heading toward an all-or-nothing showdown on June 3. That's when the Administration is threatening to revoke China's favorable trade status if China doesn't get its human-rights house in order. But it now appears there can be shades of gray. Democratic lawmakers who want to be tough on China are working with the White House on a compromise -- some trade in return for some progress on rights abuses.
 
A Vote for Russian Stability
Possibly, just possibly, Russia's leaders are moving the economy toward stability. After throwing money at industry and agriculture last year to keep them alive, the central bank has tightened the purse strings. The result: inflation, which last year hit a monthly average of roughly 20 percent, is creeping down. In March it was 8.7 percent -- still scarily high for a monthly figure, but the lowest number since market reforms began in January 1992. No doubt in recognition of this progress, last week the I.M.F. granted Russia a long-delayed $1.5 billion loan.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2161 words

HEADLINE: New Third World Fear: Investors Could Walk Away

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THE international debt crisis is finally over. Well, maybe.
A week ago, the world's biggest banks quietly agreed to restructure the last big chunk of commercial debt in Brazil, effectively marking the end of the 12-year-old lending crisis in Latin America. 
 But the deal underscored another quiet change that has been rippling through the credit and equity markets of Latin America and much of the rest of the developing world: the banks have been superseded as the primary source of foreign capital by such new private investors as pension and mutual funds and investment firms. It is a change that brings its own risks and the potential for new crises down the road, or just around the corner.
Seeking diversification and higher returns, the new players have funneled billions into what have come to be called emerging markets. For many of these markets, the flood of new money is proof that the painful economic adjustments undertaken during the debt crisis, at the behest of the banks and international lending organizations, have paid off.
But not so fast, many international economists and lending experts say. The new lenders bring something besides money with them: the potential for great volatility. Unlike the banks, whose billions were tied up in long-term loans, most of the new investors are holding debt or equity securities that trade in the open market, and they will move on when it no longer pays to stay put, the experts say.
Making matters even more unsettled, many of those managing the new billions are relative novices in the developing world. Some newcomers have had unrealistically high expectations about the emerging markets -- including their stability and safety -- and have been intemperate in terms of the breadth and number of their investments.
The recent sharp selloff in emerging-market debt has acted like a cold shower for some of the new investors. The selloff was triggered by the rise in interest rates in the United States, which made foreign investments less attractive. It sent bond values tumbling 19 percent in the developing world in the first quarter, according to J. P. Morgan & Company's Emerging Market Bond Index.
To attract -- and hold onto -- the new money, borrowers increasingly will have to meet investor demands and compete with others who need the money just as badly. Earlier this year, for example, the Turkish Government was unable to pass muster with Western bond rating agencies and is still looking for a way to borrow $1 billion.
From now on, "the markets will begin to exert more discipline on these countries," said Lincoln Rathnam, director of emerging markets at Scudder, Stevens & Clark, an investment management company based in New York. "If people don't like a particular policy, they will react to it, and exert a rather severe penalty on local securities markets."
Still, despite the recent bond selloff, the faith of many investors in the developing world remains strong, in part because of structural reforms that have already been implemented. That faith was tested in Mexico recently with the peasant uprising in Chiapas and the assassination of the ruling party's presidential candidate. While investors were rattled -- as much as $8 billion has been pulled out of the country since the start of the year -- many are staying put and some even see buying opportunities.
"There has been huge conceptual progress," said Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, a former minister of mines in Peru who is now chief executive of Westfield Capital, a Miami-based investment firm that takes equity positions in Latin American companies. "But we still have a long way to go. And the debt is still high."
Indeed, while most of the debt problems left over from the 80's have been worked out, a lot of that debt remains to be serviced, about $500 billion in Latin America alone. Without strong economic growth, meeting interest payments will be a challenge.
And that could result in the supreme test of faith for the new investors. If some governments and private borrowers default on their bonds, as many experts think is inevitable, the developing world could wind up holding the bag. In the 80's, banks had little choice but to work out their problems, pumping in more money to keep their debtors afloat. But the new investors, who individually have much less at stake, may just decide to take their losses and go elsewhere.
LAST year, the major emerging market economies posted a net gain of about $180.8 billion in foreign capital investments, according to the Institute of International Finance, a Washington-based organization established in the 80's by big banks to monitor the debt crisis.
Nearly 74 percent, or $133.4 billion, came from institutions like pension funds, mutual funds and investment banks, which invested in the equity or bonds of private companies that were formed in the wake of the debt crisis. Commercial banks, by comparison, accounted for just $23.9 billion of the gain.
That is a sharp contrast from 1981, when the banks were responsible for 77 percent of the private money that flowed into these countries.
The problem, say some observers, is that many investment decisions made over the past few years were based more on a declining interest rate trend in the industrialized world than on well-reasoned assessments of the countries and their companies.
"In the last decade there have been three markets" for the developing countries, said John F. McGillicuddy, former chairman and chief executive of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and later the Chemical Banking Corporation. "One in which they begged, one in which they were ordered and the third in which the floodgates opened. None of them are realistic."
Charles Dallara, managing director of the Institute of International Finance, added, "You could argue that the markets last year were more generous to these countries than the banks ever were."
New money "went to countries that were performing and to others that were not performing," said Mr. Dallara, who was Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs from 1989 to 1991.
At a recent conference, Mr. Dallara said the surge of indiscriminate investments ran the risk "of inducing complacency among policy makers."
But now the risk is that some unforeseen financial failure will turn the spigot off as abruptly as it was turned on.
That could be a big shock, given how much investments have grown over such a short period of time, and how much more they might still grow. Mutual fund holdings in emerging markets went from less than $1 billion in 1986 to about $45 billion at the end of last year, according to the Institute of International Finance. But that still only represents about 1 percent of their total portfolios. Potentially, "the upside of that number is around 20 percent," said Manuel Mejia, a managing director at Merrill Lynch.
For now, "the fact is these markets are still very thin," said Shafiqul Islam, a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics, a Washington-based think tank. "If you don't take some cautionary steps to reduce volatility, to reduce the risk of panic, then you could get repetitions of the past. Markets could be vigilant and keep governments under control in terms of fiscal and monetary policies. But they could overreact as well, and cause problems by overreacting."
An example of that overreaction took place in February, some bankers with years of foreign experience argue, when prices of debt securities in the emerging markets tumbled after the Federal Reserve Board began to push up short-term rates in the United States. That reaction came as a surprise to the bankers because conditions in the developing countries remain fundamentally positive.
At the same time, the bankers noted that without the structural changes that have been made in Mexico, the bond market turmoil -- coupled with that country's recent political upheavals -- would probably have provoked a financial crisis.
"Without the reform process that is in place in Mexico, and without Nafta, you could well have seen an outflow of capital like we saw in 1982," said William R. Rhodes, vice chairman at Citibank and a key negotiator with Latin America's three largest debtor nations over the past 12 years. The debt crisis began in August 1982, when Mexico said it was unable to make payments on its foreign loans.
Recent events, Mr. Rhodes said, have "stress-tested the system," but he emphasized that investors have to know "the country, the industry you are investing in."
The progress Mexico has made in opening up and privatizing its economy clearly played an important role in calming investor fears. But televised conferences between Mexican officials and money managers also helped. Twelve years ago, that level of communication was unheard of.
"The explosion of information is the biggest change that has happened" since the debt crisis started, said Angel Guerria Trevino, director of international affairs for Mexico's ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party and until recently director of Nacional Financera, the country's development bank. "The market demands a lot of information, and we are providing it. We are very transparent now."
Still, among developing countries, the movement toward investor-friendly transparency will likely be uneven. As a consequence, there will almost certainly be bumps, perhaps big bumps, along the way.
In a recent telephone conference on Latin America, David Beers, a director in the international sovereign ratings department at Standard & Poor's, calmly told clients to expect bad news in coming years.
"It appears likely there will be bond defaults over the next three to four years in this sector of the market," Mr. Beers said. "This is a phenomenon that investors have not had to grapple with since the 1930's."
THE bumpy road is a two-way street, however, as the new investors have already demonstrated to one would-be borrower.
In an attempt to capitalize on what at that point was still a healthy market, the Turkish Government tried to float a $1 billion bond issue earlier this year through Salomon Brothers and Merrill Lynch.
The effort fizzled after ratings agencies took a look at the country's rapidly rising budget deficit and poor inflation prospects and lowered their ratings on the bonds to below investment grade. "We went to the Turkish Government and said we can't do the deal at the price you wanted," one investment banker said. "And they didn't want to pay up to the point the market was demanding to get the transaction done."
The financing is still on the shelf, and Turkey is negotiating with the International Monetary Fund for a standby credit agreement.
"As all of these countries turn more to the public debt markets for financing, the issue of capital flows and access to capital markets becomes a much more important part of the credit equation," said Hendrick J. Kranenburg, executive managing director for international finance at Standard & Poor's. "And the ability of these countries to withstand periods of capital outflow, as well as inflow, becomes a very critical part of our analysis."
Policy makers in developing countries have their work cut out for them, Mr. Dallara of the Institute of International Finance said. Not only must they upgrade information for investors, he said, but they must also be consistent in their policies.
"If you deviate from sound policy over time, your access to a certain market will close up again," Mr. Dallara said.
 
 
 
A DIFFERENT ROLE FOR BANKS
 EVEN though banks were badly burned by the debt crisis -- various restructuring agreements pared more than $90 billion from the face value of their loans to developing countries since 1985, according to the Institute for International Finance -- they will continue to play a role in the world's emerging markets. But it will be a far different role than in the past.
"The banks are going to look, very selectively, at short-term trade financing," said Roland Wojewodski, a managing director in charge of corporate finance activities in Latin America for J. P. Morgan & Company. "But we are not going to see the big flows of money from commercial banks, as we did in the 1970's."
An example of the type of lending Mr. Wojewodski sees banks participating in is a $1.1 billion short-term loan for Pemex, Mexico's state-owned oil company.
The Pemex loan is the first big voluntary bank financing to the Mexican Government or any of its entities in more than a decade. Syndicate managers for the loan -- Morgan, Bank America and the Industrial Bank of Japan -- have received lending commitments in excess of the amount to be borrowed.
"Pemex is a good example," Mr. Wojewodski said. "But that is Pemex, a name that is very important in Latin America. It would be a mistake to think we would be able to do that for a lot of other companies in Latin America."

HEADLINE: At Work;
In Praise of Executive Coaching

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble 

 BODY:
WILLIAM P. MILO always thought he did a pretty good job of stroking and motivating his "direct reports," so it came as a surprise when some of his managers at the Phico Insurance Company, a large health insurer in Mechanicsburg, Pa., let Mr. Milo know they felt unappreciated. Well, not exactly unappreciated. "Through further analysis, we discovered they felt praised," said Mr. Milo, the senior vice president for administration and planning for Phico. "But when someone does a super job, they feel they aren't treated differently."
Mr. Milo learned of his very reparable flaw while he was scouting and testing leadership development programs for Phico, in search of solutions to problems posed by changes in the economy and the nature of his business. His is an industry in turmoil, both from the corporate desire for more efficiency and the country's desire for health care reform. "Re-engineering's hit us," he said. "We need to be much more flexible, more customer-focused. We need to get people to be more creative." 
 Among the programs he tried was an executive coaching seminar put on by the insurance practice of the Hay Group, the big consulting firm in New York. For three days last fall he was assessed, interviewed, benchmarked and mentored. He listened to feedback gathered before the seminar from colleagues, subordinates and supervisors and soaked it up from his co-participants. He learned that consultants had a word or phrase for every style of work, management, personality, learning or ability.
He came away, he says, understanding better what the "core competencies" -- the crucial skills -- of a leader are, how to match them with Phico's strategic goals and how to encourage his people to acquire them. The course may have helped him understand himself better. "It gives you an idea of what your motives are, whether for achievement or power or affiliation," he said. "It gives you a look inside at what drives you."
Coaching -- as executive development has come to be called -- is not new. But corporate shrinkage and the dawning era of flexible, decentralized management are making obsolete the idea that executives can expect to muscle their way to a career pinnacle and then coast until retirement. Increasingly, they are expected to be, in the words of the anthropologist Harvey Sarles, "auto-didacts," or self-teachers and lifelong learners, whose performance will evolve and improve.
But it is not so easy to push senior managers into what is essentially a training mode. "We think it's O.K. for first-line supervisors to get training, but not for higher ups," said Martin Leshner, managing director for the Hay Group and head of its insurance practice. When they think of improving their performance, most employees focus on gaining more technical skills, precisely what they don't need, in Mr. Leshner's view, especially if they are moving up the hierarchy. "Mostly, people need the ability to influence people. The way organizations operate these days, you are interacting with people who don't work for you. You can't just make them do something," he said.
Younger employees, in particular, are not receptive to the send-'em-to-the-principal school of management. "They aren't chain of command-oriented," said Steven E. Lurie, head of Lurie Executive Development, a coaching firm based in Valley Stream, L.I.
If learning to use influence rather than raw aggression is a frequent proximate cause for calling in a coach, failing to make the mental leap from technician to leader is another. One of Mr. Lurie's recent success stories, as he described it, was a manager in a small organization who had recently taken over the leadership of a team, and soon found himself at the center of struggle and tension. "There was a lot of internal competition," Mr. Lurie said. "He couldn't get straight answers or information from people, even though he was very open and available -- the opposite of the previous boss."
THE problem turned out to be that he thought his job was to tell his "direct reports" how to do their jobs. His employees felt insulted and devalued. "They were professionals who needed to be left alone," Mr. Lurie said. The boss was panicked because he didn't know how to prove his effectiveness without measurable results, like sales figures, to show. "That's pretty typical of business men and women I deal with," Mr. Lurie said. "They get rewarded for very tangible accomplishments. Leadership is habitually referred to as the soft stuff." The executive's developmental leap, as Mr. Lurie called it, was to be willing to trade his tangibles for "just" being a leader.
Feedback played an important role in helping the executive modify his style. His employees noted his ability to bring them together as a team, to keep the unit visible at the corporate level and to garner good community relationships.
For Phico's Mr. Milo, who has brought the Hay Group's program in-house so that all Phico managers may go through it, what he learned about feedback of all sorts may be the most valuable lessons of the seminar. He has already instituted more recognition programs so superachievement is acknowledged. And the strategic core competencies -- the ability to influence, for example -- rather than technical ability may become the basis of performance reviews. "The biggest skill sets are coaching, counseling, giving and getting feedback and giving recognition," Mr. Milo said, adding, "We're looking for managers to understand the impact they have on people."
 
 
 
WHAT COACHING CAN'T ACCOMPLISH
IT is not impossible to coach a person's career back to life, but most executive development experts say companies should not regard coaching as the last chance for the employee to avoid being cashiered. "Sometimes it's hard to ascertain the true motives of a company," said Martin Leshner, a development expert at the Hay Group. "I ask them not to send people they have trouble with. It's an especially bad idea if the person goes and doesn't do well." The message to other employees can be that coaching means their careers are on the line.
Steven Lurie, head of his own executive development firm, frequently sees valued employees who are stalled for one reason or another, but he too is leery of taking on lost causes. "If the person has no real future, but the company feels bad about not giving him feedback for 20 years, then it's a nonintervention," he said. "If you want a 9 and he's a 3, it probably doesn't make sense."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Faring Well in Good Times and Bad

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
TO Brian C. Rogers, manager of the T. Rowe Price Equity-Income Fund, the recent rout was welcome: prices have retreated so far that he sees value in the stock market for the first time in two years.
With prices down, yields are up and that is all-important to this fund, which relies on high-dividend-paying stocks plus a small chunk of bonds. The fund's yield, now 3.9 percent, hasheldit up in down markets. Price Equity-Income has the distinction of being a fund that has stayed the course in good times and bad. 
 Price Equity-Income returned 12.4 percent a year, on average, for the five years ended March 31, according to Morningstar Inc., Chicago-based fund researchers. That compares with a 10.6 percent gain for its peers.
But more compelling is the fund's performance in market slides. In a study by Morningstar of the 454 diversified domestic equity funds in four months in which the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell more than 5 percent (October and November 1987 and January and August 1990), Price Equity-Income had the fifth-smallest loss among all the funds, at 28.9 percent. Over all, equity-income funds lost 34.3 percent on average in those months, while growth funds lost 44.6 percent. In this year's tough first quarter, the fund fell 2.8 percent, compared with an average of 3.8 percent for the group.
In mid-March, Mr. Rogers began buying stocks, trimming the fund's cash position to 10 percent from 15 percent. "The severity of the declines has created a lot of opportunity," he says.
His recent purchases have been concentrated in three sectors. First is financial services companies "because the sector has been weak as interest rates have risen." His favorites include Travelers because of its recent merger with Primerica; Mellon Bank, which is negotiating to buy the Dreyfus Corporation, a mutual fund sponsor, and National City in Cleveland, which Mr. Rogers calls an unusual shareholder-oriented bank.
Mr. Rogers also sees value among pharmaceutical companies, whose prices have been under severe pressure because of the Administration's health care plans. He says the trend toward noninvasive surgery should benefit the group, and he likes three companies that he says have "bulletproof balance sheets": American Cyanamid, which recently spun off Cytec, its specialty chemical business, and acquired a stake in Immunex, a biotechnology firm; Schering-Plough, and American Home Products, which has a big business in over-the-counter drugs, including Advil and Dimetapp.
Mr. Rogers has also been buying utilities, one of the first quarter's hardest-hit sectors, whose losses he attributes to the bond market's dive. Prices have dropped so much that yields have risen to the 6 1/2 to 7 percent range, but he cautions that utilities probably are a short-term opportunity only, perhaps through this year. His high weighting in utilities (10.3 percent), he says, is unusual for the fund. Among the utilities he likes are Pacificorp in Portland, Ore.; Florida Progress in St. Petersberg, and Baltimore Gas and Electric.
The fund is well-diversified, holding roughly 110 stocks with exposure to most sectors of the market. And when Mr. Rogers buys a stock, he generally holds on; turnover averages just 24 to 35 percent a year, compared with a group average of 61 percent.
So it's not surprising that he says one of the most important lessons he has learned about managing money is to be patient. "I see a lot of mutual fund cash-flow figures," he says, "and I think that too many investors have inappropriate time horizons."
About 80 percent of the fund is currently invested in stocks, with 10 percent each in convertible securities or bonds and in cash, a usual mix for the fund.
Mr. Rogers takes a cool approach to the stock market. "I've never been a raging bull or doom-and-gloomer," he says. "I try to ferret out interesting situations and hope that the market recognizes them."
He looks for companies that sell at no more than 10 times earnings and have good capital structures for their industries. Simply being cheap isn't good enough; the fundamentals must be strong. "The lesson provided by I.B.M. is a good one," he says.
To build yield, Mr. Rogers looks for companies with unusually high yields relative to how the stock usually trades, aiming for an average of 4.5 percent. His overall target is a yield 25 percent above the average for the S.& P. stocks, now roughly 2.8 percent.
Mr. Rogers also has a strict sell guideline: when relative yield drops, out goes the stock. In the first quarter, he sold Ford Motor, John Deere and Scott Paper -- "three cyclicals whose stock had done quite well, so as their prices rose, their yields fell relative to the S.& P. as well as to the company's own yield histories," he said.
Right now, the fund is 5 percent invested in junk bonds, the maximum permitted by its charter. Mr. Rogers sees the investments as "interesting corporate situations" and views them as "good bets versus the equity markets." Among them are CalFed, a California savings and loan that yields 10 1/2 percent, and Coltec, an aerospace equipment maker with a strong cash position and a 10 percent yield.
As for overseas holdings -- now 8 percent -- the fund generally sticks to the A.D.R.'s of big companies with worldwide operations, like British Petroleum, Royal Dutch/Shell and British Telecom.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Japan's Political Soup Is Gaining Some Clarity

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Viewed from Washington, Japan's Prime Minister-designate, Tsutomu Hata, who is scheduled to take office tomorrow, has plenty of crises on his hands: a $60 billion trade surplus with America, North Korean neighbors with a penchant for nuclear weapons and an economic reform program that has drifted to a halt.
Seen from Tokyo, though, Mr. Hata's coalition faces a far more urgent problem: office space. Over the last two weeks, as Japan's second political Big Bang in a year blew apart existing parties, so many new political groupings formed that Parliament ran out of rooms to accommodate all of them. By latest count, there were 12 parties or parliamentary groups in the lower house, the highest number since 1948. 
 But the space squeeze is likely to be temporary. For last week the new shape of Japanese politics seemed to be emerging, even amid the chaotic political jockeying attending the selection of Mr. Hata; he replaces Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa -- the reformer forced to resign April 8 in a financial scandal of his own only nine months after ousting the long-ruling and corruption-tarred Liberal Democratic Party.
 
Let's Be Normal
 In the emerging new order, it looks like conservatives of various hues will be in and the old left wing out. And the force to be reckoned with is Ichiro Ozawa, the shadowy but brilliant strategist who with Mr. Hata runs the Shinseito (Japan Renewal) party.
Mr. Ozawa may be disliked by many for his previous role as shadow shogun of the Liberal Democrats, but he has enunciated a clear vision of where he wants the country to go. It is to become a "normal nation," with normal consumer prices, politicians who call the shots over bureaucrats, a willingness to engage in diplomacy and -- the catch for many -- a military that can join in international peacekeeping.
Mr. Ozawa is out to destroy the Liberal Democrats, or what's left of the party after he and Mr. Hata led a revolt last summer. And he is out to split the Socialists, now his coalition partners of convenience, who are apoplectic about his "normal nation" ideologically but willing to swallow some of it to stay in power.
By the time the arguing over Mr. Hosokawa's successor had died down, Mr. Ozawa had already inflicted another wound on the Liberal Democrats, luring about 5 percent of their more than 200 members to defect. He intends to eventually pull more L.D.P. fragments into his orbit, strengthening the coalition enough to throw out the Socialists. They, too, are breaking up -- a few to join Mr. Ozawa, a few to join the Communist party, and 50 or so middle-of-the-roaders desperately looking for a place in the new political constellation. Most guess that they will form something of a Liberal party, with the left wing of the old Liberal Democrats. Eventually, that may create three parties that can vie for power.
Would this new order make much difference outside Japan? Maybe, especially if one of the parties begins to explicitly appeal to consumer interests, or to debate a change in security policy. But it will take time. Meantime there's good news: With the recession on, there are a lot of empty offices downtown, just a five-minute -- and $10 -- cab ride to Parliament.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Sunset for the Oil Boom And Alaska's Life Style

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE

 BODY:
Living off the lard of North America's largest oil field, the state of Alaska has created a modern superstate unlike anything the world has ever seen -- a sort of boreal welfare society in which people are paid to live and are given a monthly bonus if they make it past the age of 65.
Alaskans pay no state income or sales taxes. Home mortgages, even for mobile homes, have long been subsidized. High schools inside the Arctic Circle have Olympic-sized swimming pools. Some of the most remote bush communities have spanking new roads-to-nowhere, and there seems to be a satellite dish next to the moose antlers in every other home. 
 Oil transformed a largely backward state. It brought flush toilets to bush villages and college scholarships to Eskimo youths. On top of all that, the state has spectacular scenery, which is at its most wondrous in the midnight twilight of late spring.
But now, with depressed oil prices and a declining supply of North Slope crude, the free ride in the Last Frontier state is nearing an end. On paper, the government of Alaska is nearly broke -- facing a huge deficit caused by flat oil prices and a diminishing flow from the mother lode of Prudhoe Bay.
Empire builders without a blank check, Alaskans are being forced to go through the same shrinking of the frontier expansion dream that the rest of the country went through a century ago. But a state that still allows homesteading and lets residents kill up to four bears a year does not seem ready to accept an unbridled tomorrow.
While boasting of their independence, Alaskans have been spending nearly four times as much, per capita, on government as the average American state. During the 1980's, a decade of minimum restraint, the state went through more than $35 billion, building among other things a barley terminal that has yet to hold a kernel of Alaskan-grown grain and a performing-arts center that is in perennial financial trouble.
Alaskan politicians, most of them Republicans, are talking about establishing an income tax, or -- a prospect even more dreaded -- capping the dividend check that every man, woman and child in Alaska receives annually, averaging about $1,000 a person.
Beyond the immediate financial woes faced by a bewildered state legislature and Gov. Walter J. Hickel is the long-term problem of how to maintain the good life and the foundations of the superstate. All the new schools, roads, community centers, the six-figure salaries for policemen in the bush country, require a flow of income that Alaskans may not be willing to pay.
In contrast to the Jack London sourdoughs who are the mythic basis of the state's self-image, many Alaskans have never known anything but a tax-free state with high wages and endless perks. They are loath to change. Last week, for example, Anchorage voters defeated a proposal to levy a small tax on alcohol to pay for civic improvements.
"The great majority of Alaskans today are spoiled and pampered citizens accustomed to receiving more money from government than they pay to support it," wrote John Strohmeyer in his new book on Alaska, "Extreme Conditions," published by Simon & Schuster. Mr. Strohmeyer noted that one in five employees in Alaska is on a government payroll.
Even the harshest critics of Alaska's spending binge praise the state for having the foresight to create the Permanent Fund, a state savings account made up of oil royalties that is now at about $15 billion. State government cannot get at the fund without a vote of the people to amend the Constitution. A portion of its earnings are paid out in the annual dividend checks -- a windfall so dear to most Alaskans that the stores all peg their biggest sales to it.
"If they ever tried to stop the dividend checks, people would rise up in arms," said Thomas A. Morehouse, a professor at the Institute of Social and Economic Research at the University of Alaska Anchorage. "The Permanent Fund stands out as the main achievement of the oil era."
Royalties from oil pay for 85 percent of Alaska's budget. This year's $3.2 billion budget was predicated on oil selling for about $18 a barrel, and every dollar below that figure amounts to a budget deficit of $150 million. Oil has been selling for about $14 a barrel.
 
Deficit and Debt
 In addition to the Permanent Fund, the state maintains a reserve fund of about $2 billion. To cover last year's deficit, the state took nearly $1 billion from the reserve fund, a move since ruled illegal by a state court. So while saddled with a deficit of nearly $600 million, the state must also pay back what it took from the reserve fund.
Production is down too. The flow of oil from Prudhoe Bay through an 800-mile pipeline to the port of Valdez peaked at more than 2 million barrels a day in 1988. It is now down to 1.6 million a day, and will fall to under a million in six years. Geologists say most of the 10 billion barrels that can be recovered from Prudhoe Bay will be drained by the year 2015.
The only bright spots have been world disasters or Middle East wars. During the Persian Gulf conflict, prices rose briefly to $35 a barrel. Governor Hickel proposed a series of projects ranging from railroad tracks across the tundra, to a water pipeline to Southern California.
But the gulf conflict was short, and with the collapse in prices, the dreams of Governor Hickel, considered the last of the original "boomer" politicians from the days when Alaska was still a territory, have also collapsed. No one thinks that waiting for the world to consume more oil, or for oil-producing nations to go to war, will get the state government through the next few months.
Openly, at least, no one hopes for war. "You go to bed hoping that all those one billion Chinese will soon trade in their bicycles for mopeds," said Chuck Logsdon, the chief petroleum economist for the state.
Mr. Hickel proposed a tax on wages, which was hooted out of the Legislature. He has now renewed his call to let Alaska sell its oil to foreign buyers, where it will fetch a greater price. By Federal law, Alaskan crude must be used for American consumers.
Major sacrifice in the form of spending cuts now seems to be an impossible chore for a legislature that Mr. Strohmeyer called a "a frontier Tammany Hall."
Some steps have been taken. The longevity bonus, a $250 a month check to any Alaskan over the age of 65, will be phased out by the end of the 1990's. But going after entitlements of younger voters will be harder.
"The first politician to propose capping the dividend check is going to be out on the street," said Mr. Logsdon.
Tourism and fishing have grown rapidly in recent years, lessening the dependence on oil and inspiring a vision of state that does not look to a gold rush or an oil gusher to keep it flush.
But so much of Alaska has a half-finished look to it, particularly this time of year when the 16 hours of sunlight are melting away winter's cover to reveal the residue of last summer's pork barrel projects.
This year, the question of whether Alaskans are willing to start paying for some of what they have built will probably be up to the voters.
Representative Ron Larson, co-chairman of the House Finance Committee in Juneau, has introduced a bill that would let Alaskans vote on "our choice of evils," as he put it: an income tax, a sales tax or capping the dividend check.
"Alaska isn't poor," said Mr. Larson. "But when we were rich, we spent our money poorly. And now we've got to pay. So how will we do it? I have no idea, but strange things can happen under the midnight sun."

HEADLINE: GROWTH OF JOBS MAY BE CASUALTY IN INFLATION FIGHT

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
With the Federal Reserve pushing up interest rates, a disagreement has surfaced about whether the central bank might be trying unnecessarily to keep at least a million unemployed people out of jobs in the belief that this is required to hold down inflation.
Neither the Federal Reserve nor the Clinton Administration, which has endorsed the Fed's anti-inflation policies so far, would say they were in favor of bolstering unemployment. That would be damaging politically, and contrary to the job-creation goals of the Administration. 
 But with the economy growing strongly and the unemployment rate falling, the Federal Reserve has responded by raising interest rates three times since early February. Some economists argue that the Fed is overreacting to a decline in unemployment, asserting that falling joblessness has a much smaller inflationary impact than it did in the past.
"The Federal Reserve may be convinced that the inflation danger is closer than many of us in the economic profession think it is," said Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Mr. Solow argues that unemployment can fall to seven million people before a shortage of workers begins to push up the inflation rate. But Federal Reserve officials say the danger point is eight million, and as unemployment has fallen toward that level, they have acted.
The connection between inflation and jobs is one of the most debated and elusive concepts in economics. No economist questions that at some point, unemployment will fall so low that the nation will lack enough people to apply for all the jobs that corporate America wants to fill. When that happens, companies compete for workers, bidding up wages in the process. The rising wages become the backbone of rising inflation.
The higher rates are intended to discourage borrowing and spending. They force business activity, and the economy, to slow down. Fewer jobs are created and unemployment rises.
At what point does the pool of unemployed workers become too small to satisfy the demand for new employees? That level seems to change with the decades. In the 1990's, the mass layoffs, the corporate downsizings and the reluctance of many companies to hire even when business is good may have lowered the threshold below what it was in the 1980's.
"My conclusion is that a good national target -- one that does not accelerate inflation -- is an unemployment rate of around 5.5 percent, or seven million people," Mr. Solow said.
If Mr. Solow's view guided the Federal Reserve's policy, the central bank might not be raising interest rates. But his opinion, which represents an important sector in economics, does not prevail at the Fed.
The central bank, with the backing of an equally important group of economists, has acted on the view that unemployment can become inflationary as it falls below 6.2 percent of the labor force, or eight million people. About 8.5 million people are now jobless, for a 6.5 percent unemployment rate, down from nearly nine million a year earlier.
For a country as large and complex as the United States, eight million unemployed people, whatever their frustrations, are really not stuck without jobs, in the view of Allen H. Meltzer, an economist with Carnegie-Mellon Institute, who endorses the Fed's decision to raise interest rates. "They are really all people between jobs," Mr. Meltzer said.
 
Workers in Transition
 Some of the unemployed are in the process of leaving one company and seeking a job with another, he said. Or they are going through a period of retraining, have left the labor force temporarily to have children or go to school, or perhaps they are part-time workers who dropped out for a while. "We need this pool to meet the normal demands of the labor market," Mr. Meltzer said.
 Sharing that view, the Federal Reserve pushed up interest rates on Feb. 4, again on March 22 and a third time last Monday. The increases were the first changes in interest rates by the central bank since mid-1992. Fed officials have noted several reasons for their actions. Strong consumer spending, rising factory production and a boom in housing could all accelerate inflation, which has been a mild 3 percent a year.
But jobs have been an overriding consideration, and the Federal Reserve's policy makers made that point in the minutes of their meeting on Feb. 4, the day they voted for the first rate increase. The policy makers expressed concern, the minutes said, that "margins of slack in labor and product markets, already reduced to fairly modest levels, would shrink further."
 
 
Less Demand for Workers
 This concern that inflation will rise as unemployment falls reflects lessons learned in the 1970's and 1980's, when the inflation rate rose as unemployment dropped to just below the current level. But in the 1990's, mass layoffs, greater use of labor-saving computers, and the sweeping reorganizations of many corporations may have greatly reduced the demand for workers, altering the old relationship between unemployment and inflation.
Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist, says he thinks this is the case. More than half of the nation's unemployed are not just temporarily between jobs, he said, but people stuck in unemployment. They are the unskilled, the chronically poor, or the victims of layoffs and forced retirements, or factory workers, clerks and middle managers whose jobs were eliminated forever as companies became more efficient.
"There seems to have been a permanent shift toward a weaker bargaining position for labor," Mr. Gordon said. He estimated that unemployment might be able to fall below seven million people before there was such a shortage of job applicants that they could demand higher wages. Before that happened, he says, many of the people now stuck in unemployment could be pulled into jobs, without driving up wages and inflation.
The Administration, caught in this debate, has not challenged the Federal Reserve view that inflation can kick in when unemployment falls below eight million. Rather, the Administration says the issue is moot for the moment. Last week, for example, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen suggested that the Fed could raise rates by another notch or two without weakening the economy and thus fostering more unemployment. The next day, the Federal Reserve announced its third rate increase.
"A divergence between the Federal Reserve and the Administration would come if the Fed, by continuing to raise interest rates, actually slows down economic growth while unemployment is still above eight million people," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office.
 
 
Bad Memories of the 70's
 Mr. Reischauer said he shared the Federal Reserve's concern about the inflationary impact of falling unemployment. That concern is based particularly on the memory of the late 1970's. Then, as unemployment fell below 6 percent, the annual inflation rate shot above 13 percent. But since then, changes in corporate behavior may have altered the formula.
The Chrysler Corporation's approach to hiring illustrates this possibility. Chrysler is among a dozen or so big companies hiring today because the demand for their products is so strong. With employment set to rise to nearly 120,000, from 116,000 now, Chrysler plans to produce a record 3.5 million cars and trucks worldwide in 1996. That compares with 2.3 million in 1988, when employment was 130,000.
Labor-saving machinery permits the extra production with fewer workers. In addition, there has been hiring for third shifts and for the reopening of a plant in St. Louis. But what if demand for Chrysler vehicles surpasses 3.5 million? Will the company open more plants, or hire more people?
"No," said Wynn Van Bussman, a senior economist for Chrysler. "We don't want to go through the costly experience of cutting back again, when demand weakens. We have drawn a line at how far we will go in hiring and in adding factory capacity. If we can't satisfy demand -- well, there are plenty of auto makers around the world who can."

HEADLINE: Political Notes;
Nonpolitical Visit to Israel Is a Campaign Oxymoron

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

 BODY:
New Jersey's Assembly Speaker, Chuck Haytaian, a candidate for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, might still be millions of dollars shy of overtaking Senator Frank R. Lautenberg in fund raising. But for this week, at least, Mr. Haytaian is likely to surpass the Democratic incumbent in miles traveled.
Mr. Haytaian is to leave on Tuesday for an eight-day trip to Israel that he and his campaign staff say is a long-planned private visit. Even though no campaign aides are accompanying the candidate and no campaign money is being spent, Mr. Haytaian surely expects to squeeze political mileage out of his trip. 
 Mr. Lautenberg is Jewish and one of his political strengths is the state's bloc of Jewish votes.
Mr. Haytaian bristles at the notion that his trip to Israel is anything but a vacation. But accompanying the candidate and his wife, Joan, are four friends who know Israeli politics as well as New Jersey's.
The Haytaian entourage includes Sanford Hollander, a former state chairman of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith; David R. Kotok, a fund raiser for philanthropic and political causes who escorted Gov. Thomas H. Kean on a 1983 trip to Israel; Alan Steinberg, former policy adviser to the Assembly Republican majority and currently Assistant Commissioner for Economic Development, and Peter Sudler, a lawyer and real-estate developer.
 
Historic Mayoral Duet At Lincoln Center
 The scene: the men's room at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Manhattan on the opening night of the Lincoln Center Theater revival of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical "Carousel."
The cast: a bevy of theater types and a politician with a taste for the lyric arts.
"Did 'Carousel' come before or after 'Oklahoma!'?" one playgoer wondered, touching off a brief debate over the sequence of the Rodgers and Hammerstein canon. Then an authoritative voice broke over the room.
"No, 'Carousel' came after 'Oklahoma!' and before 'Allegro,' " said New York's No. 1 opera fan and Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani.
His Honor was correct. And Mr. Giuliani had John V. Lindsay, the former president of Lincoln Center Theater and the last Republican mayor of New York City before him, to vouch for him.
"I don't believe ever in the history of the Beaumont men's room have two mayors used it at the same time," said Bernard Gersten, executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater. "It's all for the greater glory of the theater."
 
Stomping on the Budget Dramatized on the Air
 Using a series of campaign-style advertisements, one of the city's municipal unions is beginning a pre-emptive strike against Mayor Giuliani's budget and his plans to reduce the work force by 15,000 over 15 months.
Officers of Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America said that three 30-second advertisements would begin on cable television and radio stations this week. The $100,000 campaign is expected to last through June, when the City Council traditionally votes on the Mayor's budget.
One television advertisement shows a large foot stomping on and crushing a miniature school and a miniature hospital, as a voice says, "With every service cut, New York becomes less attractive to new business and for every salary dollar cut, New York's economy loses $2.40."
Another begins with a computer printout of the city payroll, and snapshots of city workers with their families: "This is Rudy's list, 15,000 people who work for New York City. Some are your friends, neighbors, family. And if Rudy gets his way, they will all lose their jobs this year."
Asked about the ad campaign last week, Mr. Giuliani said that just a month ago the unions had supported his plan to use severance packages to lure 7,600 workers off the city payroll.

HEADLINE: New Bidding On Coliseum Is Weighed

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that reopening of the bidding process on the long-delayed New York Coliseum development project might be the best way to insure that development proceeds there.
In a letter to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Peter E. Stangl, chairman of the authority, which owns the property, said his optimism was fading that a renegotiated transaction with Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the developer of the project, could be achieved. 
 "Given the difficulties," Mr. Stangl said, "I have come to the conclusion that rebidding the site may be the best option for achieving our mutual objective of economic development."
A spokesman for the transit agency, John Cunningham, said Mr. Stangl's call to reopen the bidding on the site did not mean that the authority was inclined to relieve Mr. Zuckerman of his obligation either to come to an agreement over a renegotiated price or to relinquish his $33.8 million down payment.
 
City Is Disappointed
 Paul Crotty, the city's Corporation Counsel, was preparing a response to Mr. Stangl's letter but did say that the initial response was that the city was disappointed.
"We disagree with the M.T.A.," he said. "We think a deal can still be done."
Mr. Zuckerman, who owns The Daily News, has a contract to build a 2.1-million-square-foot mixed-use development on the Coliseum property, at 59th Street and Columbus Circle. But for more than a year, Mr. Zuckerman has been trying to renegotiate the agreement, seeking to build a smaller project at a price lower than the $338 million called for in the contract. If Mr. Zuckerman does not close on the deal, he stands to forfeit to the authority the $33.8 million down payment.
The authority and Mr. Zuckerman have agreed to a new purchase price of $100 million for half the site; included in the price is a $20 million city subsidy from annual tax payments generated by the project. The authority, the city and Mr. Zuckerman have been at odds over terms of a renegotiated transaction.
In a letter to the Mayor last week, Mr. Stangl said that while there were still matters to be settled, the parties were very close to striking a deal. But yesterday's letter said that despite the few issues that separated the authority and Mr. Zuckerman, they could not come to terms on a down payment in a renegotiated transaction.
The primary concern of Mr. Zuckerman and his associates, Mr. Stangl said, "is to minimize their down payment under the new transaction since we would keep this money were they unable or unwilling to proceed."
Mr. Stangl also said the negotiations had been complicated by the lawsuit that Mr. Zuckerman filed last month against the authority and the city, saying that the existing contract was not valid because they had failed to satisfy contract conditions.
Although he rejected a plan offered by City Hall last week to allow bidders an opportunity to top Mr. Zuckerman's bid if a new deal is struck, Mr. Stangl did agree to join the city in having an "analysis of the fairness of the project."
