HEADLINE: DuPont Adds $214 Million in Payments to Farmers Over Fungicide

BYLINE: New York Times Regional Newspapers 

 BODY:
Du Pont has agreed to pay $214 million to 220 farmers who said their crops had been ruined by a fungicide from the company.
The settlement, announced on Friday, eliminates nearly half the suits against Du Pont in connection with the fungicide, Benlate DF, which was recalled in 1991. Since that year, when the crop damage was first reported, Du Pont paid more than $500 million to farmers. 
 Du Pont said that it accepted no liability in the settlements and that Benlate was safe. The company, headquartered in Wilmington, Del., said it was cheaper to settle the cases than contest them in trials.
"Winning jury trials does not always justify the economic costs required to uphold the integrity of our product," said a senior vice president and special counsel, John F. Schmutz.
In addition to the suits settled on Friday, 70 others have been settled, dismissed by judges or reached trial.
The settlement was announced on Friday, four days after Florida officials said that they had proved that Benlate was contaminated with a potent weedkiller.
Agriculture Commissioner Bob Crawford, who faulted Benlate for $1 billion in crop losses in Florida, said on Friday: "This settlement will help a substantial number of growers to put their farming operations back in order. This is a responsible step. I urge Du Pont to settle the remaining cases and close the chapter on Benlate."
 
Dispute Over Damage
 Du Pont paid at least $510 million in damage claims to growers -- $400 million of that total in Florida -- after a recall in 1991. The company then announced in November 1992 that it was stopping all payments and that its research had proved that Benlate had not caused damages reported by 2,100 growers in 40 states.
That announcement prompted a flurry of suits against the company.
Mr. Crawford announced on Monday that his scientists had proved that Benlate was contaminated with a class of weedkillers, sulfonylureas, that kills plants in extremely low doses.
Du Pont, the leading manufacturer of the weedkillers, denied the state's contention that the fungicide was contaminaed and said Mr. Crawford's announcement had nothing to do with the settlement, which it said had been negotiated over months.
Farmers welcomed the announcement. "I'm terribly relieved," said Carol Murphy, a fern grower in DeLand who was among those who settled. "It's been a long road, and I'm just happy it's all over. I can get on with life."
The 220 growers involved are represented by Kevin Malone, a lawyer from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who won in two jury trials against Du Pont last year. Mr. Malone said 110 growers were from Florida, 25 from the Caribbean or Costa Rica and the rest from Hawaii.
 
Victory in Blueberry Case
 In the last year four juries in Florida and one in Arkansas have found Benlate responsible for crop losses, but the awards were generally smaller than the amounts that the farmers sought. The largest award was in Arkansas, where 30 vegetable farmers were awarded $10.65 million, of which $3 million was for punitive damages.
The lone court victory for Du Pont was in February, when a jury in Florida found the company not liable for $5.5 million in damages sought by a group of blueberry farmers in Lakeland.
The total of $476 million in after-tax costs beyond Du Pont's insurance coverage makes the Benlate case the most expensive pesticide recall. Mr. Schmutz, the Du Pont lawyer, said, "This is a sad commentary that once again illustrates just how badly this country's tort-law system is out of control."

HEADLINE: Japan Split Over Role in a North Korea Showdown

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 23

 BODY:
As Japan struggled to form a new government over the last two weeks, a long-brewing dispute broke out within its fragile governing coalition over an issue that has also seized the attention of the Clinton Administration: if sanctions are imposed on North Korea or a military confrontation develops with it, is Tokyo ready to side fully with the United States?
That question was at the top of Secretary of Defense William Perry's agenda when he met on Friday with Tsutomu Hata, who is expected to be formally approved as Japan's Prime Minister on Monday. Japanese and American officials provided little detail of the discussion, but Mr. Perry said after the meeting that he was certain "we would want and we would get full support" from Japan. 
 A number of American officials have privately expressed their doubts, however, saying the issue is so sensitive in Japan that it could bring down the fragile government.
The arguments over North Korea have quickly come to symbolize a much broader debate touched off by Japan's most powerful behind-the-scenes politician, Ichiro Ozawa, over whether Japan is ready to become a "normal nation." In Mr. Ozawa's definition, that would include a willingness to join the United Nations or the United States in peacekeeping and perhaps in assuring regional security.
 
Socialists Are Opposed
 The Socialists, the biggest party in the coalition, have opposed that initiative, calling it a breach of Japan's "peace Constitution," and have objected to any effort to cut off the flow of $600 million to $1.6 billion a year sent from Japan to North Korea.
Because of the extreme political delicacy of the issue, the Japanese Government has largely resisted quiet suggestions from the United States and South Korea that it use existing currency-control laws to limit the flow of funds to North Korea.
Most of the money, which accounts for a substantial percentage of the North's national economy, comes from the 300,000 Korean-Japanese living here who profess some loyalty to the North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung.
American intelligence officials believe that some of the cash ostensibly sent by the Korean-Japanese to aid relatives in North Korea is helping to finance North Korea's nuclear weapons project. But last week, just days before Mr. Perry's arrival, the Japanese police moved for the first time against a small company believed to have sent a bit more than $100,000 to North Korea without making required reports to the Japanese authorities.
The bigger concern for the United States is whether it could use its bases in Japan to enforce an embargo or launch military action against the North in case of hostilities on the Korean Peninsula. American military and diplomatic officials here have been sketching out such scenarios for months, though they have said little about it for fear of undermining Japan's fragile Government.
 
Law Restrict U.S. Actions
 Under existing Japanese laws and regulations, American military forces are prohibited from using Japanese aviation fuel, Japanese hospitals or Japanese ammunition in their operations from bases here.
Moreover, under the 34-year-old security treaty between the two countries, the United States would not be permitted to run continuous combat operations from their bases here, and might not be able to use them to enforce an economic embargo against North Korea, American military planners say. Japan's own navy would not be permitted to resupply American forces at sea.
In recent weeks, Japanese officials have gone to some lengths to offer private assurances that if the North Korean situation worsens, laws and rules will quickly be changed. But American and some Japanese officials fear that the changes could come too late and would be quickly enmeshed in a heated national debate over Article IX of Japan's Constitution, which has always been interpreted as banning such action by the military.
"They say they are with us," said a senior American official who has been deeply involved in the issue. "But I think all of us have our doubts, especially given the weakness of the current Government."
Military officials here note that since 1988 the United States and Japan have been negotiating a cross-servicing agreement that would allow for routine use of each other's supplies and installations -- similar to agreements the United States has in Malaysia, Thailand and South Korea -- but that it has run into political obstacles on both sides of the Pacific.
 
Politicians Are Quiet
 Except for Mr. Ozawa, who is the closest ally of Prime Minister-designate Hata, Japanese politicians have said almost nothing in public about the North Korean threat beyond making vague promises to act "within Japanese law" if the United Nations imposes sanctions.
But in the last week Mr. Ozawa has repeatedly complained that the country has no institution for crisis management -- a decades-long taboo on security issues here has prevented the formation of a national security council or a unified intelligence operation -- and has warned that the country must get legally and psychologically prepared for the possibility of a confrontation off its own coast.
"If it comes to a trade embargo and a maritime blockade, we can't do anything unless we are prepared to reform domestic law with emergency legislation," Mr. Ozawa said during a meeting last week with other coalition leaders.
His effort to get the coalition to agree to prepare such legislation failed. A lengthy and bitter argument with the Socialists concluded with a vaguely worded agreement to consult closely with the United States and South Korea and other Asian countries.
Mr. Ozawa's opponents and even the Asahi Shimbun, the country's most liberal daily, have accused him of using the North Korean crisis to expand the role of Japan's forces and bend the Japanese Constitution. Japan's 1960 security treaty with Washington was intended as a one-way document obligating the United States to come to Japan's military aid, not the other way around, they note.
If emergency measures are approved, the newspaper said in an editorial on Friday, Japanese military involvement "would become a permanent fixture every time American troops took action purportedly on the basis of the Japan-U.S. security treaty."
 
An Alarming Prospect
 Most of the Socialists have acknowledged that if the United Nations imposes sanctions, Japan will have to go along. But several have expressed alarm at the prospect that the United States may seek help from South Korea and Japan in imposing sanctions outside a United Nations framework if China or other countries block any action by the Security Council.
Mr. Perry raised that possibility for the first time after a speech in Tokyo on Friday, saying that if the United Nations was unable to act, "I think we would seek a way to impose multinational sanctions, even if it did not include every nation in the world."
Japanese Government officials say that would violate a longstanding ban on taking part in collective security arrangements. But privately their biggest concern is not standing out.
Some express fear that some in the Korean community here would incite acts of terrorism if there was an effort to stop the flow of funds. Foreign Ministry and security officials in Tokyo have been meeting regularly to track the activities of the Chosen Soren, the main North Korean organization in Japan.

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
Can't Be Sold Or Bought Or Bothered

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
IN June New Jersey's black voters will go to the polls for the first major election since Edward J. Rollins Jr. boasted they could be bought for the price of a preacher. Will they turn out in droves, in righteous torrents, churning the anger that Mr. Rollins provoked into a bold show of black political power?
"No," said Samuel Kelly, as he leaned against a building in South Trenton on a sunny Thursday morning. "I figure that done passed over." 
 Mr. Kelly is no political pundit, but he may be on to something. Outrage swelled in the state like a blister last November, when Mr. Rollins told a group of Washington reporters that he had orchestrated Christine Todd Whitman's victory in part by suppressing black voter turnout. Mr. Rollins quickly retracted, insisting he had not, in fact, made judicious payments to black ministers to keep any pro-Jim Florio ruminations to themselves. But that hardly quieted the furor.
News conferences and faxes abounded. Lawsuits were filed. Congregants and clergy, state legislators and national leaders all bristled with indignation at the suggestion that ministers and elections could be bought, and that New Jersey politicians were accustomed to buying.
And then the Rollins story blew over, and a Federal investigation found no evidence of such payments. So what, if anything, is the lasting impact of Hurricane Ed? Will voter registration swell? Too early to tell. Will legislators forge a new alliance with maligned black clergy members and tackle urban ills? Unknown. Have civic groups been galvanized? The state N.A.A.C.P. did announce plans for a voter registration drive, but canceled the news conference because of a snowstorm and never rescheduled it.
In a year in which Nelson Mandela will vote -- for the first time in his life -- half the black voting-age population of New Jersey will not.
At 66, Mr. Kelly said he was old enough to remember Jim Crow laws and to believe that all people, especially all black people, should vote. But he knows why some people say they cannot be bothered:
"They feel like why should they vote? They feel like whoever gets in, it's not going to help us. But they shouldn't feel that way."
Sonia Jarvis, executive director of the National Coalition on Black Voter Participation in Washington, said voting patterns flow not along racial lines, but economic ones.
"When you're struggling to survive, voting is not at the top of your list," she said. "That's just it."
People who own homes are likelier to vote than those who rent. People with college degrees are likelier than those without, and people over age 35 likelier than those under 35. So, too, black people, who land more often on the dim side of those demographics than whites, tend to vote in lower percentages.
Ms. Jarvis said she wished that instead of proclaiming dismay, lawmakers and civic leaders had seized the Rollins moment for something concrete -- say, a voter registration drive or laying the groundwork for the Voter Registration Act of 1993, known as the "motor voter" law.
The new Federal law, which takes effect next January, will require states to let driver's license applications also serve as voter registration forms, and to put registration forms in libraries, welfare offices and other public places. Proponents estimate that as many as 50 million new voters will be added to the 136 million now registered. But much work remains to be done in putting the law into practice.
"That's the way to take it to the next level," Ms. Jarvis said. "Why not stand up and say New Jersey is going to get 100 percent behind this law?"
New Jersey lawmakers did do something concrete. Over the howls of Democrats and black leaders, the Republican legislative majority passed a law requiring that the volumes of street money that grease Election Day politics in New Jersey be handled by check instead of cash. The change will inhibit fraud, the Republicans said. But Ms. Jarvis predicts it will further chill black participation by thinning the ranks of the "get out the vote" foot soldiers in cities.
"For too many of our citizens without access to a bank account, check cashing is not automatic and costs money," she said.
This fall's United States Senate race may tell.
Meanwhile in this capital city, where decaying row houses stand within blocks of the gilded State House dome, the first black mayor seeks re-election against the white widow of a longtime and popular mayor. The race has drawn the attention of Irma Smith, 78, who passes most days at a senior center. Mrs. Smith said she had voted in every election she could remember. When asked which vote seemed most important, she could not recall.
"No one in particular," she said. "If it comes to a vote, I'm out there to vote. They're all important to me."

HEADLINE: Barriers to Immunization Peril Children, Experts Say

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Barriers to immunization are leaving millions of children needlessly at risk of measles, whooping cough, polio and other potentially serious diseases, a panel of experts has warned.
In a report made public on Tuesday, the panel, of the Institute of Medicine, said fewer than 70 percent of the country's 2-year-olds have all their recommended inoculations because of the failure of doctors, parents and health agencies to make sure children are protected. It said the barriers included factors besides the availability of vaccines and their costs. 
 "We know that underimmunized children are experiencing illnesses that could be avoided and that some may be suffering severe consequences, even death," Dr. Lorraine V. Klerman of the University of Alabama, chairman of the eight-member panel that wrote the report, said at a briefing here.
Children and their families are confronted with a variety of barriers that keep youngsters from getting the preventive care they need, she said. These include lack of access to health care, lack of insurance that covers vaccinations and outmoded practices at clinics and doctors' offices that make it difficult to keep children on schedule for the many inoculations they need in early life.
 
Praise for Clinton Program
 The report praised President Clinton's Childhood Immunization Initiative, for which Congress appropriated more than $800 million this year. The effort provides free vaccines to the uninsured and those on Medicaid and promotes education programs and efforts to improve the availability of inoculations. But the report added that "removing the financial barriers will not, by itself, achieve full immunization of preschool children."
In a Rose Garden ceremony on Wednesday intended to focus attention on the issue, the President said that the United States badly trails most of the world in immunizing children, Reuters reported.
Mr. Clinton noted that the problem is especially serious in some poor urban and rural areas, the news agency said, and called the illnesses resulting from this failure "a health disaster and a human tragedy."
The Institute of Medicine, part of the National Academy of Sciences, said in its report that data from the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show that vaccination problems involve not only the poor but also all racial, ethnic and economic groups. In 1992, for example, 75 percent of all 2-year-olds not immunized against measles were white, and 72 percent were in families with incomes at or above the poverty line.
 
Signal of Health Problems
 "A case of measles or diphtheria in a child is like the death of the miner's canary -- both signal problems in the environment," Dr. Klerman said. "The miner's canary dies because gases are present that might affect the miner. Cases of a vaccine-preventable disease signal problems in the health care environment."
More than 90 percent of the nation's babies begin their immunizations on schedule, the panel said, but return visits for subsequent inoculations fall off, indicating a need for programs to insure compliance.
 
Tracking Systems Urged
 The panel said more than 90 percent of the children in the United States are properly vaccinated before the age of 5 because it is required for school attendance. The report said states, which bear primary responsibility for public health programs, should mount similar campaigns to vaccinate younger children. It recommended that immunization records be tracked by computer to insure proper follow-up.
The report said doctors and clinics also have to do a better job of tracking the immunization status of children and reminding parents when their children need each inoculation in the series of 15 or so shots required from birth to 2 years of age.
The panel further urged that doctors re-examine such practices as giving vaccinations only on specially scheduled visits. These can be inconvenient and lead to missed opportunities for giving shots during other office visits, the panel said.
In addition, it said, health agencies need to establish programs that remove barriers to proper vaccination. One such program would be to keep clinics open at night and on weekends for working parents; another would be to reach cultural minorities about the importance of immunization.
 
Need for Parental Education
 The report said the Federal Government and the states should also consider cooperating with private health and advocacy groups to educate parents about the benefits, and occasional risks, of vaccination. In addition, it said immunization should be a part of any plan for overhauling the health care system.
The National Immunization Campaign, a private vaccination effort working with local coalitions in 16 cities to improve inoculation rates, endorsed the report and called for more grass-roots programs to get communities involved.
"We know that cost is not usually the primary barrier to immunization services," said Jennifer Perry of the Children's Action Network, a group supported by the entertainment industry and corporations that sponsors the campaign. "We think vaccine initiatives designed for and by groups in particular communities are some of the best ways to change people's awareness and behavior about immunization to improve child health."

HEADLINE: Sports, Money, Politics -- A special report.;
New Jersey's Sports Empire: New Fields, Hard Times

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
The Meadowlands sports complex, rising from swamps and garbage dumps 20 years ago, was a perfect antidote to New Jersey's image as a second-rate place with smelly air and dirty politics.
Out of a wasteland where legend said only discarded mercury and dead mobsters could be found, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority mined riches, attracting four professional sports franchises to its world-class arenas. 
But horse-racing revenues have tumbled, and the authority has gone from self-sufficiency to the public dole. It has grown, too, from a purveyor of entertainment in the Meadowlands to an ambitious developer of sports and tourism projects statewide, most with high political sponsorship.
 
A Familiar Theme
 The dependence on public subsidies has brought an increasing measure of politics, influencing the authority's hiring and shaping its policy. Its critics say the sports authority made a pact with the devil, serving Trenton's purposes in exchange for access to tax money, allowing politicians to pay for expensive projects without a public referendum.
Now, struggling under debt and the exploding competition in the entertainment and gambling industries, the authority has a fresh strategy to bolster its finances. Its theme is familiar: to grow yet again, this time into an entertainment empire that excites images of Disney by the turnpike.
A master plan for the Meadowlands to be announced this week will propose construction of several new attractions, officials say. It contemplates pouring as much as $900 million in private capital investment into the complex over the next eight years, a top authority official said. That figure is nearly twice the $471 million already invested there since construction began in 1974.
Details are not public, but officials say the options include a theme park, a baseball stadium, television studios, virtual reality theaters, hotel and office space, and an outdoor concert arena. The plans also include a rail link from Secaucus to the Meadowlands.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who has previously criticized the growth of the authority, suggested during her campaign selling some of its operations or bringing in private companies to run them. Nevertheless Michael Francis, a Whitman fund-raiser who is the new authority chairman, said the Governor agrees with the proposed expansion because it is not expected to require greater taxpayer subsidies. The state subsidy, $17 million this year, is expected to rise to $26 million next year.
Around the country public money supports sports franchises, with local tax breaks or publicly financed stadiums. But until recently the New Jersey sports authority was self-sufficient and part of the justification for expansion is to erase its growing dependence on tax money. Private companies would pay for building any new attractions, Mr. Francis said. The authority would run them and share the profits. He said the Meadowlands must be reinvigorated with family-oriented attractions to stay competitive in the fight for people's leisure time.
 
New Attractions
Additional Forms Of Entertainment
 It is a crowded field, with Las Vegas becoming a destination for family fun and proposals for a new Disney theme park in Virginia and a $1 billion Blockbuster Park on the edge of the Florida Everglades.
"Entertainment is the new buzzword in terms of economic engine," said James W. Hughes, the assistant dean of Rutgers University's School of Planning and Public Policy. But, he added, building a compelling entertainment center is difficult. "They have to invent something the market wants," he said. "That becomes very risky."
According to Mr. Francis, the authority is ready to take the plunge. "I think you're going to see a substantial expansion of the sports complex into other areas and into other ventures," he said. He declined to comment on the flirtation with the New York Yankees, but said he has talked with several baseball teams about moving to the Meadowlands. Ms. Whitman has said that she would not use taxpayer money to lure the Yankees.
State officials scoff at a recent proposal by a New Jersey financier, Robert Brennan, to buy the complex for $1 billion and bring riverboat gambling to the Meadowlands.
In the entertainment industry, Mr. Francis said, the planned expansion would make the authority "a major, major player in the country and the world."
 
Increasing Stature
A Special Aura, Tied to Politics
 In New Jersey, an expansion would increase the authority's political stature. The sports authority already has more than 3,000 full- and part-time employees operating a $200 million-a-year business. It pays among the best public salaries in New Jersey, beginning with the $175,000 annually to Robert E. Mulcahy, its president and chief executive officer. In addition to his salary, which is more than twice the governor's $85,000 annual pay, the authority provides him with a driver and membership at the famed Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, N.J.
Authority officials defend the salaries, saying the agency competes with high-paying private companies. But some people it hires serve as a reminder that the authority -- while independent by law -- is tied to the political structure that created it.
Fifteen authority officials make as much as Governor Whitman or more, including a former aide to her predecessor Jim Florio; a construction manager whose hiring, authority officials have said, was directed by Florio administration officials, and a former Democratic legislator, also hired while Mr. Florio was Governor.
 
Little Scrutiny
 Certainly Mr. Florio was not the first governor whose associates found jobs at the authority. Mr. Mulcahy was Democratic Gov. Brendan T. Byrne's chief of staff before he left to head the authority 14 years ago. And when Gov. Thomas H. Kean, a Republican, switched top aides at the State House, the authority hired his exiting chief of staff, Lewis B. Thurston.
As a candidate, Mrs. Whitman criticized political influence at the authority. But since she became Governor the authority has given legal contracts to companies with Republican ties.
The growth of the authority has faced little scrutiny by state officials. Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, chairman of the Assembly Appropriations Committee, said authorities often grow far from their original purposes, and he said his committee would closely examine any plans for the sports complex.
"In some ways, they are more powerful than the elected officials in the municipalities, the counties and the state offices," he said of public authorities. "They have legions of lawyers and spin-makers paving the way for their continued expansion."
 
'A Personality of Its Own'
 New Jersey's rich and powerful have doted on the Meadowlands complex for decades, and the authority carries a special aura. Mr. Mulcahy, who sometimes wears a blue blazer with a sports authority emblem on the breast pocket, is keeper of that legend.
"It's come to signify New Jersey," said Mr. Mulcahy, who is widely credited with the success of the complex. "Wherever you go in the country, if I tell people I'm president of the Meadowlands, they understand that."
Former Governor Byrne said the complex has helped to give the state "a personality of its own."
The authority has been good to the politicians, too. Mr. Byrne's name endures on the Brendan Byrne Arena, the indoor arena at the Meadowlands. The state aquarium in Camden, built by the authority with taxpayers' money, is named for Mr. Kean.
 
Refinancing
Legislative Help Comes at a Price
 But no question, the name the authority was most desperate to promote was New Jersey's.
The Jets and Giants are New York teams by name, but authority officials have prodded television sportscasters to remind viewers that they play in New Jersey. A medallion saying "New Jersey Meadowlands" was placed at midfield to guarantee New Jersey air time during televised games.
The arena is a total New Jersey experience. It opened in 1981 with a concert by Bruce Springsteen, the state's unofficial poet laureate. Now it is home to the New Jersey Nets basketball team and the New Jersey Devils hockey team. During timeouts at Nets games, the crowd is entertained by a group of blue-sequined dancers called the Jersey Girls.
The complex, which draws an average of 7.5 million spectators annually, is in the top rank of stadiums nationwide. It will be the site of seven World Cup soccer games this summer and the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Final Four basketball competition in 1996.
The activity is sometimes dizzying. On a recent Saturday afternoon, the Devils played a match in the indoor arena while racing fans at the track bet on televised races from around the country. Another crowd was browsing at an outdoor market in the complex parking lot.
As the hockey game ended, the arena crew had about three hours to assemble the parquet basketball court directly on the ice before the Nets' 7:30 P.M. tip-off. At the track that night, there was also a full card of harness races. The total draw for the day: about 50,000 people.
 
Racing Profits Decline
 "It has a lot of glamour and excitement," said Cary Edwards, the State Attorney General under Mr. Kean and once an authority board member. "You've got sports teams and stars."
But the glamour has lost a certain glint. The Meadowlands has been hit hard by the national decline in horse racing, the sport that initially made it such a financial success. From 1977 to 1985 the authority paid $60 million in excess revenues into the state treasury. But amid the rise of casinos in Atlantic City and the expansion of the state lottery, racing profits at the Meadowlands fell from nearly $50 million in 1977 to just over $14 million in 1992.
As its finances deteriorated, the authority appealed in 1991 to the state for help. It got more than it bargained for.
Authority officials sought aid in refinancing the authority's debt. And they left the State House with a commitment that state taxpayers would guarantee -- and helping to pay -- the authority's debt.
But Trenton extracted its price. The Legislature and the Governor's office transformed the authority into a vehicle for financing and developing politically palatable projects. To pay for the expansion, the authority's debt more than doubled. It leaped from $352 million in 1991 to more than $865 million in 1992 -- all backed by the state.
Using the authority undoubtedly reflected the confidence the state had in its ability to manage large projects. But it also freed the lawmakers to borrow money for the projects without a public referendum.
 
Avoiding Public Votes
 The sports authority legislation passed in December 1991 called for the authority to construct a $254 million convention center in Atlantic City, to undertake a $29 million renovation of the Rutgers University football stadium and build other sports arenas there and oversee a $5 million fund for sports projects at colleges around the state.
"The Legislature would never have approved it if there weren't these sweeteners," said Mr. Frelinghuysen, the Assembly appropriations chairman, who opposed the measure. "In fact, they were so sweet that most legislators couldn't resist them."
Despite the economic development benefits of the projects, the decision to circumvent a public referendum drew sharp criticism.
"It all boils down to this: Who makes the decisions -- the politicians and the special interest groups, or people who end up paying the bills?" said Lucille Tyson, a Republican committeewoman in Piscataway, the site of the Rutgers Stadium. "In this case the answer is clear."
The sports authority has the perfect Jersey pedigree. Conceived in the administration of William T. Cahill, which was marred by corruption, it sprung up on land bounded by the notorious turnpike and mercury-contaminated swamps on the moonscape dividing the state's rusting industrial husks from its suburban promises.
 
Building an Image
 The growth of the complex was part of an attempt by New Jersey's leaders to liberate the state from New York's shadow and from its own sour image.
When New Jersey's first tried to sell bonds for the complex in 1973, it failed. The New York establishment, led by Nelson A. Rockefeller as Governor and David Rockefeller as chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, persuaded Wall Street not to buy the bonds, for fear that sports teams and revenues would flow west across the river.
New Jersey's financial institutions eventually stepped forward to buy the paper, after Mr. Byrne, then Governor, pledged the state's moral obligation to back the debt.
Now as the authority plans its next expansion, the talk of a theme park and other attractions rankles some of the complex's protective parents.
"You put in a roller coaster and this and that, and pretty soon it's Coney Island rather than a dignified sports complex," Mr. Byrne allowed. "It exudes class, and we'd like to keep it that way."

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
To First Fan's Delight, Deluge of Long Balls Has Yet to Slow Down

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The remarkable increase in home runs and runs scored this season has received the White House stamp of approval.
During a Rose Garden ceremony last week, President Clinton let some baseball people know he enjoyed the early-season deluge. 
 "When Len Coleman and I were introduced to him, he started talking about how he likes the hitting that's going on this year," Tony Bernazard, a former major league player and a Players Association official, related. "He liked that part of the game. He was very interested in the game the previous day between Boston and Oakland, where Mo Vaughn and Tim Naehring went back-to-back back-to-back. He was very excited about that. I was delighted to hear that the President keeps up with baseball and especially that he likes hitting so much because I like hitting myself."
For the Clintons, and the Bernazards, happily, there was no letup in the past week. The Red Sox feat Bernazard referred to was one of the week's hitting highlights and punctuated the most intriguing development within the multitude of home runs that players are hitting.
Vaughn and Naehring hit successive home runs twice in the same game, giving them a unique place on the mushrooming list of players who have hit at least two home runs in one game. On the first five days of the past week, at least two players a day each hit a pair, if not more (Tim Raines and Cory Snyder each hit a pair and a half.)
 
38 Multi-Homer Games
 Jeff Kent of the Mets, Andres Galarraga of Colorado, Raines and Eduardo Perez of California each performed the feat a second time. When Friday's games had been completed, players had amassed 38 multiple-homer games compared with 20 during the corresponding period last season and 19 in 1987, the major leagues' record home run season.
Players, entering yesterday's games, had hit a total of 497 home runs, or 2.26 a game, compared with 344, or 1.60 a game, at this time last year and 426, or 1.93 a game, in 1987. This season's production is up 44.5 percent from a year ago and 16.7 percent from 1987.
Runs? The total of 2,296, or 10.44 a game, marks a 19.1 percent increase over last year's 1,928, or 8.97 a game, and 15.6 percent over the 1987 total for the corresponding number of games, 1,987, or 8.99 a game.
The averages for the past week slipped slightly from the figures a week ago, but not enough for President Clinton to lose interest.
 
Whose Homerdome Is This?
 Some people say the ball is livelier, some say not. The Minnesota Twins evidently are playing with both balls.
When the Twins are in the field, the umpires must use the livelier version because Twins' pitchers have given up 33 home runs, by far the most in the major leagues. When Twins are batting, the umpires apparently substitute the old balls because Twins' batters have hit only eight home runs, fewest by far in the American League.
Scott Leius leads the team with two home runs; six other players have hit one each. One of those six is Dave Winfield, who hit his on opening day. It is believed to be the only home run ever hit by a 42-year-old member of the Twins whose wife (Tonya) is expecting twins.
 
Inflation Hits the Pitchers
 Not only young pitchers or marginal pitchers have contributed to the increased run production. Kevin Brown of Texas, a 21-game winner in 1992, has an 11.63 earned run average and an 0-4 record. Pete Harnisch of Houston, whose 2.98 e.r.a. was sixth lowest in the National League last season, has a 10.26 e.r.a. in four starts. Kevin Appier of Kansas City, the American League leader last season with a 2.56 e.r.a., is at 9.00 now.
Some other victims of, or contributors to, the offensive onslaught: Bob Ojeda of the Yankees 24.00, Todd Van Poppel of Oakland 16.61, Jose Guzman of the Cubs 16.43, Arthur Rhodes of Baltimore 10.95, Anthony Young of the Cubs 9.22, Pedro Astacio of Los Angeles 9.18, Tim Belcher of Detroit 9.17, Pat Mahomes of Minnesota 8.79, Kevin Tapani of Minnesota 8.27, Bill Gullickson of Detroit 8.22, Pat Doherty of Detroit 7.90, Mark Gubicza of Kansas City 7.71, Bobby Witt of Oakland 7.66 and Scott Erickson of Minnesota 7.48.
And those are the starters. Some relief earned run averages are eye-opening numbers as well: Alan Mills of Baltimore 24.92, Tony Menendez of San Francisco 22.50, Dave Righetti of Oakland 20.25, Mike Butcher of California 16.62, Edwin Nunez of Oakland 15.19, Mark Guthrie of Minnesota 15.00, Mark Davis of San Diego 13.50, Jim Bullinger of the Cubs, 13.50, Jonathan Hurst of the Mets 12.60, Blaise Ilsley of the Cubs 10.80, Brad Pennington of Baltimore 10.50, Steve Frey of San Francisco 10.38, Mike Timlin of Toronto 10.29, Mark Gardner of Florida 10.29, Xavier Hernandez of the Yankees 10.13.
 
Tewksbury Solves the Braves
 In defeating Atlanta on Wednesday night, Bob Tewksbury gained two distinctions of note: He became the first National League pitcher to beat a team in each of the three new divisions and he became the first pitcher to last an entire game against the mighty Braves.
Considering the way the Braves have played the first few weeks, the second achievement was more impressive.
"Everyone was talking about it like they were the '27 Yankees," Tewksbury said, discussing the task the St. Louis Cardinals faced when they went to Atlanta last week. The Braves won 12 of their first 13 games, then made it 13 of 14 in the opening game of the three-game series.
"But we rebounded against a two-time Cy Young winner," Tewksbury said, referring to a victory against Greg Maddux. "That gave us momentum going into the third game."
Which is the one he pitched. He allowed only three runs, less than half the 6.3 runs the Braves had averaged.
"We played great defense," the 33-year-old right-hander said. "That's how we beat them. They put the ball in play, and we handled it. They're good, but they're only human, too."
Tewksbury, who in the past two seasons compiled a 33-15 record, gained his fourth victory against no defeats, adding the Braves to his victories over Cincinnati, San Francisco and San Diego.
 
Mariners' Hands of Stone
 When Gene Michael, the Yankees' general manager, walked into the visiting manager's office at Yankee Stadium the other evening, the visiting manager smiled broadly and said: "You got a bill for the phone? I ripped that thing off the socket."
Lou Piniella, able to laugh about it the next day, had ripped the telephone to the bullpen off the dugout wall at the end of a game the Seattle Mariners lost because of errors.
"We're not catching the ball," Piniella lamented. "I don't have an explanation. Last year we led the league in fielding. In spring training we made the second-least errors in the majors. And all of a sudden we're not catching the ball."
The Mariners, whose 90 errors were the fewest in the majors last season, were considered a preseason favorite to win their first division championship. In their past failures, their problem has been a lack of hitting or pitching. Now that they have developed those necessary elements, they can't field the ball. They have the worst fielding percentage in the majors.
 
Where's the Relief?
 Duane Ward (Toronto), John Wetteland (Montreal), Rod Beck (San Francisco), Rob Dibble (Cincinnati), Gregg Olson (Atlanta), Norm Charlton (Philadelphia) and Alejandro Pena (Pittsburgh) are on the disabled list.
Dennis Eckersley (Oakland) no longer menaces opposition batters in the ninth inning. He and Darren Holmes (Colorado), a comparative newcomer, have provided the most glaring examples of the affliction that has struck closing relief pitchers who have remained healthy.
Can't anybody here save a game anymore?
Mitch Williams might have started it with his World Series failures last year (although Eckersley's ineffectiveness began last season). Williams squandered his first save opportunity of this season Friday night. The usually reliable Jeff Montgomery of Kansas City let a victory get away, too, Friday night.
"We have to develop a new batch of closers," said Lou Piniella, who has watched his alleged closers go 0 for 3 in save opportunities this season.
While younger relievers languish on the disabled list and other colleagues struggle in the ninth, Lee Smith keeps rolling along. The 36-year-old veteran, the career leader in saves, was supposed to be finished a few years ago because of unstable knees, but there's nothing wrong with his right arm.
While Williams and Montgomery were giving away games, Smith recorded his eighth save in Baltimore's ninth victory of the season, raising his career total to 409.

HEADLINE: A Life Lesson From Wall Street

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There is something deeply disturbing in the earnestness of the article about Lawrence Kudlow. Both its substance and tone provide further evidence that economic reporting increasingly consists of little more than accounts of sandbox play among members of an elite salon -- all of whom are quite disconnected from the realities of most Americans. To be sure, coping can become difficult when life throws someone an unwieldy amount of success or failure. Just ask any of those thousands of midlevel employees throughout the United States who have lost jobs in the name of productivity -- none of whom will ever be the subject of such a windy profile.
 
MATT ROHDE
Silver Spring, Md., April 5
 
The writer is a lawyer with the Federal Government.

HEADLINE: April 17-23: U.S. and Haiti;
A Little Movement Toward Getting Tough

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Critics of President Clinton's Haiti policy got some of what they wanted last week: lots of attention and a few adjustments. Haiti's exiled President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, said it was "racist" for the Clinton Administration to summarily return Haitian refugees after intercepting them on the high seas. Randall Robinson, president of a black foreign-policy lobbying group, fasted for nearly two weeks to protest that policy and on Thursday six Democratic members of Congress were arrested after demonstrating outside the White House. 
 Stung by the criticisms, the Administration decided to press the United Nations to adopt a comprehensive embargo (the current embargo covers just fuel and arms), and it pledged to press the Dominican Republic to clamp down on oil smuggling into Haiti. But President Clinton refused to stop summarily repatriating Haitian refugees.
Stay tuned for more protests. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND;
Despite A Rebuff, Hope Springs Eternal

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
A springtime perennial from Coney Island, which just can't stop nurturing dreams, even in its decline (or perhaps because of it):
More than a decade ago, Horace Bullard, an optimistic Harlem-born entrepreneur, put together a plan to build a giant amusement park. In 1989 the Board of Estimate approved his plan. But last month the city withdrew its support, convinced that Mr. Bullard could not raise enough money to finance his $450 million dream. 
Mr. Bullard, though, remains an optimist. He says he is about to obtain the financial backing he needs, and on March 16 he sued in Supreme Court in Manhattan to win back the city's participation. The city had agreed to provide 17 of the 20 acres his project would take up along a strip facing the boardwalk between West 15th and 21st Streets.
Mr. Bullard, who started the Kansas Fried Chicken restaurant chain, said that after the city's withdrawal, Fuji Bank and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette sent him letters indicating that financial support was imminent. "Just when we have the money," he said, "the city wants to pull out."
But Catie Marshall, a spokeswoman for the city's Economic Development Corporation, said the letters were "vague."
Like the old Steeplechase park, Mr. Bullard's project would offer attractions like a metal horse steeplechase plus restaurants and games. He said it would bring 3,000 construction jobs and more than 2,000 permanent jobs. G.P.-P.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KINGSBRIDGE;
Armory's Uncertain Future

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
In 1917, the National Guard's Eighth Coastal Artillery Regiment left its rambling armory on 94th Street and Park Avenue in Manhattan for a new site in the Bronx where it would have more room and richer recruiting options.
The Bronx building, at 29 West Kingsbridge Road, is an architectural wonder, with two grand three-quarter-round towers that highlight the stately medieval-style exterior and a moat that runs across the front. It was designated a city landmark in 1974, while the regiment's former home was demolished in the 1960's. 
 But now the Kingsbridge Armory is one of five around the state being closed as a result of nationwide military cutbacks, and the building has fallen into disrepair. After serving as the site of regiment events as well as boat shows and bicycle races, it will be deserted by the Guard in September, though the regiment will continue to use the more modern annex next door.
As in several other communities in the city, the Kingsbridge regiment's impending departure has inspired many proposals on what to do with the building, igniting much debate about the landmark's future.
Two proposals dominate the debate in Kingsbridge. Officials of School District 10 would like to see several schools and an array of social services on the site to relieve crowded conditions in the district's schools. Another plan, supported by State Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell when he was an Assemblyman from the area, calls for converting it into a center for amateur athletics.
A nine-story red-brick structure with a 180-square-foot drill hall and an 800-seat auditorium, the armory covers an entire block between Kingsbridge Road and 195th Street and Reservoir and Jerome Avenues.
The state, which will cede title to the building to New York City, recently awarded a local nonprofit organization, the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, a $100,000 grant to come up with a plan on how best to use the site. In about two weeks, the development corporation will form a committee of residents and merchants who will spend a year working with consultants, drawing up a proposal for uses of the building and finding ways to pay for roof repairs, new electrical systems and other structural work, which could cost as much as $40 million.
A small shelter on the Jerome Avenue side of the building that accommodates about 90 homeless women in the winter will remain open for now, officials said. But its future must also be decided. The committee's report will be submitted to Borough President Fernando Ferrer. All current proposals will be studied, said Yves Trillon, a project director of the development corporation.
"The Kingsbridge Armory is a tremendous landmark that now needs to be turned into a tremendous resource for the community," Mr. Ferrer said. "We hope the study will provide us with some ideas and some ways to make it work for the community."
The construction of the giant armories in New York, beginning in the late 19th century, reflected the growth in the size and quantity of military equipment and in the ranks of the National Guard, which was frequently called on to deal with riots and other civil disturbances of that era.
In those that remain today, style sometimes takes precedence over substance. The moat in front of the Kingsbridge Armory, for example, would spill water into the basement windows if filled.
"We certainly have our work cut out for us," Mr. Trillon said. "This whole project is like dealing with several buildings in one." LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

Luring More Shoppers To the Lower East Side
 A campaign to revitalize the city's original bargain center on the Lower East Side and to reintroduce outlet-bound New Yorkers and American and foreign tourists to the area is well underway, said David Ceci, the executive director of the Lower East Side District Management Association, a nonprofit organization that has been sponsoring the effort. 
 Tour buses will be back along Orchard, Delancey and Grand Streets today for the first time in more than three years, he said. The number of police officers in the area has been increased, while the streets have been spruced up with new signs, storefronts and plantings. Free four-hour parking is offered in a lot that has just opened on the north side of Broome Street, between Suffolk and Norfolk Streets.
"It's becoming like it used to be in old New York," said Mr. Ceci, whose organization includes property owners, merchants, residents and elected officials.
More than 400 stores selling fabric, clothing, electronic goods, appliances, handbags, jewelry, and sheets and towels line the streets.
One thing to bear in mind: stores owned by Orthodox Jewish merchants are closed on Saturdays. But everything is open Sundays.
 
 
New Twist on Pretzels: Cheese and Sesame Toppings
 A Staten Island-based company with a major stake in frozen yogurt is planning some fancy tricks with the lowly pretzel. Everything Yogurt Inc. plans to open the Gourmet Pretzel Company this summer at La Guardia Airport, where it will sell hand-rolled pretzels with cinnamon and sugar, sesame, poppyseed and "raisin Danish" toppings. The store will also be offering flattened, open-faced pretzels with cheese-and-tomato or cheese-and-bacon toppings.
"By the end of the year," said Samuel B. Stein, director of real estate for Everything Yogurt, "we'll have 10 pretzel stores in operation around the country." The 18-year-old company's Everything Yogurt/ Salad Cafe chain has 160 stores; its Bananas and its South Philly Steaks and Fries chains account for another 140 branches.
 
Village Hotel Finishes $10 Million Renovation
 The 180-room Washington Square Hotel, in a turn-of-the-century building at 103 Waverly Place, has completed a $10 million renovation. Everything from carpeting and air conditioning to furniture and bathroom fixtures has been replaced. "But it still looks like an old Parisian hotel," said Dan Paul, the owner.
The room rates, traditionally on the low side, have stayed there. (A single with shared bath goes for $58 a night.) The hotel's de-emphasis on service remains firm: the hotel has no bellhops or room service. "I keep my labor costs down that way," Mr. Paul said. "This allows me to keep my room prices low and allows me to renovate about every 10 years."

HEADLINE: COPING;
A Lonely Cry From the Smoking Section

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
SHARON B. is a 44-year-old woman who lives on the Upper West Side and works in television production. She feels so persecuted these days, so discriminated against and vulnerable that she does not want to be further identified. I've known her for several years and was surprised at the depth of her anger. But I sympathize only to a point; Sharon is a smoker, and I am not.
"All of a sudden, I'm a smoker," she snapped. "I've stopped being a competent, intelligent, feeling woman. I'm identified as a smoker, maybe the last group of people you can pick on and still feel good about yourself." 
 New York seems to be out front in the war against tobacco, slamming door after door against smokers and creating yet another them versus us. Sharon feels the glare of other diners when she lights up in the smoking section of restaurants. On the job, the subtle sneers and wrinkled noses are often worse than the outright rage; when an executive called her "evil" as smoke plumed out of her nose, she thought it was his problem.
I admitted to her that as a former smoker, I enjoy a certain contempt for all those men and women in shirt sleeves on the pavement outside office buildings inhaling tar and nicotine in quick, guilty bursts. I think, Grow up. Quit. And stop blowing it my way.
"My cigarette has become an excuse for someone else to release all his hostilities," said Sharon. "It's a symbol. People say, 'I care about you, this is for your own good.' But I know that's not true, because I can't say to them, 'You eat too much, you drink too much.' "
"What a minute," I said. "Fatties and boozers don't blow second-hand smoke into your lungs."
"Take me to Santa Fe, I'll believe you," she said. "I can't believe I'm the problem in New York. You'll sit outside eating lunch in bus fumes, and you'll hok me about my cigarette smoke, which may or may not be dangerous to you?"
Sharon began smoking when she was 16, in Brighton Beach, hoping to learn to suck on a cigarette as gorgeously as Lauren Bacall. She stopped for a year, then started again during her mother's terminal illness. Because Sharon has been struggling with bulimia for 25 years, she is more concerned about gaining weight than damaging her lungs. Smoking relieves her stress, she says, puts her in "a state of mind of reflection"; she wonders about all the people on Prozac who don't know the long-term effects of that drug.
She smokes about a pack and a quarter each day. Several months ago, on a job in which she had been tucked into a back office with a window, the only smoking room on the floor, she noticed she was going through four packs a day.
"Everybody was stopping by for a cigarette. All these secret smokers. 'Don't tell my husband, my wife,' they'd say. I began to think, maybe this is the new secret vice you can have. These days smoking is less of a risk than extramarital affairs, but you're still slipping around. I know people who take the dog out seven times a day on the weekend, just to have a cigarette."
Sharon can be comfortable for about an hour and a half without a cigarette. She will no longer eat, she says, in Sarabeth's Kitchen on Amsterdam Avenue, which has a no-smoking policy and service she finds leisurely. She is grateful to pubby places like Teacher's on Broadway, where people still light up near the bar. On long plane flights, she loads up on natural licorice and pears, which seem to dim the craving, or chews nicotine-laced gum.
The image-conscious television industry was ahead of the rest of the city in making smokers feel like pariahs, she said. The head of one small company made her leave the office every hour for her smoke; but when she began missing West Coast calls and had to return them, he found her someplace to smoke.
"It's economic, it's psychological," she said. "O.K., I'm not naive to cancer and emphysema, but I don't believe we really care that much about health. We'd do more about pollution, about McDonald's hamburgers. This is a kind of socially acceptable witch hunt. People see something in me as a smoker that scares them.
"People are reticent to acknowledge that we all have addictions -- to relationships, to fitness regimes, to drugs. But my obsessive behavior is so clear that it triggers their fears. So they want me to feel guilty, they want me to make them comfortable."
I said: "This is a little psychobabbly for me. You are imposing your addiction on me. The smoke, the smell, the fire, the increased illnesses."
She said: "So stay away from me. Negotiate with me. But be sensitive to my needs, too. Look, we're in this city that stinks. Gunk off the buildings, exhaust fumes, dog crap on the street, inversions and sewer smells, lead and asbestos. Stuff you can't do anything about. So you take it out on smokers: they're the problem, if only they'd stop smoking, everything would be all right."
Sharon has no plans to quit, although smoking has become less pleasurable. Once it was an aid to social interaction; now it's lonely, sometimes furtive, often focused only on itself.
Sharon is looking forward to summer, when the city will be filled with European tourists, mostly smoking.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 72; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2303 words

HEADLINE: GOOD HEALTH;
IS MISPLACING YOUR GLASSES ALZHEIMERS

BYLINE: By Robin Marantz Henig; Robin Marantz Henig, who writes frequently for this magazine, is the author of "The Myth of Senility" and, most recently, "A Dancing Matrix: How Science Confronts Emerging Viruses."

 BODY:
IN LITTLE MORE THAN A DECADE, ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE HAS moved from an obscure and supposedly rare condition to become the nation's fourth-leading cause of death. The disease slowly but relentlessly eviscerates a lifetime of memories, destroying brain cells and blocking communication from one cell to another. It eventually erases all that makes a person alive, unique and human. A recent Gallup Poll found that one of every three Americans now knows someone who has it and that nearly 50 percent worry about developing it themselves. The disease afflicts four million people, and family after family has a sad story to tell about it.
 Harriet H., for example, says she did not understand her husband's condition until the night they gave a dinner party at their suburban Washington home. "It was a very nice evening; we all had a wonderful time," she says. "And then as people were getting ready to leave, my husband put on his coat to leave with them. He didn't know he was in his own home." 
IN PART BECAUSE OF THE INCREASED FAMILIARITY WITH THE ailment, there is concern in the medical world that people, and occasionally their doctors, are jumping too quickly to a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease when all that's happening is normal aging. Scientists now recognize that Alzheimer's is totally different from the memory lapses that plague everyone who gets old; it is a specific, organic condition that develops only in some human brains.
 "There is some tendency to diagnose Alzheimer's disease too readily when one is presented with the everyday kind of forgetfulness that all of us have," says Leonard Berg, professor of neurology at Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis and chairman of the medical and scientific board of the Alzheimer's Association. "Alzheimer's disease is the new phrase on the block."
 Being too quick to the diagnosis can be tragic. In making such a judgment, the doctor might be overlooking some physical and potentially treatable condition that can cause almost identical symptoms. What looks like Alzheimer's might, in fact, be caused by one of scores of underlying, often treatable, conditions -- including depression, drug intoxication, thyroid imbalance, vitamin B-12 deficiency, even a mild heart attack.
 The first step when evaluating an elderly patient complaining of memory loss is "to do a neurologic exam to see if the patient really has dementia," says Daniel A. Pollen, a neurologist at the University of Massachusetts. Dementia is the loss of intellectual abilities, like memory, judgment and language, without a loss of consciousness or alertness. "Then, if there is dementia, you have to look for a treatable cause that might explain it," adds Pollen, the author of "Hannah's Heirs: The Quest for the Genetic Origins of Alzheimer's Disease." A thorough examination is the only way to rule out these possibilities.
 The disease is named after Alois Alzheimer, a German psychiatrist who in 1907 reported the perplexing case of a 51-year-old woman who experienced intellectual deterioration. When his patient died, incontinent and bedridden, four years later, Alzheimer conducted an autopsy of her brain. He found it riddled with two abnormal cell formations that he characterized as "plaques" and "tangles." These two types of brain cell masses are today the hallmarks of the neurological disease that bears his name.
 Subsequent research has shown that the plaques are made of a brain protein known as beta-amyloid and that the tangles consist of abnormal nerve cell filaments wrapped around each other like a fraying piece of twine. To this day, the only way that Alzheimer's disease can be diagnosed with absolute certainty is if brain tissue examined under a microscope, usually after death, turns up sufficient evidence of these tangles and plaques. Brain biopsies are rarely done because they are difficult and dangerous.
 For many years, the diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease was used only for early-onset, then called "presenile," dementia. "When I went to medical school in the 40's, we were taught that Alzheimer's disease was a very rare disorder affecting people in their 40's and 50's and that none of us was ever going to see a case in our lifetimes," Berg says. "They told us that something else happens to old people, but because it affected people in their 60's and 70's, they weren't going to go into that."
 Gradually, though, scientists realized that the same plaques and tangles that appeared in the brains of people who died of presenile dementia were found in the brains of people with a later onset of the very same symptoms. Since the late 1970's, Alzheimer's disease has been used to mean dementia caused by a specific kind of brain degeneration no matter what the age of the patient.
 In much of medicine, the diagnosis of a specific disease is made by ruling out others. This is true of Alzheimer's. "If you have a good history of progression over a year or more, and if you've ruled out the possible reversible causes of the symptoms, you can usually make a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease," Pollen says. "Some people like to do MRI or CT scans to see whether there's brain atrophy -- but these are only consistent with the diagnosis, not proof."
 Reversible pseudo-dementia occurs in only about 10 percent of patients who come in for evaluations. Still, it's worth looking for, since the alternative is to consign someone with a treatable disease to a category of illness that's progressive and incurable.
 Just as there are reports of overdiagnosis, so too are there reports of underdiagnosis. Some physicians are reluctant to give such a dire name to a patient's condition; instead, they say the forgetfulness and confusion are the inevitable result of aging. "A patient came to us just a few weeks ago with dementia, who had been told by his doctor that it's just normal aging, and there's nothing anyone can do," Pollen says. It may not prove to be either; it's possible that something can be done or that it's not normal aging at all but rather a case of Alzheimer's.
 Overdiagnosis does not completely explain why Alzheimer's seems so common today, affecting a million more Americans than a decade ago. A fuller explanation is the population growth of the people at highest risk. Alzheimer's is overwhelmingly a disease of very old age. Those over 85 represent the fastest-growing segment of the population. As this age group expands, the number with the disease is expected to grow exponentially, with as many as 14 million by the year 2050.
 The prevalence rates rise steeply with age, according to a 1989 study conducted in the working-class neighborhood of East Boston. "We went door to door and interviewed everyone over 65," says Dr. Denis A. Evans, who coordinated the study while at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. More than 3,800 older people were interviewed and 467 were asked to come to a health center for further evaluations. From this sample, Evans's group concluded that for people aged 65 to 74, the prevalence of Alzheimer's was 3 percent; for those aged 75 to 84, it was 19 percent, and for people over the age of 85, the rate of Alzheimer's disease was an astonishing 47 percent. Earlier estimates had put the rate at closer to 20 to 30 percent.
 "The age distribution curve," says Evans, now at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago, "implies a dramatic increase in prevalence of the illness in the years ahead." The economic implications are staggering. The four million who have the disease now cost the nation some $90 billion a year. "Imagine the whole state of Texas," says Zaven S. Khachaturian, associate director of the National Institute on Aging. "Imagine all those people in need of long-term nursing home care. Our society simply cannot afford it."
 In response to the problem, Federal support for Alzheimer's research has increased tenfold since 1983. This has led to an eruption of scientific discoveries in the past few years. Biologists have now identified several genetic markers that seem to correlate with early-onset Alzheimer's disease, which affects as many as 10 percent of Alzheimer's patients.
 For the past 15 years, researchers have focused on the plaques and tangles identified by Alzheimer back in 1907. These brain abnormalities are most plentiful in two critical regions of the brain: the hippocampus, which controls memory, and the cerebral cortex, which controls higher order thinking and reasoning.
 In those same regions, you can also find high concentrations of beta-amyloid, the protein in many of the plaques. This finding led to the amyloid hypothesis: that the first step in a sequence of destructive events in the brain involves beta-amyloid. But a small group of Alzheimer's researchers have questioned the amyloid hypothesis, saying the presence of beta-amyloid in Alzheimer's brains is the result, rather than the cause, of the brain cell devastation.
 Then last fall, scientists at Duke University made one of the most important discoveries since Alois Alzheimer's original finding. They linked a different gene to an increased susceptibility to the most common form of Alzheimer's, the form that strikes after the age of 65.
 The Duke scientists, led by Allen D. Roses, a neurobiologist, offered an alternative to the amyloid hypothesis. They proposed that the first step in the brain cell degeneration involves a protein called apolipoprotein E (ApoE).
 The scientists found that 64 percent of Alzheimer's patients had at least one gene coding for the type of the ApoE protein known as E4. Among a control group, only 31 percent did. And they charted a clear relationship between the ApoE types and the age of onset of the disease. For those Alzheimer's patients with two E4 genes, one from each parent, the average age of onset was 68. For those with a single E4, paired with another type like E3, the average age was 75. For those with no E4, the average age of onset was 84.
 It became clear, then, that having ApoE4 is a risk factor for Alzheimer's disease, just as high cholesterol is a risk factor for heart disease. "If you have E4, you're more likely to get Alzheimer's disease; if you don't have E4, you're less likely," Roses says. Research on how E4 works, he says, holds promise for a preventive therapy within the next 10 years, perhaps as simple as a pill to supply a missing brain chemical.
 Just as diet and exercise can lessen the risk of heart disease for someone with high cholesterol, something in the environment might affect whether a person with E4 actually develops Alzheimer's. So far, evidence of environmental influences on Alzheimer's disease is scanty. But two recent studies have raised some possibilities.
 At the University of Southern California in Los Angeles, Dr. Victor Henderson reviewed the medical records and death certificates of some 2,400 women who had lived in Southern California and found that those who had been on estrogen replacement therapy were 40 percent less likely to have had Alzheimer's than those who had not taken estrogen. And at Duke, John Breitner examined 50 pairs of elderly twins who developed Alzheimer's disease at different ages -- or in which only one twin ever developed the disease -- and found that those who took anti-inflammatory drugs for arthritis were four times more likely than their co-twins to have developed Alzheimer's at a later age, or to be spared altogether. Now clinical trials are under way to see whether estrogen replacement therapy or anti-inflammatory drugs offer protection against Alzheimer's.
 WHEN THE BRAIN CELL destruction begins, the effect is at first insidious. The earliest symptoms of the disease -- often noticeable only in retrospect -- are loss of recent memory and impaired judgment. But often these deficits are easily disguised. "My husband maintained his poise for a very long time," says Harriet H., whose husband's diagnosis in 1982 came after signs of decline that began eight years before. "If we ran into you on the street and you were a friend, he would say: 'How are you? Nice to see you. How's your family?' And you would think he was absolutely fine. But he would have no idea who you were. If you were a stranger from New Guinea who had just set foot on our shores, he would say the same thing."
 At first, it's hard to distinguish these symptoms from normal forgetfulness. Harriet's husband, for instance, had always been absent-minded. But as the brain decays, the memory loss becomes more profound; people forget not only where they left their glasses but that they ever wore glasses. As the brain deteriorates, Alzheimer's changes not only memory but personality. One patient may lash out at a spouse or child; another, retreat into silence, or become confused, paranoid or belligerent. In the final stages, usually about 8 to 10 years after diagnosis, patients are often unable to control their bodily functioning, becoming unable to speak, swallow or recognize their own families.
 Harriet cared for her husband at home for 10 years. Finally, when he could no longer walk and barely recognized anyone, she put him in a nursing home. Since there is no cure, this is where most Alzheimer's patients spend their last years -- bedridden, incontinent, an empty, sad shell of what they once were.
 Curiously, the body often stays intact while the mind falls to pieces. Harriet is still moved to tears by her husband's face, which looks younger than its 80 years. "He's always had a very sweet face. Now it's just the same sweet face, but it's lost all its tension." Despite his mute helplessness, she can recognize in that face the man she once loved, the man who, in a changed but no less powerful way, she loves still. "It's a very dear face. He's a very dear man."
