HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE PRESIDENT;
Sharper Focus: Genesis of Clinton's Hard Line

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL with ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
As President Clinton struggled this week to respond to new Serbian aggression in Bosnia and to salvage his unsuccessful policy in Haiti, he took some pleasure in having forced himself to attend to foreign affairs as never before in his Presidency.
 "No one can ever say again I've been disengaged," Mr. Clinton told one adviser on Tuesday as back-to-back National Security Council meetings on Bosnia finally gave his aides what they had long pressed for: a chance to enlist the President in an extensive review of his most intractable foreign-policy problem. 
The shift came only after Secretary of State Warren Christopher and David R. Gergen, the White House counselor, began campaigns with allies in the White House to persuade Mr. Clinton to focus more on urgent foreign issues. Such opportunities had been rare.
 Even after Bosnian Serbs opened their latest offensive on Gorazde last month, five days passed before the President spoke out publicly about them. It took 12 more days before he sat down with his national security advisers for the last 26 minutes of a meeting about Bosnia.
 
A Slow Start, A Lack of Clarity
 After three harried weeks, the Administration's struggle to deal with the Serbian challenge finally produced the stern ultimatum that NATO approved on Friday. It also displayed enduring features of Mr. Clinton's foreign-policy management style: an appetite for details, an inclination to debate, an impulse to muse in public.
 At the beginning of April, the White House waited four days before fully repudiating a comment by Defense Secretary William J. Perry that left an impression that Washington was not prepared to use force to save the Muslim enclave of Gorazde. Aides say the delay sent a dangerous signal to the Serbian attackers.
 Even as the relentless bombardment was pushing the Administration toward a more assertive policy, public remarks by Mr. Clinton failed to convey the message that Washington was taking a harder line. This led to frustration at the State Department, the Pentagon and the White House.
 Before taking office, President-elect Clinton spoke candidly about the importance of "preventive" management of issues like Bosnia. He said his Administration had two choices: to "come up with a decent policy and aggressively pursue it," or "ignore it for awhile, wait for it to explode."
 The danger, he warned, would be that "the problems will swarm on us, and I might have to spend all my time on foreign policy."
 "I don't want that to happen," he said. "So we're trying to develop a disciplined, aggressive approach that will permit us the freedom to focus on America's problems at home."
 To coordinate that task, Anthony Lake, the President's national security adviser, has seized control of the foreign policy process to insure that he is the conduit for information and ideas that reach the President. But that aggressiveness has caused some frictions between the White House and the State Department.
 Mr. Clinton has performed well on foreign-policy issues for which he has a passion and an instinct, and which have a direct effect on the American people and the American economy. After winning passage of North American Free Trade Agreement and concluding a global trade treaty, for example, he is now given credit for wrestling creatively with trade issues involving China and Japan.
 Yet the lurching public statements on other issues, particularly Bosnia, illustrate how little discipline and direction there has been.
 "This is a foreign-policy process which publicly gives every indication of being out of control and not under anyone's control," said Hodding Carter 3d, a State Department spokesman in the Carter Administration who has criticized the Administration's response to Serbian aggression.
 
Around the World In 30 Minutes
 On the minutely detailed schedules prepared by Mr. Clinton's aides, the only regular daily session devoted to foreign policy remains a 10-minute briefing from the Central Intelligence Agency and a 20-minute update from Mr. Lake.
 On March 30, the day Serbian forces were first reported to have opened their offensive against Gorazde, the briefings -- in San Diego, where Mr. Clinton was on vacation -- focused primarily on North Korea's nuclear threat. The surge in fighting around the enclave of 65,000 Bosnians was not mentioned.
The attack was the first significant threat to any Bosnian town designated by the United Nations as a "safe area" since a NATO ultimatum forced the Serbs to loosen their hold on Sarajevo in mid-February. But Mr. Clinton said nothing publicly about the fighting, and his senior advisers say they can remember no conversations with him on the subject until the following week.
 With only a mid-level national security aide, William Itoh, still with him, the President remained in San Diego until April 2, when he headed to Charlotte, N.C., to watch the Arkansas Razorbacks play in the basketball championships, then returned to the White House.
 Although Mr. Clinton speaks several times each day with Mr. Lake and has begun to meet almost weekly with other security advisers, aides say the President's time is too valuable to hold additional sessions on foreign affairs.
 On the Bosnian issue, said Paul Begala, a top political adviser, "people want both restraint and resolve, and I think that's what they're getting."
But as the Serbian attacks intensified, the White House began to pay for its inattention. After an April 3 television interview in which Defense Secretary Perry left the impression that the United States would not act to save the town, Mr. Clinton and his aides did little to dispel that impression. It was not until April 7 that Mr. Lake stated clearly that military strikes to protect Gorazde had not been ruled out.
 By then, Administration officials acknowledge, the damage was done. "I don't think we acted quickly enough to correct the record," Mr. Gergen, the White House counselor, said in an interview, "and it deepened the impression that we were not willing to use air power."
 So determined is the White House to squelch the notion that Mr. Clinton is disengaged from foreign policy that it circulated a four-page document to aides in response to reporters' questions with the title, Draft Chronology of the President's Foreign Policy Engagement, April 4-21.
 And Mr. Clinton went out of his way last week to tell a group of newspaper columnists, "For the last 10 days, except for my forays on health care, I've done almost nothing but work on Bosnia and Haiti and one or two other foreign-policy issues." But even after Mr. Clinton grew more concerned with following events in Bosnia, Washington's position was not always presented clearly.
 By April 11, direct fire by Serbian tanks into Gorazde had grown so intense that NATO warplanes carried out extremely limited air strikes on Serbian positions, attacks in which the United States cooperated.
 But on April 14 and 15, Mr. Clinton emphasized that NATO was a neutral party in the conflict; his comments were prompted by reports that the Serbs had begun to regard the alliance as the enemy. The next day, a Saturday, he joined his advisers at the end of an emergency meeting on Bosnia, then began a two-day journey that included a stop at a Mustang car show in North Carolina.
 The itinerary stirred fear among some aides that the image of Bill Clinton driving his '67 convertible down the Charlotte Motor Speedway might become as unforgettable as that of George Bush roaring off the coast of Kennebunkport in his gas-guzzling speedboat after Iraq invaded Kuwait, disrupting world oil supplies.
 
Mixed Signals Make Policy Seem Muddy
 When the Serbs broke a cease-fire pledge to the Russians last Sunday night, aides say, the President made clear to Mr. Lake privately that he was ready to seek broader authority for NATO.
 But as Mr. Clinton began to plot a new course, he was sending other signals in public. On Monday, he left the impression that lifting the United Nations embargo on arms shipments to the Bosnian Government, in which Muslims predominate, was not utterly out of the question. On Tuesday, he was "intrigued" by a proposal by President Boris N. Yeltsin for summit talks on Bosnia. On Wednesday, he described the Bosnian conflict as a "civil war," only to be contradicted the next day by Mr. Christopher.
 Senior White House officials blame journalists for magnifying some shifts in emphasis, and say others are an inevitable product of Mr. Clinton's preference for communicating policy to the public, and his aversion to following scripts.
 "It's usually not an option to have the President say nothing," one top aide said. "It's like navigating a river -- sometimes you hit a rock. But if you don't have a paddle in the water, you're not going to get anywhere."
 But even some Congressional Democrats have expressed open frustration about Mr. Clinton's free-wheeling style.
 "You can't articulate American foreign policy in response to the news media," said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. "There are so many constituencies and so many nuances that no matter how good you are, you lose control of your message."
