HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Wanted: G.O.P. Candidate; Must Be Ambitious, Popular

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 24

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's approval ratings are at the same level that George Bush's were the week before he lost the 1992 election. They are where Jimmy Carter's were in 1980 immediately after an American helicopter crashed in the Iranian desert.
And yet an improbable confluence of factors, ranging from the utter disarray in New York's Republican Party to the gradual recovery of the state's economy, is starting to make Mr. Cuomo look more and more like a front-runner. 
 There is increasing concern in Republican circles, both in New York and in Washington, that the party may be squandering an opportunity. If Mr. Cuomo wins, New York's Republicans will have been shut out of the Governor's office for 24 years by the end of his term.
That void has created deep institutional problems that the party seems unable to overcome every four years. It is a party still torn between the liberal legacy left by Nelson Rockefeller and the Reagan Republicanism embraced by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. It is also a party where power is so divided -- between Mr. D'Amato, the Republican majority in the State Senate, and local power brokers in strongholds like Nassau County -- that many analysts question whether those competitors truly want to crown a new king.
It is still very early, of course. And given Mr. Cuomo's many liabilities after three terms in office, no one in either party is betting too heavily on him. In the latest poll by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion, which was conducted last month, only 36 percent of the respondents approved of his job performance.
But even the most loyal Republicans -- ranging from Senator D'Amato to Herbert London, a gubernatorial candidate -- concede that their party's electoral failings and recent political pratfalls have left the Governor in far better shape than could ever have been expected.
 
'He Has to Be Very Happy'
 "As each day goes by, Mario Cuomo's chances improve," said Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President and a prominent Republican leader. "He has to be very happy about the state of the Republican Party and the lethargy that has set in."
Richard N. Bond, a Republican political consultant and former chairman of the Republican National Committee, said his party could salvage a victory, but only because Mr. Cuomo "ranks as one of the most endangered incumbent governors in this country."
"The bad news is that we're out of position," said Mr. Bond, a native New Yorker who works in Alexandria, Va. "Essentially, we've forgotten how to win. The good news is, it might not even matter. I believe Cuomo is just that weak."
 
Factors of Misfortune
 There is no single prevailing reason that the New York race has shaped up as it has. Instead, a dozen distinct factors -- many of them misadventures that are singular to New York Republican politics -- have contributed to Mr. Cuomo's good fortune.
The Republicans have drifted from election to election without consistent direction in ideology or strategy. As illustrated by this year's field, which includes former Representative Bill Green, who was considered one of the most liberal Republicans in Congress, and Mr. London, who ran in 1990 as the Conservative Party nominee, the party's ideological focus in New York is highly diffuse.
"We've had significant victories in local elections, but there's no one power center in the party that can deliver a gubernatorial election," said a prominent Republican who spoke on condition of anonymity. "And you look in the Legislature and the congressional delegation and everyone is risk averse. They all want a sure thing."
After the 1992 election, there were at least three New York Republicans with statewide reputations who were considered capable of defeating Mr. Cuomo -- Chief Judge Sol Wachtler, Comptroller Edward V. Regan, and Senator D'Amato.
Eighteen months later, Mr. Wachtler is in jail after pleading guilty to Federal charges that he threatened the daughter of his former lover. Mr. Regan resigned last year in the middle of his term to take a job at an economics think tank, ending his prospects for higher office and insuring that the Legislature would select a Democrat, H. Carl McCall, to take his job. And Mr. D'Amato, after using his flirtation with a gubernatorial race to fill his campaign treasury, announced last fall that he would stay in the Senate. He told friends privately that he had no appetite for another bruising campaign, particularly against a pugilist like Mr. Cuomo.
 
A Field of Second-Stringers
 Without them, New York's Republicans were left with an expansive field of second-stringers. None of the losers from the 1990 Republican ticket -- Pierre A. Rinfret, George F. T. Yancey Jr., and Bernard C. Smith -- survived that year's debacle to run again. Instead, the party was reduced to searching for candidates from Congress, the State Legislature, county governments or the private sector, few of whom could claim a significant political base.
"We did nothing to build the party with that exercise," said Jay Severin, a Republican political consultant, referring to the 1990 campaign. "We didn't use it to give our younger players some game experience."
That is a distinct difference between this year's New York race and the successful 1993 Republican campaigns for Mayor of New York City and Governor of New Jersey. Both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman had run previously, Mr. Giuliani for Mayor in 1989 and Ms. Whitman for United States Senator in 1990.
 
No Repeats of 1990
 Once it became apparent that the Republican gubernatorial nominee would be a relative unknown, William D. Powers, the state Republican chairman, set out to find a candidate who could become the consensus choice of both the Republican and Conservative parties. He hoped to avoid a repeat of 1990, when the two parties nominated different candidates, Mr. Rinfret and Mr. London, who split the anti-Cuomo vote. He also hoped to avoid a divisive primary that would divert the focus of the campaign from Mr. Cuomo's record.
That effort has failed. A month before the party's state convention in New York City, to be held May 23-25, there are four announced candidates. Several others are still considering the race. The only question now about the Sept. 13 primary is how large the field will be.
To get on the primary ballot, a candidate must either win the votes of 25 percent of the delegates at the convention or collect 15,000 signatures on nominating petitions.
Senator George E. Pataki, the hand-picked candidate of Mr. D'Amato and Mr. Powers, seems certain to win 25 percent at the convention. But efforts to form a broad consensus around Mr. Pataki have been frustrated by the opposition of Ralph J. Marino, the Senate majority leader, who has longstanding political differences with him.
Mr. London, who says he has commitments from 15 percent of the delegates, also has a chance to get on the ballot at the convention. The prospects are less clear for Mr. Green, who has declared his candidacy, and for two Republicans who have not -- J. Patrick Barrett, a former state party chairman, and Evan G. Galbraith, a former ambassador to France.
 
Skipping the Convention
 Richard N. Rosenbaum, an announced candidate, plans to skip the convention and go the petition route to demonstrate his independence from the party bosses. As state Republican chairman from 1973 to 1977, Mr. Rosenbaum was once a party boss himself.
While Mr. Cuomo has started an aggressive fund-raising campaign -- he collected $1.5 million at a dinner in Manhattan last week -- the confusion in the Republican ranks has made fundraising difficult. Mr. Rosenbaum, who leads the Republican candidates in fund-raising, said he has found "an ambivalence based on the uncertainty about which Republican is going to survive all this."
At this point, none of the Republican candidates has built a large following, and that has kept voters from learning much about them. At the same time, Mr. Powers's hopes for a friendly primary seem to have vanished. Mr. Pataki and Mr. London spent the last two weeks trading insults in a volley of news releases.
While the Republicans bicker, Mr. Cuomo has benefited from encouraging economic news. State Labor Department figures show that the unemployment rate dropped to 8.1 percent in March from 8.5 percent in February, and that non-farm employment grew by 87,100 jobs between March 1993 and March 1994.
The Governor has even taken to dismissing the tardiness of the state budget, which is 24 days late, as a byproduct of good news. The Legislature, he says at every opportunity, has had difficulty divvying up the state's unexpectedly strong revenues. "So far we've not handled good fortune well," he said last week. "Maybe that's because we're out of practice."

HEADLINE: 4 Million Children Said to Live in 'Distress'

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Nearly four million American children are growing up in neighborhoods with high rates of poverty, absent fathers, unemployment and reliance on welfare, according to a new study.
The study by the Annie E. Casey Foundation, a philanthropy for poor children, said the children's choices were restricted by the troubles of their peers, neighbors and surroundings. 
 Douglas W. Nelson, the foundation's executive director, said, "We can no longer be surprised by the terrible outcomes experienced by young people who grow up in environments where drugs, violence, welfare and teen pregnancy are far more prevalent then safe schools, high school diplomas and good jobs."
He added: "These neighborhoods offer no real choices. We need to change that."
The foundation's annual study, "Kids Count Data Book," sought to quantify the number of children in stressful neighborhoods for the first time. Based largely on Census Bureau and other government data, the study found that nearly half the 3.9 million children living in very troubled neighborhoods were in six states: California, Illinois, Michigan, New York, Ohio and Texas. Every state except Idaho had such neighborhoods.
The study used five indicators to determine if a neighborhood was troubled: a poverty rate above 28 percent; more than 40 percent of the households headed by women; a high school dropout rate over 23 percent; more than 47 percent of men "unattached to the labor force," and more than 17 percent of families on welfare. A neighborhood with four of the five indicators was rated "severely distressed."
These were among the report's other findings:
*One-quarter of all children under 6 live in poverty, and over half of them in a family headed by a woman.
*One out of every four black children lives in a severely distressed neighborhood, compared with 1 of every 10 Hispanic children and 1 of every 63 white children.
*Births to single teen-agers were increasing in all but Maryland, New Jersey and New York.
*The violent death rate for teen-agers rose 13 percent between 1985 and 1991. While deaths of 15- to 19-year-olds caused by accidents decreased by 15 percent, deaths by homicide doubled.
*The violent crime arrest rate for youths 10-17 increased 50 percent from 1985 to 1991. In 1985, it was 305 per 100,000 youths; in 1991, it rose to 457 per 100,000.
The Annie E. Casey Foundation was established in 1948 by Jim Casey, a founder of United Parcel Service, and his siblings, and named for their mother.

HEADLINE: Japanese See Hopeful Sign In Transition

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 24

 BODY:
To Japan's business community, the pending change of Prime Ministers from Morihiro Hosokawa to Tsutomu Hata represents the transition from a visionary to a nuts-and-bolts manager.
Business leaders say they are optimistic that Mr. Hata will be able to put into effect some of the policies the flashy Mr. Hosokawa elucidated well but could not always carry out. These include deregulating business activities, spurring the economy with permanent income tax cuts and coming up with proposals on opening the country's markets to restart the stalled trade negotiations with the United States. 
 "Hata is a veteran politician," said Takeshi Kondo, general manager of the office of political and economic research at the Itochu Corporation, a large trading company. "He has many allies politically. He is determined to implement what Mr. Hosokawa had proposed."
Mr. Hata, chosen by the ruling coalition last week, is expected to be elected by the Parliament Monday.
 
Limited Maneuverability
 Despite his skills, Mr. Hata's maneuverability will be hampered by the same division in the ruling coalition that plagued Mr. Hosokawa, some experts said. The conservatives and leftists cooperated only out of a desire to remain in power, and the coalition nearly fell apart again last week because of differences on tax policy and North Korea.
Moreover, any push for deregulation and trade concessions will run into Japan's powerful bureaucrats.
Mr. Hosokawa attacked the bureaucrats head on, angering them. Mr. Hata, who has been Foreign Minister and Minister of Finance and Agriculture, is expected to work cooperatively with the bureaucrats, or simply follow their agenda.
He "knows where to push and where to pull" in the bureacracy, said Toshihiro Kiribuchi, a managing director of the Omron Corporation, an electronics company. "In that sense he is better. But there is a limit."
The markets reacted Friday in a mildly positive way to the transition, having already anticipated Mr. Hata's appointment. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's Nikkei average rose 165.03, to 19,964.39, on Friday. In Tokyo trading, the dollar rose by 0.87 yen, to 103.77 yen, a move that helps Japan's export-oriented industries.
Investors, fearing a long period of instability would derail Japan's nascent and fragile recovery, seemed relieved that someone would quickly step into power.
The most nettlesome economic issue facing Mr. Hata is taxes. Japanese businessmen are pushing for income tax cuts beyond the one already scheduled for this year to spur consumer spending. But the Finance Ministry, wary of a budget deficit, wants to compensate by eventually raising the national sales tax above its current level of 3 percent.
The United States also wants income tax cuts, hoping greater spending by Japanese consumers will increase imports. But it fears consumers will not spend if they know their gains from income tax cuts will be offset by higher taxes elsewhere.
Mr. Hosokawa proposed an income tax cut and eventual increase in the sales tax. But he was immediately forced to retract his proposal because of fierce opposition from the Socialist Party, the largest group in the coalition, which views the sales tax as falling hardest on the poor.
This time, Mr. Hata and Mr. Ozawa insisted that the ruling coalition agree on policies before Mr. Hata would take office. On the tax issue, the Socialists again balked and threatened to quit the coalition. They finally agreed to a compromise in which the parties will work to lower income taxes and raise indirect taxes while "trying to gain public support."
Analysts said the agreement would not prevent further disputes. Still, the prospects of the coalition's getting through a tax overhaul without falling apart are "much better than a month and a half ago," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, a Tokyo-based economist for Morgan Stanley & Company.
Mr. Hata is considered more interested in economic affairs than was Prime Minister Hosokawa. "He understands economic policy much better than Hosokawa," said a former Finance Ministry official.
 
More Involved in Trade Talks
 Mr. Hata has also been more deeply involved in the trade negotiations with the United States than was Prime Minister Hosokawa, who paid little attention to them until it was time to meet with President Clinton.
As Foreign Minister, Mr. Hata became Japan's point man on the broad-based talks leading to the two leaders' meeting in Washington in February. He spent late nights in a last-ditch, and ultimately unsuccessful, effort to forge agreements aimed at opening Japan's markets for automobiles, insurance, medical and telecommunications equipment.
But whether Mr. Hata will be able to come up with new proposals to satisfy the United States remains to be seen. Analysts say that Mr. Hata, like Mr. Hosokawa, opposes numerical targets on specific imported products. They speculated, however, that his administration might be willing to agree to a goal for reducing Japan's overall trade surplus.

HEADLINE: Lines Shift in Border War for Mexican Shopper

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico, April 24

 BODY:
Mexicans call them Malinchistas after La Malinche, the Aztec, who married the Spanish conqueror Hernan Cortes and aided his triumph over Mexico. Today, Malinchistas are Mexican shoppers who cross the border into Texas seeking cheaper prices, better selection or cachet.
They are the quarry in an intensifying battle between retailers in Texas, who are trying to keep their stores full of Mexican shoppers, and merchants in Mexico, who want them to shop at home. The Mexican side appears to have the edge, helped by none other than United States retailers like Wal-Mart and Sears. Those chains are lavishing Mexicans with more "Made in the U.S.A." products, sold in "Made in the U.S.A." settings. 
 Lower trade barriers, brought about partly by the North American Free Trade Agreement, and tougher customs enforcement against Mexican shoppers who load up on goods in Texas, are helping stores here recapture Mexican customers.
One of the complicating consequences of the free trade pact has been to sharpen enmities, pitting Mexican retailers against Texan retailers, United States apparel makers against United States merchants and United States retailing chains against themselves.
 
Mexico's Stores Learn to Compete
 In the last couple of years, both Mexican and United States retailers operating in Mexico have regained customers here with better prices and a greater variety of goods. Monterrey's first Wal-Mart, with 44 cash registers, was so crowded when it opened in November that police had to keep people from pushing in.
Mexican chains are cutting their profit margins, raising their advertising budgets and stocking their stores with United States brand names. Meanwhile, retail sales growth has slowed in many places on the Texas side of the border, with some merchants reporting declines.
But recapturing Mexican shoppers is not easy. Just ask Victor Ramirez Puente, a salesman in the jeans department at the Sears here, where he got the Levi's 501's hanging on his hips.
"Laredo," he bragged without hesitation, referring to the Texas border town more than 120 miles away. There, in trips made almost weekly, he and his friends save about $15 a pair, and more on other purchases.
Mr. Ramirez's frankness carries little risk. Among the customers his jeans department still cannot lure away from Laredo is the store's general manager, who brings whole wardrobes back.
Although some Mexicans may call each other Malinchistas, few from Monterrey hesitate to shop elsewhere for the best buys, just as few Wall Street traders hesitate to dump American stocks when foreign markets have greater appeal.
Skirmishes about the loyalties of Mexican shoppers flare as far north as Dallas, where the wealthier Mexicans fly or drive, and as far south as Mexico City, where some American border stores advertise. But the clash is loudest along the corridor between Laredo and Monterrey, an area of about three million people. Monterrey is the largest Mexican city within an easy drive of the border.
In the Laredo area, which has a population of about 140,000, retail sales in 1992 had doubled from the levels of 1987, the year after Mexico signed a global tariff agreement. Then last year, sales barely budged, in part because of a weakening Mexican economy and separate campaigns against smuggling by Mexican customs officers and United States jeans makers.
Laredo has responded by becoming more aggressive. Its merchants emphasize that they still have more efficient distribution and much lower taxes on electronics, clothing and other goods from beyond the North American free trade zone. They bombard drivers from Mexico with sales flyers in Spanish. The Laredo Wal-Mart, open until midnight, is often the busiest in the nation.
The Mall Del Norte in Laredo, with 113 stores and restaurants, is still expanding, approaching the size of the largest malls in Texas. Customers sometimes bring so much cash -- tens of thousands of dollars -- that the Sears store has installed safes near several of the cash registers.
Richard P. Perez, the manager of Sears, said he would teach the executives of his company, which is based in Chicago, how to compete for the Mexican shopper. "We're pioneers," he said, as he walked past racks of women's clothing and across what must be one of the few marble floors inside a Sears store in the United States. "If we don't write all our own rules, we're not doing justice as retailers. As Mexico goes, so goes this store."
Mr. Perez said he had pressed Sears to make the merchandising more exciting. "Only now have the people in Chicago started paying attention to what we're saying," he said.
These days, salespeople like Maru Martinez, who is from Monterrey, have to do more persuading. She helped shoppers like Silvia Gaspari, look at treadmills, but the couple wanted to do some comparative shopping back home in Mexico City.
"I remember there used to be a great difference in prices,' Mrs. Gaspari said. "Now, no. But electronics and some other things are still much cheaper here."
 
 
Tough Customs Enforcement
 Tougher customs enforcement has hurt sales at merchants in downtown Laredo, whose whitewashed store facades with Spanish lettering differ little from those across the nearby bridges to the Mexican side.
Les Norton's customers, three-quarters of them Mexican, often used to buy dozens, sometimes hundreds of pairs of sneakers or jeans from his family's three downtown stores, to resell them in Mexican flea markets, homes or small shops. Mexican customs officials and United States jeans makers have joined to curb this traffic, causing his overall sales to fall by at least 15 percent in the last year, he said.
"When Nafta got passed, we were told, 'Oh boy, things are really going to change,' " he said. "But retail merchants are the forgotten children in this whole thing."
Levi Strauss & Company has cut Mr. Norton's jeans shipments and has threatened to stop supplying him if he sells more than six pairs at a time. David Samson, a spokesman for Levi Strauss, said the company, not wholesalers posing as retailers, had the right to supply the Mexican market directly.
Levi Strauss wants to improve sales in boutiques like the one in the Monterrey Sears, where import tariffs, but also mark-ups, make prices higher than those in the United States. Jeans that could be found farther north for $35 a pair, and for much less on sale, cost about $50 here.
 
 
U.S. Goods Have Cachet
 To sell more jeans in Mexico, retailers must overcome their customers' beliefs that anything -- even the same thing -- bought in the United States must be better.
"Guess Jeans here and in the United States are very different," said Alfredo Fuentes, a customer at the Sears in Monterrey, as he rolled the cloth of a pants leg between his fingers at the Sears boutique. "Just look at the fabric. Look at the cut."
Even with more renovations planned, the Monterrey Sears has in some respects already arrived at the point where Mr. Perez wants the Laredo Sears to be. Hector Labrador, the store manager in Monterrey, has brought in a United States agency to polish his advertisements and promotions to the standards of the stores in which he spies and shops during his frequent trips north. On his last visit to Laredo in late February, Mr. Labrador and his wife spent about $500, mostly for clothing, in Dillard's, J. C. Penney and Sears. The customs agents let them pass.
With more American goods available in Monterrey, Mr. Labrador has cut his trips north to 4 a year, from about 10.
Most of the new competitors in Monterrey are off to strong starts. The Wal-Mart and the company's two new Sam's Club stores have brought Monterrey shoppers the lowest local prices they have seen. Sam's Club offers 27-inch Sony televisions for about $725, hundreds of dollars less than the prices at some local competitors and within $100 or $200 of the best prices in the United States.
At the first Sam's in Monterrey, Ovidio Rodriguez said that with the threat of tariffs, the television prices he saw in Laredo and McAllen, Tex., offered little advantage. "I'm going to buy one right now," he said.
 But he said he still seldom bought anything big without first looking to the north. His wife, Patricia Martinez, said toys and children's clothing cost a third as much in the United States. "A big difference," she said. "That's why we go to Toys 'R' Us."
Mexican merchants are hardly content to let American retailers on both sides of the border raid their clientele. Several Mexican companies have teamed with American retailers: Wal-Mart's partner is Grupo Cifra. Mexican retailers also have taken advantage of lower trade barriers to offer their customers more goods from the north.
At a Salinas y Rocha store covering a whole block of downtown Monterrey, there is a life-size cardboard Michael Jordan, hawking the latest in footwear, that beckons shoppers into the sports department. There, Carlos Guzman browsed through a rack of shorts and shirts boldly labeled "Sun Blocks. Made in Oceanside, California USA." He said he bought most of his clothes in Mexico, but shopped for electronics equipment in the United States.
 
 
New Rivals in Monterrey
 The store has spent two years planning its defense against arriving competitors that will soon include Dillard's and J. C. Penney. A year ago, the company dispatched Arturo Lozano Ayala, 34, to assume command. Mr. Lozano walks the sales floor to observe younger shoppers like Mr. Guzman.
"Our clients will go wherever there is something new," Mr. Lozano said. "We have to fight for their attention."
More sales, more aggressive advertising, lower prices, more brand names and more up-to-the-minute fashions have been among Mr. Lozano's weapons. Like other Mexican retailers, he is preparing for an era of higher turnover but lower profit margins.
But when Mr. Lozano gets enough practice in fending off foreign retailers, he may be ready for another campaign. "I hope with all my heart that we would arrive in the United States," he said. "That would be our triumph."

HEADLINE: Havana Woos Exiles, Easing Visits and Dangling Financial Carrot

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAVANA, April 24

 BODY:
The Cuban Government announced a number of measures this weekend in an effort to encourage more Cuban-Americans to visit and to attract investment here.
Scrapping many of the requirements that had limited the number of emigres' returning on visits, the Government was host to a three-day conference that was the first sizable meeting between the Communist leadership and representatives of the exile population in 16 years. 
 The gathering represented not only the beginning of a reconciliation between the Government and the more than 1.5 million Americans of Cuban descent but also what seemed to be a similar effort toward the United States.
By lifting some restrictions on visits by Cuban-Americans and hinting at lucrative investment possibilities, Havana appeared to be gambling that many exiles would lobby in the United States for an end to Washington's three-decade embargo against Cuba.
 
Waiting Period Ended
 The measures included the lifting of a five-year waiting period for return visits of Cubans who emigrate legally, the end of requirements that visitors spend money in Government-owned hotels, the creation of an office in the Foreign Ministry to deal with the needs of emigres, allowing Cuban-Americans to study in Cuban institutions, and the creation of a magazine specializing in the problems of migrants.
Although its application recently lapsed, the requirement that Cubans spend a fixed minimum in the official tourist economy has often been cited by Washington as a major obstacle to allowing greatly expanded air travel between Cuba and the United States. The United States Treasury Department allows Cuban-Americans to spend a maximum of $100 a day when visiting the country. Most other Americans are prohibited from spending money on the island altogether, a restriction that practically bars them from traveling to Cuba.
Many of the more than 200 conference participants, who were invited at least partly because of their opposition to the United States embargo, expressed enthusiasm for the changes and said they would push for a shift in Washington's policy toward the island.
If their thirst for change catches on back home, this would represent a major shift in the attitude of a Cuban-American exiles, which for years has been dominated by strongly conservative voices opposed to any openings toward the Government of President Fidel Castro.
 
Reasons to Return
 "The more the Cuban Government can recognize legitimate interests that exist in our community, the more they are giving people concrete reasons to go back to the States and lobby for changes on the other side," said Francisco Aruca, a Miami businessman and radio station operator who took part in the talks. "They have started down a route that is very serious and cannot be turned back."
United States officials continue to say that only broad democratic reforms in Cuba will bring about a lifting of Washington's embargo. Although political questions were occasionally raised by participants in this weekend's conference, the official agenda was limited to immigration issues.
Mr. Aruca's company, Marazul Charters, operates some of the 11 special flights from Miami that bring nearly 1,000 Cuban-Americans to the country each week, bearing badly needed clothing, medicines and money for relatives caught in the worst economic crisis since Mr. Castro came to power in 1959.
Many participants said Cuba's interest in drawing closer to the exiles, in addition to potentially affecting American policy toward the island, was driven by their growing contribution to the economy, whose value has been estimated at more than $400 million a year.
 
Risks for the Government
 But if they spoke with enthusiasm about the meeting, many of the participants from the United States, like dissidents here, said Havana's quickening efforts to open up the country carried as many risks for the Government as it did opportunities.
As more and more Cuban-Americans arrive -- well dressed, well educated and well fed, brandishing cash and cellular telephones and eventually seeking out investments, many here say -- Cubans whose standard of living has fallen sharply since the collapse of the former Soviet Union may feel emboldened to push for increasingly dramatic economic and political changes at home.
"Closed regimes like this cannot withstand an opening of communications," said Gerardo Sanchez, a leading Cuban dissident. "There are two kinds of groups that will always resist an end of the embargo, the most rejectionist elements of the exile community, and the President of this country."

HEADLINE: Group of 7 Optimistic on Low-Inflation Growth This Year

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Finance officials from the world's seven richest industrial countries expressed optimism today that the global economy could grow faster this year despite a recent rise in long-term interest rates.
In a chairman's statement summarizing the discussions, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said his colleagues believed a variety of signs pointed to stronger growth, with inflation remaining low. "I was pleased to hear the optimism around the table," he said. 
 Mr. Bentsen said the seven nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Canada and Italy -- had pledged to continue pursuing policies put in place last year but had not indicated that any nation was willing to come forward with new commitments.
The United States had been pushing Japan and Germany to do more to stimulate their domestic economies, given the unexpectedly deep recessions in both nations. But Japanese and German officials have so far resisted, arguing that they have done enough and that doing more would risk reigniting inflationary pressure.
The G-7 finance ministers and central bank presidents praised Russia's economic reform efforts, which led to a new $1.5 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund last week.
Russia's Deputy Prime Minister, Alexander Shokhin, and other Russian economic policy makers briefed the group today on the status of Russia's reform program.
Mr. Bentsen said the Western nations welcomed Russia's commitments to reduce the budget deficit to no more than 7.5 percent of the total economy this year and to bring inflation down to a monthly rate of 7 percent by year's end.
Based on those commitments, he said, the Group of Seven is urging the World Bank to accelerate new loans for Russia.
On global growth, Mr. Bentsen said, "The bottom line was: We agreed the fundamentals are good, and we reiterated that inflation remains under control."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

SCANDAL IN THE 30TH: A GROUP PORTRAIT
What drives police officers to step over the line into lawlessness? Of the dozen men accused in the 30th Precinct drug-corruption scandal, all had working-class backgrounds, and a few had exemplary reputations. In a wide array of interviews, people who know the accused have helped to sketch the broad contours of the officers' lives, and to provide a partial understanding of the road to the wrong side of the law. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY 

TRACKING DOWN A QUEENS ATTACKER
A lone attacker has struck eight times in broad daylight in several Queens neighborhoods, following his elderly victims from banks, threatening them with a silver pistol while demanding money and sometimes a car. Once he pistol-whipped, robbed and shot a woman inside the garage of her home. Once he stole a woman's handbag as she was unloading packages in the driveway of her house. On Friday the police released a photograph of a man they identified as a suspect. B3.
 
BRATTON ON CORRUPTION
Police Commissioner William J. Bratton does not oppose an outside agency to monitor police corruption efforts but does not want it to conduct its own investigations. This position puts him at odds with the Mollen Commission, which was established under Mayor David N. Dinkins to investigate police corruption in New York City. First in a television interview and then in elaboration by a spokesman, the Commissioner provided his most detailed position yet on an external monitor, a subject that is expected to be a central recommendation in the Mollen Commission's final report next month. B3.
 
REPUBLICANS AT CROSSROADS
The special election for a City Council seat on Staten Island tomorrow pits two politically prominent families against each other and also will determine whether the Republican Party can retain the dominance it has held for years in that district. The election, in the Council's 51st District, along the borough's south shore, is being held to fill the vacancy created by the resignation of Alfred C. Cerullo 3d, a popular Councilman appointed last month as the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. B3.
 
BRONX JUDGE ARRESTED
An acting State Supreme Court justice who has presided over many criminal cases in his Bronx courtroom was arrested and charged by the police with assaulting the woman with whom he lives and with resisting arrest by the officers who took him into custody. The judge, Frank Diaz, 53, was accused of striking his companion, Patricia Roberts, 50, in a domestic dispute, and of shoving one of the officers who arrested him about 2 A.M. at his apartment in the Norwood section of the Bronx. B3.
 
REGION
 
SEASIDE RESORT ACCUSED OF BIAS
Wildwood, N.J., used blatantly unfair zoning restrictions to try to drive out low-income families receiving rent subsidies, according to a Federal District Court judge who said a person "would have to be deaf, dumb and blind" not to have seen what was going on. Earlier this month the judge issued a temporary restraining order that prevents the city from enforcing the restrictions. Local officials refused to comment on the case but said there was never any intention to discriminate against any group. B5.
 
A REGION FALLING BEHIND
The New York metropolitan area's economy is driven by leading industries of the future that will provide the building blocks to make it stronger, but the area is still losing ground compared with other regions, according to a new report. The study, one of the most detailed looks in recent years at the economy of the immense urban conglomeration surrounding New York City, makes for sobering reading. B5.
 
BRUSH FIRE SNARLS TRAFFIC
Firefighters battled a brush fire in the marshlands near the Meadowlands complex, forcing officials to close part of the New Jersey Turnpike and Route 3. The blaze, which did not appear to be deliberately set, produced smoke that was visible in New York City and the surrounding area. No injuries, deaths or damage to buildings were reported, but Route 3, which connects Secaucus to Route 46 in Clifton, was closed for about an hour and a half. Traffic was backed up for about three miles in both directions, officials said. B5.

HEADLINE: Seaside Resort Is Accused of Housing Bias

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WILDWOOD, N.J., April 21

 BODY:
With city building inspectors on her doorstep, Nancy Carrasco made up her mind.
No, she told them, she would not budge. 
 They had informed her landlord that the two-bedroom apartment Mrs. Carrasco shared with her two children was out of compliance with the new occupancy code in this southern Jersey seaside resort. Her apartment was now considered too small to meet the new standard, she was told. For the "health and safety" of her children, she was being evicted.
Uh-uh, Mrs. Carrasco told them, setting her jaw. "You'll need a bulldozer to get me out of here," she said. "I know my rights."
That scene took place two years ago, she said, and Mrs. Carrasco is still sitting tight. Earlier this month a Federal district judge in Camden issued a temporary restraining order that prevents the city of Wildwood, just north of Cape May, from enforcing changes that effectively restricted occupancy to one person per bedroom, a requirement far above the square footage required in just about any other municipality in the nation.
 
Selective Enforcement
 Lawyers from the United States Justice Department had argued that the city approved the changes in 1990 in a calculated attempt to drive out low-income families receiving rent subsidies. Most of the activity, they said, was directed at Hispanic residents, chiefly Puerto Ricans, who had been moving into Wildwood in increasing numbers over the last decade, and was in blatant violation of the Federal Fair Housing Act.
Federal Judge Joseph E. Irenas appeared to agree. "Somebody looking at this file," he said in reference to the Justice Department complaint outlining allegations about selective enforcement of the occupancy code, "would have to be deaf, dumb and blind not to see what is going on."
City officials refused to comment on the lawsuit but said there was never any intention to discriminate against any group.
"My concern is the safety and well-being of people in this town whether they are white or black, rich or poor," said Mayor Edmund J. Grant. He said professional consultants proposed the code revisions as a way to upgrade existing housing and move Wildwood into a more prosperous future.
Still, Wildwood officials quickly agreed not to challenge the restraining order and told Federal officials the occupancy code revisions would not be enforced until the litigation was ended. Frank L. Corrado, a lawyer representing Wildwood, said it was undecided whether the city would ask for a trial on the matter. The Federal lawsuit, he noted, demanded damages on behalf of tenants who claimed to be injured by enforcement of the revised standards.
Paul Hancock, chief of the Justice Department's housing and civil rights enforcement branch, said in a telephone interview that formal complaints like those against Wildwood were unusual.
But another blue-collar summer resort in New Jersey, Seaside Heights, is being accused of amending the local housing code to drive poor families with children out of the borough.
"Seaside Heights has tried something sightly more clever than Wildwood," said Lindsay Lutz, staff lawyer for Ocean-Monmouth Legal Services, who said he was preparing to file a lawsuit against the borough in State Superior Court on behalf of two people facing eviction who assert that the new housing regulations are selectively aimed at low-income residents.
The amendments to the code, he said, came "after three years of public griping that the borough had become a dumping ground for welfare recipients." He added: "The trouble was the amended code was only enforced between Sept. 15 and May 15. It was all right if 15 drunken kids occupied an apartment in the summer but not if a mother with two kids on welfare lived there in the winter."
Mayor Ken Hershey said he had not been informed of the suit and rejected allegations that housing enforcement had been aimed at any group. "I want the housing enforcer to hit every house in town, rental or residential, and make sure everyone is in compliance with safety and health regulations," he said. "We are also working to stop summer mob scenes when 12 kids rent a house and create disturbances."
The two oceanfront resorts, about 90 miles apart, have many similarities. Both have honky-tonk pasts, drawing large summer crowds of working-class families and notable throngs of young, at times rowdy, adults, to expansive beaches and boardwalks crammed with rides, arcades and late-night bars. Historically, Seaside Heights has attracted vacationers from North Jersey and Trenton, while Wildwood pulled heavily from Philadelphia and steel and mining towns in Pennsylvania.
The heyday for both resorts was in the 1960's, when families still took a cottage at the shore for a month or a whole summer. New competition, working mothers and more second-home investment radically shifted vacation and travel patterns. And there was little interest in building expensive homes in gritty boardwalk towns where 100,000 young people thronged on weekends and fights spilled out of bars at closing times.
In Wildwood, which runs 1.5 miles along a barrier island shared with North Wildwood and Wildwood Crest, existing housing faded and decayed. Property owners converted structures for winter use and welcomed families that received rent subsidies to fill units that for nine months of the year had no other takers.
Landlords made profits, but other homeowners saw property taxes rise as children from those families streamed into local schools just as the recession was forcing failed businesses off tax rolls. They demanded local politicians do something about it.
Wildwood had a population of 4,484 in 1990. Of this number, 77 percent were white, mainly of Italian-American background, and 19 percent were black. The number of Hispanic residents was small, 312, but the figure had doubled since the 1980 census.
Puerto Rican men who arrived in Wildwood to fill menial summer jobs sent for their families after Labor Day, when many went on unemployment or other assistance, residents said. In a place where fewer than one-third of all households have children, 9 of 10 Hispanic households had children.
In 1991 the city adopted a revised property maintenance code that set the minimum floor space for a family of three at 550 square feet, 200 square feet more than the state minimum for multifamily housing and nearly 150 square feet higher than its previous standard, which followed a model code used by many state and local governments. A fourth resident would require an additional 250 square feet under the revised regulation.
At a noisy meeting later that year of Cape May County freeholders, angry residents from Wildwood complained that the resort was becoming a "welfare town" filled with families receiving assistance whose presence was costing the local school district $1.5 million. The freeholders answered that they could do little because national policies mandated the social-welfare system.
 
'Dumping Ground' for Needy
 Three days later, on Sept. 27, 1991, Wildwood's Mayor, Edmund J. Grant, complained in a letter to state officials that the city was being turned into "a dumping ground for the needy."
County and state social-assistance agencies, the Mayor said, were permitting their "clients to reside in unsafe substandard structures." He proposed using city code enforcement to relieve the situation.
Five months later building inspectors arrived at Mrs. Carrasco's address.
Her second-floor apartment is reached by a creaky rear staircase in a four-story frame building that has three other apartment units and, on the top floor, unheated summer efficiencies. She has occupied it for seven years, paying $500 a month in rent for 455 square feet of living space. Before 1989, when she and her husband separated, the family of four lived there without complaint, she said.
 
'Couldn't Believe It'
 When building inspectors came, she said, she heard them talking on a porch with her landlord. "They were asking how many school-aged children lived in the building," she said.
"It seemed clear they were targeting Hispanics on welfare," said Mrs. Carrasco, a licensed practical nurse who is not Hispanic, though her husband is from Chile, and who does not get a rent subsidy. "I couldn't believe it when they said I had to leave. With all the homeless, they're picking on people with a place to live."
She sought help from Cape-Atlantic Legal Services, whose director, Ken Goldman, brought the matter to the attention of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
"There are a number of communities that use sophisticated and insidious ways to unfairly remove people from their homes if they are the 'wrong' color or class," Mr. Goldman said. "But what took place in Wildwood was outrageous on its face."

LENGTH: 1235 words

HEADLINE: Brazil Cultivates U.S. Wine Drinkers

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GARIBALDI, Brazil

 BODY:
Never internationally known for its wines, Brazil has bucked a worldwide slump in wine exports to the United States and has emerged as the fastest growing exporter to the American market.
Brazilian wine shipments to the United States jumped 36 percent last year, thanks to Marcus James, a label with an American-sounding name but with roots deep in the vineyards of southern Brazil. 
 Marcus James, which is generally priced 20 percent lower than its Chilean competition, is expected to displace Bolla of Italy this year to become the second most popular imported wine in the United States, after Riunite, another Italian label.
Compared with Brazil, Chile exports nearly three times as much wine to the American market, under many more labels, but its sales in the United States dropped 10 percent in 1993. The traditional European wine countries of France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and Portugal also showed declines of 9 to 14 percent in sales last year to the United States.
 
Penetrating the American Market

 Brazil's exports have risen on the strength and marketing strategy of a single company, the Cooperativa Vinicola Aurora, the nation's largest wine producer and its sole exporter to the United States.
"We are still penetrating American markets," Jose A. Alberici Jr., Aurora's president, said. "We are preparing for growth of 20 to 30 percent a year."
In a 15-year campaign to win a slice of the American market, the Aurora winery imported oak casks from Kentucky and Tennessee. "Americans like the oak-flavored tastes for their reds and whites," said Mr. Alberici, who uses stainless steel vats to ferment the Marcus James wine that is sold in Brazil.
Next, Aurora adopted an American-sounding brand name, and had its American-designed labels printed in New Jersey. To get high-quality corks, Aurora imported Portuguese corks from suppliers in California. And it contracted with the Canandaigua Wine Company of Canandaigua, N.Y., the second-largest American winery after the E.& J. Gallo Wine Company of California, to market its Brazilian wines in the United States.
"We Americanized the packaging," said Howard R. Jacobson, a senior vice president for sales of Canandaigua who helped introduce Aurora wines to the market in 1988. "We never focused on the fact that this is a Brazilian wine."
 
More Exports Than Argentina
 Marcus James has already pushed Brazil ahead of Argentina in wine exports to the United States. If trends continue, Marcus James this year will lead Brazil past Portugal, Brazil's former European colonial power. But Jon A. Frederickson, a wine industry analyst in San Francisco, questioned whether the Brazilians had planted enough vines to support their market growth and to maintain price advantage in the face of less expensive wines from competitors in countries like South Africa and France.
"There is a worldwide glut of wine, a huge wine lake," said Mr. Frederickson, who publishes the Gomberg-Frederikson Report, a monthly newsletter that follows the industry. "The market is highly competitive."
Beating Italian brands has a special resonance here in southern Brazil's hilly wine country, a region settled more than a century ago by impoverished immigrants from northern Italy. Of the cooperative's 1,516 member families, Mr. Alberici said, "99.5 percent are of Italian descent."
 
100,000 Acres of Vineyards
 Italian descendants cultivate 100,000 acres of vineyards in Brazil's southernmost state, Rio Grande do Sul, and are responsible for about 95 percent of Brazil's wine production. Red and green, colors in the Italian flag, also seem to be the colors of Brazil's wine region, and the family vineyards or "cantinas" often resonate with conversations in Venetian dialect.
The agricultural cooperative bottles varieties of chardonnay, white zinfandel, riesling and cabernet sauvignon for export under the Marcus James label.
The company, based in Bento Goncalves, has achieved sales of $50 million a year, and its brochures are printed in English, Portuguese and Italian.
With the crisp air of autumn already starting here in the southern hemisphere, growers are buoyant about what they call an exceptionally strong 1994 grape harvest.
 
Little Wine Consumption in Brazil
 But outside this European corner of Brazil, the success of Marcus James is unexpected because Brazil has never been a nation of wine drinkers. Brazilians annually consume a mere 1.7 liters (1.8 quarts) a person, a fraction of their consumption of sugar cane rum. By contrast, Argentines drink about 54 liters (14.3 gallons) a person a year. In Chile, the continent's largest wine exporter, per capita consumption is about 20 liters (5.3 gallons) a year.
In addition, Brazil's economic zigzags and high inflation have caused domestic wine consumption to stumble. After falling to a 10-year low of 164 million liters in 1987, total wine production last year climbed back to 248 million liters, just below the 1986 level.
The country's ups and downs have driven out most of the multinational liquor companies that invested heavily in southern Brazil in the late 1970's. Of 14 foreign companies bottling wines here a decade ago, only four major ones remain: Seagram, Bacardi, Moet & Chandon and Remy Martin.
"I'm not going to sit around and wait for Brazilians to start drinking wine," said Mr. Alberici, who has steadily oriented his 63-year-old company toward exports. From a negligible level a decade ago, exports now account for almost one third of Aurora's sales.
Last year, when a methanol adulteration scandal shook South Americans' faith in wine from Argentina, Mr. Alberici moved aggressively into Paraguay, winning 10 percent of the wine market, largely with cheap jug wine.
 
Worldwide Excess of Wine
 But in a world awash with wine, breaking into the highly competitive American market was tougher.
"All over the world, there is an excess of wine," said Danilo Cavagni, a Moet & Chandon director who is also president of the Brazilian Wine Growers Association. "Consumption is dropping in Europe, in Argentina and in Chile. The U.S. is one of the few countries in the world where consumption is increasing."
Wine consumption in the United States was about 2.43 gallons per adult in 1992, up from 2.32 gallons the year before, according to Impact, another wine industry newsletter.
Initially, Marcus James did not specify the country of origin on its labels. But last September, Canandaigua started to play up the wine's Brazilian roots by offering to pay $1.29 to the Rainforest Alliance for every bottle coupon returned by buyers. Through a "Save the Rainforest" promotion, Canandaigua has contributed $32,500 to the alliance, a nonprofit group based in New York that is dedicated to protecting tropical forests.
Aurora's prices are kept low to promote sales to young adults. A bottle of wine sold wholesale here at the winery gate for $1.25 retails in American liquor stores for about $4.
With Canandaigua planning to expand American distribution, Aurora executives hope the cooperative's 10,000 acres of vineyards here may one day produce America's most popular imported wine. Aurora has been helped by a 50 percent drop in Riunite's sales to the United States over the last five years.
"It's been a tremendous success story," Mr. Jacobson said. "I think Marcus James can double in sales in the next three years."

HEADLINE: New York Area Economy Faces Struggle to Keep Up

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
Despite being driven by leading industries of the future that provide the New York metropolitan area with building blocks for a stronger economy, that economy has failed to gain as much ground as other regions, according to a new report to be released tomorrow.
The study, prepared for the Regional Plan Association by the economic consulting firm DRI/McGraw-Hill, offers one of the most detailed looks in recent years at the economy of the immense urban conglomeration of New York City and its surrounding area. It makes for sobering reading. 
 "The New York region faces a new reality in which we can no longer count on growth and outward expansion," said Robert A. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association. "There are a number of thriving industries in the region that are poised to do well. But they are not preordained to do well. We're going to have to work much harder for our living."
Most worrisome, the report said, is that even the region's strongest sectors have slipped over the past decade versus competitors in the 30 largest metropolitan areas in the United States.
 
Food for Thought
 The report is designed to serve as a touchstone for the annual assembly of regional political, business, economic and academic leaders and experts held by the association, a nonprofit, independent research group that has long played an influential role in guiding the placement of business and the planning of infrastructure for the New York region.
The association is in the midst of preparing its Third Regional Plan for the area stretching from Trenton to New Haven, up the Hudson Valley and across Long Island that contains about 8 percent of the nation's population. It is scheduled to be presented in 1995.
The first plan, which dealt largely with laying the groundwork for rapid growth, was completed in 1929. The second, remembered largely for its emphasis on the development of suburban employment centers, came in 1968.
For the 1990's and beyond, the goal of the organization is to provide research and recommendations to help overcome problems that impede the region in national and global economic competition. These include a disjointed public transportation system, a jumble of more than 2,000 separate government and regulatory agencies and a gulf between the location of new jobs in outlying areas and the concentration of employment-seeking immigrants and minorities in city neighborhoods.
But some critics say that because the association has grown increasingly out of touch with the fundamental challenges of the region it seeks to shape, it can no longer plan effectively for it.
"The RPA is trying to put itself back on the map, but I'm afraid it has become an increasingly suburban-oriented group that is largely peripheral to almost every major issue on the New York urban agenda today," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University.
Since the early 1980's, the New York region has reveled in one of its strongest booms of the century and endured the worst economic collapse since the Great Depression. During the recent downturn from 1989 through 1992, while the nation outside the metropolitan complex surrounding New York City essentially balanced its employment losses with gains, the New York area lost 9 percent of its jobs.
In recent years, it has come to be dominated by a handful of often well-paid but narrow occupational categories led by financial services, information and media, health care and medical research, business services, transportation, and arts, culture and tourism. These industries are expected to outpace most in the future.
Even the most vital sectors are vulnerable, though. In financial services, for example, where New York has long reigned supreme and managed to add 15 percent more jobs from 1982 to 1992, the region still lost 6 percent of its market share to other metropolitan areas. And in medicine, even as employment rose by 37 percent over the decade, the region nonetheless fell from 10.2 percent of national employment to 9.4 percent.
The New York area's leading industries are still capable of generating strong income gains that keep its working residents among the best-paid people in the nation. But these industries face threats to their competitiveness as rapidly changing markets place new burdens on mature companies, as corporate downsizing and decentralizing affect the large firms that are disproportionately concentrated in the region, and as jobs are drawn to regions that offer lower costs and fewer impediments to doing business.
"This is a very different place from the days when the Fortune 500 dominated the region from their headquarters in Manhattan," Mr. Yaro said. "Today, instead of continuing the incentive wars between states over keeping the jobs of big companies, the focus of regional economic policy should be, say, on two Lebanese brothers doing metal stamping in Queens or a recent college graduate who starts his own software company. The challenge is to make it easier to grow that kind of stuff."

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Surged 25.8% Last Month

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools rose 25.8 percent in March, capping the best first quarter for the industry in more than a decade, a trade group said today.
March orders totaled $346.8 million, compared with $275.65 million in February and up from $332.1 million in March 1993, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said in its monthly report. 
 "Domestic orders continued their strong pace giving us the best first quarter since 1980," Albert Moore, the association's president, said.
"New capital spending forecasts by U.S. manufacturers should translate into a good 1994 for the industry."
 
Surge in Investment

 
 Earlier this month, Government reports found United States companies planning the biggest investment increase in five years to raise production in a vigorous economy.
This means more business for tool makers, whose products are used by manufacturers to make a broad range of goods.
Because orders are made at the beginning of a production cycle, they provide an indication of future production.
Machine tool orders for export continued to languish in March because of soft economies abroad. They tumbled 46.7 percent to $9 million from $16.9 million in February and were off 68.2 percent from $28.3 million in March 1993.
By category, orders for metal-cutting tools increased 25.8 percent in March from a month earlier, to $231.25 million, while orders for metal-forming tools rose 25.9 percent, to $115.55 million.
The association said March shipments climbed 12.5 percent, to $304 million, from $270.2 million in February but were down 4.36 percent from $317.85 million in March 1993.
 The trade group said the backlog of machine tool orders in March climbed to $1.6 billion from $1.56 billion in February and was well above the $1.3 billion of March 1993.

HEADLINE: Treasury Auctions to Offer Bills and Notes This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of bills and notes, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. On Tuesday, the Government will sell two-year notes, followed by Wednesday's auction of five-year notes. There will be an auction of one-year bills on Thursday.
According to traders, by the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.74 percent; the six-month bill was at 4.19 percent and the one-year bill was at 4.64 percent. In when-issued trading, the two- and five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.66 percent and 6.55 percent, respectively. 
 The following taxable and tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:
